column4: To drive a private hire car in Scotland, a private hire car drivers' licence or a taxi drivers' licence must be obtained from your local authority.
To drive a taxi in Scotland, a taxi driver's licence must be obtained from the local authority.
To operate a vehicle as a private hire car, a private hire car licence must be obtained from your local authority.
To operate a vehicle as a taxi, a taxi licence must be obtained from your local authority.

For imports within the EU, no licence is required, but the Fish Health Inspectors of the Fisheries Research Services (FRS) must be informed at least 24 hours prior to the proposed movement. For more information, you can call the Marine Scotland Helpline on Tel 01224 876544.

If you fish for salmon, eels or freshwater fish in Northern Ireland you must have a licence from the appropriate regulatory body.

The appropriate regulatory body will depend on where you wish to fish and will be either the Department of Culture, Arts and Leisure (DCAL) or the Loughs Agency of the Foyle, Carlingford and Irish Lights Commissions (FCILC).

You must also have a permit from the fishery owner.

You must comply with any terms and conditions attached to a licence and permit.

To practise as an art therapist in the UK, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

This includes using any of the following protected titles:

  • art psychotherapist
  • art therapist
  • drama therapist
  • music therapist

To be eligible to apply for registration, you must:

  • hold an approved qualification
  • be in good physical and mental health
  • be of good character

You must enclose a fee and any necessary supporting documents - eg qualifications and a character reference - with your application.

The registration fee for the two-year registration cycle is £152 (£76 per year) and there is a one off non-refundable scrutiny fee of £53. The registration fee is reduced by 50 per cent. For the first two-year registration period.

Further information is available in the downloadable application pack on the HPC website.

If your application is successful, your name will be added to the register and you will receive a registration certificate and authentication card.

You must undertake continuing professional development (CPD) activities as a condition of your registration. You must keep a written record these activities, including any supporting evidence, and submit this for inspection by the HPC on request.

If the HPC is not satisfied that you are meeting your CPD obligations, your name may be removed from the register.

It is a criminal offence to call yourself an art psychotherapist, art therapist, drama therapist or a music therapist if you are not registered with the HPC. If you do so, you may be fined up to £5,000.

column3: Adventure activities licence (England, Scotland and Wales)
column4: If you provide adventure activities - ie climbing, caving, trekking or watersports - for young people under 18 years of age and charge for them, you must be licensed by the Adventure Activities Licensing Authority (AALA).

You must not move cattle, deer, goats, pigs or sheep from any premises unless the movement is made under the authority of a General Movement Licence for each species from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra). All movements must also comply with the conditions of the licence.

In addition, all movements of deer, sheep and goats must be accompanied by a completed Animal Movement Licence Document (AML) obtained from your local authority. Pigs must be accompanied by the AML movement document (until 31/03/11) or a haulier summary introduced with the electronic pig reporting system called eAML2 (operated by the British Pig Executive) from  01/10/11.

Cattle must be accompanied by their passports and all cattle movements must be notified to the British Cattle Movement Service within three days of the movement taking place.

Any animal movement will also trigger a six day standstill (or 20 days for pigs) on the premises of destination where other movements are prohibited unless an exception applies.

column3: Mixing ammonium nitrate (with fuel oil) licence (All UK)
column4:
Unless it is for immediate use at a mine or quarry, you need a manufacturing licence to combine ammonium nitrate and fuel oil to create mixtures for use in certain blasting operations.

Licences are obtained from the Health & Safety Executive (HSE) in England, Wales and Scotland. In Northern Ireland you need a licence from the Northern Ireland Office (NIO).

column3: Gas supplier, transporter, shipper or interconnector licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
You must obtain a licence from the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem) if you carry out any of the following gas related activities in England, Scotland or Wales:

  • supply gas by pipes to any premises
  • convey gas through pipes to premises or to another pipeline system
  • operate as a gas shipper (to introduce gas into, convey gas through or take gas out of a pipeline system operated by another gas transporter)
  • operate a gas interconnector  (co-ordinating the conveyance of gas into or through a gas interconnector or making such an interconnector available for conveying gas)

Applications can be made online. You can also apply in writing by completing the application form available from Ofgem which may be returned to Ofgem by post or email.

A fee of between £350 and £1,050 will be payable depending on the activities covered by the licence.

You will be required to provide detailed information on the application form including:

  • your contact details
  • details about your company and its directors
  • details of the ultimate holding company and directors, if applicable
  • shareholder details
  • previous applications and licences held
  • details of modifications that you wish to request to the standard conditions
  • any criminal convictions
  • how you propose to start your business
  • details relating to the specific activities relating to the licence

Ofgem may contact you to request additional documents to support your application, including details of your bank account, solicitors and auditors.

If you are required to attend an interview you may be asked to provide the following original company documentation:

  • incorporation documents
  • resolutions
  • minutes from meetings
  • annual returns and accounts
  • forms appointing and resigning directors
  • register of directors
  • register of members

Your application will not be processed until all relevant information and documents have been received by Ofgem and the fee has been cleared.

Once Ofgem considers that your application is complete they will provide you with a template with suggested wording for your notice of application. You must arrange for this to be published on either your own website, with a link to this on the Ofgem website, or the Ofgem website, within ten working days. The notice must be published for at least 28 days.

Your application may be refused if, amongst other things:

  • you are insolvent
  • any persons named in the application are disqualified from being involved in company affairs or have relevant unspent convictions
  • you have previously had a licence revoked or refused

Ofgem aim to make a decision about your application for gas shipper or supply licences within 45 working days after they send you notice that your application has been 'duly made'. Applications for other types of gas licences may take longer.

column3: Generation, transmission, distribution and supply of electricity licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4: To generate, transmit, distribute or supply electricity you need a licence from the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem) in England, Scotland and Wales.

column3: Gold and silver agreement for lease (England & Wales)
column4:
Gold and silver are classed as 'Mines Royal'. This means that in most cases they belong to the Crown. Because of this, if you intend to carry out gold and silver exploration for commercial gain, you should contact The Crown Estate.

You will also need permission from The Crown Estate to take away gold that you may have found or discovered, whatever the method you have used. However, if you find gold through panning it is unlikely that The Crown Estate will grant you permission to take it away.

The Crown Estate may sometimes grant you a lease of Mines Royal within a specific area. However, you will still have to get rights of access to this land from the landowner.

If you want to commercially exploit any Mines Royal, you should contact Wardell Armstrong LLP - The Crown Estate Mineral Agent.

column3: Goods vehicle operator licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
You will need a goods vehicle operator's licence to carry goods if you use a vehicle with either:

  • a gross plated weight of over 3,500 kilograms
  • if it has no gross plated weight, an unladen weight of more than 1,525 kilograms

You can apply for three types of goods vehicle operator's licence:

  • Standard licence for national operations only - you can carry your own goods in Great Britain, and carry other people's goods for hire or reward in Great Britain. You can also haul loaded trailers to or from ports within Great Britain as part of an international journey, as long as your motor vehicles do not actually leave Great Britain.
  • Standard licence for national and international operations - you can carry your own goods, and other people's goods, for hire or reward in Great Britain and on international journeys
  • Restricted licences - you can carry your own goods, but not to carry other people's goods for hire or reward.

You need to hold a goods vehicle operator's licence for each traffic area in which you have an operating centre.

Applications for new operator's licences can be made on form GV79. This form needs to be sent, along with the fee and supporting documents, to the Central Licensing Office, which processes applications on behalf of the Traffic Commissioners.
To transport animals on journeys of over eight hours, you need authorisation from the Scottish Government Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate.

If you intend to abstract water from natural water sources in Scotland, eg coastal waters, watercourses or underground water reserves, you may be required to obtain a licence from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) - you will only be required to register if your operation is from inland sources of water and between 10 and 50 cubic metres/day or from coastal and transitional waters.

column3: Speech and language therapist registration (All UK)
column4:
To practise as a speech and language therapist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

This includes using the protected titles:

  • speech and language therapist
  • speech therapist

To be eligible to apply for registration, you must:

  • hold an approved qualification
  • be in good physical and mental health
  • be of good character

You must enclose a fee and all supporting documents - eg qualifications and health reference from your GP - with your application.

The registration fee for the two-year registration cycle is £152 (£76 per year) and there is a one off non-refundable scrutiny fee of £53. The registration fee is reduced by 50 per cent if you successfully completed a UK approved programme within the last two years.

Further information is available in the downloadable application pack on the HPC website.

If your application is successful, your name will be added to the register and you will receive a registration certificate and authentication card.

You must undertake continuing professional development (CPD) activities as a condition of your registration. You must keep a written record these activities, including any supporting evidence, and submit this for inspection by the HPC on request.

If the HPC is not satisfied that you are meeting your CPD obligations, your name may be removed from the register.

It is a criminal offence to call yourself a speech and language therapist if you are not registered with the HPC. If you do so, you may be fined up to £5,000.
To hold a collection, or sale of articles, in a public place for charitable purposes, you need a licence or permit from the local authority.

column3: Registration to carry out gas work (All UK)
column4:
In order to work legally on gas fittings or gas storage vessels you must be registered on the Gas Safe Register.

You can apply online or by filling out an application form which can be downloaded from the Gas Safe Register website.

You application must include valid evidence of competence which must be less than five years old, such as:

  • National Accredited Certification Scheme for individual Gas Fitting Operatives (ACS)
  • ACS aligned National or Scottish Vocational Qualifications

If your qualifications are more than five years old, you will need to retrain before registering.

When you register for the first time you will be given probationary registration status which will last for three months. During this period you must notify the Gas Safe Register of all gas work carried out and they will carry out inspections to make sure the work has been completed to the required standards. If gas work notified to the Gas Safe Register or inspected by them is not at the required standard they can extend the probationary period. Once you have demonstrated your competence, your probationary period will finish.

You will be required to pay fees which are currently:

  • £228 for a one off non-refundable application fee
  • £210 annual registration fee
  • £63 registration fee for any additional engineers

If you are accepted onto the Register it will be for a period of 12 months - you will then need to renew your application every year. The Gas Safe register will contact you by letter or email outlining what you need to do. You will need to pay a renewal fee.

If you are registered with the Gas Safe Register continuously for a period of five years then you will be required to update your current qualifications by completing a relevant aptitude test at an accredited gas assessment centre before the end of the five year period.

Failure to hold current evidence of qualifications may result in your removal from the Gas Safe Register.

If you carry out gas work you must:

  • carry out the work safely and competently
  • make sure that the work has been tested and commissioned
  • be registered for the category of work carried out
  • keep to all standards and documents as listed in the technical standards and normative documents list
  • carry a licence card
  • let the Gas Safe Register know if your licence card is lost or stolen and return it to them if asked to do so
  • ensure that all work meets the requirements of the Health & Safety Executive (HSE) in England, Wales and Scotland and the HSENI in Northern Ireland 
  • not do anything that would contribute to unsafe gas work or illegal activities
  • notify the Gas Safe Register about any concerns about unsafe gas work carried out by others
  • keep records of gas work to be provided to the Gas Safe Register upon request which must detail the person doing the gas work, what the gas work was, the date of completion, the address where the work was done and action taken for unsafe situations
  • report gas work if it is notifiable under Building Regulations

column3: Gaming machine supply and maintenance certificate (Northern Ireland)
column4: To sell, supply or maintain gaming machines in Northern Ireland you need a certificate issued by the local court.

column3: Export licence for cultural goods (All UK)
column4:
To export cultural goods over a certain age and value, either permanently or temporarily, you need an individual licence from the Export Licensing Unit of the Arts Council.

Objects of cultural interest include:

  • works of art
  • furniture
  • antiques
  • means of transport
  • manuscripts
  • archaeological items

You do not need a licence to export:

  • a cultural object which is less than 50 years old at the time of export
  • postage stamps and other articles of philatelic interest
  • birth, marriage or death certificates relating to your personal affairs or those of your spouse for dispatch to another European Union (EU) member state
  • letters or other writings written by or to you or your spouse

If you are intending to export a cultural good within the EU, you will need to apply for an individual UK licence if the cultural good is above the UK age and financial thresholds set out in the UK Open General Export Licence (OGEL) and the Arts Council's 'UK Export Licensing for Cultural Goods: Procedures and guidance for exporters of works of art and other cultural goods'.

If the cultural good is below the relevant UK thresholds, it can be exported under the terms of the OGEL without you needing to apply for an individual export licence. 

If you are intending to export a cultural good outside the EU, you will need to apply for an individual EU licence. This is if the cultural good is above the EU age and financial thresholds set out in EC Council Regulation 116/2009 and the Arts Council's 'UK Export Licensing for Cultural Goods: Procedures and guidance for exporters of works of art and other cultural goods' unless the cultural good is below the relevant EU thresholds but above the relevant UK thresholds, in which case you will need to apply for an individual UK licence.

Contact the Export Licensing Unit for an individual UK or EU application form.

You may need to provide additional information with your application, such as a photograph of the item or details of its provenance (where it arrived in the UK in the past 50 years).

Your application may be referred to an expert adviser in a national museum or gallery for scrutiny. If the expert objects to the permanent export of the cultural good on the grounds of national importance, the case will be referred to the Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art and Objects of Cultural Interest, which will recommend whether the Department for Culture, Media and Sport should defer a decision on the licence application in order to allow a UK institution or individual to raise funds to purchase the item.

If you intend to export a cultural good temporarily, rather than permanently, you will need to specify the date of re-importation on the export licence application.

If an export licence is granted, conditions may be attached.

If you provide false information in your application or fail to comply with any conditions attached to a licence, you may be fined and/or imprisoned for up to two years.

It is important that you read the Arts Council's guidance before making an application.

You can ring the Export Licensing Unit on Tel 020 7973 5188/5228/5139/5387/5194/5241 or email them at elu@artscouncil.org.uk.

If you are engaged in the shoeing of horses or other equine animals (known as farriery) in England, Scotland or Wales, you need to be registered with the Farriers Registration Council (FRC).

To be eligible to apply for registration, you must either:

  • hold an approved UK qualification, eg the Diploma of the Worshipful Company of Farriers (DipWCF)
  • hold a European farriery qualification
  • have sufficient professional farriery experience obtained in another European state

If you hold a European farriery qualification, registration is not automatic. The FRC must first assess your education and training to ensure it meets their requirements. If not, you will have to undertake a period of training under an Approved Training Farrier (ATF) or pass an aptitude test of diploma standard.

If you operated in a European state where farriery is not regulated, you must also provide evidence that you practised farriery on a full-time basis for two years during the past ten years.

If you are applying from another overseas country, have two or more years' farriery experience but don't hold a recognised qualification you will either have to:

  • take the DipWCF examination at the earliest opportunity
  • complete a prescribed number of weeks at an approved training college, including completion of the NVQ Level 3 in Farriery and then the DipWCF examination
  • undertake an apprenticeship with an ATF, including completion of the NVQ Level 3 in Farriery and then the DipWCF examination

You can apply to register on the FRC website. Make sure you choose the correct application form, depending on your entry route.

You must enclose a registration fee and all supporting documents, eg qualifications and proof of identity, with your application.

You will only be entitled to practise farriery once you receive written confirmation of registration.

If your application is successful, your name and contact details will be added to the register and you will receive a certificate of registration.

You need to pay an annual retention fee to stay on the register.

If you are found guilty of serious professional misconduct, convicted of an offence involving cruelty to animals or it is discovered that you were not properly qualified when you registered, your name may be removed from the register.

It is a criminal offence to carry out farriery or call yourself a farrier or shoeing smith if you are not registered with the FRC. If you do so, you may be fined up to £1,000.

column3: Registration with the Financial Services Authority (All UK)
column4:
To undertake regulated financial activities, you must be authorised by the Financial Services Authority (FSA).

A regulated activity is one which relates to investments that are specified by the Treasury or that relate to property. Examples include:

  • dealing with investments (buying, selling etc) or offering or agreeing to do so, and in the case of insurance contracts, carrying out the contract
  • arranging investment deals
  • accepting deposits
  • asset administration and safekeeping
  • investment management
  • advising on investments
  • creating, running or winding up collective investment schemes
  • computer or web-based investment transactions
  • dealing in securities - eg stocks and shares and/or certificates representing them, options and/or futures
  • dealing with debentures, bonds, loan stock etc, including government bonds etc
  • collective investment scheme units
  • dealing with insurance contracts
  • Lloyd's syndicates
  • loans secured on land and other arrangements involving land

Applications are made to the FSA. You must meet the threshold conditions. These conditions are that:

  • you have the correct legal status - those dealing with insurance contracts must be a company, a registered friendly society or a member of Lloyd's and those accepting deposits or issuing electronic money must be a company or a partnership
  • you have a head office or registered office, or if not a company, carry on business in the UK
  • those dealing with contracts of insurance have claims representatives in each European Economic Area (EEA) state
  • close links with another entity won't affect the FSA's supervision of you
  • you have suitable resources to carry on the regulated activities
  • you are fit and proper to carry on the regulated activities

Applications must contain a statement detailing the regulated activity or activities you wish to carry out and provide an address for service of any notices or documents. You must also include any other required information.

You cannot apply for authorisation for a regulated activity if you already have an authorisation.

Your authorisation will detail which regulated activities you can carry out and may include limitations on how an activity can be carried out. Authorisations may also include requirements you must comply with.

You may only promote or invite people to take part in investment business if you or a person who approved the promotion are authorised.

If the FSA believe that you are not a fit and proper person to carry out regulated activities, you may be served with a prohibition order preventing you from carrying out a particular function.

Your authorisation may be revoked under certain circumstances - eg if you gave false or misleading information to get your authorisation.

If you carry out regulated activities without being authorised you may commit a criminal offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

If you're not authorised but describe/hold yourself out to be so, you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000, imprisoned for six months or both. For offences involving publicly displaying material, the fine will be up to £5,000 multiplied by the number of days the display occurred. If you promote or invite people to take part in regulated investment without being authorised you may commit an offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

If you fail to comply with a prohibition order you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000.

Agreements you make when you are not authorised or that are made through a non-authorised third party will be unenforceable against the other person. The other party to the contract may seek to recover any monies paid by them and c
column5:
ompensation.

There are additional requirements for those practitioners applying from an EEA state or Treaty country.

Some people may be exempt from authorisation.

column4: To run a freshwater land-based fish farm in Northern Ireland, the farm must be licenced by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

You must hold a licence from the Department of Culture, Arts and Leisure to sell, or offer or expose for sale, salmon, trout, eels, pike or pollen, from any vehicle or place.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.
To move live fish, gametes, shellfish and spat in Northern Ireland you need a permit from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARDNI).

If you own or use a fishing vessel in the UK to fish for sea fish you will need a fishing vessel licence from the Fisheries Offices of the Marine Management Organisation in England and Wales, the Environment and Rural Affairs Department of the Scottish Government in Scotland or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development in Northern Ireland.

A vessel must be registered with the Registry of Shipping and Seamen (RSS) before it can be issued with a fishing vessel licence unless the vessel:

  • is a salmon coble
  • has an overall length of 10 metres and under and is not propelled by an engine (for example the vessel only has oars or a sail)
  • has an overall length of 10 metres and under and will only be used to fish for common eels

You must also have a licence entitlement before you can license your vessel for the first time. You will acquire licence entitlement if you buy a vessel with or without its licence. You may also buy an existing separate licence entitlement.

You must apply to your local Marine Management Organisation (MMO) - using form AFL7 'Establishment or transfer of an entitlement and transfer of a licence' - to transfer the licence into your name before you can apply for a licence.

Once the licence entitlement is in your name, you need to convert it into a fishing licence. To do this you must send the following to your local MMO:

  • your valid certificate of registry
  • form AFL2 'Application for a fishing licence for a British registered fishing vessel'
  • completed AFL7 showing you as the entitlement holder

You must send the original documents, not copies. Your local MMO office will try to process your application within five working days.

The type of licence you need depends on the size of your vessel and the category your fishing activities fall into.

Vessels are divided into two groups for licensing purposes - those that are:

  • 10 metres and under in overall length
  • over 10 metres in overall length

The three licence categories are:

  • Category A - authorises vessels to fish for all available quota stocks and up to a restricted tonnage for combined pelagic stocks
  • Category B - authorises vessels over 10 metres to fish for a restricted range of quota stocks and a restricted tonnage of combined pelagic stocks
  • Category C - authorises vessels over 10 metres to fish for a range of miscellaneous stocks and a restricted tonnage of combined pelagic stocks

You do not need a fishing licence if:

  • you only fish for salmon or migratory trout
  • your vessel is 10 metres or less in length and you only fish for common eels
  • you only fish within the 12 nautical mile limits around Jersey, Guernsey or the Isle of Man - you should contact the relevant authority for advice about their licensing requirements
  • you only use your vessel for carrying anglers who are fishing for pleasure

If you own or use a fishing vessel it must be registered with the Registry of Shipping and Seamen unless the vessel:

  • is a salmon coble
  • has an overall length of 10 metres and under and is not propelled by an engine (for example the vessel only has oars or a sail)
  • has an overall length of 10 metres and under and will only be used to fish for common eels

You will need to complete a British ship form and submit it with the appropriate fees and support documentation:

  • a copy of certificate of incorporation - if the owner is a body corporate
  • safety certificate - for vessels over 15 metres
  • International Tonnage Certificate (ITC69) - if the vessel is over 15 metres
  • Seafish Certificate

When you apply, your vessel will be issued with a Carving and Marking note. This must be carved and marked onto your vessel by an Authorised Measurer. A measurement of vessels:

  • 15 metres in length and over is carried out by one of the classification society surveyors, who complete a certificate of measurement and an International Convention certificate 1969
  • under 15 metres in length in England, Wales and Northern Ireland is carried out by a local Coastguard - in Scotland measurement is carried out by a local fishery officer and a certificate of measurement only is issued for these vessels

You must then return the Carving and Marking note and the measurement certificate to the UK Ship Register, along with the appropriate fee.

You must have a list of nominated names for the vessel. These names must be unique to the port that you wish to register under. A Certificate of Registry is valid for five years and must be renewed if you want to continue to fish for profit.

You can get full or simple registration for a fishing vessel.

Full registration requires:

  • proof of ownership, including Bills of Sale for the last three years
  • builders certificate for new vessels
  • forms MSF 4740, MSF 4728 including a declaration of the maximum continuous engine power (MCEP), MSF 4705 and MSF 4743

If you would like to register a mortgage against your vessel you will require a full registration.

Alternatively, you can register your vessel through a simple registration where only the receipt of invoice is acceptable. Mortgages cannot be recorded against a vessel with a simple registration.

Every vessel must be surveyed before it can be registered on the UK Ship Register.

Surveys are usually carried out by a UK Ship Register surveyor, though they may be carried out by a Class surveyor.

The Principal Fishing Surveyor (PFS) will request a copy of all existing statutory certification in order that new certificates can be prepared prior to survey. Details of certification, plans and operational information will be discussed by the owner and the PFS.

If, during a survey, your vessel meets international standards of safety and pollution prevention, a short-term certification can be issued immediately. Full term certification would then follow in due course.

If you own a fishing vessel that is under 15 metres in length overall, it will not be subject to a regular statutory survey. However, all registered small fishing vessels must be seaworthy and equipped to a safe standard so still need to have regular inspections.

If you sell door to door or in the street without a stall or fixed location you may need a pedlar's certificate.

To be a pedlar you must:

  • trade on foot
  • carry your goods with you (although case law has suggested that a small means of transporting goods may be acceptable)
  • generally keep on the move, pausing to make sales

Certificates are issued by the police in the area in which you have resided for the previous month. You must be above 17 years of age, a person of good character, and in good faith intend to trade as a pedlar.

A fee of £12.25 will be charged and the certificate will remain in force for one year.

Once issued you are entitled to trade as a pedlar in any part of the UK providing the certificate remains in force. But you should note that in some local authority areas, and across London pedlary is restricted to door to door selling.

Certificates are not required by commercial travellers, sellers of fish, fruit, or victuals or people selling at markets or fairs.

If you fall outside the definition of pedlar you may be a street trader and require a street traders' licence.

You must produce your licence on request.

If you trade as a pedlar without a certificate or give or lend your licence to someone else to use, you may be fined up to £200. If you provide false information to obtain a licence, forge, help forge or carry or use a forged licence you may be fined up to £200, imprisoned for up to six months or both. You licence will be endorsed to show any convictions.

If you provide day care for children under the age of eight, such as an all-day nursery, you will need to register with Ofsted in England or the Care and Social Services Inspectorate in Wales (CSSIW).

column3: Distiller's licence and approval of plant and processes (All UK)
column4:
If you plan to manufacture spirits, you need the following from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC):

  • a distiller's licence
  • approval of the plant and processes you intend to use

Distiller's licence

Standard wording for a distiller's licence application is available in guidance on the HMRC website.

Applications should be sent to the HMRC National Registration Unit. No fee is payable.

If you intend to produce spirits at more than one set of premises, you must get a licence for each.

If you're not the owner of the premises, you may obtain a licence in joint names with the owner.

HMRC may refuse your application or apply conditions to your licence if the largest still to be used in the manufacturing process has a capacity below 18 hectolitres.

If you manufacture spirits without a licence, you may be fined up to £5,000. Spirits, stills and other utensils and materials used in the manufacturing process may also be forfeited.

Approval of plant and process

As well as a distiller's licence, you should apply in writing to the HMRC National Registration Unit for approval of the plant and processes you intend to use in the manufacturing process.

There is prescribed form for this, but your application should contain:

  • the location of the proposed distillery
  • a full description of the manufacturing process
  • the number and description of the vessels used in the manufacturing process and use of all plant
  • a plan of your premises

No fee is payable.

Approval will be given in writing and may be subject to conditions.

Significant changes to plant or processes must be notified in writing to the National Registration Unit.

If you have any queries about obtaining a licence or approval, you should call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

To operate a domiciliary care agency in England in order to provide care in a person's home, you need to register with the Care Quality Commission (CQC).

The service provider - which can be an organisation, partnership or individual - must register. If you are registered as an organisation or partnership then the person responsible for managing the services must also register. If you are registering as an individual, you don't need to have a separately registered manager unless you don't intend to be in charge full-time.

There are separate registration forms for each category of provider. Applications forms are available from the CQC website and once complete should be emailed to the CQC.

No application fee is payable, however once registered you must pay an annual fee towards ongoing compliance monitoring and any changes you wish to make to your registration. Fees can be paid by cheque of BACS.

Along with your application, you must:

  • provide details of each location from where you will provide domiciliary care services
  • list the regulated activities you intend to carry out
  • meet essential standards of quality and safety
  • make a declaration of compliance

You may not need to register if you only provide staff to other registered providers - eg a nursing home.

If you carry out a regulated activity without being registered, you will be committing an offence, and you could be fined and/or imprisoned.

To record or use television or radio broadcast material for non-commercial educational purposes in an educational establishment, you need a licence from the Educational Recording Agency (ERA).

For Open University broadcasts a separate licensing scheme is in operation.

column3: Notification of imports of live fish and shellfish from outside the European Union (England & Wales)
column4:
If you wish to import live fish or shellfish into England and Wales from another country outside the European Union (EU), you must notify Animal Health (AH) at least 24 hours in advance of the import taking place.

Countries outside the EU are known as 'third countries' for these purposes.

You must already be authorised by the Fish Health Inspectorate (FHI) to import live fish and shellfish and you can only import species covered by your authorisation.

Once you are authorised you must ensure that any imports from outside the EU are accompanied by a health certificate issued by the competent authority in the country of origin.

These imports must go through a border inspection post where the health certificate is inspected by AH.

Notifications should be made on a Common Veterinary Entry Document (CVED) and you must provide details about your business, the consignor/exporter, species and number of fish in the consignment, place of final destination, transit points and journey details.

There is no charge for notifying AH.

Separate forms must be completed for each individual import.

Consignments of fish or shellfish from within the EU only need to be accompanied by a health certificate if they include species susceptible to, or carriers of, an EU controlled disease.

If you fail to notify AH in advance of an import of live fish or shellfish, you may face an unlimited fine.

If you are importing live fish or shellfish from within the EU you should notify the FHI instead.

To net for salmon and sea trout or fish for eels using nets, trawls or traps you need a licence from the Environment Agency in England and Wales, or permission from the relevant private land owner in Scotland. An Environment Agency consent is required to trap signal crayfish.

column3: Leisure business craft licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you want to operate a boat for holiday hire, day hire, passenger trips or as a floating restaurant on British Waterways (BW) controlled waters, you need a leisure business licence from BW.

British Waterways manages the canal network and many river navigations in England, Scotland and Wales.

Before applying for a licence you must make sure that your:

  • insurance covers third-party liability for at least £1 million
  • boat complies with BW's standards for construction and equipment
  • boat has a home mooring

If you intend to operate a passenger boat carrying more than 12 passengers you must also obtain a passenger certificate from the Marine and Coastguard Agency.

If you intend to carry fewer than 12 passengers, you must complete a declaration of compliance with the Inland Waters Small Passenger Boat Code as a part of obtaining a licence.

You should also discuss your business requirements with your local BW leisure business manager.

A business craft licence application form can be downloaded from the BW website.

You will need to provide details about your boat, mooring location, Boat Safety Scheme certificate and insurance.

You must pay a licence fee on application. This is determined by the size of the boat and whether it will be used on canals and rivers or rivers only.

You should send the completed application form, licence fee and a copy of your current insurance certificate(s) to BW's Boat Licensing Team. They will confirm your application with the local BW office before sending you your licence.

Licences must be renewed every 12 months.

You must display your licence on both sides of your boat and comply with all other terms and conditions attached to your licence.

If you operate without a licence your boat may be confiscated and sold or destroyed. If you fail to comply with any terms and conditions of your licence your licence may be revoked.

column3: International road freight operators licence (Northern Ireland)
column4: To use a vehicle (with a gross plated weight in excess of 3.5 tonnes) to carry other people's goods for payment on international journeys, you need a licence from the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Northern Ireland (DVLNI).

column3: Laser or intense pulsed light treatment registration (England & Wales)
column4:
To offer treatments involving intense pulsed light systems or lasers, you must register with the Care Quality Commission (CQC) in England or the Healthcare Inspectorate Wales in Wales.

Physiotherapists using Class 3b lasers are exempt.

In some areas you may also need to obtain a licence from the local authority.

To sell on credit, hire or lease out goods for more than three months, lend money, issue credit cards or trading checks, arrange credit for others, offer hire purchase terms, collect debts, help people with debt problems or advise on people's credit standing, you need a licence from the Office of Fair Trading (OFT).

To obtain a licence, you must satisfy the OFT that you are 'fit and proper'. You must provide information about the persons involved in running the business and any criminal convictions, court judgments or other relevant information. The OFT will consider whether you, and those participating in your business, have the skills, knowledge and experience to carry out the activities covered by your licence to a reasonable standard. The OFT will also consider the practices and procedures you propose to operate in connection with your licensable business activities.

You must also comply with rules on other matters such as:

  • credit advertising
  • canvassing off-trade premises
  • form and content of credit agreements and copies
  • pre-contract information
  • cancellation rights
  • statements and notices
  • early settlement
  • brokerage fees
  • debt collection

For more information contact your local trading standards service or the OFT.

You must be licensed to provide conveyancing services in England and Wales.

Conveyancing services include:

  • preparation of transfers, conveyances, contracts and other documents and services related to the disposition or acquisition of estates or interests in land
  • preparing any instrument of transfer or charge for the purposes of, or making an application for registration under, the Land Registration Act 2002
  • preparing any other legal instrument relating to real or personal estate

The Council for Licensed Conveyancers (CLC) issues licences to enable licensed conveyancers to provide conveyancing services and probate services. Other regulators have similar powers.

Applications must be submitted in accordance with the CLC Rules and must be accompanied by a fee.

Licences may be issued subject to conditions.

column3: Private hire vehicle driver licence (England & Wales)
column4:
If you drive a minicab or other private hire vehicle (PHV) in England or Wales, you need a licence from your local authority. If you are operating in London you need a licence from Transport for London.

In order to apply you must hold a full UK or European Community driver's licence. You may also need to pass a test set by the local authority to assess your route-finding skills.

You will need to provide evidence that you are a 'fit and proper' person. This usually entails getting an enhanced Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) disclosure and having a medical check. Your local authority may also impose additional requirements.

Completed licence applications should be accompanied by:

  • your current driver's licence
  • a fee (these are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area)

A licence will be granted for up to three years before you need to renew it and will usually be subject to conditions such as keeping your cab clean or helping passengers with their luggage.

You must display a badge issued by your local authority that is visible to passengers in your vehicle.

If you operate as a PHV driver without obtaining a licence or pick up fares that are not pre-booked you may be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to comply with any conditions imposed by the local authority, your licence may be suspended or revoked.

If you own the PHV, you must hold a vehicle licence before you can use it for business purposes.

If you also take your own bookings (eg by telephone or through a booking office you run), you need an operator's licence.

column3: Private hire vehicle (minicab) operator licence (England (excluding London) and Wales)
column4: To be a private hire vehicle (minicab) operator in England (excluding London) and Wales, you must be licensed by the local authority. In Scotland minicab operators are not licensed.

column3: Private hire vehicle (minicab) licence (England (excluding London), Scotland and Wales)
column4: If you run a private hire vehicle (minicab) in England (excluding London), Scotland and Wales, you need a licence from the local authority.

To undertake audit work, you need to be a member of, and subject to regulation by, a recognised auditing supervisory body (RSB), a status held by some of the professional accountancy bodies. You must be eligible to work under the rules of the RSB.

In order to be eligible for membership of an RSB, you must hold a recognised professional qualification.

Once registered, you will be required to:

  • demonstrate that you can conduct statutory audit work properly and with integrity
  • ensure your independence as an auditor, recording any threats to independence and the steps taken to safeguard the proper conduct of the audit
  • comply with any standards set by the RSB
  • comply with rules relating to confidentiality of information
  • if you are an auditing company, have arrangements to prevent anyone from exerting influence over the way in which an audit is conducted where the integrity of the audit could be affected

You may not act as a statutory auditor if you:

  • are an officer, employee or partner of the audited person, or of someone who works with the audited person
  • are an officer or employee of an associated undertaking of the audited person, or a partner or employee of such a person
  • have any other prohibited connection with the audited person or an associated undertaking of the audited person

If at any time you become prohibited from acting as an auditor by virtue of being convicted of a relevant offence or by no longer being independent, you must immediately:

  • resign your position
  • give notice in writing to the audited person that you have resigned and state the reason for the resignation

If you act as a statutory auditor without being eligible to act or fail to resign and give notice if you become ineligible you may be fined.

To operate as a bookmakers and take on-course and off-course bets you need a licence from the local Magistrates' Court. If premises are used in taking off-course bets then you will also need an office licence.

If you plan to produce wine or made-wine for sale, you must first obtain the following from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC):

  • a wine producer's licence
  • approval of your premises and plant

Wine is defined as any drink produced by fermentation of fresh grapes or the juice (must) of fresh grapes.

Made-wine is any other drink containing alcohol - apart from beer or cider - that is made by fermentation rather than distillation or any other process (including drinks like mead and 'alcopops').

You must also have a licence to produce sparkling wine if it exceeds 5.5 per cent in strength, unless you intend to do so in an excise warehouse - a place approved by HMRC for the holding of goods on which excise duty is suspended.

You can apply for a licence on form L5 - application for a licence to carry on an excise trade - which is available on the HMRC website.

A separate licence is needed for each set of premises at which your wine or made-wine is for sale.

As part of your application, you must make entry of the premises and plant you intend to use. This involves creating a plan describing and showing the position of each room, place and vessel that you use in the production process.

Applications should be sent to the HMRC National Registration Unit.

No fee is payable and the licence will last until you stop trading.

You must keep the licence on your premises and produce it on request for inspection by HMRC officers.

If you produce wine or made-wine without a licence or premises approval, you may be fined. The wine and all vessels, utensils and materials used in the production process may also be forfeited.

If you have any queries about obtaining a licence or approval, you can call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

If you are operating in an excise warehouse, you don't need to make entry, but you will need authorisation from HMRC to deal in duty-suspended goods.
To produce wool with four or more sheep you need to register with the British Wool Marketing Board (BWMB). Separate arrangements apply in Shetland, where wool is sold through a co-operative.

To run a zoo in Northern Ireland, you must have a licence from the Department of the Environment (DOE) Northern Ireland.

In order to be eligible for a zoo licence, you must not have been convicted of an offence involving the ill-treatment of animals, nor employ anyone who has been so convicted.

At least two months prior to making an application for a licence, you must announce your intention, in writing, to DOE.

This notice must identify where the zoo is situated, the kinds and numbers of animals to be kept, how they are to be accommodated and arrangements for their wellbeing. You must also specify approximate numbers of staff to be employed (and their categories), visitors and motor vehicles expected and the number and location of means of access to the zoo. You should also include information on how you will implement the following conservation measures:

  • participating in at least one of either conservation research, conservation skills training, exchange of information relating to species conservation, captive breeding, or repopulation or reintroduction of species into the wild
  • promoting public education and awareness of the conservation of biodiversity
  • keeping your animals under conditions which satisfy the biological and conservation requirements of each species
  • maintaining a high standard of animal husbandry
  • preventing the escape of animals
  • preventing the intrusion of pests and vermin

You are also required to keep records of the zoo's collection, including animal health, the numbers of different animals, any acquisitions, births, deaths (with causes), disposals and escapes.

You must also publish notice of your intention to make an application in at least two national newspapers, and make this notice available at the proposed site and to DOE.

Before a licence is granted or renewed, your zoo will be inspected to see whether the conservation measures will be met. You must comply with the licence conditions and any directions issued by DOE. Licence conditions may be amended at any time by DOE to ensure that conservation measures are implemented.

A new licence will be granted for four years, and you must display your licence, or a copy of it, at each public entrance to the zoo.

Your zoo will be inspected regularly to ensure that conservation measures and licence conditions are being met. You will be given at least 28 days written notice of planned inspections.

An inspector may require the attendance of any veterinary practitioner employed in the zoo, and you may have three representatives present at the inspection. You must produce all your records related to the implementation of conservation measures.

DOE may carry out a special inspection of your zoo at any time if they feel that your conservation measures require investigation, or if your zoo is to be closed and DOE need to make arrangements for the future care or disposal of your animals.

If you do not comply with the condition specified in your licence, or the public do not have enough access to the zoo, DOE may make a zoo closure direction.

You can renew an existing licence at least six months before it is due to expire. You must apply to DOE, who will arrange for your premises to be inspected and assess the report. They may request you apply for a renewal using the same process as if it was a new licence. A licence will be renewed for six years.

You may transfer a licence to another person if DOE approves it. If a licence holder dies, the licence automatically passes to their personal representatives for a period of at least three months. You must notify DOE if you wish to cancel your licence.

You may apply to DOE for an exemption if your zoo is too small or does not exhibit enough animals or species.
To remove more than 20 cubic metres of water a day from a watercourse or underground water reserve in England or Wales you will normally need an abstraction licence from the Environment Agency.
To sell goods by competitive bidding you may need to register the premises in which you auction with the local authority.

column3: Licence to provide ringtones for downloading (All UK)
column4: To provide ringtones for downloading you are likely to need a licence from PRS for Music.

column3: National road freight operators licence (Northern Ireland)
column4: In Northern Ireland, to operate a goods vehicle with a gross weight of over 3.5 tonnes, which is used to carry goods for profit, you need a licence from Driver and Vehicle Licensing Northern Ireland.
In Northern Ireland, to operate a vehicle that carries more than eight people, for business purposes, you need a road service licence from Driver and Vehicle Licensing Northern Ireland.

To make copies of newspaper content for teaching purposes, you generally need a licence from the Newspaper Licensing Agency (NLA).

Making copies can include photocopying, faxing, scanning and emailing.

An educational licence permits you to make copies from:

  • UK national and regional newspapers
  • newspaper websites
  • certain specialist and foreign titles

It also permits you to:

  • use an overhead projector to project newspaper content onto a screen
  • include newspaper content in study literature
  • receive and distribute newspaper content from a public relations or press cuttings agency

You can apply for an educational licence on the NLA website.

Annual fees consist of a basic licence fee calculated on the total number of staff and students at your educational establishment and, where appropriate, additional fees for frequent paper and digital copying.

If you have not applied for a licence before, you may also have to pay an indemnity charge to cover past copying.

Licences are subject to certain conditions - eg keeping records of the number of copies made and making these available for inspection by the NLA on request.

If you make copies of newspaper content without a licence, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you fail to pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, the NLA may terminate the licence.

If you are a business that makes copies of newspaper content for internal use - eg articles relating to your business, industry or competitors - you may need a business licence from the NLA instead.

column3: Quarantine premises licence (England, Scotland and Wales)
column4:
To run quarantine premises for animals, you need a licence from Animal Health and Veterinary Laboratories Agency on behalf of the Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) (England), the Scottish Government (Scotland), the Welsh Government (Wales).

In order to be granted a licence, you must satisfy the issuing department that your premises are under the supervision of a veterinary surgeon, or if your premises are purely for research, a registered medical practitioner authorised to act on a veterinary surgeon's behalf.

Conditions may be attached to a licence.

You must have a system in place to identify the animals received at your premises. You must also keep records for each animal, detailing its receipt, release or death, any treatment and any other relevant information. Information must be recorded within 36 hours of any relevant event and records must be kept for 12 months from the date of the event. You must produce records to an inspector or constable when required.

column3: Licence to train racehorses (England, Scotland and Wales)
column4:
To train racehorses for entry into steeple chases, hurdle races and national hunt flat races you need a licence from the British Horseracing Authority (BHA).

Licences can be for jump races, flat races or a combined licence for both races.

Licences last for one year and must be renewed annually.

There are numerous criteria you must meet to hold a licence. You must:

  • have at least five years experience in training yards or stables, with at least two years in a senior, responsible position - eg Assistant Trainer
  • have at least three wins with a spread of horses as a permit holder
  • have managed a point to point yard for two years and have a minimum of ten point to point wins with a spread of horses
  • have NVQ level 3 in Racehorse Care and Management
  • attend and pass three one-week long courses held at the British Racing School or the Northern Racing College
  • attend a day-long seminar at Weatherbys
  • have public liability and employer's liability insurance
  • be fit and proper to hold a licence, including a consideration of honesty and integrity - eg consideration of any criminal convictions
  • comply with health and safety requirements
  • confirm that any employees are paid in line with the Racing Industry Minimum Rates of Pay and employed under required working standards
  • have suitable premises and facilities to train horses

If you are applying for a licence for the first time, you will also have to show that you can recognise disease and health issues in horses and have knowledge in areas such as horse anatomy, feeding, racecourse requirements and the Rules of Racing.

You must also provide a business plan, professional references, details of the yard lease or agreements for its use, a projected profit and loss account and a reference to confirm you have around £40,000 in capital or as an overdraft.

You must pass background checks and your yard and facilities will be inspected by a British Horseracing Authority Stable Inspector. Facility requirements will vary depending on whether you wish to train for jump or flat races.

Ideally you should have at least three horses in training.

You may be asked to attend an interview to show your knowledge, understanding of the Rules of Racing and management skills etc.

Licences will be subject to a fee which must be included in your application.

As part of the honesty and integrity requirements, licences are not usually issued to bookmakers.

Licences only allow training from a specified yard. If you wish to train from a different stable or yard you must have approval to do so.
To operate a railway network, you need a licence from the Office of Rail Regulation.

If you run an independent school offering full time education, you need to register with the Department for Education (DfE) in England or the Welsh Government in Wales.

You must meet required standards on the:

  • quality of education provided
  • spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of students
  • welfare, health and safety of students
  • suitability of staff
  • premises and accommodation provided at your school
  • information provided by your school
  • handling of complaints

Your application to enter your school in the register must be made in the prescribed manner, and must contain the required information, including:

  • the age range of students
  • the maximum number of students
  • whether the school is for male or female students or both
  • whether the school provides accommodation for students
  • whether the school is specially organised to make special educational provision for students with special educational needs (SEN) and, if so, the types of SEN provided for

Your school will be inspected to ensure it is suitable. You will be notified as to whether it is suitable or not and, if it is, your details will be entered onto the register.

You must make an application in writing to DfE or the Welsh Government for approval of any material change to the school or the running of the school. This includes but is not limited to change of proprietor, change of address, or the change of any of the information which was required in the application for registration. In Wales, a material change also includes the provision for students with special educational needs.

Your school may be removed from the register if there is a material change that has not been approved.

Your school will be regularly inspected to ensure that standards are being met, and are likely to continue to be met.

If your school is not meeting the relevant standards, you may be required to submit an action plan for approval, specifying the steps that will be taken to meet the standards, and the time by which each step will be taken.

If you do not submit an action plan, or if an approved action plan is not complied with, a relevant restriction may be imposed on you, or your school may be removed from the register.

If a relevant restriction is imposed, you must take one or more of the following steps by a specified time:

  • cease to use any part of the school's premises for all purposes, or for specified purposes
  • close any part of the school's operation
  • cease to admit any new students or new students of specified descriptions

You may be required to provide the Secretary of State in England or the Minister for Education and Skills in Wales, with certain information relating to your school on request.

You may be considered unsuitable to take part in the management of an independent school, in which case you will be prohibited from doing so. The DfE or the Welsh Government may remove your school from the register if it is satisfied that someone who either owns or carries out certain work for the school is prohibited under certain legislation.

If you fail to register you could be liable to up to six months imprisonment or a £5,000 fine, or both.

column3: Licence to release non-native animals and those animals and plants listed under Schedule 9 of the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (England, Scotland & Wales )
column4: To release non-native animals and plants into the wild, you need a licence from Natural England or the Central Science Laboratory (for the release of biological control agents only) in England, the Scottish Government Agricultural Department in Scotland and the Environment, Planning & Countryside Department in Wales.

column3: Registration of a residential family centre (England)
column4:
If you operate a residential family centre, you need to register.

You may only run or manage a centre if you are fit to do so. You must:

  • be of integrity and good character
  • be physically and mentally fit
  • have the appropriate experience, skills and qualifications
  • have certain information, detailed in schedule 2 of Residential Family Centres Regulations 2002, available

You must compile a statement of purpose containing the centre's objectives, the services provided and the arrangements for protecting residents under the age of 18. You must also produce a resident's guide and make this available to every resident parent.

You must create a written placement plan for each family. If there is conflict between the interests of the members of a family, you must prioritise the welfare of the child.
Care provision must meet requirements regarding:

  • the health, welfare, treatment and supervision of residents
  • ensuring residents are not at risk of suffering harm or abuse
  • respect for residents' wishes, feelings, privacy and dignity
  • storage, administration and recording of medicine
  • training staff in first aid
  • standards of cleanliness and hygiene
  • management of complaints
  • health and safety risk assessment and fire management
  • prevention of toxic conditions and the spread of infection at the centre
  • access by residents to such medical advice or treatment as necessary
  • regular review of the quality of care provided

No resident may be subject to physical restraint unless it is the only means of securing the welfare of a resident and there are exceptional circumstances. Corporal punishment may never be used.

You must implement a written child protection policy for safeguarding child residents, which sets out the procedure to be followed in the event of any allegation of abuse or neglect. You must have appropriate staff disciplinary procedures in place.

Your premises and facilities must be of sound construction, free from hazards, kept in a good state of repair and be otherwise suitable. This includes provision of suitable laundry, personal hygiene and food storage and preparation facilities, and suitable ventilation, heating, cooling and lighting. Each family must be provided with at least one private room which is adequately furnished.

The premises must be sufficiently equipped to meet the needs of any disabled resident.

There must always be a sufficient number of competent staff. You must only employ someone if they are of integrity and good character, are fit to do the work, have suitable qualifications and training, and if you have obtained the relevant information about them   
All permanent appointments must be subject to the satisfactory completion of a period of probation. All employees must receive appropriate training, supervision and appraisal.

You must notify a resident parent of any incident affecting their child's welfare unless this would place the child's welfare at risk. You must give immediate notice to RQIA of any:

  • death, injury, involvement in prostitution of, or child protection enquiry involving, a resident under the age of 18
  • accident, infectious disease, or other event which adversely affects the welfare of a resident or requires the calling of police
  • any serious complaint about the home or a member of staff

If you are the owner but do not manage the centre you must regularly visit and interview residents and staff to determine the standard of care being provided. You must inspect the premises and records and prepare a written report.

You must give notice of any significant change to the centre or the running of the centre, or of you are conv
column5:
icted of any criminal offence.

You must keep the necessary records.

column4:
To run a residential care home for adults in England you need to register with the Care Quality Commission (CQC).

The service provider - which can be an organisation, partnership or individual - must register. If you are registered as an organisation or partnership then the person responsible for managing the services must also register. If you are registering as an individual, you don't need to have a separately registered manager unless you don't intend to be in charge full-time.

There are separate registration forms for each category of provider. Applications forms are available from the CQC website and once complete should be e-mailed to the CQC.

No application fee is payable, however once registered you must pay an annual fee towards ongoing compliance monitoring and any changes you wish to make to your registration. Fees can be paid by cheque of BACS.

Along with your application, you must:

  • provide details of each location from where you will provide residential care services
  • list the regulated activities you intend to carry out
  • meet essential standards of quality and safety
  • make a declaration of compliance

If you carry out a regulated activity without being registered, you will be committing an offence, and you could be fined and/or imprisoned.

If you intend to deposit  duty-suspended excise goods that you own in an excise warehouse or you intend to buy and store duty-suspended excise goods that are already held in an excise warehouse, you must be registered and approved by HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) as a Registered Owner unless:

  • you are not a revenue trader
  • you are an authorised excise warehousekeeper storing your own goods in your own excise warehouse
  • the goods are UK duty-paid excise goods that are being warehoused for export under the excise duty drawback scheme (see Notice 207)
  • the goods are wine or made-wine
  • the goods are hydrocarbon oil, bioethanol or special energy product
  • you are a non-UK based owner and have appointed a duty representative to act on your behalf

Owners requiring registration must apply on form EX60 and duty representatives intending to act on behalf of overseas owners must apply on form EX64. If the business is a partnership, you must also complete form Excise 102. These forms can be downloaded from the HMRC website.

HMRC will only consider applications from owners and duty representatives who are based in the UK.

Prior to acting for an overseas owner, a duty representative must carry out checks to make sure the owner does not have a business establishment or fixed address in the UK.

When applying for registration, you must allow a minimum of 30 working days for your application to be processed. You are also required to send an up to date business plan with your application.

Other details you must disclose include:

  • any unspent convictions (other than minor motoring offences) that you or other key personnel in the business have
  • any previous registrations as an owner or duty representative, including your previous registration number, name and address

All applicants will receive a pre-approval visit from HMRC in order to determine whether or not they are suitable for approval.

If your application is accepted and approval is granted, you will be issued with a certificate of registration.

You will only be permitted to hold dutiable goods of the class or description specified on your certificate of registration.

You must give the excise warehousekeeper a full copy of your certificate of registration before depositing or buying dutiable goods in their excise warehouse.

If you fail to register or comply with any conditions of your approval, you may be fined and your goods may be forfeited.

To make copies of newspaper content - eg articles relating to your business, industry or competitors - for internal use in a business, you generally need a licence from the Newspaper Licensing Agency (NLA).

Making copies can include photocopying, faxing, scanning and emailing.

A business licence permits you to make copies from:

  • UK national and regional newspapers
  • newspaper websites
  • certain specialist and foreign titles

It also permits you to receive and distribute newspaper content from a public relations (PR) or press cuttings agency.

You can apply for a business licence on the NLA website.

Annual fees consist of a basic licence fee calculated on the total number of staff or turnover and, where appropriate, additional fees for frequent paper and digital copying.

If you have not applied for a licence before, you may also have to pay an indemnity charge to cover past copying.

Licences are subject to certain conditions - eg keeping records of the number of copies made and making these available for inspection by the NLA on request.

If you make copies of newspaper content without a licence, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you fail to pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, the NLA may terminate the licence.

If your business is a press cuttings agency or a PR agency that supplies newspaper content to clients, you will need a PR licence from the NLA instead.

If you make copies of newspaper content for teaching purposes, you need an educational licence from the NLA instead.

column3: Vehicle Registration Plate Supplier Registration (All UK)
column4:
To supply vehicle registation (number) plates (including manufacturers, distributors, motor factors, motor dealers, car repairers and retail outlets), you need to register with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

Applications must contain all required information for the register and are subject to a fee of £40 for each premises where plates are to be supplied.

The register contains:

  • the name and residential address of a sole trader and all partners for partnership businesses
  • the business name for Scottish partnerships, the name and registration number for companies and limited liability partnerships (LLPs) or any other name traded under for sole traders
  • the address of the registered office for companies and LLPs, the address of the principal place of business (if not the registered address for companies and LLPs) and the address of any premises where business is carried out from (or where business as a plate supplier is to be carried on in Scotland)
  • a telephone number
  • the date of registration as a supplier and any suspension date
  • details of any convictions for any person or partner within the last five years, or 30 months in the case of someone under 18
  • the identification number given on registration

You must get the following information from a purchaser before supplying a plate:

  • business name and address of the principal place of business (or registered address if this is the same for LLPs and companies)
  • if the purchaser is not a business, their name and residential address
  • if an agent for a purchaser, the name and address of the agent
  • the registration mark on the plate
  • the connection between the purchaser and the mark or the vehicle the plate is to be attached to

If you are not a repairer and if the plate is to be fixed to a vehicle before it is to be sold or transferred, you don't have to obtain the final two pieces of information.

Insurance details may also be required in certain circumstances.

You must keep sales records for every plate, including the information obtained from the purchaser, the registration mark and details of documents viewed for verification purposes - eg document reference number and driver number - or copies of them.

You must give notice of any changes to information in your application or if you stop supplying plates within 28 days.

You must allow an authorised person or constable to enter your premises and inspect any plates or records.

Failure to comply with requirements may mean you commit an offence and could result in a fine of up to £5,000 depending on the offence.

If you provide false or misleading information, your registration may be revoked, you may be banned from applying for registration for up to five years, or both. You will also have to pay a fine. If you commit an offence other than providing false or misleading information your registration may be suspended for up to five years, as well as, or instead, of a fine.

Your registration may be cancelled if the DVLA think you have not carried on a business as a plate supplier for at least 28 days.

Exemptions apply in certain circumstances.

To run a nursing agency, you need to register with the Care and Social Services Inspectorate Wales (CSSIW).

You may only carry on or manage a nursing agency if you are fit to do so. You must:

  • be of good character
  • be physically and mentally fit
  • have satisfactory information available

You must run the agency with sufficient care, competence and skill.

You must compile, make available and keep under review a written statement of purpose which includes a statement as to the nature of the services provided.

You must take such training as is appropriate to ensure that you have the necessary experience and skills.

You must ensure that any nurse supplied by your agency:

  • is of integrity and good character
  • has the necessary qualifications, skills and experience
  • is physically and mentally fit for the job
  • has full and satisfactory information available

The selection of a nurse for supply must be under the supervision of a nurse.

Every nurse you supply must at all times, when working for a service user, wear identification showing their name, the name of the agency and a recent photograph.

Personal information about a patient may only be disclosed to any member of staff where necessary to provide an effective service to the patient.

There must be at all times an appropriate number of suitably qualified, skilled and experienced staff. Each employee must receive appropriate supervision, and be provided with a job description outlining their responsibilities.

You must establish a procedure for obtaining information from service users about the performance of your agency's nurses, and you must take any necessary steps to address any problems.

You must provide each nurse who is employed by your agency with a written statement of the terms and conditions on which they will be supplied to work for a service user, in particular specifying their employment status.

You must prepare and provide to every member of staff, a staff handbook which includes information on the conduct expected of staff and disciplinary action which may be taken against them, their roles and responsibilities, and record keeping requirements.

Before a nurse is supplied, the service user must be informed of the name of the nurse and the means of contacting them, as well as the name of the member of agency staff who is responsible for that nurse, and details of how the service user may contact you or a nominated person.

You must keep the required records.

You must implement and make available an effective complaints system for handling complaints, which is appropriate to the needs of service users. Staff must be trained in the operation of the complaints procedure.

You must establish and maintain a system for monitoring, reviewing and improving the quality of care given to service users, and following a review you must prepare a report.

You must comply with any request by the National Assembly that you undertake an assessment of the service your agency provides to service users, by supplying the assessment in the form required within 28 days. You must comply with any notice by the National Assembly to take action that they consider necessary.
