Your premises must be suitable for the purpose of achieving the aims and objectives of the agency set out in the statement of purpose.

You must give notice of any significant change to the agency or the running of the agency, or if you are convicted of any criminal offence.

To run a nursing home, you need to register with the Care Quality Commission (CQC).

Your application must be made in the required form. You must comply with any conditions that CQC imposes.

CQC will register your nursing home according to the requirements set out in the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2010 and associated guidance on compliance with the Regulations, the Essential Standards of Quality and Safety. These are available on the CQC website. 

You may only carry on or manage a nursing home if you are fit to do so. You must:

  • be of good character
  • be physically and mentally fit
  • have satisfactory information available
  • have the necessary qualifications, skills and experience

You must ensure that your service protects the health, safety and welfare of users, and that you regularly review the quality of your services.

You must take such training as is appropriate to ensure that you have the necessary experience and skills.

You must ensure that each service user receives safe and appropriate care, by means of:

  • assessing the needs of the user
  • planning and delivering care and treatment so as to meet individual needs, ensure the welfare and safety of the user, follow any published best practice guidance and avoid unlawful discrimination

You must have procedures in place for dealing with emergencies which would affect the provision of services, in order to reduce any associated risks to service users.

You must protect service users against the risks of inappropriate or unsafe care, by operating systems which enable you to:

  • regularly assess and monitor the quality of the services provided against the requirements
  • identify, assess and manage risks
  • where necessary, make changes to the care provided
  • ensure that decisions are taken at the appropriate level, and the appropriate people are held accountable

You must ensure that service users are safeguarded against abuse, and you must ensure that any form of control or restraint used is neither unlawful nor otherwise excessive.

You must ensure that both service users and employees are protected against identifiable risks of infections, by means of risk assessment, treatment, and appropriate standards of cleanliness and hygiene for premises and equipment.

You must make appropriate arrangements for the obtaining, recording, handling, storing, dispensing, administering and disposal of medicines.

You must ensure that service users are provided with, and enabled to consume, a choice of suitable and nutritious food and drink, in sufficient quantities to meet their needs, taking into account the user's religious or cultural background.

You must ensure that your premises are of suitable design and layout, and are secure and adequately maintained.

You must ensure that equipment is properly maintained, suitable for purpose and used correctly. Equipment must be available in sufficient quantities to meet user's needs and promote the independence and comfort of service users.

You must ensure that the dignity, privacy and independence of service users is promoted, and that they are sufficiently informed and enabled to participate in decisions relating to their care or treatment, where possible, and that you have arrangements in place for obtaining their consent to treatment or care.

You must implement an effective complaints system for identifying, receiving, handling and responding to complaints, under which every complaint is fully investigated.

You must keep accurate records on each service user.

You must only employee people who:

  • are of good character
  • have the necessary qualific
column5:
ations, skills and experience
  • are physically and mentally fit
  • have satisfactory information available

    • You must ensure that there are always sufficient numbers of suitably qualified, skilled and experienced workers.

    You must ensure that your employees receive appropriate training, supervision and appraisal, and are enabled to obtain further relevant qualifications.

column4: If you use premises to take off-course bets you need a licence from the local Magistrates' Court. Licences will only be granted to individuals that hold a bookmaker's licence.

column3: Registration of beer brewer or beer packager (All UK)
column4:
If you intend to brew beer for sale you must first register your premises with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

If you brew or package beer, you may also apply for registration to hold beer on your premises without payment of excise duty. You will need to specify the classes of beer which you intend to hold.

A sample application form for registration is available in guidance on the HMRC website.

As part of your application you must enclose a plan of the premises to be registered.

Applications should be sent to the HMRC National Registration Unit.

You must register at least 14 days before you produce or package any beer.

A separate registration is required for each business premises in which beer is produced or held.

No fee is payable and the registration will last until you stop trading.

Conditions may be attached to your registration - eg in relation to the classes of beer you may hold in duty suspension on your registered premises.

A certificate of registration will be issued for each set of premises registered for the production of beer.

A registered holder certificate will be issued for each set of premises registered to hold certain classes of beer without payment of duty.
 
You must keep the certificate of registration and/or your registered holder certificate on your premises, and produce it on request for inspection by HMRC officers.

If you brew or hold beer on unregistered premises or fail to apply with any conditions of registration, you may be fined and the beer may be forfeited.

If you have any queries about registering, you can call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

If you are not a producer or packager of beer, you may hold beer in duty suspension in an excise warehouse - but you will need authorisation from HMRC.

If you intend to operate UK-registered aircraft on commercial passenger or cargo flights outside the European Economic Area (EEA), you need to apply to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) for a route licence.

The EEA comprises European Union countries, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway.

You must already hold an air operator's certificate (AOC) and an operating licence from the CAA before you can apply for a route licence.

If granted, a route licence will usually authorise flights anywhere within the scope of your AOC.

You can download a route licence application form from the CAA website.

Applications should normally be made at least six months before you intend to start operating.

 The CAA issues two classes of route licence, both of which allow the carriage of passengers, cargo or mail (or any combination of these). The difference between them lies in the way space on the aircraft is sold:

  • scheduled licences authorise flights where at least some of the capacity is sold direct to the public without the involvement of a charterer
  • charter licences authorise flights where all the capacity on the aircraft is sold to one or more charterers for resale

Completed applications should be sent to the CAA's Airline Licensing and Consumer Issues team.

There is no charge for applying for a route licence.

If the CAA is satisfied that a licence should be granted, it will normally publish details of your application on its website and, if an interested party submits a written objection, hold a public hearing at which you can provide evidence in support of your application.

You will be notified of the CAA's decision at the end of the hearing. 

A licence may be granted subject to such terms as the CAA thinks appropriate.

Licences will last indefinitely, provided that your operating licence is not suspended or revoked.

However, holding a route licence does not automatically allow you to start operating. You will also need to be granted traffic rights by the government at the other end of the route. Negotiation of traffic rights is undertaken by the Department for Transport (DfT), although charter services airlines are generally required to seek permits directly from the countries concerned.  The DfT will be able to provide more information on the availability of traffic rights.

If you operate flights outside the EEA without a route licence or in breach of any terms of your licence, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.
 
Flights to or from the UK using foreign-registered aircraft (whether operated by a UK licensed airline, another EEA carrier or a non-EEA airline) are not covered by route licences but by permits granted by the DfT. Contact the DfT for a permit if this applies to you.

If you keep cattle, you must ensure each animal is individually registered with the British Cattle Movement Service (BCMS) in England, Scotland and Wales or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) in Northern Ireland.

To register your animals you must apply to the relevant body for a passport. The relevant body must receive the application within a total of 27 days from birth.

All identification tags must be in the correct format. They must be approved, show the letters 'UK' followed by your 12 digit number that is unique to the herd and the animal. Unused tags must be securely stored. You must not alter, deface or obliterate tags.

You will normally receive a passport within 7 days of applying.

If you import an animal from within the European Union (EU), you must apply for a passport within 15 days of the animal arriving at the holding destination.

If you import an animal from outside the EU, you must apply for a passport within 15 days of tagging the animal.

You must submit a passport application for bison calves within seven days of birth, although you can defer their tagging for up to nine months if you do not move them from their holding of birth, or separate them from their dam.

You must keep identification documents and produce them on request. If an identification document is lost, stolen, destroyed or illegible, you must apply for a replacement within 14 days of becoming aware of this. Fees may be payable. If you find the original, you must return it to the relevant authority within seven days.

You must comply with any notice requiring you to surrender identification documents or movement cards.

You must also ensure that you:

  • Accompany each animal with its valid passport when moving between holdings. Each passport must be given to a new keeper and if sold through a market, the market operator.
  • Tag bovine animals and notify bovine births, movements and deaths to the Cattle Tracing System within the legal deadlines.
  • Keep an up to date herd register for your cattle.
  • Ensure that the conditions of the General Licence for the Movement of Cattle are complied with when any movements are made. There is an obligation in the licence for keepers to inspect any cattle being moved for signs of foot and mouth disease. If you find any evidence of the disease, you must immediately notify your local Animal Health Divisional Office. If you do find evidence of disease, the cattle movement licence is invalid, and you are not allowed to move any animal kept on the premises.
  • Do not move untagged cattle from a holding.
  • Replace all removed, lost or illegible tags within 28 days.
  • Do not apply unapproved tags or duplicate identification codes.

You must not falsely alter or deface an identification document, obstruct an inspector or fail to provide assistance, information, documents or records, or provide false/misleading information. You must not use an identification document for any animal other than the one issued it. You must provide any information required to an inspector or BCMS on request.

column3: Registration as a firearms dealer (All UK)
column4:
Any business that manufactures, sells or transfers shotguns, firearms or ammunition, and anyone involved in the repairing, testing or proving of them, must register with the police.

In order to sell firearms, including air weapons, by way of trade or business, you must register as a firearms dealer with the local police.

You must complete application form 116 and return it to your local chief officer of police with the correct fee.

You must provide information on all places in the area where your business will be carried out.

You will be required to explain the nature of your business and show that you have an understanding of firearms legislation.

The chief officer of the police can attach any reasonable conditions to your licence, and may change these at any time with written notice.

As a registered firearms dealer, you must:

  • keep firearms secure
  • not sell firearms or ammunition to anyone under the age of 18, or anyone you believe to be drunk or unsound of mind
  • not sell firearms or ammunition to anyone who is not authorised to own a firearm or shotgun
  • not carry out your business in a place that may be a danger to the public

If you obtain new premises that are not entered in the register, you must notify the chief officer of the police as soon as possible. You must include all necessary information.

To renew your registration certificate, you must return your current certificate to the police and apply for a new certificate in the standard way. You must do this within or before three years from the granting of your original certificate.

You must keep a register of all firearms or ammunition transactions and you must record all transactions within 24 hours of their occurrence, in particular the quantities and descriptions of all firearms and ammunition:

  • manufactured - including the dates for these
  • purchased or acquired - including the names and addresses of the sellers or transferors and the dates of the transactions
  • accepted for sale, repair, test, proof, cleaning, storage, destruction or other purpose
  • sold or transferred - and the areas where the person's firearm certificates where issued
  • in your possession for sale or transfer at the date of your last stocktake

When recording the above information you must include the names and addresses of all relevant parties, and the date these transactions occurred.

Details on the register must be kept for at least five years from the date of the transaction.

You must allow the police to inspect the register and your stock if requested.

If you sell, let or lend a shotgun to a holder of a visitor's shotgun permit, you must notify the police, in writing, of the transaction within 48 hours.

If you operate an independent school that provides boarding for more than 295 days in a year, your school is defined as a children's home. You need to register the school with the Department for Education and the home with Ofsted Children's Directorate in England or the Care and Social Services Inspectorate Wales (CSSIW).

column3: Independent school (under compulsory school age) registration (England)
column4:
If you run an independent school that provides day care for pupils under compulsory school age, you need to register with the Ofsted Early Years Directorate or the Department for Education (DfE). Ofsted registration is required if children attend who are under 3 but not rising 3; or no child attending Early Years Foundation Stage provision is a pupil of a school; or the provision is not part of the school's activities.

You must comply with certain requirements, including provision of enhanced criminal record certificate applications, suitability for providing the service and first aid qualifications.

You must also provide specific information including your full name, date of birth, address and telephone number and details of any criminal convictions and/or cautions.

You must also comply with additional requirements including:

  • ensuring the welfare of the children being cared for
  • ensuring a written procedure is available for review and is followed to protect children from abuse or neglect
  • that you are suitable to work with children, are of good character, have suitable skills and experience and are physically and mentally fit to do the work
  • ensuring a system is in place to ensure anyone working with the children fits the suitability criteria and have the appropriate qualifications
  • ensuring premises are suitable and safe
  • that health and safety risk assessments are carried out on the premises, equipment and activities at least once per calendar year
  • ensuring the children's behaviour is managed suitably
  • ensuring a written complaints procedure is in place

You must keep the required records on each child.

You must ensure that specific information is given to parents, including a copy of the complaints procedure, the procedure for ensuring the safety of children from harm and abuse and information on the activities.

You must notify the Chief Inspector of the following:

  • the death or serious injury of a child or other person on the premises
  • the sudden serious illness of a child
  • allegations of serious harm or abuse to a child
  • food poisoning that affects two or more children
  • any event likely to alter the suitability of a carer or person living or working on the premises

You must be covered for death, injury, damage, public liability or other loss by adequate insurance.

You must display your certificate of registration and you must provide a copy of the registration to a parent if requested.

You must not smoke or consume drugs or alcohol whilst providing childcare, or allow alcohol, drugs or tobacco to be consumed on the premises or in the presence of a child being cared for.

You must not use corporal punishment on a child or allow others on the premises to use such punishment.

To operate a marine fish farm in coastal waters you need a seabed lease from The Crown Estate.

The Crown Estate owns virtually all the seabed around the UK out to 12 nautical miles (ie to the territorial sea limit).

Application forms are available on The Crown Estate website and can be submitted either electronically or by post.

No fee is required to make an application for a seabed lease.

Applications should be accompanied by:

  • a scale plan of the area of seabed to be leased
  • any relevant consent references 
  • a brief outline of the business/production plan for the proposed site, including details of financial resources, strategy plan and decommissioning measures in the event of termination of the lease

It is recommended that you check on the availability of the proposed location before making an application. Enquiries can be made in writing to enquiries@thecrownestate.co.uk.

As well as a seabed lease, you also require authorisation from the Fish Health Inspectorate in order to operate as a fish farm.
If you look after one or more children (under eight years old in England) in domestic premises you need to register with Ofsted in England.

column3: Registration of chiropractors with the General Chiropractic Council (all UK)
column4: To practise as a chiropractor, you need to register with the General Chiropractic Council (GCC).

column3: Cider or perry maker's registration (All UK)
column4:
If you make cider or perry for sale and your total production - including any for your own consumption - in any rolling period of 12 consecutive months either exceeds 7,000 litres (70 hectolitres), or is likely to do so, then you need to register the premises on which it is produced with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

You must also register if you render cider or perry sparkling, unless you intend to carry out this process in an excise warehouse - a place approved by HMRC for the holding of goods on which excise duty is suspended. You may produce cider or perry and sparkling cider or perry on the same registered premises.

You should apply for registration on form CP 30, which is available on the HMRC website.

A separate registration is needed for each set of premises where you intend to make cider or perry for sale.

As part of your application, you must make entry of the premises and plant you intend to use. This involves creating a plan describing and showing the position of each room, place and vessel that you use in the production process.

The plan should be submitted with your application to the HMRC National Registration Unit (the address is listed on the form).

No fee is payable and the registration will last until you stop trading.

You must keep the certificate of registration on your premises and produce it on request for inspection by HMRC officers.

If you produce cider or perry on unregistered premises, you may be fined. The cider or perry and all vessels, utensils and materials used in the production process may also be forfeited.

You may claim exemption from registration if your total production in any rolling period of 12 consecutive months does not exceed 70,000 litres (70 hectolitres). To claim exemption you must download form CP 33 from the HMRC website and then complete and return it to the HMRC National Registration Unit.

If you have any queries about registering, you can call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

If you are operating in an excise warehouse, you don't need to register, but you will need authorisation from HMRC to deal in duty-suspended goods.

column3: Licence to hold clinical trials (All UK)
column4: To carry out clinical trials of investigational medicinal or tissue engineered products in the UK you need a Clinical Trial Authorisation from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).

column3: Coal mining and exploration licence (All UK)
column4: To carry out coal mining operations, including exploration and operating opencast or underground mines, you need a licence from the Coal Authority in England, Scotland and Wales or the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) in Northern Ireland.

column3: Hackney carriage driver (taxi) licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4: If you are a hackney carriage (taxicab) driver in England (excluding London), Scotland and Wales you need a licence from the local authority. Conditions of the licence vary around the country.

column3: Music licence for theatrical productions (All UK)
column4:
To use sound recordings for on-stage or off-stage effects, you are likely to need a licence from Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL). A licence from PRS for Music may also be required.

You may also need a PRS for Music licence - but not a PPL licence - if you are playing live music during a performance.

If you stage live music events in public, eg a concert or festival, you are likely to need a licence from PRS for Music.

PRS for Music administers the rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to songs, instrumentals, etc.

You can apply for a licence on the PRS for Music website.

A licence fee is payable, but this varies depending on the type of type of live music that will be played at the venue.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms and fees, on the PRS for Music website.

You can also contact PRS for Music on 0845 300 6033 or at live.musiclicence@prsformusic.com.

If you stage live music events in public without obtaining a licence you may be infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you manage a theatre, see our separate summary on the licences you need to play music on your premises.

column3: Licences to play music in a theatre (All UK)
column4:
To play music in a theatre, whether live or from a recording, you may need a licence from PRS for Music and/or Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL).

PRS for Music administers the rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to songs, instrumentals etc.

PPL administers the rights of record companies and performers in relation to sound recordings (eg CDs).

If you play live music you will need a licence from PRS for Music, if you play recorded music you will need a licence from both PRS for Music and PPL.

You also require separate licences for music played as part of theatrical productions (eg on-stage or off-stage sound effects) [S&M] and background music played during the entry and exit of audiences and during intervals.

Licence fees are payable, but these vary depending on the type of licence applied for and from whom.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms and fees, on both the PRS for Music and the PPL websites.

You can also contact:

  • PRS for Music on Tel 0845 300 6033 or at live.musiclicence@prsformusic.com
  • PPL on Tel 020 7534 1070 or email ppnb@ppluk.com

If you play recorded, copyrighted music in public without obtaining a licence you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

column3: Licences to play background music (All UK)
column4:
If you play recorded music in public, eg a radio, CD or music channel on your business premises, you are likely to need licences from PRS for Music and Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL).

PRS for Music administers the rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to songs, instrumentals etc.

PPL administers the rights of record companies and performers in relation to sound recordings (eg CDs).

Businesses that might need a licence include:

  • shops
  • offices and factories
  • hairdressers and beauty salons
  • cinemas and theatres
  • hotels and guesthouses
  • restaurants and cafes
  • pubs, bars and nightclubs
  • sports grounds and other sporting facilities (eg bowling alleys)
  • gyms and other health facilities
  • bingo halls and casinos
  • social clubs and members' clubs
  • churches and halls
  • public transport

You need to be licensed even if customers don't generally visit your premises (employees count as members of the public for these purposes).

Licence fees are payable, but these vary depending on the type of licence applied for and from which organisation.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms and fees, on both the PRS for Music and the PPL websites.

You can also contact:

  • PPL on Tel 020 7534 1070 or email ppnb@ppluk.com
  • PRS for Music on Tel 0800 068 4828 or at musiclicence@prsformusic.com

A PRS for Music licence also allows you to play live music on your premises, eg in a pub, restaurant or nightclub.

If you play recorded, copyrighted music in public without a licence you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages. 

If you manage a theatre, see our separate summary on the licences you need to play music on your premises.

column3: Passenger carrying vehicles drivers licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
To drive a public service vehicle (PSV) in England, Scotland and Wales, you must have the relevant category added to your driving licence by the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

To be granted a PSV category on your driving licence you must complete a medical examination, a vocational theory test and a practical test.

You must then apply to the DVLA on the form PSV421, supply all information and documents (eg driving licence) requested and pay the correct fee. Your current licence will be returned with the relevant category added to it.

You must notify the DVLA of any changes to your circumstances that may affect your licence - such as change of name or address - and surrender it for replacement.

If you are disqualified from holding an ordinary driving licence for any reason, or your licence is refused or revoked, you must surrender your PSV licence to the DVLA.

You must also deliver your licence to the DVLA within seven days for endorsement or cancellation where it has been endorsed, suspended or revoked.

If your driving licence entitled you to drive cars prior to 1 January 1997, you can drive a minibus that is not being used for hire or reward, provided you are 21 or over and the minibus has a maximum of 17 seats including the driver's.

If you wish to hold a provisional PSV licence, you will need to apply to the DVLA.

To operate premises in which the processing or handling of meat takes place you need approval from the Food Standards Agency or the local food authority, depending on what you are doing.

This applies to:

  • red and poultry meat slaughterhouses
  • game handling establishments
  • cutting plants
  • cold stores
  • meat products
  • minced meat and meat preparations plants
  • plants producing edible co-products
  • premises where the rewrapping of all these products takes place

A Veterinary Manager will be responsible for assessing the application and will make an appointment in due course to inspect the establishment in order to assess whether it may be granted approval or conditional approval.

If you move animals on to or from a holding you must do so under the terms of the general movement licence issued by the Scottish Government Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate. If the conditions of this licence are not met then the right to move livestock may be suspended and an individual movement licence will be required.

To operate a UK sea vessel (up to 24 metres load line length) in commercial activities you need a small commercial vessel certificate from the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA). Commercial activities include carrying cargo and/or up to 12 passengers, providing a service that does not necessarily involve cargo or passengers and operating a UK pilot boat of whatever size.

For certification, you must apply to an MCA-recognised certifying authority.

Your application should include a completed Application for Examination form - known as an SCV1 - and the relevant fee. You must include ownership and vessel details - including description of the ship, overall length and its name - along with any additional information the approved certifying authority requests.

Your vessel must be inspected and surveyed against the relevant codes of practice above. You must also meet one of the six categories of code requirements dependent on the type and use of your vessel:

  • Cat 0 - unrestricted service
  • Cat 1 - up to 150 miles from a safe haven
  • Cat 2 - up to 60 miles from a safe haven
  • Cat 3 - up to 20 miles from a safe haven
  • Cat 4 -up to 20 miles from a safe haven, in favourable weather and daylight
  • Cat 5 - up to 20 miles from a nominated departure point, in favourable weather & daylight

Your vessel may be restricted to less than the specified operating limits above.

The MCA-authorised Certifying Authority will arrange for a vessel survey and inspection to ensure your vessel meets all the above criteria. They will also provide you with guidance on the administrative process.

You must ensure your vessel also complies with all of the requirements of the Small Vessels in Commercial Use for Sport or Pleasure, Workboats and Pilot Boats – Alternative Construction Standards.

If you pass the inspection, you will be issued with a certificate confirming the details to be entered onto the Small Ship Register.

You must ensure that your vessel is marked with its registered number (including the prefix 'SSR'). This must be painted on, or fixed to the exterior of the hull, deck or superstructure where it can be readily seen. Each digit of the number should be a minimum of 30 millimetres in height and 20 millimetres in width, except for the number 1, which should be 5 millimetres in width and have a thickness of 5 millimetres with a space of 5 millimetres between each digit.

You must notify the MCA if there are any changes to the ownership of the vessel or other registration particulars. You must also pay the relevant re-registration fee.

column3: Taxi and minicab driver's licence (Northern Ireland)
column4: To drive a licensed public or private hire taxi vehicle you need a licence from Driver and Vehicle Licensing Northern Ireland (DVLNI).

column3: Hackney carriage (taxicab) vehicle licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4: If you own or run a hackney carriage (taxicab), it needs to be inspected and licensed by the local authority. This applies to England (excluding London), Scotland and Wales.

All taxi vehicles, both public and private hire, need to be inspected for roadworthiness by the Driver and Vehicle Testing Agency and need a licence from Driver and Vehicle Licensing Northern Ireland (DVLNI) on an annual basis.

To run a laying hen establishment with over 350 hens or eggs that are being supplied to the Class A egg market you need to be registered with Animal Health Veterinary Laboratories Agency in England and Wales.

Registration applications must include the following information:

  • the name and address of the establishment
  • farming method(s) used - ie caged, barn, free range or organic
  • maximum capacities for each farming method used, including the maximum number of laying hens present at one time for each method
  • the name and address of the keeper and owner if different
  • the registration number of any other establishment kept or owned by the keeper and owner, if applicable

You must allow authorised officers access to your premises. You must provide information or assistance required by them and must not provide false information.

If you fail to comply with requirements, you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £2,500 and/or imprisoned for up to three months.

You must notify Animal Health Veterinary Laboratories Agency with 28 days of any changes to the information detailed in your registration.

column3: Notification of imports of live fish from within the European Union (England & Wales)
column4: To import live fish into England or Wales from the European Union you need to notify the Fish Health Inspectorate.

column3: Live fish and shellfish importer authorisation (England & Wales)
column4:
If you wish to import live fish and shellfish into England and Wales, you need to be authorised by the Fish Health Inspectorate (FHI) - part of the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas).

This includes imports intended for:

  • fish farms
  • 'put and take' fisheries
  • restocking
  • scientific research
  • public aquaria and zoos
  • spas and medical use (nibble fish)

You don't need to be authorised to import live or dead fish or shellfish for immediate human consumption or immediate processing for human consumption. However, imports from outside the European Union (EU) will require health and hygiene certification.

To become authorised you must complete application form AAH2, providing details about your business, suppliers, species of fish you wish to import, holding site and facilities and water source.

If you intend to hold fish on your own site you must also include a biosecurity measures plan with your application. This needs to be documented and approved by the FHI in order for authorisation to be granted.

You don't need to pay an application fee.

If you fail to apply for authorisation when required to do so you may be faced with an unlimited fine.

Once you are authorised you must notify FHI or Animal Health - if you are importing live fish or shellfish from outside of the EU - at least 24 hours in advance of your import arriving in England or Wales.

Consignments need to be accompanied by health certificates if they are from outside the EU or are species susceptible to, or carriers of, an EU controlled disease.

If you intend to introduce imported fish into inland waters, including fisheries, in the UK you must obtain section 30 consent from the Environment Agency. If you are introducing non-native fish, you also need an Import of Live Fish Act licence from Cefas.

column3: Notification of imports of live shellfish from within the EU (England & Wales)
column4: To import live shellfish from within the European Union you need to give notification to the Fish Health Inspectorate.

Food premises that handle products of animal origin such as meat, dairy, egg or fish product are required to be inspected and approved by the Local Authority or the Meat Hygiene Service.

The approval of food premises of this type is to ensure that additional requirements above the general requirements for food premises are met, as premises of this type often involve more high risk operations.

All food premises producing products of animal origin are required to be approved unless exempted.

Exempted food premises businesses are generally food retail businesses selling directly to the public or to other businesses that supply the final customer, such as caterers, pubs, restaurants and other retailers.

The conditions for exemption are defined as when the activities are marginal, localised and restricted. These terms are generally defined as:

  • marginal - up to a quarter of the business conducted in terms of food
  • localised - in the immediate vicinity, usually this means within 30 miles of the county boundary in which the business is located
  • restricted - products of animal origin such as meat, dairy, egg or fish, but not products such as wild game and wild game meat

Note that rules concerning temperature controls storage or transport still apply to exempted businesses.

column3: Registration of a food business establishment (All UK)
column4:
If you run a new food business establishment you must register with the environmental health service at your local authority at least 28 days before starting food operations.

Registration applies to most types of food business, including those that store, prepare, distribute or sell food on premises, and also catering businesses run from home and mobile or temporary premises, such as stalls and vans.  If you use two or more premises, you will usually need to register each one with the relevant local authority.

When registering you will need to provide information about your business and the types of food activity you undertake.

You don't need to pay a fee when applying for registration or if your food business requires approval.

If you make, prepare or handle food of animal origin, such as meat or dairy products, you may need to have your establishment premises inspected and approved by your local authority. Meat plants such as slaughterhouses and cutting plants need approval from the Food Standards Agency (FSA) instead. However, if your premises requires approval, you don't need to register as well.

If you operate a food business without registering (or gaining approval), you may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

You should notify your local authority of any significant changes to your food business prior to any changes taking place.

column3: Public service vehicle operators licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4: To operate a vehicle capable of carrying more than eight passengers for hire or reward, you need a licence from the local Traffic Commissioner. In some circumstances smaller vehicles need to be licensed.

To run a pet shop in Northern Ireland that sells animals, you need a licence from the Veterinary Service of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development.

Licences are issued by local Divisional Veterinary Offices. The licence must be renewed every year.

Fees will be payable and conditions may attach to a licence.

If you make copies of articles and extracts from books, magazines, journals and digital titles protected by copyright, you need a business licence from the Copyright Licensing Agency (CLA).

Making copies includes photocopying, faxing, scanning and emailing.

Different licences are available for different business sectors. These include:

  • hotels licence - for hotels and conference centres that make copies available for clients
  • copyshops licence - for shops that provide a photocopying service
  • document delivery licence - for businesses supplying documents to clients
  • press cuttings agency licence - for businesses providing print or electronic clippings to clients
  • law licence - for law firms and barristers chambers
  • pharmaceutical licence - for pharmaceutical, healthcare and biotech companies
  • business licence - for other businesses that make copies of copyrighted material

There are also licences available for schools and further and higher education establishments.

You can apply for a licence on the CLA website.

Licence fees are paid annually, and fees and conditions vary depending on the type of licence you apply for.

If you make copies of copyright material without a licence, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you fail to pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, the CLA may suspend or terminate the licence.

Note that certain works and categories of material - such as printed music, newspapers and maps - are excluded from all CLA licences. A list of excluded categories and works is available on the CLA website. If you wish to make copies of excluded works, you should contact the rightsholder directly for permission to do so.

If you use any of your land as a caravan site, you must be licensed by the local district council.

If you run a caravan site without a licence, you may be fined.

You must also comply with any conditions imposed against your licence.

For full details on this and other mandatory requirements for caravan site owners see our guide on setting up and running a caravan site.

If you provide amusement machines in your premises you must have a licence for the machine or the premises. If the licence is for the machine the licence will be a special amusement machine licence.

Licences are issued by HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC).

You must display your licence in your premises and produce it when requested by an officer authorised by HMRC. You must also allow an inspector to inspect your premises and machines when requested.

Licences will be valid for one to 12 months and detail the types of machines you can provide.

You will have to pay amusement machine licence duty on any licence you hold. The amount of duty will depend on the type of machine and the period of your licence. If your licence is for 12 months you may be able to pay duty in instalments. Interest will be calculated into the instalments. If you fail to pay an instalment your licence will be revoked and you will still be liable to pay the unpaid duty. In addition any amusement machines on your premises may be forfeited.

Your licence may restrict how many amusement machines you can have on your premises. You must have a licence for each type of machine you provide.

You will only be granted a special amusement machine licence for a small prize machine and if you and the machine meet conditions. This type of licence will be valid for 12 months.

If you offer amusement machines without a licence HMRC may serve you with a notice detailing the circumstances of when they believe you offered machines without a licence and requiring you to produce your licence. HMRC may issue a default licence and request from you any unpaid duty that would attach to that licence.

If you provide amusement machines without the appropriate licence you may have to pay a civil fine. If you recklessly or intentionally provide amusement machines without a licence you may commit a criminal offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both. In addition your machines may be forfeited.

If you fail to produce your licence to an inspector or allow an inspector to inspect your premises or amusement machines you may be given a civil fine.

The following machines will be not require a licence:

  • machines that aren't gaming machines
  • two-penny machines
  • machines where the cost of a game is no more than 30 pence and the prize in a single game is worth no more than £8 of which no more than £5 is given as cash
  • machines where the cost of a game is no more than ten pence and the prize in a single game is worth no more than £15 of which no more than £8 is given in cash
  • machines where the cost of a game is no more than £1, the prize in a single game is worth no more than £50 and the prize is not cash or cannot be exchanged for cash

You do not need a licence if you are providing amusement machines at a charity event, eg fete, fair, dinner, etc where all the proceeds go towards charitable purposes and the machines are not the only reason why people would be attending.

If your business sells air holiday packages, chartered flights or scheduled flights where a ticket is not issued straight away, you must have an air travel organiser's licence (ATOL) from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

There are different types of licence that you can apply for:

  • standard ATOL - if you intend to carry more than 500 passengers per year
  • small business ATOL - if you intend to carry 500 or less passengers per year
  • ATOL to ATOL trade sales - if you only intend to sell flights or holiday packages to other ATOL holders
  • franchised ATOL - if you are a member of an approved travel trade organisation and intend to carry less than 1,000 passengers per year

There are different application forms, fees and supporting documents required depending on the type of licence you apply for. More information about the individual licences and application forms is available on the CAA website.

For franchised ATOLs, you should apply for a licence directly to the approved organisation to which you belong.

The CAA must be satisfied that your business is fit to hold a licence. This will involve providing details of the history of people in a position of influence in your business.

For some licences your business must also meet certain financial criteria.

Once you have sent your application forms, fees and supporting documents to the CAA, you will be invited to attend a formal meeting to discuss the financial and fitness aspects of your application. A decision on your application will usually be made at or soon after the meeting.

The decision letter may specify certain requirements that you must meet before a licence is issued. You will be given up to two months to comply with these requirements.

If your application is granted, you will be issued with a licence and a unique ATOL number. You must comply with the standard terms of that licence - eg in relation to the number of passengers you can carry each year, as well as any specific restrictions or conditions.

Once you are licensed, you must contribute to a customer protection fund called the Air Travel Trust (ATT). Contributions are calculated by multiplying the number of passenger bookings by a set passenger charge specified by the CAA.

When selling flights or air holiday packages you must supply the buyer with an ATOL receipt or ATOL confirmation invoice at the time of payment.

The maximum validity period for an ATOL is one year, though they can be issued for shorter periods.

If your business fails to meet the fitness and financial criteria, or if you fail to contribute to the ATT, your licence may be suspended or revoked.

If you sell air holiday packages or flights without a licence or in breach of any terms or conditions attached to your licence, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

column3: Local bus service registration (England (excluding London), Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you operate a local bus or coach service for profit, you must register your service with the traffic commissioner for the area in which you intend to operate.

The Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA) maintains the registration system on behalf of the traffic commissioners.

To qualify as a 'local service' passengers must be charged separate fares over short distances and must be able to get off the bus within 15 miles (24.15 kilometres) of the place where they were picked up. The route itself can be any length.

If passengers can make journeys of 15 miles or less over some parts of a long-distance service, those parts of the route should be registered as separate local services.

Registration is not required for rail replacement services or for certain not-for-profit transport schemes, eg school buses owned and operated by local authorities.

If your bus service operates partly within Greater London, you will also need a London service permit for that part of the route with passenger stops in London.

To apply for registration you must already hold either:

  • a public service vehicle (PSV) operator's licence
  • a community bus permit

Application forms are available from VOSA.

Your application should contain details about your service, vehicles and route and should be accompanied by:

  • a map of the route 
  • a full timetable
  • an application fee of £60 (£13 for a community bus service)

Unless there are special circumstances, you should ensure that your application is made at least eight weeks before the proposed start date of the service.

Vehicles will be expected to comply with statutory requirements regarding exhaust emissions and all new vehicles should be fully accessible to people with disabilities.

You need to register in each traffic area where your service has stopping points. However, in practice, the traffic area office to which you sent your application will copy it to the others.

You must also send copies of your completed application form and supporting documents to every local authority or Passenger Transport Executive that covers the route of your journey. You can get a list of addresses from traffic area offices.

If your registration is accepted, you will receive a letter confirming this from the traffic area office.

Once your service has been registered, you must ensure that you either display or have on your vehicles:

  • a fare table
  • a timetable including details of the days when the service is to run

The service number and destination (or route) must be displayed prominently on the outside of each vehicle.

If you fail to operate your service as registered, the traffic commissioner will carry out an investigation which may result in:

  • conditions being attached to your PSV operator's licence which stops you from running certain local services or, in more extreme cases, any local service at all 
  • you having to pay a fine

column3: Music licences for physical products (All UK)
column4:
If you make copies of music on to any physical product, you may need a licence from the Mechanical-Copyright Protection Society (MCPS).

In alliance with PRS for Music, MCPS administers the 'mechanical' rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to the copying of music on to:

  • audio products, eg CDs, records
  • audio-visual products, eg DVDs
  • customised music products, eg karaoke discs, backing tracks or music quiz compilations
  • products that use music as part of their soundtrack, eg films and computer games

The type of licence you need depends on your operation. Licences are required for businesses that:

  • manufacture or distribute audio products for retail
  • manufacture and distribute audio products to the public with magazines or newspapers for sale in the UK
  • manufacture or distribute audio and audio-visual products for the promotion of a single or album release to the music industry
  • manufacture and distribute customised music products 
  • import audio, audio-visual, karaoke, toy and novelty products into the UK
  • use music in productions such as films or TV/radio adverts
  • use music in computer games, novelty or promotional products
  • supply music, eg jukeboxes, to business locations for the purpose of playing to members of the public
  • record music to be played as background music to an exhibition

Licence fees are payable, but these vary depending on the type of licence applied for.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms, on the PRS for Music website.

You can also contact the MCPS Recorded Media team on Tel 020 8378 7500 or at applications@mcps.co.uk.

If you use copyright music in your products without being licensed, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

To carry out MOT testing in England, Scotland or Wales, you need authorisation from the Vehicle and Operator Services Agency (VOSA). Both businesses and individuals can be licensed as an Authorised Examiner.

Private businesses are unable to carry out MOT testing in Northern Ireland as all vehicle testing is carried out by the Driver and Vehicle Testing Agency.

VOSA may make any investigations or inspections they believe necessary before authorising a person or business for MOT testing.

Individual testers must not carry out any examination unless they have successfully completed a course of instruction for carrying out examinations. They must also provide VOSA with the details of any vehicle testing stations where you will be conducting vehicle examinations.

Individual testing approval may be limited to specific motor vehicles and specific types or methods of examinations. This is also the case for businesses.

Individuals must display a sign indicating they are authorised for MOT vehicle examination outside the vehicle testing station where they are authorised to carry out examinations.

Authorised businesses must display a sign to show the specific authorisation they have and include a list of names of those who are approved to carry out testing - known as nominated testers. Businesses must also notify VOSA of all nominated testers working at their testing station and inform them of any who cease to work there.

Nominated testers must only carry out tests if they have the relevant training and experience, undergo monthly quality control checks and attend regular refresher training. The Authorised Examiner is ultimately responsible for the all nominated testers and tests carried out.

If your business is a registered company or partnership, at least one of the directors must have completed a course of instruction in the functions of authorised examiners.

VOSA may carry out inspections of your individuals' or businesses' vehicle testing stations and apparatus. They will be give three days' notice of any inspection.

You must inform VOSA of any changes in your business which relate to the terms of the authorisation.

You must keep records - either paper or electronic - of the outcome of all vehicle inspections that you undertake.

column3: Licence to manufacture, assemble or import medicines for human use (All UK)
column4:
You require a manufacturer's licence to manufacture or assemble licensed medicinal products for human use in the UK, to export products or to import licensed medicinal products for human use from countries outside the European Economic Area.

Licences are obtained from the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).

Applications must be made in the format required by MHRA and include any required samples, documents and information. They must include a description of the medicinal products that are to be licensed. This description should either be an appropriate general classification or by a description of the actual product.

The MHRA will take into account the operations to be carried out under the licence and the premises where these will take place, the equipment to be used, the qualifications of the supervisor of operations and arrangements for maintaining and keeping records or products to be manufactured or assembled.

The MHRA will decide your application within 90 days.

A licence may be granted subject to provisions. You will be served a notice if your application is refused or if your licence is granted subject to provisions that were not in your application. You may make representations in relation to any such notice within the time frame allowed and subject to conditions, eg you must provide a written summary of any oral representations you will make and provide copies of supporting information.

If the MHRA wish to reject your application in relation to questions on the safety, quality or efficiency of a product they must refer your application to a committee, known as an appropriate committee. If the committee can't advise they will notify you of this. You can make representations to the committee if this occurs within a time allowed by them. If you intend to give oral representations you must provide a written summary of these representations and any documents you intend to use to support you within six months of the date you were notified.

After any representations have been made and the committee has told the MHRA of its decision the MHRA will advise you of the result.

You must hold a product licence to be able to hold a manufacturer's licence or the products to be manufactured must be by order of a product licence holder, or by the sponsor of a clinical trial where the products in question are to be used.

Licences will apply for either five years from the date it was granted or until it is either revoked by the MHRA or surrendered by you for products which are governed by EC Directive 2001/83/EC relating to medicinal products for human use.

You may be served with a notice from the MHRA requesting further information. You must provide this information. You must also notify the MHRA when a product is placed on the market within two years from the date of your licence being granted.

Your licence may be revoked, suspended or varied if it is found you provided false or incomplete information in your application, you have breached any provisions in the licence, there has been a change of circumstances in any of the provisions of your licence or you have failed to comply with a notice to provide further information.

If you manufacture, assemble, export or import products without a licence you may commit a criminal offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both. If you fail to provide information when requested by notice you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

You may apply to have your licence varied. Applications must be in writing, specify the required variation include any information in support. You must also include any required fee.
To be able to use the title 'architect', you need to register with the Architects Registration Board (ARB).

To provide commercial television services in the UK, you need a licence from Ofcom. Programme content, advertising and transmission technical standards are all regulated as part of the licence agreement.

Under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1967, dealers who provide TV equipment (including video recorders and PC TV cards) for sale or hire are legally obliged to notify TV Licensing of customers' names and the address where the equipment is to be installed. Failure to do so within 28 days of sale could result in prosecution and a financial penalty of up to £1,000. You can now register as a dealer online.

If you watch or record programmes as they're broadcast, you must be covered by a TV Licence. You don't need a TV Licence to watch videos or DVDs, to use online catch up services, or to watch clips on websites like YouTube. If you only use TV equipment for closed circuit television, you don't need a TV licence.

One TV Licence will cover all the TV sets and other equipment in a single business premises. Any residential accommodation on your business premises needs to be covered by a separate licence. If your business has several sites, you can apply for a company group licence to save on administration.

If your premises aren't covered by a TV licence, you could be liable for prosecution and a £1,000 fine.

For more information, contact TV Licensing's business team on Tel 0300 790 6124.

column3: Temporary export licence for cultural goods (All UK)
column4: To loan works of art or other cultural goods over a certain age and value from a museum or art gallery to an exhibition abroad or to take cultural goods abroad temporarily for sale or private enjoyment, you may need a temporary export licence from the Export Licensing Unit of the Arts Council.
To fell trees in England, Scotland and Wales, you may need a felling licence from the Forestry Commission. In some circumstances other permissions or exceptions may apply.

column3: Licences to use music online or on mobile technology (All UK)
column4:
To use copyright music online or on mobile technology you are likely to need a licence from PRS for Music and Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL) or Video Performance Limited (VPL).

PRS for Music administers the rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to songs, instrumentals, etc.

PPL and VPL administer the rights of record companies and performers in relation to sound recordings (eg CDs) and music videos respectively.

The type of licence you need depends on your operation. Licences are required for businesses that use copyright music:

  • for online radio stations
  • for music streaming websites
  • for music download services
  • for subscription music services
  • in webcast services
  • as audio downloads in a podcast 
  • to sell as ringtones or ringback tones

Licence fees are payable, but these vary depending on the type of licence applied for and from whom.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms, on both the PRS for Music and the PPL websites.

You can also contact:

  • PRS for Music's Broadcast & Online Licensing team on Tel 020 7306 4991 or at onlinelicensing@prsformusic.com
  • PPL's TV or Radio Broadcast Licensing Teams at tvbroadcasting@ppluk.com or radiobroadcasting@ppluk.com

If you use copyright music or music videos online or on mobile technology without being licensed, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

column3: Licence to use music on the radio (All UK)
column4: To broadcast copyright music on the radio you are likely to need licences from PRS for Music and Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL).

column3: Licences to use music on television (All UK)
column4:
To use copyright music in television programmes you are likely to need licences from PRS for Music and Phonographic Performance Limited (PPL) or Video Performance Limited (VPL).
 
PRS for Music administers the rights of composers, lyricists and music publishers in relation to songs, instrumentals, etc.

PPL and VPL administer the rights of record companies and performers in relation to sound recordings (eg CDs) and music videos respectively.

The type of licence you need depends on your operation, eg broadcasting programmes or producing television programmes for broadcasters.

Licence fees are payable, but these vary depending on the type of licence applied for and from whom.

Licence names are not necessarily the same on the PRS for Music and the PPL websites. For example, if you run an independent television production company that wants to use copyright music in a television programme, you may need an IPC licence from PRS for Music and a television secondary sales licence from PPL.

You can find more information about the type of licence you need, as well as application forms, on both the PRS for Music and the PPL websites.

You can also contact:

  • PRS for Music's TV licensing team at tvchannels@prsformusic.com
  • PPL's TV broadcast licensing team on Tel 020 7534 1003 or email tvbroadcasting@ppluk.com

If you broadcast recorded music or music videos in a television programme without obtaining a licence you may be infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.
To practise as a physiotherapist or physical therapist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

To possess, buy or acquire a firearm or shotgun, you need a relevant firearm or shotgun certificate issued by the police. You must also have a certificate to buy ammunition.

You must contact the chief officer of police in your area to obtain the correct application form.

You will also need to include up to four passport photographs and two references. Your referees will be required to provide a statement explaining that there is no reason why you should not be granted a licence, disclose any other relevant information and verify your passport photographs.

You will also have to pay the relevant fee, unless you are covered by a specific fee exemption.

To get a shotgun certificate, in addition to the above, you must also convince the chief officer of police that you possess no danger to public safety or to the peace.

If you are under 18 years old, you will also have to provide a good reason for having a firearm, shotgun or ammunition.

Your certificate must specify the firearms or shotguns you hold and have the correct identification numbers, if known. You must comply with all conditions attached to the certificate. The chief officer can vary the conditions of your certificate at any time by giving notice in writing.

You must be able to produce your firearm certificate and any relevant documents if requested by the police.

A certificate usually lasts for five years from the date it was issued or renewed. It can be renewed for another five years by applying through the same method as above.

If you hold a firearms certificate, you can get a European firearms pass. You can also apply for this at the same time as a firearms certificate. The European firearms pass will state the registered firearms, the date of issue of the pass and length of issue. European firearms passes are normally valid for five years or the length of your firearm certificate - whichever is shorter. You can renew a European firearms pass by applying to the chief police officer.

You must not shorten the barrel of any shotgun to a length of less than 24 inches.

Certain firearms are completely prohibited. You will not be able to acquire a licence for them and it is an offence to possess, buy or acquire them.

column3: Registration of independent health care service (England & Wales)
column4: To operate an independent health-care service such as a private hospital or clinic, you need to register with the Care Quality Commission (CQC) in England or the Healthcare Inspectorate Wales (HIW) in Wales.
To operate a commercial or sponsored local bus service in London, you need to apply to the Licensing Manager at Transport for London (TfL) for a London service permit.

column3: Manufacturing authorisation for veterinary medicines (All UK)
column4:
To manufacture veterinary medicines you require a manufacturer's authorisation from the Veterinary Medicines Directorate (VMD).

A marketing authorisation will also be required.

To be authorised you must have suitable staff, premises, facilities and equipment to make, store and control the medicines and must be able to comply with the Veterinary Medicines Regulations 2009.

The authorisation will show:

  • the types of products to be made or imported
  • where they are to be made, your name and address and the address of the premises
  • the names of qualified people who can act under the authorisation

Your premises will be inspected regularly whilst you hold an authorisation.

Medicines must be made in accordance with the marketing authorisation that relates to the product.

In addition to the general authorisation there are specific authorisations for:

  • manufacturers of autogenous vaccines
  • manufacturers of products for administration under the 'cascade'
  • non-food animal blood banks
  • equine stem cell centres

Fees are payable.

To operate as an aircraft maintenance engineer, you may need a licence from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). Two licence types are appropriate - EASA Part 66 and UK National BCAR Section L.

Licences may be subject to conditions and you will only be granted a licence if the CAA feel that you are a fit and proper person to hold a licence and that you have the relevant experience, knowledge, skill and competence in aeronautical engineering. To prove this you must supply evidence of qualifications and take any required exams or tests.

By holding a licence you will be able to issue:

  • maintenance review certificates for aircraft specified in your licence
  • certificates of release regarding repairs, replacements, modifications, maintenance, overhauls and inspections of aircraft and equipment
  • certificates for fitness for flight

Licences will be valid for a maximum of five years and can be renewed. The CAA will maintain oversight of the licensed person to ensure that you are still a fit and proper person to hold the licence and are adequately qualified.

You must not carry out work under your licence if you are unfit. If you do so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500.

This licence is separate to an aircraft maintenance licence required under Part 66 of EU Commission Regulation 2042/2003.

The EASA Part 66 licence and the BCAR Section L licence contain similar privileges, but are separated by the types of aircraft an engineer can work on - EASA aircraft and UK National Annex 2.

column3: Denatured alcohol production and distribution (All UK)
column4:
Denatured alcohol is commonly used for industrial purposes - eg the manufacture of cleaning fluids and perfumes - and is alcohol with chemicals added to prevent its use as a beverage. Alcohol denatured in accordance with approved formulations is not liable to excise duty.

There are three approved classes of denatured alcohol, which must be produced in accordance with specific formulations:

  • completely denatured alcohol (CDA)
  • industrial denatured alcohol (IDA)
  • trade specific denatured alcohol (TSDA)

Producers

If you intend to produce denatured alcohol you must either:

  • be a licensed distiller, rectifier or compounder with authorisation from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to denature alcohol
  • hold an excise licence to denature alcohol from HMRC

To become authorised you must write to:

National Registration Unit
Portcullis House
21 India Street
Glasgow G2 4PZ
 

You must explain that you wish to be authorised to denature alcohol and give details of your distiller, rectifier or compounder licence.

You must also apply for a licence on form L5 - application for a licence to carry on an excise trade - available on the HMRC website. In the specified trade section you must enter 'denaturer'.

Your licence may cover more than one set of premises.

Whether or not you are authorised or licensed, you must also:

  • apply to the National Registration Unit (NRU) for approval of your planned manufacturing process
  • make entry of each set of premises you intend to use to make denatured alcohol (unless your premises are approved as an excise warehouse)

Your application for approval of your manufacturing process must be made in writing (there is no prescribed form) and include:

  • your name and contact number
  • address of the premises where you intend to denature alcohol
  • your VAT registration number (if applicable)
  • the class or classes of denatured alcohol you intend to make
  • the formulation you intend to follow
  • the process you intend to use when mixing the alcohol with the other substances specified in the formulation

HMRC's approval will be in writing and may be subject to conditions.

To make entry of your premises you will need to obtain one of the following forms from HMRC:

  • form EX 103 - for private traders
  • form EX103A - for companies

You should fill in the form as directed, describing all the rooms, vessels, utensils etc which you will be using for your trade. Diagrams may be required. Each room, vessel etc must be given an identifying name or number, as well as being physically marked.

The form should be sent to the NRU, along with your other application documents. No fee is payable.

An HMRC officer may inspect your premises prior to your application being granted.

Distributors

If you deal wholesale in denatured alcohol you must hold an excise licence from HMRC. To deal wholesale you must sell quantities of no less than 20 litres to any one person.

You must apply for a licence on form L5 (see above). In the specified trade section you must enter 'distributor'.

Your application should be accompanied by a letter explaining what denatured alcohol you intend to distribute.

Your licence may cover more than one set of premises.

If you intend to hold stocks of IDA or TSDA you must:

  • apply to the NRU for authorisation using the standard wording for an application contained in HMRC guidance
  • make entry of each set of premises you intend to use to hold denatured alcohol (see above)

You must only sell IDA and TSDA to authorised users and have a cop
column5:
y of that authorisation.

If you fail to comply with the requirements covering the production and distribution of denatured alcohol, you may be fined and any denatured alcohol on your premises may be forfeited.

If you have any queries about obtaining a licence, authorisation or approval, you should call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

column3: Licence to rectify or compound spirits (All UK)
column4:
If you plan to rectify (re-distill) or compound (mix with other substances) spirits, you need a licence from HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) and, unless you are operating in an excise warehouse, you will also have to make entry of your premises and plant.

You can apply for a licence on form L5 - application for a licence to carry on an excise trade - which is available on the HMRC website.

Applications should be sent to the HMRC National Registration Unit.

No fee is payable and the licence will last until you stop trading.

If you rectify or compound spirits without a licence, you will be liable to a civil penalty.  If you supply HMRC with inaccurate information, you may be fined.

Unless you rectify or compound spirits in an excise warehouse, you must make entry of your premises and plant. To do so you will need to obtain one of the following forms from HMRC:

  • form EX 103 - for private traders
  • form EX103A - for companies

You should fill in the form as directed, describing all the rooms, vessels, apparatus, pipelines etc which you will be using for your trade. Diagrams may be required.

Each room, vessel etc must be given an identifying name or number, as well as being physically marked.

If you need more pages than are provided with the form, you can use form EX 103B.

The form should be sent to the National Registration Unit, along with your licence application. No fee is payable.

When you have returned the completed form, an HMRC officer will may contact you to inspect your premises and plant before sending you a letter of approval in duplicate. This will set out any specific conditions you will have to adhere to. You should sign and return one copy to HMRC.

If you operate in an excise warehouse you don't need to make entry, but you will need authorisation from HMRC to deal in duty-suspended goods.

If you have any queries about obtaining a licence or approval, you can call the HMRC Excise Helpline on Tel 0845 010 9000.

column3: Voluntary registration as state-registered hairdresser (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you are a hairdresser, you may choose to register as a state-registered hairdresser (SRH) with the Hairdressing Council.

This will allow you to:

  • obtain a certificate which confirms your legal right to trade with the public and that you are qualified to practise as a hairdresser
  • apply for the Master Craftsman Diploma
  • acquire credentials to have your skills recognised internationally

If you choose to register with the Hairdressing Council you need:

  • a minimum of NVQ Level 2 or six years' hairdressing experience
  • to pay a registration fee of £37 (or £45 for a framed certificate)

However, even if you choose not to apply for SRH status, you must check whether you need to register your hairdressing business with your local authority for health and safety reasons (England and Wales only).
To practise as an occupational therapist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as an operating department practitioner, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as an orthoptist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as an orthotist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as a paramedic, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as a prosthetist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as a chiropodist or podiatrist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).
To practise as a clinical scientist, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

To practise as a dietitian, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

This includes using either of the protected titles:

  • dietitian
  • dietician

To be eligible to apply for registration, you must:

  • hold an approved qualification
  • be in good physical and mental health
  • be of good character

You must enclose a fee and all supporting documents - eg qualifications and health reference from your GP - with your application.

The registration fee for the two-year registration cycle is £152 (£76 per year) and there is a one off non-refundable scrutiny fee of £53. The registration fee is reduced by 50 per cent if you successfully completed a UK approved programme within the last two years.

Further information is available in the downloadable application pack on the HPC website.

If your application is successful, your name will be added to the register and you will receive a registration certificate and authentication card.

You must undertake continuing professional development (CPD) activities as a condition of your registration. You must keep a written record these activities, including any supporting evidence, and submit this for inspection by the HPC on request.

If the HPC is not satisfied that you are meeting your CPD obligations, your name may be removed from the register.

It is a criminal offence to call yourself a dietitian or dietician if you are not registered with the HPC. If you do so, you may be fined up to £5,000.

column3: Discharge of trade effluent permit (England, Wales & Northern Ireland)
column4: If your business discharges or has the potential to discharge trade effluents (liquid waste, including wash water) into a foul sewer, you need a permit from the local water and sewerage utility.
To operate as a secondhand motor vehicle dealer in Scotland, you need a licence from the local authority.

To arrange for the disposal or recovery of waste on behalf of another person, you need to register as a waste broker with the Environment Agency in England and Wales or the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).
To operate as a premises-based bookmakers, you need a premises licence from the local licensing authority.

column3: Vehicle Immobilisers (Clamping) Licence (England, Wales & Northern Ireland)
column4:
You need a Vehicle Immobilisers licence if you undertake any of the following activities:

  • moving a vehicle by any means
  • restriction of movement of a vehicle by any means (including the immobilisation of a vehicle by attaching a device to it)
