  • release of a vehicle which has been moved or restricted, where release is effected by returning the vehicle to the person who was otherwise entitled to remove it, by removing any restriction on the movement of the vehicle by removing the device or by any other means 
  • demanding or collection a charge as a condition of any release of or for the removal of the device from a vehicle

Vehicle immobiliser activity only applies:

  • to activities carried out for the purpose of preventing or inhibiting the removal of a vehicle by a person otherwise entitled to remove it
  • where it is proposed to impose a charge for the release of the vehicle
  • to any activities carried out in relation to a vehicle while it is elsewhere than on a road within the meaning of the Road Traffic Act 1988

This licence requirement applies to anyone, eg land occupiers, in-house employees, staff supplied for the purposes of or in connection with any contract to a consumer or volunteers.

There are certain exclusions, refer to paragraphs 2 and 3A of Schedule 2 of the Private Security Industry Act 2001 for full details.

There are two types of Security Industry Authority (SIA) licence:

  • a front line licence required if undertaking licensable activity
  • a non-front line licence required for those responsible for the management, supervision, and/or employment of individuals who engage in licensable activity, as long as front-line activity is not carried out - this includes directors or partners

To obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check, a criminal record check, and hold the appropriate SIA-approved qualification.

column3: Environmental permit for discharges to surface water or groundwater (England & Wales)
column4:
To discharge anything other than clean, uncontaminated water to inland freshwaters (eg rivers, lakes and streams), groundwater (eg boreholes), estuaries and coastal waters, you must have an environmental permit or registered exception from the Environment Agency.

You must comply with all the conditions of your permit or exemption.

To practise as a radiographer, you need to register with the Health Professions Council (HPC).

This includes using the protected titles:

  • radiographer
  • diagnostic radiographer
  • therapeutic radiographer

To run a riding establishment (where horses or ponies are hired out for riding or used for riding instruction) in England, Scotland or Wales, you need a licence from the local authority.

You must be over the age of 18 years old to be eligible for a licence.

You must show the local authority that you are suitably qualified to hold the licence - through approved qualifications or proven experience of horse management.

The condition of your horses will be taken into account. They must be kept in good health, be physically fit and suitable for the purpose it is kept. You must also have suitable accommodation for any horses you keep, and ensure that they are supplied with adequate food, drink and bedding materials.

You also have to show that your horses are regularly exercised and that you have appropriate steps to safeguard horses in an emergency.

The local authority may authorise a veterinary surgeon or practitioner to inspect your riding establishment and horses before granting a licence. You may then be inspected at any time after your licence is granted.

The fee payable for the licence is set by your local authority. The licence is valid for one year.

You must not let out a for hire or for riding instruction without supervision of a responsible person aged 16 years or older if a rider is not competent enough.

You must never leave the carrying out of the business to anyone under 16 years old.

You must also hold an insurance policy that covers liability for injury to anyone riding your horses or anyone injured by the riding of your horses.

Any horse found on inspection of the premises that need veterinary attention must not be returned to work until you provide a certificate to show it is fit again for work.

You must keep a register of the horses in your possession aged three years and under which are usually kept on your premises. These should also be available for inspection.

You must also comply with any additional conditions attached to the licence.

You will not be issued a licence if you have been disqualified from keeping a riding establishment, a pet shop, keeping animals (including boarding establishment) or if you have committed animal health or welfare offences.

column3: Notification to process personal data (All UK)
column4:
You must notify the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) if your business processes personal data in an automated form.

'Personal data' means data which relates to a living person who can be identified from that data. It includes employment details, client information and information captured on CCTV.

If you do process personal data, your business is a 'data controller' for the purposes of the Data Protection Act 1998.

Most businesses must notify the ICO unless they only process personal data for the following purposes:

  • staff administration (including payroll)
  • advertising, marketing and public relations for their own business
  • accounts and records
  • judicial functions
  • personal, family or household affairs (including recreational purposes)

The following are also exempt from the requirement to register:

  • some not-for-profit organisations
  • data controllers who only process personal data for the maintenance of a public register
  • data controllers who do not process personal data on computer

To check whether you are exempt, use our self assessment tool - the link to this is displayed on the right-hand side of this page.

You should always check with the ICO if you are unsure whether you are exempt from notification.

You can notify the ICO by:

  • filling in an online notification form, printing it out and sending it to the ICO
  • completing a notification form request and posting it to the ICO
  • ringing the ICO's notification helpline and requesting a notification form

You need to fill in details of your business and a general description of the processing of personal information being carried out by the data controller.

A notification fee of £500 applies to data controllers with either:

  • a turnover of £25.9M and 250 or more members of staff
  • if they are a public authority with 250 or more members of staff.

All other data controllers - including registered charities and small occupational pension schemes (regardless of their size and turnover - must pay £35 per year unless they are exempt.

Once you have successfully notified the ICO, the details of your business will be entered on the register of data controllers.

You need to renew your registration each year. If you fail to do so you are committing a criminal offence and could be faced with an unlimited fine. The ICO will write to you before the expiry date and explain the process for renewing your entry on the register.

column3: Control of major accident hazards notification (All UK)
column4: To handle, produce, use or store dangerous substances you may need to notify the Health & Safety Executive and either the Environment Agency in England and Wales, Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) in Scotland or the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA) in Northern Ireland.

column3: Car boot sale or other temporary market authorisation (England & Wales)
column4:
If you intend to hold a temporary market - eg a car boot sale, farmers' market or craft fair - or permit your land to be used as the site of a temporary market, you may have to give notice to the local authority for the area where you intend to hold that market.

You are considered to be holding a temporary market if you organise, or allow to be organised on your land, a gathering of buyers and sellers which comprises  at least five stalls, vehicles or pitches and is not held in a building or on a highway. However, this does not include:

  • a market or fair which you have the right to hold by way of statute, royal charter etc
  • an auction of farm livestock or deadstock
  • a market held on land on land where planning permission has been granted for that purpose

To find out if you must be authorised to hold a temporary market, you should contact your local authority. If so, you must give at least one month's notice of the following details:

  • name and address of the person intending to hold the market
  • day(s) on which the market will be held
  • opening times of the market
  • site on which it will be held
  • name and address of the site occupier (if different from the market organiser)

In some cases you may have to submit an application form for approval.

You may need to pay an application fee and, if you don't own the land, you may also need to provide written consent from the land owner.

You may be exempt from the requirement to give notice if the majority of the proceeds of the market are to be used for charitable, social, sporting or political purposes.

If you fail to give notice when required to do so, you are committing an offence and you may be fined up to £2,500.

If you allow your land to be used as a caravan site by the public, you need a site licence from the local authority for the area where your caravan site is situated.

Before a licence can be granted, a caravan site must first be granted planning permission.

Contact your local authority for a licence application form.

You may be required to provide a site plan with your application, showing boundaries, caravan standings, facilities, etc.

You don't generally need to pay a fee for this licence but you should always check with your local authority.

Once granted, a licence will last indefinitely, unless your planning permission for the site expires.

Conditions may be attached to your licence regarding the layout of the site and the provision of sanitary and other facilities.

If you fail to obtain a licence or comply with licensing conditions, you may be fined up to £2,500. Repeated convictions for breaching licence conditions could end up with your licence being revoked.

You don't need a licence if:

  • you hold a caravan exemption certificate (these are issued to organisations that organise caravanning activities for their members)
  • your site is occupied by up to five caravans certified by an exempted organisation and for the use of members only
  • your site is being used temporarily for caravan rallies or by travelling showmen, seasonal workers or builders
  • your site is less than five acres and three or fewer caravans are stationed there for a maximum of 28 days in any 12-month period

If you allow your land to be used as a camping site, you need a camping site licence from your local authority instead. This only applies in England and Wales - a camping site licence is not required in Scotland.

To run a cattle holding you must be registered with the nearest Animal Health Divisional Office (AHDO) in England, Wales and Scotland or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) in Northern Ireland.

To register your cattle holding, you must notify the relevant body of:

  • the address of the holding you intend to keep your cattle
  • your name and address
  • details of your stock
  • your County Parish Holding (CPH) number - where relevant
  • your herdmark

Before you can move your animals onto a new holding, you must apply to the relevant organisation for a CPH number. The organisations are as follows:

  • the Rural Payments Agency for England
  • the Rural Inspectorate for Wales
  • the Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate for Scotland

You do not need a CPH number in Northern Ireland.

For new holdings, or holdings you have recently acquired, you must make this notification within one month. You will then be issued with a herdmark. To get a herdmark in Northern Ireland, you should contact the DARD.

When moving your animals onto the holding, you must comply with the General Licence for the Movement of Cattle and cattle movement notifications.

You must also maintain a herd register and record details of births, movements - both on and off the holding - and deaths. You must keep these records for ten years from the end of the calendar year in which the last entry was made. They may be inspected at any time by the British Cattle Movement Service.

You must notify the relevant body of any changes to your holding within one month of the date of changes.

You must also apply with any cattle identification requirements.

If you wish to employ a child you may need to obtain a work permit for that child from the local authority where your business is based.

A child includes any person who has not yet reached compulsory school leaving age.

It is illegal to employ children under the age of 13 unless they are taking part in a paid performance (eg a play or film), sport or modelling and you have obtained a child performance licence from the relevant local authority.

Children aged 13 may only be employed if your local authority allows it and even then only on an occasional basis:

  • by their parents in light agricultural or horticultural work
  • in categories of light work set out in local byelaws

There are strict rules governing the hours that children can work and the types of work they can do.

Check with your local authority to see what kinds of work children are permitted to do in your area and whether a work permit is required.

If a permit is required, you will need to complete an application form providing details about your business, the child, the job which the child is to be employed to do and the hours which they will be expected to work.

You will also need to provide:

  • a statement by the child's parents that the child is fit to work and they agree to the employment (this may be part of the application form)
  • evidence that the job is not dangerous (eg a risk assessment)

An application fee is generally not payable.

If a permit is granted you will receive a letter of confirmation from the local authority.

If you fail to obtain a work permit for a child that you employ, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £1,000.

If you intend to run a sex shop, cinema or a strip club, you need a licence from the local authority for the area where you intend to set up your business unless the authority agrees to waive this requirement.

Not all areas permit sex shops, cinemas or strip clubs to operate so you should check first with the relevant local authority.

If you apply for a waiver, you may either do this as part of your licence application or separately. An authority will only waive the requirement if it considers that it would be unreasonable or inappropriate for you to hold a sex shop, cinema or strip club licence.

Applications must include your personal details (including any criminal convictions) and should be accompanied by an application fee - these are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area - and any supporting documents that your local authority requests.

Contact your local authority for an application form or visit their website to apply online. You must be aged 18 or over to apply for a licence.

Once you've applied for a licence you must:

  • publish an advert about your application in a local newspaper
  • display a notice about your application in or near your premises for 21 days

If you don't apply electronically you must also send a copy of your application to the police force for the area where your sex establishment would be based.

Conditions may be attached to your licence, eg regulating your hours of opening, your shop displays and advertisements and how visible the interior of your shop is to people passing by.

You must also ensure that no one under the age of 18 is allowed to work at or visit your sex establishment.

A licence is usually valid for up to one year, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

You must display a copy of the licence and licensing conditions in the place specified in the licence or face a fine of up to £1,000.

If you operate a sex establishment without a licence or fail to comply with any conditions of that licence, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £20,000.

To keep a sheep holding, you need to register with the nearest Animal Health Divisional Office in England, Wales and Scotland or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) in Northern Ireland.

To register your sheep holding, you must notify the relevant body of:

  • the address of the holding you intend to keep your animals
  • your name and address
  • details of your flocks
  • your County Parish Holding (CPH) number - if you have one

You will then be issued with a flockmark.

You must register a holding within one month of becoming a keeper or obtaining the holding. If you have more than one holding, you must register each one separately.

If, at any time, you make any changes to existing holdings, you must notify the relevant body as soon as possible.

Before you can move your animals onto your holding, you must apply to the relevant organisation for a CPH number. The organisations are as follows:

  • the Rural Payments Agency for England
  • the Rural Inspectorate for Wales
  • the Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate for Scotland

You do not need a CPH number in Northern Ireland.

When moving your animals onto the holding, you must comply with the General Licence for the Movement of Sheep and Goats and all relevant animal movement notifications.

You must keep and maintain a holding register to record all details of births, movements - both on and off the holding - and deaths. You must also keep information on tags and replacement tags for all your sheep. The holding register must specify:

  • the address of the holding
  • CPH and flock numbers
  • the species held
  • type of production - eg milk, meat, wool, dairy or breeding stock
  • the address of the keeper - if different from holding

You must record any movements within 36 hours from the time they were moved.

You are required to keep one holding register for each individual holding you have.

The holding register must be in the format specified by the relevant body, and may be kept in either electronic or paper form. You must keep these records for three years from the date when the last animal on the holding is moved off it or dies.

You must notify the relevant body of any changes to your holding within one month of the date of changes.

You must also apply with any sheep identification requirements.

column3: Skin treatments registration or licence (England & Wales)
column4:
If you provide certain skin treatments in England (outside of London) and Wales, both you and your premises must be registered with the local authority for the area where your premises are located.

These treatments are:

  • tattooing
  • semi-permanent skin colouring
  • cosmetic piercing
  • electrolysis
  • acupuncture

In Greater London (except for the City) you must obtain a special treatment licence from your local authority instead. In addition to the treatments listed above, this also covers treatments such as massages, manicures, chiropody and saunas.

You must only provide treatments in the area where you are registered to do so.

If you operate without registering or from unregistered premises, you are committing an offence and may be fined.

None of these treatments require registration if carried out by, or under the supervision of, a medical practitioner or dentist.

Contact your local authority for a registration form or visit their website to apply online.

You will usually need to provide details about yourself and your premises, as well as pay a one-off registration fee. These are set by the local authority and may vary from area to area.

In London, you must also send a copy of your licence application to the Metropolitan Police and the London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority.

In order for your registration to be approved, you must comply with all requirements contained in local byelaws relating to staff hygiene and the safety and cleanliness of premises, furniture and equipment. Your premises will usually be inspected as part of this process.

If approved, you will be issued with a certificate of registration (or licence).

You must display a copy of this certificate (or licence) and any byelaws in a prominent place on your premises. If you fail to do so you may be fined.

Registration lasts for as long as you intend to operate in that area, but if you fail to comply with local authority byelaws it may be suspended or cancelled. You may also be fined.

However, in London, licences must be renewed regularly (up to every 18 months) and a renewal fee is payable.

To put a builder's skip on a public road, you must have permission from the local authority.

Some local authorities issue permits to individuals, while others issue them to the skip hire company (skip operators licence). Please consult your local authority for details.

Permission may be granted subject to conditions relating to:

  • where the skip is placed
  • the dimensions of the skip
  • how it must be painted to make it immediately visible to oncoming traffic
  • how the skip's contents must be handled or disposed of
  • the skip's removal at the end of the period of permission

Once permission has been granted, you must ensure that the skip is:

  • properly lighted during the hours of darkness, and marked in any way that has been required in the conditions of the permission - eg with reflecting material
  • clearly and indelibly marked with your name and telephone number or address
  • removed as soon as is practicable after it has been filled

You must erect any barriers and traffic signs that are necessary for preventing or warning of danger to traffic or for regulating traffic, and remove them as soon as they are no longer needed.

If you fail to comply you may be fined up to £1,000.

If you breed dogs for sale you may need a licence from your local authority.

You will be presumed to be carrying on a dog breeding business if, during any 12-month period, five or more litters of puppies are born to bitches which you keep on your premises (or elsewhere).

In Scotland, a licence is also required to rear dogs for sale.

Contact your local authority for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

Applications must include details of your premises and the dogs kept and should be accompanied by a licence fee. Fees are set by local authorities, and may vary from area to area.

Before a licence is granted, your premises will be inspected for suitability by a veterinary surgeon or practitioner and/or a local authority inspector.

In particular, you will need to demonstrate that:

  • the dogs are kept in suitable accommodation
  • the dogs are adequately supplied with food, water and bedding
  • the dogs receive adequate exercise
  • the dogs continue to receive adequate food, water, bedding materials and exercise when being transported to or from your premises
  • you have taken appropriate steps to protect the dogs in case of fire or other emergency, eg by providing fire extinguishers
  • you have taken all reasonable precautions to prevent and control the spread of disease among the dogs, eg by providing isolation facilities

Licences are valid for one year and must be renewed before the expiry date if you wish to continue as a dog breeding establishment.

Licences will be subject to conditions including:

  • not mating bitches until they are at least one year old
  • ensuring that bitches do not give birth to more than one litter per year and six litters in their lifetime
  • maintaining accurate breeding and sale records

If you are a licensed dog breeder, you must:

  • only sell dogs at a licensed breeding establishment, a licensed pet shop or a licensed Scottish rearing establishment
  • not sell dogs (except to a licensed pet shop owner or rearing establishment) if you know or suspect that the buyer intends to re-sell them
  • not sell a dog which is less than eight weeks old, unless it is to a licensed pet shop or rearing establishment
  • not sell to the keeper of a licensed pet shop or rearing establishment a dog which was not born at a licensed breeding establishment
  • ensure that any dog sold to a licensed pet shop or rearing establishment is wearing a collar with an identifying tag or badge when delivered

Similar requirements regarding the sale of dogs apply to licensed rearing establishments in Scotland.

If you don't obtain a licence before breeding or rearing dogs for sale or fail to comply with any licensing conditions or requirements surrounding the sale of dogs, you are guilty of an offence and could be imprisoned for up to three months and/or fined up to £2,500.

You may also be disqualified from keeping dogs and, if in possession of a licence, may have that licence suspended or revoked.

If you obstruct or delay any authorised person from entering or inspecting your premises you may be fined up to £1,000.

column3: Explosives manufacturing and storage licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4: If you manufacture or store explosives, you must have a licence from the Health & Safety Executive (HSE), the police or your local licensing authority.

column3: Fireworks manufacture and storage registration (All UK)
column4:
To run wholesale and retail premises that store and/or sell fireworks of up to 2 tonnes (net explosives content), you must be registered, or licensed, with the local authority Trading Standards (or in former Metropolitan Authorities, the Fire and Rescue Service) in England, Scotland and Wales.

In Northern Ireland you need to register with the Northern Ireland Office.

To run wholesale or retail premises storing more than 2 tonnes (net explosives content), you need a licence from the Health & Safety Executive.

To keep goats, you need to register your holding with the nearest Animal Health Divisional Office in England, Wales and Scotland or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) in Northern Ireland.

To register your goat holding, you must notify the relevant body of:

  • the address of the holding you intend to keep your animals
  • your name and address
  • details of your flocks
  • your County Parish Holding (CPH) number - if you have one

You will then be issued with a herdmark.

You must register a holding within one month of becoming a keeper or obtaining the holding. If you have more than one holding, you must register each one separately.

If, at any time, you make any changes to existing holdings, you must notify the relevant body as soon as possible.

Before you can move your animals onto your holding, you must apply to the relevant organisation for a CPH number. The organisations are as follows:

  • the Rural Payments Agency for England
  • the Rural Inspectorate for Wales
  • the Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate for Scotland

You do not need a CPH number in Northern Ireland.

When moving your animals onto the holding, you must comply with the General Licence for the Movement of Sheep and Goats and all relevant animal movement notifications.

You must keep and maintain a holding register to record all details of births, movements - both on and off the holding - and deaths. You must also keep information on tags and replacement tags for all your goats. The holding register must specify:

  • the address of the holding
  • CPH and flock numbers
  • the species held
  • type of production - eg milk, meat, dairy or breeding stock
  • the address of the keeper - if different from the holding

You must record any movements within 36 hours from the time they were moved.

You are required to keep one holding register for each individual holding you have.

The holding register must be in the format specified by the relevant body, and may be kept in either electronic or paper form. You must keep these records for three years from the date when the last animal on the holding is moved off or dies.

You must notify the relevant body of any changes to your holding within one month of the date of changes.

You must also apply with any goat identification requirements.

To grow hemp in the UK, you need a licence from the Home Office.

You must apply using the online application form on the Home Office Drugs Licensing website. You must register with the Home Office online and submit the MD 29 application form electronically.

You must provide your contact details and the other following information:

  • field location numbers, names or grid references
  • hectarage details
  • farm map with a marked growing area
  • seed type, THC content and confirmation of whether this is a European Union approved seed

You must pay the relevant fee with your application. New licences usually cost £580, with licence renewals costing £326.

To be eligible for a licence you must also undergo an enhanced CRB check.

Your application may be subject to a compliance visit, although this is rare. Generally applications are considered through the 'light touch regime' process which involves assessing your electronic application only.

The Home Office may impose restrictions on where you plant the crop. They may also request that you screen your crop or locate your crop sensitively - eg not in the vicinity of schools or areas of public access.

You must inform the Home Office of any changes to your growing season or planting location. You must send full details of your changes and your application reference or licence number. Your licence will not need to be amended.

You should also information your local police of your growing location.

You must hold the licence before you can begin to grow hemp.

Licences last for a growing season, and you must renew your licence before you can begin to grow for the next season.
To run a hairdressing business you may need to register with your local authority and comply with local health and safety rules in parts of England, Wales and Scotland.

If you own a house or other property and rent it out as a house in multiple occupation (HMO), you must have a licence from the local authority for the area where the property is based.

To qualify as a HMO, the property must be occupied by three or more unrelated tenants as their only or main residence and must have a shared kitchen, bathroom or toilet.

When applying for a licence, you must provide details of your business, as well as the address of and details about the HMO.

You may also need to provide copies of supporting documents such as the tenancy agreement and a Gas Safe certificate.

You will usually have to pay an application fee - these are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

Once you have submitted your application you must display a copy of it for 21 days in a prominent place outside the HMO where it can be easily read by all neighbours and passers-by.

A licence will only be granted if the local authority considers that the property is suitable for occupation as a HMO, eg in relation to its location, condition or amenities, or can be made suitable by the inclusion of conditions in the licence.

The local authority can attach any conditions to a HMO licence that it sees fit, such as requiring work to be carried out in the property by a specified date.

If you breach any conditions you may be required to rectify the breach (and in some cases have rent payments suspended until this is done), have your licence revoked or even be fined up to £10,000.

A licence generally lasts for three years from the date you receive notice that it has been granted before you need to renew it.

If you rent out a HMO without being licensed, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £50,000.

column3: Authorisation to advise on or arrange general insurance (All UK)
column4: To advise on, arrange or sell general insurance products, you need authorisation from the Financial Services Authority (FSA). Authority is needed even if this is only a small part of your business.
To offer meals or refreshment for consumption between 23.00 and 05.00, on or off the business premise, you need a licence from the local authority.

To introduce live fish, fry or ova into inland waters, including fisheries, you need to apply for written consent from the Environment Agency. This is called a Section 30 consent.

You can apply for a Section 30 consent either online or by completing the FR1 application form. You must provide details of the species of fish to be introduced, your supplier, the date of the planned introduction, the water or fish farm that the fish come from and the waters where you intend to keep them. You may not need consent to move fish between authorised fish farms.

You don't need to pay an application fee.

The Environment Agency will process applications within 20 days of receipt. If your application is successful you will receive written consent. This will only apply to the date, site and consignment of fish specified on the consent. If you want to introduce more fish at a later date, you must make another application.

If you introduce fish, fry or ova without consent you may be fined up to £2,500.

For further guidance please contact the Environment Agency's Fish Movements Team on Tel 01480 483968.

If you are introducing non-native fish, you also need an Import of Live Fish Act licence from Cefas.
To promote a lottery in Northern Ireland you need to register with the local authority. Private lotteries and some small lotteries do not need to be registered.

To operate a market stall, you may need a licence from the local authority.

You should contact the local authority where you want to operate for their application process and to find out the terms under which you may operate a market stall.

You may have to pay a fee to obtain a stall and will have to provide the information they request. The local authority might allocate your stall location.

You must abide by any rules that the local authority sets for the market day. You may be required to pay for any damage you cause to the stall or surrounding area.

The local authority may make or alter any rules it believes appropriate for the market - such as hours of operation or fees to be paid.

To run a business as a motor salvage operator, you need to register with the local authority.

You must apply using the form required by your local authority. Fees may be payable with your application.

Information that must be included in your application is:

  • your full name and date of birth
  • your residential address, the address for each administrative area you will be carrying out business
  • if the application is for first registration or renewal
  • if you have had any registration applications refused and the reasons for refusal
  • any convictions under the Vehicle Crimes Act 2001 or other criminal convictions
  • if you are bankrupt

You must be a fit and proper person to be registered. Any relevant previous criminal convictions will be taken into account when considering if you are a fit and proper person.

You will be classed as a motor salvage operator if, as part of your business you:

  • recover for sale or re-use parts from motor vehicles and sell or dispose of scrap from the rest of the vehicle
  • buy and repair or re-sell written-off vehicles
  • buy or sell motor vehicles that will be used for the activities listed above

Registration lasts for three years and you must renew your registration before the end of the three years.

You must keep records of the following for each vehicle you receive:

  • the vehicle's registration number, identification number, make, model and colour
  • the supplier's name, address and contact details
  • the supplier's proof of identity used
  • the condition of the vehicle
  • the date when the information is recorded

In addition when you sell or dispose of the vehicle you must record:

  • the date of sale or disposal
  • the name, address and contact details of the person receiving it
  • details of proof of identity supplied by the vehicle's purchaser
  • the condition of the vehicle
  • the date the information is recorded

Records must be kept for six years from the last entry for the vehicle.

You must notify the local authority if there are any changes that will alter the information you provided in your registration application. Notification must be made with 28 days of the change. If you are not carrying on a business as a motor salvage operator you must notify the local authority.

If you are no longer considered a fit and proper person your registration may be cancelled. It may also be cancelled if the local authority believes you have not carried on business as a motor salvage operator for at least 28 days. If registration is cancelled the local authority doesn't have to consider any further applications from you for three years from the date of cancellation.

If your application is refused the local authority do not have to consider any further applications from you within three years of the refusal.

If your registration is to be refused or cancelled you will be served with a notice from the local authority detailing reasons and allowing you to make representations either verbally or in writing. Appeals can also be made to your local magistrates' court.

If you operate as a motor salvage operator without being registered you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000.

If you provide false or misleading information in your application you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000. If you have previously had an application refused or cancelled the fine will be up to £5,000.

If you fail to provide notification of any change in information or that you are not carrying out business as a motor salvage operator you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

If you fail
column5: to keep records you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £2,500.

column3: Notification of work with ionising radiation (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you plan to start working with ionising radiation you need to notify the Health & Safety Executive (HSE) at least 28 days beforehand.

This requirement applies if you do any of the following:

  • produce, process, handle, use, hold, store, transport or dispose of artificial radioactive substances and some naturally occurring sources (eg at nuclear power stations)
  • use electrical equipment emitting ionising radiation at no more than 5 kilovolts (eg X-ray equipment in medical or dental practices)
  • work in places where the radon gas concentration exceeds certain levels (eg in mines)
  • work with naturally occurring radioactive materials (eg that occur in oil and gas pipes or during smelting operations)

Suppliers of radiation equipment should inform their customers of the need to give 28 days' notice to HSE well in advance.

However, there may be instances - particularly with radon or naturally occurring radioactive materials - where it is not possible to provide 28 days' notice before commencing work. In such cases, you must notify HSE as soon as you become aware of the presence of ionising radiation.

Your notification should take the form of an email or letter (HSE does not provide a form) and should contain the following information:

  • your business name and address and a contact number or email address
  • address of the premises where the work activity is to be carried out and a contact number or email address
  • the nature of your business
  • category of the source of the ionising radiation, ie sealed source, unsealed radioactive substance, electrical equipment or an atmosphere containing the decay products of radon (known as the 'daughters of radon')
  • whether or not any source is to be used at premises other than those notified
  • the dates of notification and commencement of work activity

HSE also recommends including a brief summary of the work that you intend to undertake with ionising radiation.

HSE contact details are available on the HSE website.

If you intend to start site radiography work, HSE will issue you with further notification requirements that you must submit at least seven days prior to each job taking place.

If there is a material change in the work you are doing that would affect the notification details provided, you must notify HSE immediately of those changes.

The following are exempt from the notification requirement:

  • work carried out on a nuclear licensed site
  • work generating very low quantities or concentrations of radioactive substances
  • cathode ray tubes intended for the display of visual images
  • any other electrical apparatus operating at less than 30 kilovolts

If you're unsure whether notification applies to you, you can call the HSE infoline on Tel 0845 345 0055 or email hse.infoline@santia.co.uk.

To operate a zoo you must have a licence from the local authority where the whole - or majority part - of the zoo is located.

A zoo is defined as somewhere were wild animals are displayed to the public for purposes other than a circus or pet shop, and which is open for seven days or more in 12 consecutive months.

At least two months prior to making an application to your local authority you must announce your intention to make an application in writing to your local authority.The notice must identify where the zoo is situated.

The notice must cover the kinds and numbers of animals to be kept, how they are to be accommodated and arrangements for their wellbeing. You must also specify approximate numbers of staff to be employed (and their categories), visitors and motor vehicles expected and the number and location of means of access to the zoo. You should also include information on how you will meet conservation measures.

You must also publish notice of your intention to make an application in at least one local and one national newspaper, and make this notice available at the proposed site and to the local authority.

The local authority may rely on representations from any relevant party. If part of the zoo is located in another local authority area, your application may be referred to the planning authority for that area.

Your premises will be inspected before your licence is granted, or before you renew or alter a licence. The local authority will notify you in writing at least 28 days before the inspection. Your premises will then be periodically inspected throughout the licence period.

A new licence will be granted for four years and you may have to pay a fee. The local authority can attach conditions to your licence for ensuring the proper conduct of the zoo, including indemnity insurance for any damage caused by animals. They may consult you before doing this. Your licence can be altered at any time by the local authority if it is necessary to ensure proper conduct of the zoo.

Your licence will be refused if anyone working in or managing the zoo has committed an offence involving the mistreatment of animals or if the establishment of the zoo would affect the health and safety of people or law and order in that area, or if the zoo will negatively affect the wellbeing of the animals.

You must implement mandatory conservation measures in your zoo such as promoting public education and awareness for conservation of biodiversity, accommodating animals in biological and conservational requirements fit for their species, have satisfactory measures to prevent animal escape, prevent intrusion of pests and vermin.

You must also carry out one of the following activities:

  • conservation research which may benefit a species
  • training in conservation skills
  • information exchange for the conservation of animals
  • breeding wild animals in captivity
  • repopulating an area through the reintroduction of animals

You are also required to keep records of the zoo's collection, including animal health, the numbers of different animals, any acquisitions, births, deaths (with the causes), disposals and escapes. 

You can renew an existing licence at least six months before it is to expire. You must apply to the local authority who will arrange for your premises to be inspected and assess the report. They may request you apply for a renewal using the same process as if it was a new licence. A licence will be renewed for six years.

You may transfer a licence to another person if the local authority approves it. If a licence holder dies, the licence automatically passes to their personal representatives for a period of at least three months. You must notify the local authority if you wish to cancel your licence.

column3: Pleasure boat licence (England, Wales & Northern Ireland)
column4:
To hire out water-bound pleasure crafts (including sailboards, rowing boats, canoes, motor boats, pedallos and larger boats) that are for personal use or carrying passengers, you need a licence from your local authority.

You must not carry more passengers than are permitted, normally no more than 12.

You may also be required to hold a licence to navigate a passenger carrying pleasure boat.

This does not apply to boats used on waters owned or managed by the British Waterways Board who have their own licensing regime.

If you wish to allow a child to take part in a public performance (such as film, play or musical), sporting event or modelling assignment that you are organising and for which the child will be paid, you need a licence from the local authority for the area where the child lives.

A public performance includes:

  • any show for which an admission fee or other charge is made
  • any show which takes place on licensed premises
  • any production which is being filmed, broadcast or recorded for public exhibition

A child includes any person who has not yet reached compulsory school leaving age.

You don't need a licence if the child is not being paid to take part in the performance, eg in the case of a school play.

You will usually need to complete an application form providing details of:

  • your business
  • the production, sporting event or modelling assignment and the child's part in it
  • times, dates and duration of performances or activities
  • number of days and hours per day that the child will appear in the performances or activities (including rehearsals)
  • what the child will earn
  • arrangements that you will make for the child in relation to, eg schooling and chaperoning

You will also need to provide:

  • a statement by the child's parents in support of the application (this may be part of the application form)
  • the child's birth certificate or other evidence of age
  • two identical prints of a photograph of the child taken during the previous six months
  • a copy of the contract, draft contract or other documents containing details of the agreement regulating the child's appearance in the performance or the activity for which the licence is required
  • a letter from the child's school authorising their absence
  • a declaration, where the child is under 14 years of age, that the part they are acting or dancing can only be taken by a child of approximately the same age

An application fee is generally not payable.

You should apply at least 21 days before the performance or activity is due to start.

The local authority may interview you, the child and the child's parents during the process of determining your application and may request that the child is medically examined to ensure they are fit to participate.

If your application is granted, you will be issued a licence specifying the arrangements for the child to take part in the performance or activity.

Licences will be subject to a number of conditions, eg in relation to the number of days the child can be expected to perform and the arrangements you need to make for the provision of a matron/chaperone and for the child's education during the term of the licence.

Premises where performances or rehearsals are to take place must be approved by the local authority to ensure they are suitable for children.

You will also be required to keep detailed records relating to the performance or activity and produce these for inspection on request.

If you allow a child to take part in an unlicensed performance, or fail to comply with any conditions attached to your licence, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £1,000, imprisoned for up to three months or both.

column3: Licence to keep non-native crayfish (England & Wales)
column4:
To keep non-native crayfish, which are all crayfish other than the native or white clawed crayfish - Austropotamobius pallipes - you need a licence from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) in England, the Department for Rural Affairs in Wales, the Scottish Government Environment and Rural Affairs Department in Scotland or the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) in Northern Ireland.

This licence does not allow you to release or introduce any other species of non-native crayfish into the wild. To introduce or release non-native species into the wild you will require a licence issued under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981.

A Door Supervisor licence is required if manned guarding activities are undertaken in relation to licensed premises*, except where the activity only involves the use of CCTV equipment or falls within the definition of cash and valuables in transit or close protection. A Door Supervisor licence is required if you are performing this activity on behalf of yourself or your employer or your services are supplied for the purposes of or in connection with any contract to a consumer.

*'in relation to licensed premises' means when those premises are open to the public, at times when alcohol is being supplied for consumption, or regulated entertainment is being provided, on the premises.

There are two types of Security Industry Authority (SIA) licence:

  • A front line licence is required if undertaking licensable activity, other than key holding activities - this also covers undertaking non-front line activity. A front line licence is in the form of a credit-card-sized plastic card that must be worn, subject to the licence conditions. 
  • A non-front line licence is required for those who manage, supervise and/or employ individuals who engage in licensable activity - this includes directors or partners - as long as front line activity is not carried out. A non-front line licence is issued in the form of a letter that also covers key holding activities.

In order to obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check, a criminal record check, and hold the appropriate SIA-approved qualification.

column3: Explosives on vessels and in harbours licence (all UK)
column4: To bring explosives into a harbour, handle explosives in a harbour, and load and unload explosives within a harbour you need a licence from the Health & Safety Executive (HSE) in England, Scotland and Wales. In Northern Ireland you need a licence from the Northern Ireland Office (NIO).

column3: Human fertilisation and embryology licence (All UK)
column4:
If you undertake the procurement, testing, processing, preservation, storage and distribution of gametes, embryos and/or provide in-vitro fertilisation, or artificial insemination treatments, you need to register for a licence from the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA).

  • Licences for treatment, non-medical fertility services (eg procuring and distributing sperm) and storage of gametes and embryos (known collectively as treatment and storage licences).
  • Licences authorising activities for the purposes of a research project.

You need separate licences to authorise both treatment/storage and research.

You also need a separate licence for each premises at which licensed activities are to be carried out.

Before applying for a licence, you should complete an initial enquiry form and email this to the HFEA.

The HFEA will then help get you started and assign an inspector who will be able to advise you on the licensing process and the requirements you need to meet in order to be granted a licence.

These relate to issues such as record-keeping, traceability of gametes and embryos, obtaining consents in writing, counselling for patients and the provision of information and documents to the HFEA.

You will also be expected to comply with the standards and supporting guidance set out in the HFEA Code of Practice which covers such things as professional conduct, clinical governance, quality management and confidentiality.

You need to nominate a named person to act as the 'person responsible' for your licensed centre. This person must meet certain qualifying criteria as they will be charged with ensuring that:

  • all licensing conditions are complied with
  • the HFEA is notified about serious incidents or serious adverse reactions
  • staff at your centre are of good character and are suitably trained and qualified
  • the centre's premises are suitable
  • proper equipment and suitable practices are used when carrying out licensed activities
  • proper arrangements are made for the keeping and disposal of gametes and embryos

You must pay an application fee when you submit your completed application form. This depends on the type of licence you are applying for.

Treatment and storage licences may be granted for a period of up to five years and research licences for up to three years. On expiry, you will need to apply for renewal and pay a renewal fee.

Your compliance with the terms of your licence and with the Code of Practice will be monitored by the licensing authority which carries out regular inspections of licensed premises.

If you do not comply with the terms of your licence you may have your licence revoked. If you perform certain restricted activities, such as implanting a cloned embryo in a woman, or carrying out licensable treatment without a licence, you will be committing an offence.

If you breach conditions of the licence or fail to obtain a licence you may be fined, imprisoned for up to ten years or both.

If you plan to impound (store) water (eg by using a dam or weir) in England and Wales, you need an Impoundment Licence from the Environment Agency. You will also need permission if you want to alter or remove existing impounding works.

To run a horse riding establishment in Northern Ireland, you need a licence.

Licences are issued by the local Divisional Veterinary Offices. The licence must be renewed every year.

Fees will be payable and conditions may attach to a licence. Activities which need a licence include the hiring out of horses or ponies for riding or riding instruction.

If your business has a turnover of more than £2 million and handles more than 50 tonnes of packaging in a calendar year you must comply with certain packaging waste obligations.

You can either meet your obligations individually or use a compliance scheme to help you meet them.

If you register with a compliance scheme they will take on your recycling and recovery obligations. You will need to pay them a fee and supply them with any relevant information that they require, such as the amount of packaging you handle.

If you choose to meet your obligations individually you will need to register with the Environment Agency in England and Wales or the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) by 7 April of the year in which the obligations are to apply to your business. You must also show that you have met your recycling and recovery targets as calculated under schedule 2 of the Producer Responsibility Obligations (Packaging Waste) Regulations 2005.

If you fail to comply, you will be fined up to £5,000 in a magistrates' court or an unlimited fine in the Crown Court.

column3: Permission to run a business on a pavement (England & Wales)
column4: To put advertising boards, display stands or any other object on a public pavement (including a footpath, verge or carriageway) you may need to register your business with the local authority.

column3: Animal boarding establishment licence (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you run a boarding kennel or cattery you must be licensed by your local authority.

Applications must include details about you and your premises and should be accompanied by a licence fee. Fees are set by local authorities and may vary from area to area.

Before a licence is granted, your premises may be inspected for suitability by a veterinary surgeon or practitioner and/or a local authority inspector.

In particular, you will need to demonstrate that:

  • animals are kept in suitable accommodation
  • animals are adequately supplied with food, water and bedding
  • animals receive adequate exercise
  • you have taken appropriate steps to protect animals in case of fire or other emergency, eg by providing fire extinguishers
  • you have taken all reasonable precautions to prevent and control the spread of disease among animals, eg by providing isolation facilities

Licences are valid for up to one year and must be renewed before the expiry date if you wish to continue as an animal boarding establishment.

Licences will be subject to conditions including the need to keep a register containing:

  • a description of all animals received
  • their arrival and departure dates
  • the name and address of the owner

Registers must be available for inspection on request by vets or other authorised officers.

If you don't obtain a licence or fail to comply with any licensing conditions, you are guilty of an offence and could be fined and/or imprisoned for up to three months.

If you obstruct or delay any authorised person from entering or inspecting your premises you may be fined up to £500.

You may also have your licence suspended or revoked.

To keep a pet shop you need a licence from the local authority for the area where your shop is located.

A pet shop includes any premises where animals are sold as pets, including your own home. However, it is an offence to sell animals as pets on the street, from a market stall or in other public places.

Contact your local authority for a pet shop licence application form or visit their website to apply online.

In deciding whether to grant a licence the local authority will need to be satisfied that:

  • animals will be kept in suitable accommodation at all times in regards to temperature, size, lighting, ventilation and cleanliness
  • animals will be provided with adequate food and drink and where necessary will be visited at suitable intervals
  • mammals will not be sold at too young an age
  • reasonable steps will be taken to prevent the spread of infectious diseases among animals
  • appropriate steps will be taken in case of fires or other emergencies

In addition, the local authority may impose special conditions on the licence which will only apply to your premises.

The local authority may authorise any of its officers or any veterinary surgeon or veterinary practitioner to inspect your premises. The inspection can take place at any reasonable time.

A fee, determined by the local authority, will be payable at the time of your application and when you renew your licence. The licence will be valid for one year.

If you keep a pet shop without a licence or fail to comply with any conditions in your licence, you may be fined up to £500, imprisoned for up to three months, or both. You may also have your licence cancelled.

You will not be deemed to be keeping a pet shop if you sell pedigree animals that you have bred or that are from the offspring of an animal you've kept as a pet.

Premises where petrol is stored in a tank and dispensed directly via a pump into the fuel tank for an internal combustion engine require a Petroleum Licence from your local Petroleum Licensing Authority.

A Petroleum Licence is also required at domestic and non-workplace premises for the storage of petrol in excess of 275 litres, or where the strict requirements of the Petroleum-Spirit (Motor Vehicles etc.) Regulations 1929 can not be met.

In England and Wales the licensing authority is:

  • the fire and rescue authority - in Greater London or a metropolitan county
  • the county council or county borough council - in all other areas

In Scotland, the licensing authority is the local council.

Contact your licensing authority for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

A fee will be payable on application. This will depend on the amount of petrol being stored and the length of time you want the licence to last before renewal (usually up to three years).

A licence will state the name and address of the premises to which it is issued, how long it is valid for and any conditions that the local authority may deem appropriate for the safe-keeping of petroleum-spirit at the premises.

If you operate a petrol filling station and do not obtain a licence or comply with its conditions, you could be fined and/or imprisoned for up to two years.

column3: Registration to sell non-medicinal poisons (All UK)
column4: To sell a range of chemicals including caustic soda, chemical toilet fluids, drain cleaners and some pesticides and weed killers, you need to be registered with your local authority. The chemicals are listed in Part II of the Poisons Act and are referred to as non-medicinal poisons.
To erect any scaffolding or hoarding on a public highway, you need a licence from the local authority.

To deal in scrap metal, including buying, selling or storing, you need to register with your local authority in either the area you live or the area where your metal store is located. You may need to register with more than one local authority.

You must provide the local authority with your name, home address or registered office, addresses for scrap metal stores (if different to your home or registered address) and how you carry out the business (eg is your store in a different local authority area).

If anything changes to affect how your business operates, you must notify the local authority to change the register. You must also notify the local authority if you stop dealing in scrap metal. All notifications must be made within 28 days of the changes.

Your registration last for three years and you can renew this for another three years when your registration is set to expire.

You must keep a book at each of your scrap metal stores to record all scrap metal received, processed or despatched from there. You may keep a separate book for scrap metal received and a separate book for scrap metal processed or despatched.

For scrap metal received, you must record the:

  • description and weight of scrap metal
  • date and time the metal was received
  • details of the person providing the scrap metal
  • price paid for the metal - if relevant
  • value of metal received - if no price was paid for its receipt
  • registration mark of any mechanical vehicles delivering the metal

For scrap metal processed or despatched, you must record the:

  • description and weight of scrap metal
  • date and time of processing or despatch
  • process applied to scrap metal - if relevant
  • name and address of the person scrap metal is sold to or exchanged and the price paid - if despatched
  • value of the metal immediately before despatch or processing - if it is not to be sold or exchanged

You must keep all records for at least two years from the date of the last entry in the book.

If you deal in scrap metal as part of your business as an itinerant collector you may be exempt from keeping certain records. However you must still keep receipts of the weight of any scrap metal you sell and its aggregate price. You must keep these receipts for at least two years and may need to produce these.

If you fail to keep records correctly, or deal as a scrap metal dealer when not registered, you can be fined £1,000. You may also have additional conditions imposed on you. You will not be able to receive scrap metal between 18.00 and 08.00 and any scrap metal you receive must remain at that place - in the form it was received - for at least 72 hours before moving it. This order can remain in force for up to two years.

You must not receive scrap metal from anyone under the age of 16, or give false details when selling on scrap metal.

You must also allow any reasonable inspection of your premises or records books if requested in writing.

If you are additionally operating motor salvage as part of your scrap metal operations you may also need to register as a motor salvage operator with your local authority.

If you keep or own premises housing 350 or more laying hens, you must register your premises with the Scottish Government's Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate (RPID).

If you grade eggs on your premises, you must also apply for those premises to be registered as an egg packing centre.

To apply to register, you must complete form EMR3 and send it to RPID either by post or email. You will need to provide all the information requested in the form, including hen numbers and details of your buildings.

You are not required to pay an application or registration fee.

Your premises must also be inspected before your registration will be approved.

Your premises must:

  • be an area suited to the scale of operation
  • be clean, well maintained and free from extraneous odours
  • protect your hens from sudden or constant noise
  • have suitable ventilation and lighting
  • be properly cleaned and disinfected
  • protect eggs from wide fluctuations in outside temperature
  • have areas reserved for handling and storing of eggs or for storage of other products which cannot impart extraneous odours to the eggs
  • include clean and well-maintained equipment

Within 21 days of receipt of your application, RPID will record your establishment on the register and allocate you with a registration number indicating farming method, Member State code and a unique identifier.

RPID may exchange information with the Food Standards Agency Scotland for the purposes of tracing eggs put on the market for human consumption.

If any of the information in your application changes, you must notify RPID in writing. If you fail to do so, your establishment may be removed from the register.

If you fail to register premises housing 350 or more laying hens with RPID, you will be committing an offence and could be fined up to £5,000.

This requirement does not apply if you're rearing laying hens for breeding. However, breeding establishments with 100 or more breeding birds are required to register separately with RPID.

To provide registered adult placement services in Scotland you must be registered with Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee when you apply, and your application must include:

  • details on yourself (if operating as an individual) or your organisation
  • details of the manager (if you will not be the manager of the service)
  • references
  • financial details - eg a statement from the bank on your financial standing and reliability
  • declarations regarding any convictions, bankruptcy or previous involvement in registered services

You must provide information on your proposed service, in particular:

  • its name and address
  • a statement of aims and objectives
  • staffing, recruitment and training
  • suitability and fitness of accommodation

You must also attach the following documents:

  • recruitment policy
  • programmes for staff induction, development and training
  • financial information
  • aims and objectives statements

SCSWIS will inspect your premises, staff and management before they approve the application. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards. You can find these online.

To meet the required standards you must:

  • provide a detailed introductory pack to explain your service to users - this includes the aims of the service, the support provided, fees information, complaints procedures and your recent inspection report
  • have adequate management and staffing arrangements in place - you must show that carers receive quality training and have knowledge of policies and procedures, that management is supportive and reliable, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive and includes the relevant assessments and criminal checks
  • have in place written adult placement agreements with users to define the service and set out terms of the contract
  • meet all applicable legal requirements with regard to adult placement carers, their abilities, qualifications and knowledge
  • provide a clean, accessible and secure environment
  • draw up a personal plan for each user that is tailored to each persons preferences, interests and comforts
  • demonstrate competence with aids and equipment for users
  • have systems in place to protect users - such as risk assessments, and protection from bullying or harassment
  • demonstrate respect for the social, cultural and religious beliefs of users

SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to the registration. You must keep your certificate of registration - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in any premises you have.

To hold a private market including a car boot sale in Scotland you might need a market operator's licence from the local authority.

You may not need a licence if the proceeds are used for charitable purposes or not for private gain or the market is only for the sale of livestock, fodder or grain.

Conditions may be attached to the licence as to opening times, provision of toilets, layout of market and public safety.
To sell goods second-hand, including at auction where you are selling goods on your own behalf, you need a second-hand dealer's licence from the local authority.
To operate as a street trader you may need a licence from the local authority.
To discharge business or trade effluent into a sewer you need to obtain consent or a letter of authority from Scottish Water.
To operate a local bus service in Scotland you must register with the Traffic Commissioner for the Scottish traffic area.

If your premises are used as a place of public entertainment, you must hold a public entertainment licence.

Such a licence is not required in certain circumstances - eg for an athletic or sports ground being used for sports or athletic purposes or entertainment that is being provided on premises licensed under the Licensing (Scotland) Act 2005 during licensed hours.

Licences are obtained from the licensing authority for the area where the activity is to be carried out. Licensing authorities are the local authority for that area.

Applications may be subject to a fee and should be made in writing in such a form as required by the licensing authority - including by electronic means. Applications must be signed by the applicant or their agent - including by electronic means.

The facility to submit written applications - including providing signatures - by electronic means may not be provided by all local authorities.

column3: Wholesale dealer's authorisation for veterinary medicines (All UK)
column4:
To deal wholesale in veterinary medicines you require wholesale dealer's authorisation from the Veterinary Medicines Directorate (VMD). You will need an authorisation even if you do not supply medicines for profit.

You can only supply medicine to which the authorisation relates.

Your premises which are to be authorised must be clean and free from contamination, secure, lockable and weatherproof. They must also be able to comply with any storage conditions relating to the medicine covered in the authorisation.

You must also have an emergency recall plan and technically competent staff.

The authorisation will detail:

  • the medicine covered
  • where they are to be stored
  • your name and address and the premises address if different
  • details of the qualified person to act under the Guidelines on Good Distribution Practice for Human Use

An authorisation will lapse after five years of you don't deal in the medicine covered under it in that time.

You must:

  • store medicines as required under the marketing authorisation
  • have a stock audit each year
  • provide information to the VMD when required 
  • comply with the Guidelines on Good Distribution Practice of Medicinal Products for Human Use if the medicines are authorised human medicines

There are additional requirements for sheep dip.

This does not apply to holders of a manufacturing or marketing authorisation.

Small quantities of medicines supplied by one retailer to another may be exempt.

Application and annual fees are payable.

column3: Marketing authorisation of veterinary medicines (All UK)
column4:
If you place veterinary medicines on the market, the product must have Marketing Authorisation from the Veterinary Medicines Directorate (VMD) or the European Medicines Agency. 

Fees are payable.

A manufacturing authorisation will also be required for the items produced.

Applications must include all relevant information and any scientific documentation to show the safety, efficiency and quality of the product. Information that must be included in your application includes data required under European Directive 2001/82/EC Annex 1 and:

  • the name and address of the holder and the holder of the manufacturing authorisation if different
  • the name of the medicine
  • the chemical name or make up of the medicine
  • the manufacturing method
  • indications, contra-indications and adverse reactions
  • dosage for the animals the medicine is intended for
  • any precautionary or safety measures for storing, administering or disposing of the medicine
  • withdrawal periods for medicines intended for food producing animals
  • testing methods and results
  • details of your pharmacovigilance system and risk management system
  • details of the medicine characteristics and proposed packaging and leaflets
  • proof of the manufacturer's authorisation
  • any relevant information if the medicine is from outside the UK
  • details of the qualified person you have who are responsible for pharmacovigilance
  • any applications you have made to have a substance included under Council Regulation (EEC) No 2377/90

You must report any adverse reactions to the VMD, or competent authorities in other member States where it is authorised if it administered outside the European Union (EU).

You must also provide regular safety reports detailing adverse reactions (including nil reports) to the VMD.

Exceptions may apply as to which information must be provided.

Time limits may apply as to when an application can be made.

You must be established in an EU member State to be able to apply for authorisation.

Authorisations will be valid for five years.

Certain veterinary medicine products are exempt.
To carry passengers, mail or cargo by air for commercial purposes you require an operating licence from the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA).

You may need a phytosanitary certificate if you export the following goods to certain countries outside of the European Union (EU):

  • any tree, wood, bark, soil or forest tree seed
  • non-manufactured wood products in the form of packaging cases, boxes, crates, drums or pallets
  • used forestry machinery

Phytosanitary certificates are issued by the Forestry Commission to the equivalent national plant protection organisation (NPPO) in the importing country. They certify that the material has been inspected, is considered free from quarantine (and other) pests and that it conforms to the plant health regulations of the importing country.

You can apply for a certificate online if you will require certificates on a regular basis, but you will need to register with the Forestry Commission and agree to certain terms and conditions of their Electronic Application for Phytosanitary Certification system first. Alternatively, you can send paper copy applications to the Forestry Commission on form PH25.

You will need to declare the following on your application:

  • country of destination (as well as any non-EU country of transit)
  • the means of transport and port of entry

You will also need to provide full information about the consignment, including:

  • the species of wood (except for wood packaging material) 
  • any treatment applied - eg kiln-drying, heat treatment or fumigation
  • the description and quantity - eg number of packs of sawn wood, volume of logs, number of pallets or crates and any identification marks

Some countries also require an import licence or permit which will be issued by that country's NPPO. If this is the case, you will need to produce it with your application.

If the material originated outside the EU or Switzerland was imported with a phytosanitary certificate, and the consignment has not been stored, split up, combined with other consignments or repackaged, you will need a re-forwarding phytosanitary certificate. You will need to send the Forestry Commission the original phytosanitary certificate or sufficient information to allow that certificate to be traced.

A fee of £15 is payable for issuing a certificate and a minimum fee of £37 is payable if an inspection is required. Inspections are time based, ie £37 for the first hour (including office and travel time) and £9.25 for each 15 minutes or part thereof thereafter.

If you make a false statement on a certification application you can be fined up to £5,000.

To carry out house-to-house collections for charitable purposes - ie promote house-to-house collections - you must apply for a licence from either the local authority or the local police force (the licensing authority).

If your collection is to cover all - or a substantial part - of England or Wales, you may be granted an exception from requiring collection licences.

You should check with the local authority of the area for which you intend to make collections before applying.

In your application, you must provide:

  • details about the purpose of the collection
  • details of the area/areas where collections are to be made
  • any prescribed information as set by the licensing authority

You must also show that:

  • the collection is worthwhile - ie that it will raise an adequate amount of money for charity
  • no-one involved in the collections will be paid excessively from the proceeds of the collections
  • that you and anyone collecting under the licence are fit and proper

Your application will be refused if:

  • you cannot show the above requirements
  • the licensing authority believes that an offence under the Vagrancy Act could be committed
  • you have not carried out due diligence to ensure those acting for you are fit and proper
  • you have refused to provide any information requested
     

A collections licence is generally valid for 12 months.

If you are found to have withheld information on your application, your application could be refused, or your licence revoked. If, at any time you are found to have provided false information, you could be guilty of an offence and imprisoned for up to six months, fined, or both.
