If you use a prescribed badge or certificate of authority that you are not licensed to do so, or if you use a badge or certificate that resembles an authentic in order to deceive, you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

If you or anyone collecting on your behalf fails to provide a policeman with their name, address and signature, they will also be guilty of an offence and could be fined up to £200.

If you carry out house-to-house collections without being licensed, you will be guilty of an offence and could be imprisoned for up to six months, fined up to £1,000, or both.

If you provide false or misleading information you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

Club premises certificates are offered to private clubs, such as the Royal British Legion, working men's or cricket or rugby clubs, where access to the public is restricted and alcohol is supplied other than for profit.

The licensing authority will assess whether applicants qualify for a club premises certificate. Applicants that don't qualify may have to apply for a Premises Licence instead.

Applicants should keep the licensing authority informed of any changes to the way the club operates during the application process and following the award of the certificate.

Like other licensed premises, clubs licensed in this manner can apply for Temporary Event Notices.

column3: Collective worship music reproduction licence (All UK)
column4:
If you photocopy hymns or worship songs (music or words) for assemblies or other collective worship activities at your school, you need a licence from Christian Copyright Licensing International (CCLI).

This licence can only be obtained in addition to a collective worship copyright licence.

You can apply for a licence online on the CCLI website.

You must pay a licence fee based on the number of pupils at your school.

Licences are subject to certain conditions, such as:

  • ensuring that all photocopied songs are inscribed with your licence number
  • supplying CCLI with a copy of any photocopied song on request
  • using CCLI's CopyReport software to report all the songs that have been photocopied under your licence

You must renew your licence annually.

If you photocopy hymns or songs without a licence, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you fail to pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, CCLI may terminate the licence. If that happens, you must stop using any photocopied songs and arrange for them to be destroyed.

If you want to photocopy from non-music publications - eg drama scripts or text books - you must contact the Copyright Licensing Authority instead.

If you reproduce the words of hymns or worship songs for use during assemblies or other collective worship events at your school, you need a licence from Christian Copyright Licensing International (CCLI).

You will require a licence if you:

  • create your own service sheets or hymn books for pupils and staff
  • create your own overhead projector acetates
  • create your own song words database for use with song projection software
  • type song words into your computer and store them for future use
  • record music from your services - eg carol services - on video or audio

If you want to photocopy directly from music publications, you must also have a collective worship music reproduction licence.

You can apply for a collective worship copyright licence online on the CCLI website.

You must pay a licence fee based on the number of pupils at your school.

Licences are subject to certain conditions, such as:

  • ensuring that all reproduced songs contain the full and correct song title, writer credit(s) and copyright notice
  • supplying CCLI with a copy of any reproduced song on request
  • using CCLI's CopyReport software to report all the songs that have been reproduced under your licence

Licences must be renewed annually.

If you reproduce the words of hymns or worship songs without a licence, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

If you fail to pay the licence fee or comply with any other licence conditions, CCLI may terminate the licence. If that happens, you must stop using any reproduced songs and arrange for them to be destroyed.

To market any passenger carrying vehicle that can seat eight passengers excluding the driver (M1 category) or any goods vehicle having a laden mass up to 3.5 tonnes (N1 category), as a manufacturer or professional importer, you need to register with the Department for Business, Innovation & Skills (BIS). You will need to declare responsibility for the end-of-life treatment of your brands of vehicles.

Your application must be made in writing and contain the following information:

  • the name of your business
  • the name, address and telephone number of your registered office or principal place of business
  • the address for serving notices - if different from the above
  • a description of the vehicles that you are declaring responsibility for placing on the market

Your information will be entered onto a public register, which will be updated with whether you meet your end-of-life vehicle (ELV) requirements. You must comply with all ongoing ELV requirements, in particular:

  • using the allowed levels of heavy metals in your vehicles - eg cadmium, lead, mercury and hexavalent chromium
  • marking and coding plastic and rubber materials for dismantling and recovering purposes
  • providing a BIS-approved 'free take-back system' - you must apply to BIS for approval of your system (including all relevant details) within six months of placing your vehicles on the market
  • meeting the reuse, recovery and recycling targets for scrapped vehicles - to recover 85 per cent (by weight) and recycle at least 80 per cent (by weight) of your ELVs

You must keep technical documents to show compliance with all ongoing requirements for four years from the date you put the vehicles, materials and components on the market. The Vehicle Certification Agency is the enforcement authority for this, and can ask to see these documents, at any time, to prove your compliance.

You must ensure that your take-back system is reasonably accessible to any person who owns a vehicle for which you have declared responsibility. However, you may make alternative arrangements - if necessary - for the collection of ELVs where not accessible.

You must also submit details to BIS of the reuse, recovery and recycling rates that you achieve on an annual basis. You must return this information to BIS by 1st July for each preceding year. Any compliance information you provide to BIS will be kept on a public register for no longer than four years.

If you produce fewer than 500 vehicles a year in each European Union member state, you only need to comply with the restrictions on heavy metals. However, you must still keep technical documents to prove compliance.

BIS may at any time enter and inspect your premises to check compliance with any ELV requirements.

column3: Wild and protected bird licence (England, Scotland, & Wales)
column4:
If you intend to kill or take wild birds, take eggs or nests or disturb specially protected birds, you need a licence from Natural England, Scottish Natural Heritage or the Countryside Council for Wales, depending on where the activity is intended to take place.

Wild birds can only be killed or, along with eggs or nests, taken in order to:

  • prevent serious damage to livestock, crops, fruit, vegetables, fisheries etc
  • prevent the spread of disease
  • preserve air safety
  • conserve wild birds
  • preserve public health or safety

Traps, nets, snares etc that are normally prohibited for killing or taking birds may be used under licence.

Specially protected birds can only be disturbed in order to:

  • preserve public health or safety
  • monitor or ring them for scientific, research or conservation purposes
  • photograph or film them

A list of specially protected birds is available on competent authority websites.

Applications forms are available on the competent authority website and you must use the correct form for the activity you want to carry out.

You must provide your personal details, location and details of the activity you want to carry out, as well as any other information specific to your application.

You should submit the following documents with your application:

  • authorisation to use the land for the licensed activity (if you are not the owner or occupier)
  • any other information relevant to your application - eg copies of relevant photographs or a conservation report

No fee is payable for a licence.

Licences will state how long they are valid for and any conditions that you must comply with.

General licences are also available for certain activities that affect prescribed species - eg killing crows by a landowner to prevent the spread of disease. You don't need to apply for these licences but you must comply with the conditions attached to them.

If you fail to obtain a licence or comply with the terms of a licence, you are committing an offence and may be fined, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

column3: Licences to carry out regulated scientific procedures on protected animals (All UK)
column4: To undertake experimental or scientific procedures applied to protected animals, a personal and project licence is required from the Home Office. Any place where such work is carried out must also be designated as a scientific procedure establishment.

column3: Personal licence for the sale of alcohol (England & Wales)
column4:
If you sell alcohol from licensed premises, you or a member of your staff must hold a personal licence, so that every sale or supply of alcohol is authorised by a personal licence holder.

You must be 18 years or older and hold a licensing qualification – for example the National Certificate for Personal Licence Holders (NCPLH) Level 2.

Applications for a personal licence should be made to your local authority and, once granted, the licence will be valid for ten years.

If you run premises that are used to supply alcohol, you must have a premises licence.

A premises licence is also required if you provide hot food and drinks between 11pm and 5am, and if you provide the following forms of regulated entertainment, either for profit or for charity:

  • theatrical performance
  • film exhibition
  • indoor sporting event
  • boxing or wrestling (indoor or outdoor)
  • live music
  • recorded music
  • dance
  • provision of facilities for making music
  • provision of dancing facilities

Applications for a premises licence must include the applicants' details and those of the designated premises supervisor, who must be a personal licence holder.

The designated premises supervisor is responsible for making sure the premises operate legally and meet any conditions attached to the licence. Applications must include a detailed plan of the premises and an operating schedule.

Private clubs are an exception to the requirement for a premises licence, as they may instead require a Club Premises Certificate.

If you operate a commercial bingo club you must be licensed.

Licences are obtained from your local magistrates court.

In order to obtain a licence you must be:

  • over 21 years old
  • live in Northern Ireland, for at least 12 months before the application
  • registered, if you are a company

column3: Collect or produce forest reproductive material licence (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you collect or produce forest reproductive material that you intend to market or use in forest reproductive material production, you must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Forest Service, Northern Ireland.

Licences may be subject to conditions.

column3: On-construction domestic energy assessor accreditation (England & Wales)
column4:
If you operate as an on-construction domestic energy assessor (OCDEA) you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the carrying out of energy assessments on new build dwellings and is approved by the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG).

The two ways to demonstrate that you are a qualified OCDEA are:

  • accreditation of prior experiential learning - you must be able to show that you meet the National Occupational Standards, evidence of experience creating Standard Assessment Procedure (SAP) reports and may have to provide sample energy performance certificates (EPCs) you have produced
  • qualification - if new to the field you must qualify for the level three diploma and certificate in on-construction domestic energy assessment before you can seek accreditation

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are a fit, proper person who is qualified (by education, training and experience) to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare EPCs and recommendation reports using standard forms
  • follow your scheme's code of conduct
  • enter any EPCs or recommendation reports that you produce onto the relevant register

If you are an OCDEA you must:

  • assess new-build properties only
  • use plans and specifications to collect data on the dimensions, construction, heating and hot water provision of the property and enter the information into an approved SAP programme
  • produce EPCs and energy assessments for new-build dwellings

As an energy assessor you may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification and accreditation system, ie if you are qualified and accredited to carry out domestic energy assessments you must not carry out commercial energy assessment unless also qualified and accredited for this area.

When issuing an EPC, you must include a declaration of any personal or business relationship that you have with:

  • any person who commissioned the certificate, or on whose behalf the certificate was commissioned - or any person who you believe may have a personal or business relationship with such a person
  • any person who you believe may have an interest in the building

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill.

You must ensure that any EPC or recommendation report that you issue, and the data which was used to produce the document or calculate any asset rating, is entered onto the relevant register kept by DCLG or an organisation/person keeping a register on their behalf, before you give the document to the person who requested that it be issued.

column3: Licence for skin piercing and tattooing (Scotland)
column4:
To run any form of skin piercing or tattooing business including acupuncture, ear and body piercing and electrolysis (whether from premises or mobile), a licence must obtained from your local authority.

You may be exempt if you are a regulated health care professional.

column3: Domestic energy assessor for existing buildings accreditation (England & Wales)
column4:
If you operate as a domestic energy assessor (DEA) for existing buildings you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the carrying out of energy assessments on existing dwellings and is approved by the Department for Communities and Local Government.

If you're a DEA you must:

  • carry out energy efficiency assessments on existing dwellings only
  • collect data on the dimensions, construction, heating and hot water provision of the property and enter it into an approved software programme - Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure (RDSAP)
  • produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) for homes being marketed for sale, for other homes sold and for homes when rented

RDSAP is the government approved standardised system for doing an energy survey on an existing dwelling, eg for homes being sold or rented out. A full Standard Assessment Procedure (SAP) requires many data items that can't obtained through a visual inspection or that may take too long to collect. RDSAP is an industry agreed standard set of data items and a standard way of inferring the missing data.

SAP is the procedure for energy assessments of domestic premises. It is used to show that they comply with part L of the Building Regulations 2010. SAP is used for new build dwellings where detailed construction data is available for use in the energy assessment.

You will normally need a level three diploma and certificate in domestic energy assessment. Some accreditation schemes may accept evidence of relevant experience as an alternative to the diploma. This procedure is known as accreditation of prior experience and learning - it applies if you already use RDSAP and produce SAP reports and EPCs when a dwelling is sold or let.

From 1 April 2012 if you are an existing DEA and want to continue practising and maintain your accreditation, you will need to obtain a new top-up qualification. This is because a revised version of the EPC, which contains significant changes to its content and format, will be in use from that date

The training is likely to take about 8 hours. When you have completed the training, you will be required to take a short online assessment to demonstrate you have acquired the necessary additional knowledge and understanding.

The stand-alone qualification will be available until October 2012 at which point it will be incorporated into the standard training for DEAs. If you have not undertaken the additional training and passed the online assessment within this timescale, you will need to start again from scratch. 

In order to become accredited, you'll have to:

  • show you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show you are fit, proper and qualified to carry out energy assessments
  • meet the National Occupations Standards for DEAs
  • prepare EPCs and recommendation reports using standard forms
  • follow your scheme's code of conduct
  • enter any EPCs or recommendation reports that you produce and the data which was used to produce them or any asset rating onto the national register operated by Landmark on behalf of DCLG

You'll need to submit a fully completed and signed application form, a basic Criminal Records Bureau check and proof of qualification to your accreditation scheme.

When producing EPCs or inspection reports you must include a declaration detailing if you have a business or personal relationship with either the person who commissioned the certificate or on whose behalf it was commissioned or anyone with an interest with either of these people or in the building.

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill.

Mixed use buildings - when the building is built, sold or rented out - should be treated as a dw
column5:
elling if the living accommodation is more than half of the total area of the building and the commercial part could revert to living accommodation without significant alteration. A house with a portion separated out as a workshop, office or surgery should be dealt with as a mixed use building.

In other cases you should treat the dwelling and the non-dwelling parts separately using the most appropriate methodology for each part. For example, where a building contains both flats and offices you should use SAP or RDSAP for the flats and Simplified Building Energy Model or Dynamic Simulation Modelling for the offices, provided that you are qualified to produce an assessment using those software packages.

column3: Air conditioning system energy assessor accreditation (England & Wales)
column4:
To operate as an air conditioning system energy assessor (ACSEA) you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the types of work you undertake and is approved by the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG).

There are two different levels of competence for ACSEA qualification:

  • level 3 - for inspection of simple/packaged air conditioning systems
  • level 4 - for inspection of complex/central air conditioning systems

You can also qualify by way of prior experience known as accreditation of prior experiential learning. This means that if you already have experience of inspecting air conditioning systems you must show - when applying to an accreditation scheme - how you meet the National Occupational Standards at either level 3 or level 4. You may need to take top-up training.

Once qualified you can apply for accreditation. You must register with a scheme that provides accreditation for air conditioning system energy assessors.

As an energy assessor you may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification and accreditation system, ie if you are qualified and accredited to carry out domestic energy assessments you must not carry out commercial energy assessment unless also qualified and accredited for this area.

Approval of accreditation may be limited as to the types of air conditioning systems you may inspect.

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are a fit and proper person who is qualified (by education, training and experience) to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare air conditioning energy inspection reports (ACR) using a standard format
  • follow your scheme's code of conduct
  • enter ACRs produced by you onto the relevant register if required to do so by the accreditation scheme of which you are a member

Lodgement of ACRs onto a central register is currently voluntary. Mandatory logement comes into force on 6 April 2012.

When issuing an ACR, you must include a declaration of any personal or business relationship that you have with:

  • the person who commissioned the certificate, or any person on whose behalf the certificate was commissioned - or any person who you believe may have a personal or business relationship with such a person
  • any person who you believe may have an interest in the building

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill. You must ensure that any ACR that you issue - and the data which was used to calculate any asset rating and to produce the document - and a copy of the ACR is passed to the accreditation scheme of which you are a member. This must be done before you give the document to the person who requested that it be issued.

If you operate as a non-domestic energy assessor (NDEA) for existing buildings you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the carrying out of energy assessments on existing non-domestic buildings and is approved by the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG).

There are three levels of qualification for NDEAs:

  • level three - an assessor can use Simplified Building Energy Model (SBEM) software to produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) for simple existing buildings
  • level four - an assessor can use SBEM software to produce EPCs for new and existing complex buildings
  • level five - an assessor can use Dynamic Simulation Modelling (DSM) software to produce EPCs for new, more complex buildings

SBEM is a computer programme that analyses a building's energy consumption. It uses a description of the building's geometry, construction, use, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning and lighting equipment. From this it calculates the monthly energy use and carbon dioxide emissions of the building.

DSM is a software tool that models energy inputs and outputs for different types of buildings over time. It is used where SBEM will not be sophisticated enough to provide an accurate assessment of a building's energy efficiency.

There are two routes to accreditation as a level three or four NDEA qualification either by holding the correct qualification or accreditation of prior experiential learning (APEL). If you have experience in the commercial sector you must be able to show how you meet National Occupational Standards (NOS) when applying for accreditation.

You can only obtain level five accreditation through APEL. If you already use DSM software you must be able to show how you meet NOS, you must produce sample EPCs and undertake top-up training as necessary. You may also be required to hold a professional qualification.

You must register with a scheme that provides accreditation for NDEAs.

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are a fit, proper person who is qualified (by education, training and experience) to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare EPCs and recommendation reports using standard forms
  • follow your scheme's code of conduct
  • enter any EPC or recommendation report that you produce and the data which was used to produce the document or calculate any asset rating onto the relevant register kept by the DCLG or an organisation/person keeping a register on DCLG's behalf

As an energy assessor you may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification and accreditation system, ie if you are qualified and accredited to carry out domestic energy assessments you must not carry out non-domestic energy assessments unless also qualified and accredited for this area.

When producing EPCs or inspection reports you must include a declaration detailing whether you have a business or personal relationship with either the person who commissioned the certificate, any on whose behalf it was commissioned or anyone with an interest with either of these people or in the building.

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill.

Mixed use buildings - when the building is built, sold or rented out - should be treated as a dwelling if the living accommodation is more than half of the total area of the building and the commercial part could revert to living accommodation without significant alteration. A house with a portion separated out as a workshop, office or surgery should be dealt with as a mixed use building.

In other cases you should treat the dwelling and the non-dwelling parts separately using the most appropriate methodology for each p
column5: art. For example, where a building contains both flats and offices you should use Standard Assessment Procedure or Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure for the flats and SBEM or DSM for the offices.

column3: Operational ratings assessor (production of display energy certificates) accreditation (England & Wales)
column4:
To work as an operational ratings assessor (ORA) producing display energy certificates (DECs) for public buildings which have a total useful floor area over 1,000 square metres, you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers that type of work and is approved by the Department for Communities and Local Government (DCLG).

In order to become accredited you must meet the relevant National Occupational Standards (NOS) in full. This includes showing full knowledge of operational rating methodology and the ability to use the approved operational rating software.

There are two routes to accreditation as an ORA. One is accreditation of prior experiential learning - if you already have experience of energy management or energy assessment you must show how you meet the NOS in full. You must include your experience of using operational rating software and may be required to produce example DECs and advisory reports. You may also need to take top-up training. You may also be required to hold a professional qualification.

The other route is by qualification by obtaining a level three diploma in display energy assessment.

In addition some schemes may require you to obtain a Criminal Records Bureau check if you are to carry out work in schools or care homes for example.

You must register with a scheme that provides accreditation for ORAs.

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are a fit and proper person who is qualified (by education, training or experience) to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare DECs and advisory reports using a standard form for each type of document
  • follow your scheme's code of conduct
  • enter DECs and advisory reports produced by you onto the relevant register

As an energy assessor you may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification and accreditation system, ie if you are qualified and accredited to carry out domestic energy assessments you must not carry out commercial energy assessment unless also qualified and accredited for this area.

When issuing a DEC, you must include a declaration of any personal or business relationship that you have with:

  • the person who commissioned the certificate, or any person on whose behalf the certificate was commissioned - or any person who you believe may have a personal or business relationship with such a person
  • any person who you believe may have an interest in the building

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill. After assessing the building, you must also issue an advisory report containing recommendations for improvement of the energy performance of the building.

You must ensure that any DEC or advisory report that you issue, and the data which was used to calculate any operational rating, and to produce the document, is entered onto the relevant register kept by the DCLG before you give the document to the person who requested that it be issued.

If you want to carry out any work that would demolish, damage, remove, repair, alter or add to a scheduled monument, or to carry out any flooding or tipping operations on land in, on, or under a monument you need to obtain scheduled monument consent (SMC) in advance.

Scheduled monuments are nationally important monuments that have been afforded statutory protection through their inclusion in the Schedule of monuments maintained under section 1 of the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Areas Act 1979.  They have archaeological, architectural, artistic, historic or traditional interest.

In England, SMC should be obtained from English Heritage, on behalf of the Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS).

In Scotland, SMC should be obtained from Historic Scotland, on behalf of the Scottish Ministers.

In Wales, SMC should be obtained from Cadw, the Welsh Government's historic environment service.

Applications should be accompanied by:

  • a plan identifying the monument
  • other plans or drawings as are necessary to describe the works

You will receive an acknowledgement letter and all owners/occupiers who are detailed in your application form will be given an opportunity to comment on your proposals.

You may be contacted for further information or to arrange a visit to examine the monument and its site.

Works carried out must comply with any conditions attached to the SMC - eg in relation to the building material that must be used or the way in which the work must be done.

If you don't carry out any works within five years of the grant of the SMC (or other specified period), the consent will cease to have effect at the end of that period.

If you carry out any works on a scheduled monument without consent, you are committing a criminal offence and may be fined.

It is also a criminal offence to cause reckless or deliberate damage to a scheduled monument without consent, or to use a metal detector or remove an object found with a metal detector from a protected site without a licence from the relevant authority.

You are strongly advised to contact the relevant regional authority for an informal discussion at an early stage when you are considering works that might affect a scheduled monument.
To provide betting facilities at a track or sports stadium in Northern Ireland, you need a licence from the Department of Social Development.

column3: Licence to show a single film title in public (All UK)
column4:
To show a single film title in public on a commercial or non-profit basis, you need a licence, issued on a title-by-title basis, from the copyright owner.

This includes films that are screened in DVD, Blu-Ray or video format.

Filmbank Distributors Ltd (Filmbank) offer such permissions - in the form of a single title screening licence (STSL) - on behalf of a group of studios.

The Motion Picture Licensing Company (International) Limited (MPLC) also offers such a service to film clubs and societies via the MPLC Movie Licence.

The licence you need depends on the film you are screening and the market sector your business operates in, such as event or festival management. You should check carefully with the licence provider to ensure you get the right licence for your specific needs.

A licence fee is payable. For commercial events this is based on a minimum guaranteed per title, or 35 per cent of box office takings, whichever is greater.

You can also obtain blanket licences from MPLC or Filmbank to show multiple film titles over the course of a year.

If the film you want to show is not available through MPLC or Filmbank, you need permission from the individual distributor.

If you show copyright films publicly without being licensed, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

Note that, under the Licensing Act 2003, venues that show films may need a premises licence as well.

column3: Licence to show unlimited films in public (All UK)
column4:
To show films in public, where no admission fee is charged and no title names are advertised, you need a licence from the copyright owner. This includes films that are screened in DVD, Blu-Ray or video format.

You would need a licence if you show films to:

  • enhance training materials or corporate communications
  • create a welcoming environment in a common or waiting area
  • provide an amenity for guests, residents, passengers or patients
  • reward children, eg at after-school clubs

The Motion Picture Licensing Company Ltd (MPLC) offers the MPLC Umbrella Licence® which grants permission from over 400 major Hollywood studios and independent producers under one blanket agreement.

Filmbank Distributors Ltd (Filmbank) offer a more limited public video screening licence (PVSL) agreement for a lower number of producers. There are also licences for specific businesses, such as hotels, ferry companies and events organisers.

The licence you need depends on the film you are screening and the market sector your business operates in. You should check carefully with the licence provider to ensure you get the right licence for your specific needs.

An annual licence fee is payable, but this varies depending on the type of licence you apply for.

You can also obtain licences from MPLC or Filmbank to show a single film title in public on a commercial or non-profit basis.

If the film you want to show is not available through MPLC or Filmbank, you need permission from the individual distributor.

If you show copyright DVDs, Blu-Ray or videos publicly without being licensed, you are infringing copyright and could be sued for damages.

Note that, under the Licensing Act 2003, venues that show films may need a premises licence as well.

column3: Licence to work with asbestos (England, Wales & Scotland)
column4:
Before carrying out any type of asbestos work you must obtain up-to-date training from a competent provider. Most substantial work involving asbestos materials (including removal and demolition) requires a licence issued by the Health & Safety Executive (HSE). Typically this work will be on a medium to large scale and will involve asbestos insulation which cannot be removed without being broken (including pipe and boiler lagging, sprayed asbestos coatings and asbestos insulating board).

Only work which is sporadic and of low intensity (ie the concentration of asbestos does not exceed 0.6 fibres per cm³ over a 10 minute period) is exempt from the requirement to hold a licence.

column3: Authorisation to carry out controlled water activities (CAR) consents (Scotland)
column4:
If you carry out any controlled water activity, you must be authorised by the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

A controlled activity is any activity which directly or indirectly has, or is likely to have, a significant adverse impact in the water environment. This includes:

  • any activity liable to cause pollution of the water environment, such as the discharge of a pollutant into water
  • abstraction of water
  • construction, alteration or operation of impounding works in surface water or wetlands
  • carrying out building or engineering in or near to inland water or wetlands
  • artificial recharge or augmentation of groundwater

If you deal in venison, you must be licensed by your local authority.

You are considered to deal in venison of you barter, exchange or carry out any transaction by which venison is disposed of for value.

Licences are valid for three years and may be renewed, provided you have not been disqualified.

You must keep a book in which you record all your purchases and receipts of venison, including all prescribed details.

When you purchase or receive venison from another licensed venison dealer or from a licensed game dealer, you must record in your book:

  • that the venison was purchased/received
  • the name and address of the person from whom you obtained the venison
  • the date the venison was purchased/received
  • the number of carcases and sex of the venison
  • the species of deer, if it is possible to identify it

On request by any authorised person or any constable, you must produce for inspection and allow copies to be made of:

  • your book
  • all invoices, consignment notes, receipts and other documents which may be required to verify any entry in the book
  • all venison in your possession or under your control

Your book and the relevant documents must be kept for three years from the day on which the last entry was made in the book, or the date of the entry to which the document refers.

You must not deal any venison which you know, or have reason to believe, has been killed unlawfully.

You must allow a constable to search your vehicle or to seize any deer where they have reasonable grounds to suspect that an offence has been committed. You must also allow any constable authorised by a warrant to search your premises, and to seize any article which they have reasonable grounds for believing to be evidence of the commission of an offence.

If you fail to comply, you may be disqualified from holding a licence, fined up to £2,500 or imprisoned for up to three months.

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

If you operate an adoption support agency you must be registered with Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Education, Children's Services and Skills.

Your application will be subject to a fee.

In order to be registered to operate an adoption support agency, you must prove that you:

  • are a fit and proper person
  • are physically and mentally fit
  • have the appropriate skills and qualifications

Once you are registered, you must comply with all related rules under the regulations. You must:

  • Ensure that any adoption support services you provide are always appropriate and that you have an appropriate written complaints procedure - all complaints must be fully investigated, written records kept and all children must be able to make a complaint.
  • Ensure that all records are stored securely, and that any records not kept on the premises are kept in appropriately secure conditions.
  • Have a written statement of purpose - this should include the aims and objectives of your agency and should be readily available and kept under review so as to be up to date. Your agency must at all times be conducted in a manner that is consistent with your statement of purpose.
  • Produce and regularly review a written children's guide to the agency which includes contact details for the registration authority and a summary of the complaints procedure. The guide must be given to each child to whom you are providing support services, and to each adult who acts for a child. It must also be produced in a form that is appropriate to the age and understanding of the children.
  • Manage the agency with sufficient care, competence and skill, and undertake any training necessary to ensure that you have sufficient experience and skills for carrying on the agency.
  • Appoint a manager (if you do not intend to be in day-to-day management of the agency) and notify the registration authority of their details.
  • Implement a written policy to safeguard children from abuse or neglect, and set out the procedure to be followed in the event of an allegation of abuse or neglect.
  • Have a disciplinary procedure under which an employee will be suspended where necessary for the welfare of children, and where any failure to report abuse or neglect is a ground for disciplinary proceedings.
  • Maintain records on each person to whom the agency provides adoption support services, and on each member of staff.
  • Ensure you have a suitable number of competent, qualified and supervised staff. You may only employ workers who are physically and mentally fit, are of good character and have suitable skills and qualifications.
  • Provide all employees with appropriate training, supervision and appraisal and any permanent appointment must be subject to the satisfactory completion of a period of probation. You must provide all employees with a job description outlining their responsibilities, and ensure that they are enabled to obtain further appropriate qualifications.
  • Ensure your premises are suitable for achieving the aims and objectives of your statement of purpose. You must ensure that there are adequate security arrangements at the premises.
  • Notify the registration authority of any significant change to the running of the agency, and of certain events including the death or injury of a child. You must give notice if you are convicted of a criminal offence.

If you fail to comply with any of these provisions, you will be guilty of a criminal offence and could be fined.

Once registered, you must pay an annual fee, and if you wish to manage more than one establishment you must be registered for each.

If you operate an independent fostering service you must be registered with Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Education, Children's Services and Skills.

Your application will be subject to a fee.

In order to be registered to operate a fostering agency, you must prove that you:

  • are a fit and proper person
  • are physically and mentally fit
  • have the appropriate skills and qualifications

Once you are registered, you must comply with all related rules under the regulations, including:

  • protecting the health and welfare of each child
  • showing respect for the child's wishes
  • promoting contact between a child and their relatives and friends, where appropriate
  • ensuring that foster parents act in accordance with established policies
  • ensuring that foster parents promote the leisure interests and educational achievement of the child
  • providing foster parents with any necessary training, advice and support to enable them to provide appropriate care for the child
  • monitoring certain matters once you have placed a child
  • staff training
  • establishing an appropriate complaints procedure
  • having a written statement of purpose to outline the aims and objectives of your fostering service
  • producing and regularly reviewing a written children's guide to your service - including contact details for the Chief Inspector and a summary of the complaints procedure - for each foster parent and each child placed
  • always having a suitable number of competent, skilled and supervised staff to ensure that the welfare of the children is protected
  • only employing workers who are fit and proper, physically and mentally fit and who have suitable qualifications
  • ensuring all employees receive appropriate training, supervision and appraisal
  • implementing a written policy to safeguard children from abuse or neglect, and setting out the procedure to be followed in the event of an allegation of abuse or neglect
  • implementing a written policy on acceptable measures of control, restraint and discipline of fostered children
  • having a disciplinary procedure under which an employee will be suspended where necessary for the welfare of children, and where any failure to report abuse or neglect is a ground for disciplinary proceedings
  • maintaining up to date records on prescribed matters and ensuring all records are kept confidentially and securely
  • constituting a fostering panel to perform the prescribed functions

You may only approve a foster parent if, after carrying out an assessment, you consider them and their household to be suitable. You must have referred a written report to the foster panel and taken their recommendation into account when making your decision.

You must notify the potential foster parent in writing of your decision and, if they have been approved, you must enter into a written foster care agreement with them.

You must review each approval every year and prepare a written report. Where a foster parent is no longer suitable, you must give them written notice of this.

If a foster parent gives you notice that they wish to terminate their agreement, you must send a copy of the notice to the relevant placing authority and area authority.

You must also notify the Chief Inspector of any significant change to the running of the home, and of certain events including the death or injury of a child, or a serious complaint about a foster parent. You must give notice if you are convicted of a criminal offence.

You must pay an annual fee of £1,597.

If you wish to manage more than one establishment you must be registered for each.

To provide registered care at home services in Scotland under you must be registered with the Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee when you apply.

The SCSWIS will check your premises, staff and management before they approve the application. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards. You can find these online.

To meet the required standards you must meet include:

  • provide a detailed introductory pack to explain your service to users - including the aims of the service, the support provided, fees information, complaints procedures and your recent inspection report
  • have adequate management and staffing arrangements in place - you must show that carers receive quality training and have knowledge of policies and procedures, that management is supportive and reliable and that the recruitment process is comprehensive and includes the relevant assessments and criminal checks
  • have in place written adult placement agreements with users to define the service and set out terms of the contract
  • draw up a personal plan for users which includes a mutually-agreed tailored plan with a nominated member of staff, and is regularly reviewed
  • provide a clean, accessible and secure environment
  • provide a service that can be tailored to each individual's personal and social preferences
  • demonstrate competence with aids and equipment for users
  • have systems in place to protect users - such as risk assessments, and protection from bulling or harassment
  • demonstrate respect for the social, cultural, religious beliefs and private lives of users
  • ensure that care workers help with the nutritional needs of users (eg assisting with food shopping or cooking when required) and healthcare provision

The SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a registration. You must keep your certificate - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in any premises you have.

If you deal in knives, swords or other articles with a blade or sharp point that are designed for use as a weapon, you must have a knife dealer's licence.

Licence applications must be made in writing to the local authority for the area in which your business operates.

Application forms are available from most local authorities.

You must provide details about yourself and your business and completed forms should be accompanied by an application fee.

Fees are set by the local authority and may vary from area to area.

From the date of making your application, you must (where possible) display a notice in or near your premises for 21 days stating:

  • that you have made an application for a licence
  • the details specified in your application
  • that any objections/representations relating to your application must be made to the local authority, the form in which they must be made and the deadline for doing so

You must also declare that you are displaying a notice in your application. If you are unable to display a notice - ie because you don't have sufficient rights in the premises to do so - you must declare this instead, along with the reasonable steps that you have made to acquire those rights.

At the end of the 21-day period you must submit a certificate to the local authority stating that you have complied with the requirement to advertise notice of your application.

Once you are licensed, you must make detailed written records on the same day as any transaction. These records must be kept for three years from the date of the transaction. You must provide full details of:

  • the customer's name
  • how you verified the customer's name
  • how you checked that the customer was at least 18 years of age, or why you thought this was not necessary
  • the item involved in the transaction

You must ensure that certain listed items are not visible from the street or any public entrance to the premises.

You must display a notice which must be visible at all times at the point of entry to your premises, at the point of sale or counter, and in a position where all customers can see it. The notice must be A4 size, and the lettering must be legible and no less than 5 millimetres high. The notice must contain the following wording:

  • "it is an offence to sell to a person under the age of 18 any knife or knife blade (except if the person is aged 16 or over and the knife or blade is designed for domestic use)"
  • "it is also an offence to sell to a person under the age of 18 any razor blade, axe, sword or other article which has a blade or which is sharply pointed and which is made or adapted for use for causing injury"
  • "customer may be asked to provide details of his/her age and identity (which may be recorded or copied and kept for inspection for up to 3 years)"

If you are dealing in swords, you must also take all reasonable steps to find out what the sword will be used for and include this information in the record of your transaction.

Other conditions may be attached to your licence - eg in respect of secure storage and display of the knives.

A licence is usually valid for one year, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

If you have separate premises for the selling and despatch of stock, you may need a licence for each premises.

If you sell second hand knives you may be required to hold both a second hand dealer's licence and a knife dealer's licence.

You don't need a licence to:

  • sell kirpans, skean dhus or folding pocket knives with blades shorter than 8.91 centimetres or knives designed for domestic use
  • teach or train another person in sports such as fencing or archery, provided that you
column5:
're qualified to do so
  • sell or supply arrows or other articles at historical re-enactment events

column4:
If you operate a public weighbridge for which a charge is made, you require a certificate of competence issued by the Chief Inspector for Weights and Measures for the local authority where your weighbridge is located.

Contact your local authority for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

Your application must include the name of the person to be certified, the type of weighbridge to be used and its address. Arrangements will be then made for you to sit a test.

A fee maybe payable for this certificate and this will depend on the local authority.

If you hold a public weighbridge certificate of competence then you must:

  • carry out weighing on demand (unless you have reasonable cause not to)
  • carry out the weighing fairly
  • provide a written statement of the weight to the person requiring the weighing
  • make a record of the weighing including the date, time and, for vehicles, details to identify the vehicle and the type of load on the vehicle
  • keep records of weighings for two years
  • make sure that you obtain the name and address of the person requesting the weighing
  • not carry out double weighing for trade purposes (this is also known as axle weighing)

If you fail to comply with the requirements you could be fined up to £5,000, imprisoned for six months or both.

You must obtain approval from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) to operate an assembly centre where cattle, pigs, sheep or goats, originating from different holdings, are grouped together to be uesd in the course of intra-Community trade.

You can apply for approval online or by contacting your local DARD office.

You will be contacted by DARD within 15 working days to arrange an inspection visit. At the inspection visit you will be given information on the approval process and an indication of the measures that need to be taken to gain approval.

In order to obtain approval, you must ensure that your assembly centre meets certain minimum conditions.

Your centre must be under the control of an official veterinarian who ensures that:

  • the animals being exported are healthy and free from clinical signs of disease
  • all relevant testing has been carried out prior to the animals entering the assembly centre
  • between leaving the holding of origin and arriving at the destination, the animals do not come into contact with any cloven-hoofed animals that have a different health status
  • the animals have been and will be transported by means that meet the necessary requirements regarding construction and cleanliness, and are accompanied by the appropriate documentation

In addition, your assembly centre must:

  • be situated in an area which is not subject to national or European prohibitions or restrictions
  • be cleaned and disinfected before use, as required by the official veterinarian
  • be dedicated exclusively for the purpose of being an assembly centre
  • have sufficient and appropriate facilities for loading, unloading, housing, watering, feeding, treating, inspecting and isolating the animals. These facilities must be easy to clean and disinfect
  • have appropriate equipment for cleaning and disinfecting rooms and vehicles
  • have an appropriate storage area for food, litter and waste
  • have an appropriate system for collecting waste water
  • include the use of an office for the official veterinarian
  • comply with any requirements for the operation of the centre which DARD has specified as being necessary to ensure the centre is operated in accordance with the regulation of intra-community trade of animals and animal products where there are issues as to the health of the animal

When the inspection report is completed, proving all conditions are met, notice of approval will be issued within ten working days. Normally approval is granted within 40 working days of the application being received (although this could vary depending on the standard of your premises) and you will then be granted an approval number along with an exporting herd/flock number.

If you wish to work as an actuary - ie someone who helps organisations measure the risk and probability of future uncertain events - you should:

  • have an A-level (or equivalent qualification) in maths
  • hold a good degree (usually 2:1 or above)
  • work in a trainee position at an actuarial firm to develop your skills while you qualify
  • register as an actuarial student and gain your qualifications

You will need to apply for registration as a student member of the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries (the Actuarial Profession).

The Actuarial Profession represents its members and regulates them regarding ethical conduct, professional standards, education and professional development.

You can download an application form from the Actuarial Profession website.

You will need to send the following with your application:

  • copies of your qualifications
  • the signatures of two referees
  • a declaration that you are a fit and proper person to be admitted as a student
  • a one-off entrance fee and annual subscription payment

Once you're registered you must study to pass the Actuarial Profession's exams (unless you apply for an exemption from certain exams by having already demonstrated sufficient knowledge of the exam syllabus).

You will study a range of topics, such as statistical modelling, economics and financial actuarial maths, by distance learning usually over a period of between three and six years.

If you pass these exams and attain a satisfactory level of work-based skills you will become an Associate member of the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries and gain the right to describe yourself as an actuary. If you choose to do so, you may then take further specialist exams to qualify as a Fellow.

Once you've qualified you should undertake a set amount of continuing professional development work each year.

If you work as a window cleaner you need a licence.

Licence applications must be made to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) for the area in which your business operates and should be:

  • made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority)
  • signed by yourself
  • accompanied by a fee

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the area from which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • any other information required by the licensing authority

Each licensing authority will have different requirements, but it is likely you will need to enclose:

  • proof of your public liability insurance
  • a copy of your employers liability insurance if you are an employee
  • at least two passport photographs

Conditions may be attached to your licence.

A licence is usually valid for three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

If you fail to hold a licence or provide a false statement on your licence application you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to comply with a licence condition you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

You must notify the licensing authority of any changes in circumstances that affect you or your business. If you fail to notify the licensing authority you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

If you have to surrender your licence and fail to do so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £500.

To provide social housing with grant you may need to register with the Tenant Services Authority (TSA). If so, you will need to comply with TSA rules about your financial affairs, constitution and management arrangements.

If you distribute any free printed material, such as leaflets or cards advertising your business, you must obtain the consent of your local authority in order to distribute on land which is designated by them as requiring consent. The authority may designate any land that they own and any part of a highway that they are responsible for.

Exceptions to this requirement apply to the distribution of printed material:

  • on behalf of a charity where the printed matter relates to, or is for the benefit of, the charity
  • where the distribution is for political purposes or for the purposes of a religion or belief

'Distribution' includes offering or making available to members of the public - including placing material on vehicles. However, it does not include putting material inside a building or letterbox or distributing inside a bus or taxi.

To obtain consent you must complete an application form. Contact your local authority for a notification form or visit their website to apply online.

You may also be required to pay an application fee, which will vary depending on:

  • the local authority you're applying to
  • the number of distributors you want to use
  • whether you're applying for a single event consent or an annual consent

Conditions may be attached to the consent regarding:

  • the material to be distributed
  • the times or dates it may be distributed
  • the area of designated land in which it may be distributed

If you fail to comply with any conditions, the consent may be revoked.

You may be required to produce written evidence of the consent upon request by an authorised officer. Failure to hold a valid permit may lead to a fine of up to £2,500 or a fixed penalty notice, and the printed material may be confiscated.

column3: Domestic energy assessor (existing dwellings) accreditation (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate as a domestic energy assessor (DEA) for existing dwellings in Northern Ireland, you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the types of work you undertake and is approved by the Department of Finance and Personnel (DFP).

A DEA is qualified to assess the energy efficiency and prepare energy performance certificates (EPCs) and reports containing recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of existing dwellings. A recommendation report must be issued with an EPC.

If you're a DEA you must collect data on the dimensions, construction, heating and hot water provision of the dwelling and enter it into an approved software programme - Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure (RDSAP) and produce EPCs for homes being marketed for sale or rental.

RDSAP is the government approved standardised system for doing an energy survey on an existing dwelling, eg for homes being sold or rented out. A full Standard Assessment Procedure (SAP) requires many data items that can't be seen in a survey or that may take too long to collect. RDSAP is an industry agreed standard set of data items and a standard way of inferring the missing data.

SAP is the procedure for energy assessments of domestic premises.

To join a scheme you must either:

  • hold a current qualification in energy inspection - this forms part of a National Occupational Standard (NOS) in Energy Inspection
  • have approved prior experience and learning equivalent to the NOS requirements - this is gained via the Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) route

As an energy assessor you may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification and accreditation system.

To become accredited you must complete an application form and provide any supporting documents and application fee that the accreditation scheme requests. Each scheme has its own application form and requirements for membership.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your scheme.

An assessor from Northern Ireland accredited by an approved scheme also qualifies to work in England and Wales.

If you wish to become a DEA you'll need to get a basic Access NI certificate before you apply to an accreditation scheme as some schemes require it to be sent with the application form. If you already hold a standard or enhanced Access NI check some schemes may accept this.

To become accredited you must:

  • show you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments independently
  • show that you are fit, proper and qualified to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare EPC and recommendation reports using a standardised format
  • follow your scheme's Code of Conduct
  • enter any EPC or recommendation report that you produce and the data which was used to produce them or any asset rating onto the relevant register held Landmark on behalf of the DFP

When producing EPCs or inspection reports you must include a declaration detailing if you have a business or personal relationship with the person who commissioned the certificate or on whose behalf it was commissioned, anyone with an interest with either of these people or the building.

If you operate as a non-domestic energy assessor in Northern Ireland, you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the type of work you undertake and is approved by the Department of Finance and Personnel (DFP).

A non-domestic energy assessor is qualified to assess the energy efficiency of offices, shops, factories etc and produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) and reports containing recommendations for cost-effective improvements of their energy performance.

To join an accreditation scheme you must either:

  • hold a current qualification in energy inspection - part of a National Occupational Standard (NOS) in Energy Inspection
  • have approved prior experience and learning equivalent to the NOS requirements - gained via the Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) route

There are three levels of qualification:

  • level three - an NDEA can use Simplified Building Energy Model (SBEM) software to produce EPCs for simple existing buildings
  • level four - an NDEA can use SBEM software to produce EPCs for new and existing complex buildings
  • level five (APEL only) - an NDEA can use Dynamic Simulation Modelling (DSM) software to produce EPCs for new, complex buildings

SBEM is a computer programme that analyses a building's energy consumption. It uses the building's geometry, construction, use, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning and lighting equipment to calculate the monthly energy use and CO2 emissions of the building.

DSM is software that models energy inputs and outputs for different building types over time. It's used where SBEM isn't sophisticated enough to give an accurate assessment of a building's energy efficiency.

Qualifications/APEL may only be valid for specific areas of energy inspection, eg certain energy assessment methodologies or building types. You may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification/APEL.

To become accredited you must complete an application form and provide any supporting documents and application fee the accreditation scheme requests. Each scheme has its own application form and membership requirements.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee.

An assessor from Northern Ireland accredited by an approved scheme also qualifies to work in England and Wales.

You must:

  • show you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments independently
  • show you are fit, proper and qualified to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare EPCs and recommendation reports using standardised forms
  • follow your scheme's Code of Conduct
  • enter any EPC or recommendation report that you produce and the data used onto the relevant register held by Landmark on behalf of DFP

When producing EPCs or inspection reports you must include a declaration detailing whether you have a business or personal relationship with either the person who commissioned the certificate, on whose behalf it was commissioned or anyone with an interest with either of these people or the building.

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill. When you issue an EPC, you must also issue a report containing recommendations for cost-effective improvement of the building's energy performance.

column3: Air conditioning energy assessor accreditation (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate as an air conditioning system energy assessor in Northern Ireland, you must be a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the types of work you undertake and is approved by the Department of Finance and Personnel (DFP).

An air conditioning system energy assessor is qualified to assess the energy efficiency of air conditioners and produce written reports containing:

  • an assessment of the air conditioning efficiency and the size of the system compared to the cooling requirements of the building
  • appropriate advice on possible improvements to the system, replacement of the system and alternative solutions

To join an accreditation scheme you must either:

  • hold a current qualification in energy inspection - this forms part of a National Occupational Standard in Energy Inspection
  • have approved prior experience and learning equivalent to the National Occupational Standard requirements - this is gained via the Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) route

Qualifications or APEL may only be valid for specific areas of energy inspection, eg for certain energy assessment methodologies or types of air conditioning system. You may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification/APEL.

To become accredited you must complete an application form and provide any supporting documents and application fee that the accreditation scheme requests.

Each scheme has its own application form and requirements for membership, but you will always be required to provide evidence of your qualifications/APEL and your fitness and suitability to carry out energy assessments.

You can find a list of approved schemes on the DFP website.

Once you are accredited, you must follow your scheme's code of conduct and ensure that energy assessments are carried out with reasonable care and skill.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your scheme.

An assessor from Northern Ireland accredited by an approved scheme also qualifies to work in England and Wales.

column3: Display energy certificate (DEC) assessor accreditation (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate as a display energy certificate (DEC) assessor in Northern Ireland, you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers that type of work and is approved by the Department of Finance and Personnel (DFP).

A DEC assessor is qualified to assess the energy performance of large public buildings and prepare DECs and advisory reports containing recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of those buildings.

A large public building is a building with a total useful floor area over 1,000 square metres which is occupied by a public authority or an institution providing public services to a large number of people.

In order to become accredited you must meet the relevant National Occupational Standards (NOS) in full. This includes showing full knowledge of operational rating methodology and the ability to use the approved operational rating software.

To join an accreditation scheme you must either:

  • hold a current qualification in energy inspection - this forms part of a NOS in Energy Inspection
  • have approved prior experience and learning equivalent to the NOS requirements - this is gained via the Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) route

For the APEL route you must include your experience of using operational rating software and may be required to produce example DECs and advisory reports. You may also need to take top-up training. You may also be required to hold a professional qualification.

Qualifications or APEL may only be valid for specific areas of energy inspection, eg for certain energy assessment methodologies or types of building. You may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification/APEL.

In addition some schemes may require you to obtain an Access NI check if you are to carry out work in schools or care homes for example.

To become accredited you must complete an application form and provide any supporting documents and application fee that the accreditation scheme requests.

Each scheme has its own application form and requirements for membership, but you will always be required to provide evidence of your qualifications/APEL and your fitness and suitability to carry out energy assessments.

You can find a list of approved schemes on the DFP website.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your scheme.

An assessor from Northern Ireland accredited by an approved scheme also qualifies to work in England and Wales.

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are fit, proper and qualified to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare DECs and advisory reports using a standardised format
  • follow your scheme's Code of Conduct
  • enter any DECs or advisory report that you produce and the data used to produce the document or DEC onto the relevant register held by Landmark on behalf of DFP

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill.

Whenever you issue a DEC, you must issue with it an advisory report containing your recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of the building.

When issuing a DEC, you must include a declaration of any personal or business relationship that you have with:

  • any person who commissioned the certificate, or on whose behalf the certificate was commissioned - or any person who you believe may have a personal or business relationship with such a person
  • any person who you believe may have an interest in the building

If you operate as a domestic energy assessor in Scotland, you must be a member of an organisation which has been approved by the Scottish Government to deliver services in relation to energy performance certificates (EPCs).

A domestic energy assessor is qualified to assess the energy efficiency of houses and other residential properties and prepare EPCs and reports containing recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of those buildings.

This is a legal requirement when homes over 50 square metres are sold or rented.

Your approved organisation is responsible for ensuring that you are suitably qualified and accredited to conduct energy assessments.

Some organisations are only approved to provide EPC services for certain types of building, eg commercial buildings, so make sure you check this before applying.

When you apply to join an approved organisation you must provide any supporting documents and application fee that the organisation requests.

Each approved organisation has its own application process and requirements for membership, but you will usually be required to provide details of your qualifications, training and fitness to carry out energy assessments.

You can find a list of approved schemes on the Scottish Government website.

Once you are a member, you must follow your organisation's code of conduct.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your organisation.

As a member of an approved organisation which produces domestic EPCs you must:

  • carry out energy efficiency assessments on existing dwellings only
  • collect data on the dimensions, construction, heating and hot water provision of the property and enter it into an approved software programme - Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure (RDSAP)
  • produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) for homes on sale and for homes when rented out

RDSAP is the government approved standardised system for doing an energy survey on an existing dwelling, eg for homes being sold or rented out.

You must ensure that any EPC that you issue, and the associated data, is entered onto the relevant register kept by the Scottish Government before you give the document to the person who requested that it be issued.

If you wish to produce EPCs you will need to get a basic Criminal Records Bureau (CRB) check carried out before you apply to an accreditation scheme as some schemes require it to be sent with the application form. If you already hold a standard or enhanced CRB check some accreditation schemes may accept this.

In the case of mixed use buildings - when the building is built, sold or rented out - EPCs should be produced for each dwelling and one or several EPCs produced for the non domestic area. Technical guidance should be sought in cases of doubt.

If you operate as a commercial energy assessor in Scotland, you must be a member of an organisation which has been approved by the Scottish Government to deliver services in relation to energy performance certificates (EPCs).

A commercial energy assessor is qualified to assess the energy efficiency of offices, shops, factories etc and produce EPCs and reports containing recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of those buildings.

This is a legal requirement when commercial buildings over 50 square metres are sold or rented out.

Your approved organisation is responsible for ensuring that you are suitably qualified and accredited to conduct energy assessments.

For example you may be required to have knowledge (either existing or through qualification) of Simplified Building Energy Model (SBEM) software. SBEM is a computer programme that analyses a building's energy consumption. It uses a description of the building's geometry, construction, use, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning and lighting equipment.

Some organisations are only approved to provide EPC services for certain types of building, eg residential buildings, so make sure you check this before applying.

When you apply to join an approved organisation you must provide any supporting documents and application fee that the organisation requests.

Each approved organisation has its own application process and requirements for membership, but you will usually be required to provide details of your qualifications, training and fitness to carry out energy assessments.

You can find a list of approved schemes on the Scottish Government website.

Once you are a member, you must follow your organisation's code of conduct.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your organisation.

You must ensure that any EPC that you issue, and the associated data, is entered onto the relevant register kept by the Scottish Government before you give the document to the person who requested that it be issued.
