The EPC for mixed use buildings - when the building is sold or rented out – should be generated using the Reduced Data Standard Assessment Procedure and the EPC for the commercial part produced using SBEM.

If you run a theatre it must be licensed by your local district council.

Fees will be payable with the licence application.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

column3: On-construction domestic energy assessor accreditation (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate as an on-construction domestic energy assessor in Northern Ireland you must be suitably qualified and a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the types of work you undertake and is approved by the Department of Finance and Personnel (DFP).

An on-construction domestic energy assessor is qualified to assess the energy efficiency of new build homes from plans and produce energy performance certificates (EPCs) and reports containing recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of those buildings.

To join an accreditation scheme you must either:

  • hold a current qualification in energy inspection - this forms part of a National Occupational Standard (NOS) in Energy Inspection
  • have approved prior experience and learning equivalent to the NOS requirements - this is gained via the Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL) route

For the APEL route you will have to show evidence of experience creating Standard Assessment Procedure (SAP) reports and may have to provide sample energy performance certificates (EPCs) you have produced.

SAP is the procedure for energy assessments of domestic premises. It is used to show that they comply with Part F 2006 of the Building Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2000.

Qualifications or APEL may only be valid for specific areas of energy inspection, eg for certain energy assessment methodologies or types of building. You may only conduct inspections in areas covered by your current qualification/APEL.

To become accredited you must complete an application form and provide any supporting documents and application fee that the accreditation scheme requests.

Each scheme has its own application form and requirements for membership, but you will always be required to provide evidence of your qualifications/APEL and your fitness and suitability to carry out energy assessments.

You can find a list of approved schemes on the DFP website.

You will usually be issued with an identity card and have to pay an annual membership fee to your scheme.

An assessor from Northern Ireland accredited by an approved scheme also qualifies to work in England and Wales.

In order to become accredited, you will have to:

  • show that you can carry out consistent and accurate energy assessments in an independent manner
  • show that you are a fit, proper and qualified to carry out energy assessments
  • prepare EPCs and recommendation reports using a standardised format
  • follow your scheme's Code of Conduct
  • enter any EPC or recommendation report that you produce and the data used to produce the document or EPC onto the relevant register held by Landmark on behalf of DFP

You must carry out energy assessments with reasonable care and skill. When you issue an EPC, you must issue with it a recommendation report containing your recommendations for the cost-effective improvement of the energy performance of the dwelling.

When issuing an EPC, you must include a declaration of any personal or business relationship that you have with:

  • any person who commissioned the certificate, or on whose behalf the certificate was commissioned - or any person who you believe may have a personal or business relationship with such a person
  • any person who you believe may have an interest in the dwelling

If you wish to operate gaming machines in your premises you must hold an amusement permit.

You must submit your application to the district council in which your premises are located together with a fee. A copy of the permit application must also be served on the sub-divisional commander of the police sub-division where your premises are located.

You must comply with any conditions attached to permit.

If you own a sex shop you need a licence, unless the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) has agreed to waive this requirement. You may apply for a waiver either as part of your licence application or separately.

You must be over 18 for a licence to be granted.

Licence applications must be made to the licensing authority for the area in which your business operates and should be:

  • made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority)
  • signed by yourself or your agent
  • accompanied by a fee

You may also need to provide additional documents so that background checks can be carried out on you by the police.

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application for a licence (or a waiver if appropriate) must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name, age and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name, age and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the address and the area in which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name, age and address
  • any other information reasonably required by the local authority

Your licence application must also contain either:

  • a declaration that you are displaying a public notice in relation to your application (see below)
  • a declaration that you do not have rights in the premises that enable you to put up a notice, and detailing the reasonable steps that you have made to acquire those rights

From the date of making your licence application, you must (where possible) display a notice in or near your premises for 21 days stating:

  • that you have made an application for a licence
  • the particulars specified in your application
  • that any objections/representations relating to your application must be made to the licensing authority, the form in which they must be made and the deadline for doing so

You must place an advert detailing your application in a local newspaper named by the licensing authority within seven days of making your application and provide a copy of the advert to the licensing authority.

At the end of this period you must submit a certificate to the licensing authority stating that you have complied with the requirement to advertise notice of your application.

Conditions may be attached to your licence, eg regulating your hours of opening, your shop displays and advertisements and how visible the interior of your shop is to people passing by.

A licence is usually valid for up to one year, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

You must display a copy of the licence in the place specified in the licence.

Once you have a licence, you must obtain permission from the local authority before making any material changes to the premises or, if applicable, to the vehicle, vessel or stall. You must notify the local authority as soon as possible of any other changes to details that you specified in your original or renewal application.

If you fail to have a licence or comply with licence conditions, allow anyone under 18 on your premises or provide a false statement on application you may commit an offence and be fined up to £20,000.

If you fail to notify the licensing authority or fail to obtain consent you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000.

If you fail to surrender your licence if requested to do so or fail to display your l
column5:
icence you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

Failing to allow an authorised officer or constable to inspect your premises is an offence and subject to a £1,000 fine.

In addition to any fine your licence may also be revoked.

column4:
To provide registered child minding services in Scotland you must be registered with Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee when you apply, and your application must include:

  • details on yourself (if operating as an individual) or your organisation
  • details of the manager (if you will not be the manager of the service)
  • references
  • financial details - eg a statement from the bank on your financial standing and reliability
  • declarations regarding any convictions, bankruptcy or previous involvement in registered services

You need to provide information on your proposed service, in particular:

  • its name and address
  • a statement of aims and objectives
  • staffing, recruitment and training
  • suitability and fitness of accommodation

You must also attach the following documents:

  • recruitment policy
  • programmes for staff induction, development and training
  • plans of the premises
  • copies of planning permission, the building warrant and building completion certificates - if relevant
  • surveyors reports
  • ventilation, heating and lighting details
  •  financial information
  • aims and objectives statements

SCSWIS will inspect your premises, staff and management before they approve the application. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards to be registered. You can find these online.

To meet the required standards you must:

  • provide appropriate information for users of the service - this includes the aims of the service, the support it provides, fees information and the complaints procedure
  • allow visitors to observe the service before they use it
  • provide a safe environment - this should be smoke free, hygienic and stimulating
  • provide services and facilities that conform to relevant legislation and are clean and well maintained
  • ensure standards of care that protect a child's health and wellbeing - this includes providing the opportunity for children to rest or sleep, maintain a well-balanced diet, and have access to fresh air and physical play
  • employ workers with the relevant skills and competency to understand child and young person development, can interact with children, and can assess this development to improve future learning
  • offer a balanced range of activities to all ages of young persons
  • ensure mutual respect between staff, children, parents and carers - in particular staff working with parents to improve child development and behaviour
  • ensure there are adequate management and staffing arrangements - you must show that staff receive quality training, have knowledge of policies and procedures, that management is supportive and reliable, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive
  • have in place adequate management and staffing arrangements - demonstrate that staff receive quality training, have knowledge of policies and procedures, and benefit from supportive and reliable management, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive
  • draw up written agreements with users to define the service and set out terms of the contract - this should include information on the date the service begins, who provides the service, charges, and length of service

SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to the registration. You must keep your certificate of registration - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in
column5: any premises you have.

column4:
If you operate as a hairdresser or barber in Northern Ireland, you may need to register with the local district council for the area where your premises are based.

Contact your local district council to find out whether you need to register. If you do, you will usually need to fill out an application form and you may need to pay an application fee.

Your premises may be inspected before a certificate of registration is issued.

You must also comply with any byelaws enacted by your district council in relation to:

  • cleanliness, proper lighting and ventilation of your premises
  • precautions to be taken against infection or contamination
  • instructing staff in hygiene and the efficient use of equipment
  • public liability insurance

If you operate without being registered or fail to comply with council byelaws you may be fined and, where appropriate, have your registration cancelled.

If you run an independent school it must be registered with the Department of Education (DE).

A registration will be provisional until the school has been inspected on behalf of DE.

Your school will not be registered if you have been disqualified from being an independent school proprietor, your premises is disqualified from being a school or your premises are being used for an activity that they are disqualified from being used for.

If you operate an independent school that is not registered or do anything intended to make it appear that your school is provisionally or fully registered you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500, imprisoned for up to three months or both.

You may be served with a notice of compliant if the DE believe that your school is objectionable on one of the following grounds:

  • the premises or parts of it are unsuitable for use as a school
  • the accommodation provided is unsuitable given the number, sex and ages of the pupils
  • you have failed to comply with pupil welfare requirements for a child accommodated at your school
  • suitable and efficient teaching is not being provided taking into account the age, sex and abilities of the pupils
  • you or any teacher are not a fit and proper person to be a proprietor or teacher

The notice will give full details of any failure and give steps to be taken to remedy the failure, together with a time period of when these steps must be taken.

You can appeal against a notice of complaint to the Independent Schools Tribunal.

If you use premises as a school when you have been disqualified from doing so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500, imprisoned for up to three months or both.

You must keep a register of all pupils that attend your school. If you fail to keep such a register you may commit an offence and be fined up to £200.

column3: Support services providing day care to adults registration (Scotland)
column4:
To provide support services providing day care to adults registered in Scotland you must be registered with Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee when you apply, and your application must include:

  • details on yourself (if operating as an individual) or your organisation
  • details of the manager (if you will not be the manager of the service)
  • references
  • financial details - eg a statement from the bank on your financial standing and reliability
  • declarations regarding any convictions, bankruptcy or previous involvement in registered services

You need to provide information on your proposed service, in particular:

  • its name and address
  • a statement of aims and objectives
  • staffing, recruitment and training
  • suitability and fitness of accommodation

You must also attach the following documents:

  • recruitment policy
  • programmes for staff induction, development and training
  • plans of the premises
  • copies of planning permission, the building warrant and building completion certificates
  • surveyors reports
  • ventilation, heating and lighting details
  • financial information
  • aims and objectives statement

SCSWIS will inspect your premises, staff and management. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards. You can find these online.

To meet the required standards you must:

  • provide detailed information documents to explain your service to users - this includes the aims of the service, the support provided, users' rights and responsibilities, complaints procedures, and your recent inspection report
  • have adequate management and staffing arrangements - you must show that staff receive quality training, and have knowledge of policies and procedures, that management is supportive and reliable, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive
  • have in place written agreements with users to define the service and set out terms of the contract
  • draw up a personal plan for each user that includes a mutually-agreed tailored plan with a nominated member of staff and is regularly reviewed
  • provide a secure environment that provides personal and public spaces
  • provide a service that can be tailored to each individual's personal and social preferences
  • provide access to, and demonstrate competence with, and relevant aids and equipment for users
  • have systems in place to protect users - such as risk assessments, and protection from bulling or harassment
  • demonstrate respect for the social, cultural and religious beliefs of users

SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to the registration. You must keep your certificate of registration - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in any premises you have.

If you offer tattooing, semi-permanent skin colouring, cosmetic piercing, acupuncture or electrolysis in Northern Ireland, you may need to be registered with your local district council.

If you work from premises, they may also need to be registered.

Your application for registration must contain the information required by the council, which may include details of the premises and particulars of any relevant convictions you have received. A fee may also be payable.

Once registered, you will be issued with a certificate of registration.

You must comply with the district council's bye-laws on cleanliness and hygiene.

The requirement to register does not apply where you are registered as a medical practitioner, dentist, physiotherapist or chiropodist, or you are practicing under someone who is registered as such.

You must allow an authorised officer access and entry onto your premises if they are carrying the appropriate warrant.

If you fail to register, or do not comply with bye-laws, you may be fined up to £1000.

column3: Premises approval for civil marriage or civil partnership ceremonies (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you wish to hold a civil marriage or civil partnership ceremony in your premises, or on your vessel, they must be approved by your local authority.

You should send the application form to your local authority with a description of your premises, details of your public liability insurance and the application fee where applicable.

Application and renewal fees are set locally.

You may apply for approval to last for up to three years or for temporary approval which is valid for a specific date.

You must comply with conditions attached to an approval, eg that the sale or consumption of food and drink should be kept separate from where the civil marriage ceremony takes place.

If you exhibit, use or train performing animals in England, Wales or Scotland, you must be registered with your local authority.

Applications must contain details about the animals and the performances they are to take part in. Applications may be subject to a fee.

You will be issued with a certificate of registration.

Your premises may be inspected and you may be required to produce your certificate.

If a complaint of cruelty is proven against you, you may be prohibited from exhibiting or training performing animals, or you may have conditions imposed. Your registration may also be suspended or cancelled.

If you exhibit or train any performing animal without being registered you may be fined up to £2,500. You may also be prohibited from exhibiting or training performing animals.

This does not apply to the training of animals for military, police, agricultural or sporting purposes, or the exhibition of these animals.

If you allow your land to be used as a camping site by the public for more than 42 days consecutively - or 60 days in a year - you require a licence from your local authority.

There are exceptions for organisations that hold camping exemption certificates.
Specified risk material must only be removed at slaughterhouses or cutting plants authorised by the Food Standards Agency (FSA).

If you have a premises licence in Scotland and are holding a special event that requires an extension to your normal licensing hours, you must make an extended hours application to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing board) for the area in which your premises are based.

Contact your licensing board for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

You will need to provide details of the event or occasion and the additional hours you want to be licensed for. You also need to pay an application fee of £10.

Licensing boards will only grant an extension that allows you to serve alcohol for a continuous 24-hour period in exceptional circumstances.

The maximum period your licensing hours can be extended is one month.

Licensing boards have the power to extend your licensed hours by the period specified in your application or for such other period as they consider appropriate.

The conditions attached to your premises licence might be modified during the extended hours, or new conditions may be added.

Once your licensing hours have been extended by an extended hours application, they cannot be extended further.

You don't need to apply for an extension of hours where alcohol is:

  • consumed within 15 minutes of the end of your licensed hours - ie drinking-up time
  • sold to hotel residents or consumed by residents or their guests
  • consumed with a meal within 30 minutes of the end of your licensed hours, as long as it was purchased along with the meal during licensed hours

If, in any other circumstances, you sell alcohol or allow it to be consumed on or taken from your premises outside of licensed hours, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £1,000.

You can't apply to extend your licensed hours if you hold an occasional licence.

If you hold a premises licence, a personal licence or are from a voluntary organisation and wish to sell alcohol from unlicensed premises, you must apply for an occasional licence.

For example, where a restaurant wants to sell alcohol in the course of catering for an event - eg a wedding - taking place on private property, they must apply for an occasional licence.

Occasional licences are issued by the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing board) for the area in which the premises hosting the event are based.

Applications must be accompanied by an application fee of £10 and should contain the following details:

  • your name and address
  • a description of the premises
  • the activities to be carried on in the premises
  • whether alcohol will be sold for consumption on or off the premises (or both)
  • the period during which the licence will have effect
  • the times when alcohol will be sold for consumption on and/or off the premises
  • the times when any other activities - eg sale of food - will be carried on
  • whether children will be allowed on the premises and, if so, the age at which they can enter, the times they can do so and the parts of the premises they are allowed access to

A licensing board won't grant an occasional licence for a period exceeding 14 days.

Contact your licensing board for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

If granted, your licence will be subject to certain conditions - eg in relation to authorised sales, pricing and age verification.

If you sell alcohol, or allow alcohol to be sold on unlicensed premises you may be fined up to £20,000, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

If you are a voluntary organisation, you can apply each year for a maximum of:

  • four occasional licences lasting for four or more days each
  • 12 occasional licences lasting for four days or less each

However, the total number of days covered by occasional licences must not exceed 56.

Licences will only be granted for events connected with the activities of your voluntary organisation.

To provide registered nurse agency services in Scotland you must be registered with the Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee and you must provide the following information:

  • details on yourself (if operating as an individual) or your organisation
  • details of the manager (if you will not be the day to day manager)
  • references
  • financial details - eg a statement from the bank of your financial standing and reliability
  • declarations regarding any convictions, bankruptcy or previous involvement in registered services

You need to provide information on your proposed service, in particular:

  • its name and address
  • a statement of aims and objectives
  • staffing, recruitment and training
  • suitability and fitness of accommodation

You must also attach the following documents:

  • recruitment policy
  • programmes for staff induction, development and training
  • financial information
  • aims and objectives statements

SCSWIS will inspect your premises, staff and management before they approve the application. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards. You can find these online.

To meet the relevant standards you must:

  • provide a detailed introductory pack to explain your service to users - this includes the aims of the service, the details of service provision, quality monitoring processes, fees information, and complaints procedures
  • draw up written agreements with users which define the service and set out the terms of the contract
  • ensure that there are always sufficient nurses to meet the needs of users present
  • draw up a service arrangement that provides for a review of service agreements, regular checks with users and good monitoring of the quality of the placement
  • maintain accurate up to date records on nurse quality, suitability and consultations
  • ensure there are adequate management and staffing arrangements - that nurses have received quality training, have knowledge of policies and procedures, and are registered with the appropriate nursing bodies, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive and includes relevant assessments and criminal checks
  • ensure that a consistent standard of care is delivered by
    nurses who are competent to work in the service area
  • meet all applicable legal requirements with regard to adult placement carers, their abilities, qualifications and knowledge

SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions of the registration. You must keep your certificate - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in any premises you have.

If you run an independent school your school must be registered with the Registrar of Independent Schools in Scotland.

To register as an independent school, you must apply to the Office of the Registrar of Independent Schools for registration using the electronic application form and provide the following information:

  • the name of the school
  • your proposed school's address
  • nominated contact details
  • the type of school and its dates of operation
  • the maximum pupil numbers
  • the date from which the school is to be operational
  • proposed curriculum
  • health and safety information - including a Fire Risk Assessment
  • statement of aims
  • school prospectus
  • Child Protection Policy and Procedure
  • admissions policy

You must undergo a pre-registration inspection by HM Inspectorate of Education (HMIE) whilst the school is not operational. This inspection will check that the proposed accommodation is fit for purpose, agree the maximum number of pupils and ensure that appropriate consideration has been given to the care and welfare of pupils.

Your application will be granted if you can show that:

  • efficient and suitable education will be provided
  • pupils' welfare will be adequately safeguarded
  • you - or the proprietor - are fit to be the proprietor of the school
  • all teachers are adequately qualified to teach in a school
  • accommodation at the school is adequate and suitable for all pupils

Once registered you must:

  • Comply with any registration conditions that have been attached
  • Submit to a post-registration inspection by HMIE within nine months to ensure the quality of education, accommodation and the care and welfare of pupils. HMIE will publish a report which will include action points for the school. These will determine the timing of the next inspection.

You will then be subject to regular HMIE inspections to check you meet any requirements imposed.

column3: Licence to possess specified animal pathogens or carriers (Northern Ireland)
column4:
Your business must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development if you possess specified animal pathogens or carriers of such pathogens.

Licences will be in writing and there are strict conditions attached to a licence with which businesses must comply.

You must have the required qualifications if you are a street works operative and your presence is required on site at all times for any street works that involve:

  • breaking up the street, any sewer or drain
  • tunnelling under the street, any sewer or drain
  • boring under the street
  • opening the street

You will be considered to have the relevant qualification if you hold a certificate of competence from an approved body. This certificate shows that you have achieved the relevant units of competence for the work being carried out and that that certificate is registered in an approved register.

The approved bodies for issuing certificates of competence are:

  • City and Guilds of London Institute
  • Scottish Qualifications Authority
  • Certification and Assessment Board for the Water Industry (CABWI)

To obtain a certificate of competence, you must hold certification for the following areas:

  • location and avoidance of underground apparatus
  • monitoring signing, lighting and guarding
  • excavating in the highway
  • reinstating and compaction of various types of road construction materials

As well as the certificate of competence, you must also show that you have practical competence in the following areas:

  • excavation in the highway
  • excavation, backfilling and reinstatement of construction layers with a cold-lay bituminous surface
  • reinstatement of construction layers in hot-lay and cold-lay bituminous materials
  • reinstatement of concrete slabs
  • reinstatement of modular surfaces and concrete footways

Alternatively, you can have a qualification from another member state of the European Community which gives an equivalent guarantee of skill and competence.

You must also register your Certificate of Competence with the Street Works Qualification Register (SWQR). The SQWR will then provide a plastic photo identification card to show you have the requisite qualifications.

A registration is valid for five years. In Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland you can reregister by contacting the registration body within three months of the expiry of the previous registration. To reregister in England, you must undertake a reassessment of your held qualifications.

If you wish to build a marina that connects to waters owned or managed by British Waterways you require consent from British Waterways.

A fee will be payable and terms and conditions will be applicable.

column3: Business craft used on inland waterways (Northern Ireland)
column4:
Commercial craft used on inland waterways in Northern Ireland must be registered with Waterways Ireland.

Before registration you must:

  • have had the vessel surveyed by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA)
  • ensure the master of the vessel is in the possession of a Boatmaster's licence issued from the MCA

You must register in order to use the Erne System if your boat has an engine more powerful than 7.5 kilowatts. The boat must also display the registration number.

The Lower Bann Navigation does not require registration, but you will still be required to inform Waterways Ireland of your intention to conduct a commercial operation.

To place advertising displays on the road or pavement in Scotland, you require written consent from your local authority.

Conditions may be attached to any consent granted and a fee may be payable.

To place tables and chairs outside your premises or deposit building materials in the road or erect staging or scaffolding you also require Road Occupation Consent.

If you produce or hold hazardous waste at any premises in England or Wales, you must register those premises with the Environment Agency.

'Hazardous waste' is any waste which can be harmful to human health or the environment and includes:

  • asbestos
  • lead-acid batteries
  • solvent-based inks and paints
  • fluorescent light tubes
  • electrical equipment containing hazardous components

You are exempt from the requirement to register if you produce less than 500 kilograms of waste in any 12-month period.

You can register online, by paper application form, or by telephoning the Environment Agency. Your waste manager can also register you on your behalf. You must provide the following information when you register:

  • details of your business – including your standard industrial classification (SIC) code, number of employees and Companies House number if you are a limited company
  • details of your business premises - specifically where the
    hazardous waste is being produced, stored, treated or disposed of

You must pay a registration. The fee is determined by your method of application, with online registration being the cheapest.

Once you have registered, the Environment Agency will provide you with a registration number (known as a premises code). You will need this code to show that you have registered your premises and to allow someone to legally collect your hazardous waste. You may also need your premises codes to check or alter your business details.

The registration is valid for 12 months and must be renewed each year.

Mixing different categories of hazardous waste, or hazardous waste with non-hazardous waste or non-waste, is only allowed in certain circumstances. If you mix hazardous waste as part of the process of disposal or recovery of the waste, you must have an environmental permit.

If you treat waste or are a consignee, you must have an environmental permit or registered exemption.

If you produce, hold or remove hazardous waste from premises that are neither registered nor exempt, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £5,000.

column3: Practising as a costs lawyer (England and Wales)
column4:
To act as a costs lawyer (formerly known as a law costs draftsman) you must be a qualified member of the Association of Costs Lawyers (ACL).

Costs lawyers are concerned with all aspects of legal costs - ie costs payable by a client to his solicitor, costs payable between parties and legal aid costs.

There are two levels of ACL membership.

If you are over the age of 18 and have a minimum of four GCSEs at grade C (including maths and English) or above you can apply for student membership. If you don't meet the qualification requirements, you may need to sit an aptitude test.

You will need to provide a business reference (as well as a character reference) with your application so it is strongly recommended that you already have experience of working with a costs lawyer. However, you are not required to be employed in costs law at the time of your application.

Applications for membership are accepted once per year.

You can download an application form from the ACL website, and completed forms should be returned to the ACL.

You must also attach a copy of your CV and an application fee of £50.

Student members must undertake the ACL Modular Training Course and will be required to complete all assignments applying to one module within a year of induction in order to remain a member and to progress to the next stage of the course. Further details of the Modular Training Course - and the cost of studying each module - can be found on the ACL website.

If you have a law degree, certificate of completion of the Law Society Legal Practice Course, Bar Vocational Course or ILEX qualifications, you may be exempt from studying certain subjects within the course modules.

Once you have completed the training course, passed the exams and completed three years qualifying employment you will be admitted as a full member of the ACL - ie a costs lawyer. This enables you to advise litigants on aspects of costs law.

All members must pay an annual subscription fee to the ACL. The level of fees will be determined by the class of membership that you hold.

Once you are qualified to act as a costs lawyer, you must:

  • comply with the ACL's byelaws and code of conduct rules
  • ensure you have sufficient insurance cover
  • undertake at least 12 hours continuing professional development each year

If you fail to comply with byelaws or code of conduct rules you may be fined, suspended or expelled from the ACL.

column3: Solvent emissions - pollution prevention and control permit Part B (Scotland)
column4:
If you run a business in Scotland that uses organic solvents, you may require a pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

If you are not already authorised or if you are planning a new business, you should contact SEPA for advice on whether you need a permit and how to apply. Part B PPC permits regulate smaller installations that only have the potential to cause emissions to air. You can apply online or use a paper form.

Your application may also be considered by any of the following consulting bodies:

  • the Health & Safety Executive - for sites that required a nuclear licence
  • the relevant Health Board where the installation will operate
  • your local authority
  • Scottish Natural Heritage - if the installation may affect a Site of Special Scientific Interest

The permit may have specific conditions attached, depending on your operations. You must also follow any best available techniques to prevent and minimise pollution. They may also cover conditions relating to the operation of your business, the use and storage of solvents, and the keeping of records.

If you are using solvents in paints, varnishes and vehicle refinishing products, there are other rules you must comply with.

If your business is larger, you may need a Part A PPC permit. This covers dressing, printing, coating, degreasing, painting, cleaning or impregnating in plant with a consumption capacity of more than 150 kilograms per hour or more than 200 tonnes per year.

If you hold equipment in Scotland containing Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs), you must register annually with the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

A registration fee is payable.

If you wish to show, demonstrate or perform a hypnotism act in public, you must have authorisation from the relevant local authority in England and Wales. You must have permission regardless of whether your performance is live or broadcast.

You may also need a theatre or entertainment licence as well, depending on your type of performance.

The local authority may require a reasonable fee to be paid for your licence, though this is discretionary.

If you are performing in Scotland, you must have permission, or the premises must hold a premises or other entertainment licence. Permission in Scotland is obtained from the authority issuing the premises licences.

You must comply with any conditions attached to an authorisation. In addition to this, you must make any changes to your show if requested by your local licensing authority.

You must not give a performance of hypnotism on a person who is under 18 years of age.

column3: Accredited electrical and electronic equipment producer compliance scheme (Scotland)
column4:
If you produce electrical and electronic equipment (EEE) in Scotland, you must be a member of a Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) accredited producer compliance scheme.

To produce EEE from the start of a year, you must join a scheme on or before 15 November the year before. If you start your business or operations any time after the 15 November, you have 28 days to register from the date of your intention to produce.

To register for a scheme you must provide all the information requested by that scheme. This usually includes business information and contact details, the compliance period you wish to be registered for and information on the EEE produced.

You will be issued with an EEE producer registration number, which you must declare to any distributor you sell or supply EEE to.

You must comply with your scheme's ongoing requirements and provide information - in the requested format - on your total EEE put on the market for reporting requirements and the different categories of EEE produced.

You must keep records of the amount of EEE in tonnes that you have put on the UK market during your compliance period, and how much is to be used in private households or used other than in private households. You must keep these records for at least four years and make them available when requested.

Joining a compliance scheme will cover your obligation to finance the cost of the collection, treatment, recovery and the environmentally sound disposal of waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) from private households or users other than private households that arises during that compliance period.

If your scheme's approval is withdrawn by SEPA, you will have 28 days to register with a new scheme. Alternatively, you can notify SEPA that you intend to join a scheme that is currently in the process of applying for accredited producer compliance scheme approval.

You should provide your scheme with information on any reuse and environmentally sound treatments used for new EEE put on the market.

If you put EEE on the market outside the UK, you must provide the relevant authority with information on the amount of EEE, the categories, and how it is to be used. You must keep these records for four years.

You must apply for a safety certificate if you operate a sports ground in Northern Ireland that has been designated by the Department of Culture, Arts and Leisure (DCAL) as requiring a safety certificate, or if you operate a non-temporary stand at a sports ground which the local district council has determined to be a regulated stand.

Applications should be made by completing an application form available from your local district council. Applications should be accompanied by the following:

  • fee of £100
  • site layout plan
  • structural condition report

You must provide any requested information within the time specified.

You may apply for:

  • a general safety certificate to allow the sports ground to be used for a specified activity or number of activities over an indefinite period
  • a special safety certificate to permit the sports ground to be used for a specified activity or number of activities on specified occasions

To be eligible for a safety certificate you must be in a position to prevent contravention of the terms and conditions of a certificate.

column3: Sports ground safety certificate (England, Scotland and Wales)
column4:
You must hold a safety certificate if you operate a designated sports ground in England, Scotland or Wales that holds more than 10,000 spectators, or a Premier League or Football League ground in England and Wales that holds more than 5,000 spectators.

To obtain an application form for a safety certificate, you should contact the local authority in which your ground is situated. Your application may be subject to a fee.

You may apply for either:

  • a general safety certificate to allow the sports ground to be used for a specified activity or activities over an indefinite period
  • a special safety certificate to permit the sports ground to be used for a specified activity or activities on specified occasions

You will be required to return your application to the local authority with detailed information regarding the structure, capacity and your safety management systems. You may also have to provide a scale plan of the ground and additional information as required. You must provide this within the time specified.

You must comply with the terms and conditions attached to the certificate, such as keeping safety maintenance or attendance records.

You may apply to have your safety certificate amended, replaced or transferred to another suitable person.

If you hold a general safety certificate, you must notify the local authority before extending, or altering the sports ground or installations - for example, by changing the entrances or exits.

You must allow authorised officers to inspect your sports ground and take copies of your records at any reasonable time.

Failure to comply with the safety certificate requirements may result in a fine and/or imprisonment for up to two years.

column3: Pollution prevention and control permit Part B - dry cleaning (Scotland)
column4:
If you operate a dry cleaning facility in Scotland that uses solvents, you must obtain a pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

You must include the following information with your registration form:

  • your business details - including business address, type of business, and any owners
  • an authorised contact to deal with any further questions
  • site plans and maps of the location
  • information on the solvents you use - and the risk levels of them
  • details of the machines you use, how they are maintained and when they were installed
  • staff information - eg training, supervision and qualifications
  • how and where you store the solvents that you use - prior to use, after use and solvent-contaminated materials
  • details of any spot cleaning you undertake

You must return your completed registration form to the relevant SEPA office.

An application fee may be charged.

column3: Consent for discharges to waterways (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you intend to discharge any of the following into a waterway or water contained in any underground strata you must have consent or authorisation from the Department of the Environment (DOE):

  • any trade or sewage effluent
  • any other poisonous, noxious or polluting substance

This does not apply to any discharge which is made from a vessel.

To obtain the correct application form, you should contact the Water Management Unit of the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA), an agency within DOE.

Details of the application must be advertised in the local press. The cost of advertising is the responsibility of the applicant. Guidance on the wording of the advertisement and further instructions will be supplied by DOE.

DOE will consult with a number of bodies during the application process, including:

  • NIEA Natural Heritage Directorate
  • the local district council
  • local NIEA Water Quality field staff
  • Department of Culture, Arts and Leisure (DCAL) Inland Fisheries Division
  • Loughs Agency (for discharges in the Lough Foyle/Carlingford Lough catchments)

You have the right of appeal to the Water Appeals Commission should you not be content with the Department's decision on your application. Details on how to appeal will be included on the covering letter accompanying the decision. 

You must comply with any additional conditions that DOE attach to your consent. A consent issued under the terms of the Water Order may be reviewed by the Department at intervals of not less than 4 years, or at any time at the request of the consent holder.

If you make a discharge any trade or sewage effluent without consent, or breach any condition of a discharge consent, you may be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding £20,000, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months.

Any consent may be revoked by the Department if no discharge has been made under the consent for a period of 12 months.

To make a change to your consent, you must contact DOE for the relevant form or information you must provide. You must also notify the DOE if you intend to transfer the consent to another party.

column3: Controlled waste carrier, broker and dealer registration (England & Wales)
column4:
If you transport controlled waste in Great Britain you need to register with the Environment Agency in England and Wales.

Controlled waste is commercial, industrial and household waste.

If you transport, broker or deal in other people's controlled waste, or your own construction or demolition waste, you must register as an upper tier waste carrier, broker or dealer unless you fall into one of the categories for lower tier waste carriers.

If you had a waste carrier or broker certificate before 29 March 2011, you don't need to do anything. When your certificate is due to be renewed it will be replaced with an upper tier certificate.

You must register as a lower tier waste carrier, broker or dealer if you only carry, arrange the disposal or recovery of, or deal in:

  • animal by-products
  • waste from mines and quarries
  • waste from agricultural premises

You will also need to register in the lower tier if you carry, broker or deal in waste, and are:

  • a waste collection, disposal or regulation authority
  • a charity or voluntary organisation

If you were registered as a professional collector or transporter of waste before 29 March 2011, you do not need to do anything. You will automatically transfer to being a lower tier carrier, broker or dealer.

From the end of December 2013, you will also need to register as a lower tier carrier if you normally and regularly carry controlled waste produced by your own business.

There are some exemptions and exclusions from the need to register.

If you have registered as an upper tier you will receive a certificate of registration. You must produce this certificate when requested to do so. If you have registered as a lower tier you will receive a letter confirming your registration.

If you operate a guard dog kennels you must be registered with your district council.

If your application is successful you will be provided with a certificate of registration.

If you run a sex cinema or sex shop, you may need a licence from the District Council.

A sex cinema is any premises, vehicle, vessel or stall, which is not a dwelling and is used for the exhibition of moving pictures, which are concerned primarily with, or are intended to encourage:

  • sexual activity or acts of force or restraint which are associated with sexual activity
  • genital organs or urinary or excretory functions

The requirement for a licence does not apply to the provision or demonstration of articles to be used mainly for birth control.

You may also apply to the council for the requirement for a licence to be waived. This can either be made as part of an application for a licence, or separately. The council may waive the requirement where it considers that requiring a licence would be inappropriate.

To be eligible to apply for a licence, you must:

  • be at least 18 years old
  • not be disqualified from holding a licence
  • have been resident in the UK at least six months immediately before the application or, if a corporate body, must be incorporated in the UK
  • not have been refused the grant or renewal of a licence for the premises in question within the last 12 months, unless the refusal has been reversed on appeal

Applications must be made in writing and you must supply two copies of each application, which must contain the following information as well as any other details required by the council:

  • if you are applying as an individual - your name, address and age
  • if you are applying as an organisation - the name of the organisation, address of its principal office and the names and addresses of the people responsible for its management
  • either the address of the premises or, if the application relates to a vehicle, vessel or stall, details of where it is to be used as a sex establishment

You must give public notice of the application within seven days by publishing an advertisement in any local newspapers specified by the council, and you must supply the council with a copy of every advertisement published.

If the application is for premises, you must display notice of it for 21 days - beginning with the date of the application - in a place where it can be conveniently read by the public on or near the premises. This notice must identify the premises or specify where it will be used as a sex establishment.

Once you have been granted a licence, you must exhibit a copy of the licence and any regulations under which it is held, in a place specified in the licence.

A licence will usually be valid for one year, although it may be granted for less time. You must comply with any standard conditions that the council prescribes for sex establishments, which may relate to opening hours, advertising and visibility.

You must not:

  • employ anyone who is disqualified from holding a licence
  • employ, or allow onto the premises, someone who is under 18 years old
  • contravene, or permit the contravention of, any term, condition or restriction specified in the licence

If you fail to comply, you may be fined up to £20,000.

You must allow a constable or an authorised officer of the council entry to your premises, if they have a warrant.

You must apply for approval from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) if you want to:

  • market a new unapproved pesticide - commercial level approval
  • carry out research and development work on a pesticide - experimental approval
  • import a pesticide into the UK identical to an approved pesticide - parallel import approval
  • extend the use of an approved pesticide - specific off label approval

DARD's approval process follows that of the Chemicals Regulations Directorate (CRD) who issue approvals for Great Britain.

If you operate any of the following meat establishments, you need approval from the Food Standards Agency (FSA):

  • slaughterhouse
  • farm slaughter facility
  • game handling establishment
  • cutting plant

When co-located with any of the plants listed above, the following establishments also need approval from the FSA:

  • minced meat, meat preparations and mechanically separated meat establishment
  • processing plant
  • cold store
  • re-wrapping establishment

However, if these establishments are not co-located with a slaughterhouse, cutting plant etc you need food premises approval from your District Council.

Application forms for meat plant approval are available on the FSA website. Your application should be accompanied by documents including a site plan and information about your operation.

You don't need to pay a fee when applying for approval.

If you need any help or advice in completing the application form, you can contact the FSA Approvals Team on Tel 02890 417759.

The Veterinary Public Health Unit of the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD VPHU) carry out some functions on behalf of the FSA in Northern Ireland.

An officer from DARD VPHU will be responsible for assessing your application and will make an appointment to inspect your premises and will make a recommendation to FSA in Northern Ireland regarding the suitability of your establishment for approval.

If you operate a meat plant without approval, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

Approved slaughterhouses and cutting plants require additional authorisation to remove  certain specified risk material (SRM) from cattle, sheep or goats, including:

  • the vertebral columns from cattle
  • the spinal cords from sheep and goats aged over 12 months or which have a permanent incisor erupted through the gum

If you intend to trade from a fixed pitch on a street (stationary trader) or from various streets within a certain district (mobile trader) you need a street trading licence from the relevant district council.

You don't need a licence if you are trading:

  • under a pedlar's certificate by visits from house to house
  • as a door-to-door salesman
  • at an established market or fair
  • as a news vendor selling newspapers or magazines from a holder which is carried
  • by conducting a authorised public collection for charity

Application forms should be available to download from your district council website or you may be able to apply online.

You must have reached school leaver's age to apply for a licence.

Your application should be accompanied by an application fee set by the district council (these vary from area to area).

You may also be required to provide two photographs of yourself and any other documents requested, such as a public liability insurance certificate.

Your local authority may only refuse your application on certain statutory grounds, such as if the location is unsuitable or you make false statements in your application.

If granted, your licence will specify:

  • where you can trade (ie your trading pitch or the area(s) within the district)
  • the days and times during which you are allowed to trade
  • the description of goods or services you are allowed to sell
  • the size and type of stall, vehicle, container, etc you may use for your trade
  • how goods, stalls, containers, etc must be stored
  • how refuse must be dealt with

Your name and licence number must be prominently displayed on your stall, vehicle, container, etc.

A licence is valid for up to three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

You must carry your licence with you at all times when you are trading and must produce it for inspection if requested to do so.

You may be required to pay charges for refuse collection, street cleaning or other services provided by the council.

You may employ someone to assist you without having to obtain a separate licence for them. However, they must also comply with any conditions attached to the licence.

A district council may also issue temporary licences. These licences will last no more than seven days and are normally only granted for special events or festivals. You may not be granted more than five temporary licences in a year.

If you fail to obtain a licence when required to do so, or to comply with any conditions attached to that licence, your goods, vehicle, stalls, etc may be forfeited and you may be fined up to £1,000. Your licence may also be revoked for persistently failing to comply with conditions or paying fees or charges due to the council.

If you are selling food, you will also need to be registered as a food business with your local authority.

If you are run a large shop (ie one which has more than 280 square metres retail floor space), you may only open for trade on Sundays between the hours of 13.00 and 18.00.

However, if you run a large shop that is situated in a holiday resort you may give notice to the district council for that area specifying up to 18 Sundays in a year where your shop will be exempt from that rule.

This exemption only applies to Sundays (other than Easter Sunday) that fall between 1 March and 30 September in any calendar year.

Contact your local district council for a notification form or visit their website to notify them online. No fee is payable.

You must notify your district council of the dates of the Sundays you would like to open. The notification will take effect 14 days after the date it is given, unless your district council agrees that it should come into effect earlier.

If the area where your shop is located has not been designated as a holiday resort you can't use this exemption. Contact your local district council for more information on how areas are designated as holiday resorts.

If you open outside permitted hours on a Sunday without notifying the council, you could be fined up to £50,000.

If you operate a domiciliary care service in Northern Ireland, you must comply with the Minimum Standards for Domiciliary Care Agencies, The Domiciliary Care Agencies Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007 and be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

If you wish to operate or manage more than one service, you must make a separate application for each organisation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a registration.

If you fail to comply with the requirements, you may commit an offence.

If you wish to transport or convey gas from one place to another through a pipeline in Northern Ireland, you must be licensed by the Utility Regulator.

Full details of the documents and particulars to be provided, along with a sample application form, can be found in the Gas (Applications for Licences and Extensions) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1996 on the Legislation.gov.uk website.

You may also request that a licence is exclusive, ie that no one else can carry out operations of the type you are authorised to carry out or within the area you are authorised to operate in for a period specified by the Utility Regulator (but not exceeding 20 years). However, if you apply for an exclusive licence you will have to provide reasons for this in your application.

You must pay an application fee of £800.

Within 14 days of making your application, you must place a notice - including a copy of the application - in the Belfast Gazette and in a local newspaper for each area where you intend to operate. You should send a copy of each notice to the Utility Regulator as soon as possible after it is published.

The Utility Regulator will review applications within one month of receipt. The criteria against which your application will be reviewed are available on the Utility Regulator's website.

If the Utility Regulator is satisfied that your application should be granted, a notification of intent will be placed on their website and a consultation will run for at least 28 days.

You will be notified of the Utility Regulator's decision at the end of the consultation period. 

If your licence is granted, it will subject to a range of standard and bespoke conditions.

Your authorisation will be valid for the period specified in the licence.

As well as a conveyance licence you also need consent from the Utility Regulator to construct a pipeline exceeding seven kilometres in length and with a design operating pressure exceeding seven bar gauge.

Alternatively, if you intend to use pipelines forming part of the gas transmission network to convey gas, you also need to apply to the Utility Regulator for certification once your licence is granted. 

If you operate without a licence or outside the terms of your licence or make false statements in your licence application, you are committing an offence and may be faced with an unlimited fine.

If you wish to excavate under any public road, footway or footpath, you must have a valid road opening permit issued by your local authority.

Your application must be made through your local authority and a fee may be payable.

If your work could possibly affect the apparatus of any statutory undertakers then you will be given details of this apparatus and you must give written notice of your application to these undertakers.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a consent issued by the local authority.

column3: Authorisation to use university in an institution's title (Scotland)
column4:
If you operate an educational institution and you wish to use 'University' in the title of your institution, you must have consent to do so from the Privy Council.

You must also meet specific criteria in order to be eligible.
Specific risk material (SRM) must only be removed at slaughterhouses or cutting plants approved by the Food Standards Agency (FSA).
Specific risk material (SRM) must only be removed at slaughterhouses or cutting plants approved by the Food Standards Agency (FSA).

The European Union Emissions Trading System applies to the following business activities:

  • combustion installations with a rated thermal input exceeding 20 megawatts eg operating boilers, electricity generators and combined heat and power (CHP) schemes
  • metal ore (including sulphide ore) or sintering installation
  • iron and steel businesses
  • mineral oil refineries
  • coke ovens
  • the mineral industry (cement, glass, ceramics, lime production)
  • production of pulp from timber or other fibrous materials
  • paper and board with a production capacity greater than 20 tonnes per day
  • nitric acid production

If you carry out any of these activities you must hold a greenhouse gas emissions permit from one of the following regulators:

  • the Environment Agency in England and Wales
  • the Scottish Environment Protection Agency in Scotland
  • the Industrial Pollution and Radiochemical Inspectorate department of the Northern Ireland Environment Agency in Northern Ireland

Once you have a permit, you may be eligible to an allocation of free emissions allowances.

Applications for the permit must be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

Applications must include:

  • a description of the installation and site and its address and national grid reference and the name of the local authority or authorities the installation is situated in
  • the emissions-generating activities to be carried out in the installation including a description of the technology used and the materials used in carrying out those activities
  • the sources of specified emissions from the relevant activities
  • a description of planned measures to monitor and report specified emissions
  • a description, including the reference number, of any environmental licence issued in relation to the installation
  • any further information which the applicant wishes the regulator to take into account
  • the name, address and telephone number of the applicant, the correspondence address if different, the registered number and the registered or principal office address if the business is a registered company and the name and address of the ultimate holding company if the applicant is a subsidiary
  • a non-technical summary of the installation information

You must provide any other information requested by the regulator.

The regulator will decide your application within two months of the date the application was received. Conditions will be attached to a permit.

You will not be granted a permit if the regulator believes that you will not be the person operating the installation or that you will ensure that monitoring and reporting conditions will be met.

Where an application is for a permit to operate more than one installation, the application must contain the required information in relation to each installation.

You must comply with all of the conditions contained in the permit. Your regulator may review the conditions of the permit at any time. You are required to notify the regulator when you cannot comply with conditions.

Conditions will include requirements to monitor and report on emissions, including specifying the frequency of monitoring and methods used and that annual reports are submitted. Conditions will requiree you to surrender allowances that are equal to your reportable emissions within four months of the end of the scheme year when the emissions took place.

If you fail to comply with requirements you may commit a criminal offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both. In addition there may be civil financial penalties for excess emissions or understating reportable emissions. If you fail to pay required fees your permit may be revoked.
column5: The regulator may serve you with an enforcement notice detailing any breaches and how these should be remedied.

column3: Issue certificates of design or construction (Scotland)
column4:
If you want to issue certificates of design or certificates of construction, you must be either:

  • appointed directly by the Scottish Ministers as an approved certifier of design or of construction
  • a member of a scheme that has been approved by the Scottish Ministers

If you offer driving tuition for payment, you must be registered with the Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA).

In order to be registered you must:

  • Be the holder of a current driving licence - either from Northern Ireland or granted under the corresponding law in Great Britain - or a Community Licence which authorises you to drive in Northern Ireland.
  • Have held the driving licence or a relevant equivalent for a total of at least four years within the last six years.
  • Not have been disqualified from driving for any part of the four years preceding the date of your application.
  • Be a 'fit and proper' person to have your name entered in the Register. Each applicant is subject to a Criminal History Check carried out by Access Northern Ireland (ANI). All spent and unspent convictions, motoring and non-motoring, will be taken into account when the Registrar assesses your suitability to be entered on the Register.

In order to pass the qualifying examination, you must pass the three components of the test in the following order:

  • theory test - which consists of a test of driving theory followed by a hazard perception test
  • driving ability and fitness test - which consists of a test of eyesight and driving technique
  • instructional ability and fitness test - in which you must give practical driving instruction to an examiner as if the examiner were a pupil

The whole examination must be completed within two years of passing the theory test.

For the driving ability and fitness test or the instructional ability and fitness test, you must provide a vehicle that conforms to the required standards.

For an instructional ability and fitness test, your vehicle must have an appropriate insurance policy that covers both you and the examiner.

Before the test you must produce a licence authorising you to drive a motor vehicle of the appropriate class and, if the licence does not contain a photograph of you, an approved document as evidence of your identity.

Once you have passed the examination, you must pay the appropriate fee and apply to DVA to have your name entered on the Register within 12 months of passing the qualifying examination.

Your application must include:

  • a completed Registration application form
  • a completed Access NI application form
  • two colour photographs

At all times when giving paid instruction, the certificate must be displayed either on your person or in the car you use for tuition in such a position and manner as to be plainly and distinctly visible.

Once you are registered, you will, when required by the Registrar, be asked to undergo continued ability and fitness tests, which consist of an examiner being present whilst you are instructing a pupil. If you are unsuccessful, you must retake the test within fourteen weeks.

If you wish to practise as an advocate in Scotland - equivalent to a barrister in England and Wales - you must:

  • hold a degree in Scottish law from a Scottish university
  • obtain the Diploma in Legal Practice from a Scottish university
  • complete at least 21 months continuous training in an approved solicitor's office on the same basis as a trainee solicitor
  • be admitted to the Faculty of Advocates

The first stage of admission to the Faculty is to apply to be an 'intrant' - ie a candidate for admission. You must apply to the Court of Session and the Faculty. Forms are available from the Faculty and you must pay court and matriculation fees of £330. Your application should be made by the end of the year before the year in which you wish to start your pupillage.
  
You must then sit an entrance exam in evidence, practice and procedure.

If you pass the exam you will be expected to start a period of pupillage (known in Scotland as 'devilling') in October of the same year. Devilling comprises a mix of compulsory skills training courses and time spent working with a practising advocate of at least seven years' standing (known as a 'devilmaster').

The onus is on you to contact a prospective devilmaster. If you encounter difficulties, the Clerk of Faculty can assist you.

You will be expected to attend court and consultations with instructing solicitors with your devilmaster. You will also discuss the preparation and presentation of cases and draft written pleadings and opinions.

Devilling lasts between eight and nine months and your admission to the Faculty depends on your devilmaster certifying that you are a fit and proper person to be an advocate and that you have been involved in a wide range of work. Your competence in various aspects of written and oral advocacy will already have been assessed during devilling.

If you successfully complete devilling, you will be admitted as a member of the Faculty. You will be required to pay entry money of £850 upfront or £1,000 by instalment to the Faculty.

The Regulations as to Intrants - these are the rules governing the admission process to becoming an advocate - can be downloaded from the Faculty of Advocates website.

If you intend to practise as a barrister in Northern Ireland, you must:

  • hold an approved law degree
  • hold the Degree of Barrister-at-Law from the Institute of Professional Legal Studies at Queen's University Belfast
  • be called to the Bar of Northern Ireland

Once called to the Bar, you must complete a 12-month pupillage (or other period as directed) with either:

  • a barrister in independent practice of not less than seven years' standing
  • a barrister nominated by the Executive Council of the Inn of Court of Northern Ireland (through its Education Committee)

In general, you must not conduct any case or part of a case until you have completed to the satisfaction of the Education Committee six months' pupillage.

Once your pupillage has ended you must complete a minimum of 12 hours of continuing professional development each year.

If you provide indoor entertainment at your premises, you must be licensed by your local district council.

Licences are required for:

  • theatrical performances
  • dancing, singing, music or other similar forms of entertainment
  • circus performances
  • public contests, matches, exhibitions or displays of boxing, wrestling, judo, karate, billiards, pool, snooker, darts or similar sports and games

The licence will be required where, in return for payment, people are admitted to your premises to observe or take part in the above forms of entertainment, or to be supplied with refreshments. However, this does not apply to a licensed cinema or an educational institution.

The requirement to register does not apply to music or singing during the course of religious worship.

Licences are also required for outdoor musical performances that are wholly or mainly held in the open air and on private land. However, certain activities are exempt from this requirement, including garden fetes, sporting or athletic events, and exhibitions or displays where music or singing is incidental to the main activities.

Subject to certain exceptions, you may only provide machines for entertainment, or equipment for games such as billiards, pool or snooker, in accordance with the terms of an entertainment licence.

Applications must be submitted in writing and you must supply three copies of the application in the prescribed form, with each one containing the required information and a copy of any plans, certificates or other documents that the council requires. Applications must be accompanied by the statutory fee.

You must give public notice of the application within seven days, by publishing an advertisement in the local newspapers specified by the council. This requirement does not apply to an educational institution, or a church hall or similar building occupied for public religious worship.

If you make an application for premises for which construction hasn't been completed, the council may grant the licence subject to a condition that it has no effect until confirmed by them.

Licenses will usually be valid for one year, although the council may grant licences for either 14 specified days or for any 14 days within a 12 month period.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence. These include conditions for regulating conduct and times of use, and may include provisions such as securing adequate fire precautions and preventing disturbance.

If you fail to comply, you may be fined up to £5000.

You must allow a constable or authorised officer of either the council or the Fire and Rescue Service Board entry to your premises if they require it and have a warrant.

To move animals onto a holding, you need a general or specific movement licence from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

Any animal moved under licence must be kept separate throughout the movement from any animal not being moved under that licence, eg if the animals are unloaded before reaching their ultimate destination or if animals are being moved under difference licences.

You must not move any bovine animal, goat, pig, sheep, deer, llama or alpaca from a holding if another animal has been moved on to the holding during the previous six days - known as the standstill period - unless the other animal is put into isolation or the movement was licensed by DARD.

You must not move an animal into - or out of - a licensed isolated facility except under licence from DARD.

Dealers
Dealers may move livestock to - or from - trading premises provided that:

  • the movement is made under DARD licence
  • the animal is moved directly from the trading premises to its destination within six days of its arrival at the trading premises, and provided that the destination is not a market, collecting centre, other trading premises or place used for sale or trade of animals
  • record keeping requirements are met

Dealers must keep the following records:

  • registration number of the vehicle used and name of person transporting the animal
  • the name, address, and holding number of the seller, the date of purchase, breed and gender of the animal
  • the name, address and holding number of the purchaser
  • the date of sale, breed and gender of the animal and its premises of destination
  • the individual animal identification number

Records must be kept in a permanent and legible form and retained for the following periods:

  • three years for pigs
  • four years for sheep or goats
  • ten years for bovine animals, llama or alpaca
