These records must be produced for a DARD inspector upon request. In addition, you may be required to provide your name and address.

If you move cattle onto - or from - your holding, you must give notification of the movement to the British Cattle Movement Service (BCMS).

You do not have to apply for a licence to move cattle, but you must comply with the General Licence for the Movement of Cattle (GLMC).

You must inform BCMS within three days of moving an animal on or off a holding. If moved off a holding, you must record the date in the animal's passport, sign it, and pass the identification document - except the notice of registration - to the transporter. You must not move an animal that does not have a valid passport.

You must not move any cattle from an area if it has only been moved there within the last six days. You must not move an animal to a slaughterhouse unless it is within 48 hours of its slaughter.

You must inspect all animals before you move them, and any evidence of disease must be reported to your Divisional Veterinary Manager.

If you receive any animal on your holding you must make sure the identification documents are given to you and you must record in the passport within 36 hours of the animal's arrival:

  • the date of its arrival
  • the holding number
  • your name and address
  • your signature

If you import an animal from outside Great Britain, it may only be moved from its entry point to a holding if it has a passport and a movement document. Keepers must record all information within 36 hours of arrival.

If you export any animal to a non-European Union country, you must send the passport to the BCMS within seven days of its export. Animals must not enter markets unless accompanied by their identification documents, a passport issued in another country or a movement document.

Cattle keepers must also keep up to date herd registers for each holding and include the following information:

  • official eartag number
  • dam official eartag number
  • date of birth
  • sex
  • date of movements on and off holding
  • details of where the animal has moved to or from
  • keeper details of whom cattle were sent to, received from, breed, date of death

The register must be completed within 36 hours of a movement, within seven days of a death and within seven days of a birth in a dairy herd or 30 days of the birth of any other calf.

You must keep the register for ten years if you are a cattle keeper or three years in any other case from the end of the calendar year when the last entry was made.

You must also ensure that you comply with cattle tagging regulations, apply for passports and notify births and deaths to the BCMS.

If you operate a day care setting for children under the age of eight years on non-domestic premises for more than two hours in any one day and more than five days per year in Wales, you must be registered with Care and Social Services Inspectorate Wales (CSSIW).

Applications for registration must contain specific information and on you, your premises, any person who may be on your premises, and your arrangements for day care.

Registration may be refused if you don't comply with certain criteria, and will be refused if you are disqualified from registration - eg if you are barred from regulated activity relating to children. If registration is granted, you must comply with any conditions attached to the registration.

At any time, CSSIW can notify you of any action you must take to ensure compliance with the requirement to register, registration conditions, legislation, regulations or the National Minimum Standards for Regulated Child Care.

Failure to comply with the above may result in enforcement action.

To manufacture explosives, including fireworks, in Northern Ireland, you require a licence from the Secretary of State.

If you manufacture explosives, you must:

  • take steps to prevent fires and explosions, and protect people from the effects of fire or explosion
  • separate buildings with explosives from inhabited buildings

If you dispose of explosives, you must ensure that they are disposed of safely.

If you decontaminate explosive-contaminated items, you must ensure they are decontaminated safely.

You must not permit anyone under the age of 16 years to work in your manufacturing business. You must only allow someone aged 16 or 17 years old to work in your business if they are being supervised.

Exceptions to the requirement for a licence include:

  • manufacturing 100 grams or less of explosives for laboratory analysis, testing, demonstration or experimentation
  • manufacturing certain ammunitions to be used at historical re-enactment events
  • preparing and assembling of fireworks at the place of intended use
  • preparing and assembling of explosives for use in theatrical, television or cinematic special effects
  • mixing for immediate use of certain substances at a mine or quarry, to produce an explosive which is not cap-sensitive
  • using desensitised explosives in the manufacture of products which are not in themselves explosive

Applications must be made to the Secretary of State on an approved form and a fee may be payable. You must comply with any conditions of the licence, which will include specifications of the site and, within it, the places where the explosives may be manufactured and the maximum quantity of explosives which may be manufactured or present at any one time.

In certain situations, the licence will only be granted after a public hearing. In this case, you will be issued with a draft licence containing the proposed conditions. Within 28 days of receiving the draft licence, you must:

  • publish in a local newspaper a notice which gives details of the application, invites representations on matters affecting the health and safety of persons, and gives the address where the manufacture is proposed, at which a copy of the application and draft licence may be inspected
  • take reasonable steps to give this information to every person who resides or works within the public consultation zone

You will only be granted a licence if the place in which explosives are proposed to be manufactured is suitable for that purpose, and if you are a fit person to manufacture explosives.

If your licence is revoked, you must ensure that:

  • all explosives are removed from the site as soon as is practicable
  • those explosives are deposited at a site which is licensed or registered for such storage, or are suitably disposed of
  • the licence or certificate of registration is returned to the Secretary of State within 28 days of the revocation taking effect

If you operate a petrol filling station in Northern Ireland, whether or not the petrol is dispensed for retail purposes, you need a licence from your district council.

Contact your council for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

You need to pay an application fee which ranges from £41 to £118 per year, depending on how much petrol you store.

A licence will state to whom it is issued, how long it is valid for (usually one year) and any conditions that are attached - eg alterations to the premises, notification of spills and other incidents or record keeping.

If you operate a petrol filling station without a licence or fail to comply with the conditions of your licence, you could be fined up to £1,000. Your petrol and tanks may also be confiscated.

You may be refused a licence if you have a history of persistent offending for safety breaches in relation to petroleum licensing.

column3: House in multiple occupation registration (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you let a house in multiple occupation (HMO) in Northern Ireland, you must register with the Northern Ireland Housing Executive (NIHE) under the House in Multiple Occupation Statutory Registration Scheme.

Registration is for five years and renewals for further periods of five years can be made.

Registration and renewal fees are payable.

You must:

  • ensure the property is not overcrowded
  • adhere to the HMO Management regulations
  • ensure the property is fit for the number of occupants, ie there is enough cooking space and space to store and prepare food, toilets and washing facilities for all the occupants
  • provide adequate fire escapes and other fire precautions

You must provide the NIHE with any information they require in relation to your HMO.

If the NIHE believe that your HMO is overcrowded you may be served with an overcrowding notice which will detail the overcrowding and will prevent you from overcrowding the premises. You may appeal to the Magistrates' Court against any such notice within 21 days of it being served. If you fail to comply with a notice you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to provide information requested by the NIHE after being served with an overcrowding notice, or provide false information, you may commit an offence and be fined up to £500. The NIHE may also limit the number of people permitted to live in your HMO. If you fail to comply with the limit you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £2,500.

If you fail to provide information to the NIHE in relation to your HMO you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £1,000 or £5,000 if you provide false information.

If you fail to provide adequate cooking and wash facilities or adequate fire escapes and other fire precautions you may be served with a notice by the NIHE detailing work that must be done to remedy the failure. You may appeal to the Magistrates' Court against such a notice on certain grounds within 21 days of the notice being served. If you fail to carry out any works the NIHE may carry out the works for you and the expenses for doing so may be recovered from you.

If you give an undertaking to the NIHE that a part of the HMO won't be used for human occupation and fail to comply with this undertaking you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £5,000 and up to one tenth of the fine paid every day that you continue to breach the undertaking after you are convicted.

column3: Camping and caravanning exemption certificates (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
A camping or touring caravan exemption certificate is a certificate which, in certain circumstances, allows a recreational organisation to camp or caravan on land without a site licence or the need to apply for planning permission.

Applications in England are made to Natural England and in Wales and Scotland to their respective Regional Assemblies.

Online applications, using the form on the Natural England website, can be made for Scotland and Wales and these will be forwarded to the relevant Regional Assembly.

If you move cattle onto - or from - your holding, you must give notification of the movement with the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) either in writing or online.

Notification must be made within three days of the movement.

If you act as a conveyancer in Scotland, you must be registered with the Law Society of Scotland (LSS).

Conveyancing is the legal process of buying and selling property and conveyancers are solicitors who specialise in all aspects of property law.

Contact the LSS for a registration form.

In order to become registered you will need to show the LSS that you are:

  • properly qualified
  • a 'fit and proper person' to act as a conveyancer (eg don't have any criminal convictions for fraud, theft etc)

When you send your application, you must include all supporting documents that the LSS requests.

You must also pay a registration fee.

The LSS may attach conditions to your registration.

As a conveyancer you must comply with rules regarding:

  • general standards of conduct
  • conflicts of interest
  • conduct of conveyancing transactions
  • client accounts and interest on clients' money
  • record keeping
  • complaint handling and satisfaction of claims
  • continuing professional development activities

If you practise as a conveyancer without registering you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to comply with any rules of conduct you may be found guilty of professional misconduct.

If you wish to store gas in a gas storage facility in Northern Ireland, you must be licensed by the Utility Regulator.

You should enclose the following with your application:

  • copies of your annual accounts, auditors' reports and interim accounts
  • copies of your Memorandum and Articles of Association
  • details of your expertise, and the expertise of any sub-contractors you intend to use, in carrying out operations of this type
  • a scale map showing the proposed location of the gas storage facility
  • a development plan
  • details of your safety mechanisms and procedures
  • details of your proposed arrangements for complying with the standard licensing conditions and any modifications requested to those conditions
  • an application fee

You must place a notice - including a copy of the application - in the Belfast Gazette and in a local newspaper for each area where you intend to operate. You should send a copy of each notice to the Utility Regulator as soon as possible after it is published.

The Utility Regulator has also set out criteria that will be used to assess licence applications. Following a review and consultation process the Utility Regulator will notify the applicant of the decision to grant a licence or not.

If a gas storage licence is granted it will subject to a range of standard and special conditions.

If you deposit, keep, treat or dispose of waste in Northern Ireland, you may need a waste management licence (WML) from the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA).

This includes in - or on - land, via a mobile plant and permitting such activities.

You can apply online or use a paper form available from NIEA. You must provide all the information requested in the form, including:

  • any maps or plans
  • site references
  • planning permissions
  • relevant previous convictions
  • financial provision
  • descriptions of how your site is used

You should contact NIEA to discuss your proposals before completing the application.

If you fail to provide enough information, NIEA may return, refuse or postpone your application.

You (or someone else in management of your business) must also prove that they are technically competent, by holding the relevant certificate from the Waste Management Industry Training and Advisory Board (WAMITAB). If you are awaiting a relevant WAMITAB certificate, NIEA may still approve your application. However, you must produce the certificate within two years of your application.

NIEA may require you to carry out certain works before issuing your licence. They may also issue a notice to anyone else that has an interest in the land - eg the land owner, lessee or occupier - informing of their intention to grant a WML. These people can then make representations to NIEA in response.

NIEA will not grant a licence if you do not have planning permission or water discharge consent when it is needed. You should obtain these before you consider applying.

Your licence may have specific conditions attached to it, depending on your type of waste management - eg hazardous or putrescible waste. If you dispose of waste, your licence will have limits or guidance for the following:

  • types and quantities of waste
  • technical requirements
  • security precautions you must take
  • the waste treatment site
  • treatment methods for waste

You will be subject to periodic inspections by NIEA. You will also be required to keep records of quantity, nature, origin, destination and frequency of collection, mode of transport and treatment method of any waste which is disposed of or recovered at your site. NIEA can request these records at any time.

Some activities may be exempt from a licence and or require a registered exemption instead. To register an exemption, you must include information specific to your type of waste activity.

To surrender a WML, you must complete and return the relevant form to NIEA and pay a fee.

column3: House to house charitable collections licence (Northern Ireland)
column4:
To promote or make charitable house to house collections in Northern Ireland, you require a licence from the Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI). Apply to the PSNI station in the area in which the collection is to be made.

Limited exceptions apply when a licence will not be required.

To operate as a slaughterman in Northern Ireland, you must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

This applies to anyone who:

  • stuns, slaughters or kills animals
  • restrains animals for the purpose of stunning, slaughtering or killing
  • piths stunned animals
  • shackles or hoists stunned animals
  • bleeds animals which are not dead
  • assesses effective stunning or killing

However, you don't need a licence to:

  • kill an animal in an emergency - eg where it's in distress
  • slaughter your own animals for private consumption
  • slaughter or kill for a non-commercial purpose
  • kill animals as a means of notifiable disease control in accordance with the specific requirements of the regulations
  • shoot animals in the field
  • dislocate the necks of or decapitate poultry on agricultural premises where the birds were raised
  • kill surplus chicks or embryos in hatchery waste
  • shackle birds before stunning
  • operate automatic equipment that stuns, slaughters or kills animals - as long as this doesn't require you to carry out any of the above activities for which a licence is required
  • slaughter or kill animals under veterinary supervision

Before applying for a licence, you must obtain a certificate of competence from a veterinary surgeon authorised by DARD. You must satisfy them that you:

  • are able to carry out such activities without causing considerable avoidable pain, suffering or excitement to any animal
  • have sufficient knowledge of the Welfare of Animals (Slaughter or Killing) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1996 and other legislation, as well as any supporting codes of practice
  • are fit and proper to hold a certificate
  • are not below the age of 18

If you are applying for a provisional slaughterman licence, you don't need a certificate of competence, but you must satisfy an authorised veterinary surgeon that you are fit and proper and at least 18 years old. Under a provisional licence, you may only work in the presence of a full licence holder, covering the same species, operations and equipment or a veterinary surgeon.

You must notify DARD if you have been refused a licence to slaughter animals, had a licence revoked or been convicted under any animal welfare legislation.

If you are applying for a full slaughterman licence, you must also enclose:

  • your certificate of competence
  • two passport sized photographs, with your name in block capitals on the back of each

No fee is payable for a certificate of competence, provisional licence or full licence.

Application forms can be downloaded from the DARD website or you can apply online. The same form is used to apply for a certificate of competence, provisional licence or full licence.

If granted, your licence will state which operations you are licensed to carry out, which species of animal you may carry out operations on and the equipment or instruments you can use.

Additional requirements apply to the slaughter and killing of animals other than at a slaughterhouse or knacker's yard.

The slaughter of animals without stunning to meet Jewish and Muslim religious requirements must only be carried out in approved slaughterhouses.

If you wish to slaughter animals for food using the Jewish religious method (shechita), instead of a certificate of competence you may obtain a licence from the Rabbinical Commission for the Licensing of Shochetim in England and Wales or the Chief Rabbi in Scotland. You must then submit this with your application for a slaughterman licence.

If you fail to comply with these requirements, you may be fined and/or i
column5: mprisoned.

column4:
If you operate an egg packing centre in Scotland, you must be registered with the Scottish Ministers. You should contact the Scottish Government's Egg Marketing Inspectorate for registration.

To qualify for registration, your premises must have:

  • suitable candling equipment continuously staffed to allow the quality of each egg to be examined separately
  • a device for measuring the air cell
  • a machine for grading eggs by weight
  • one or more approved balances for weighing eggs
  • equipment for marking eggs with a producer code

Authorisation will be granted providing your equipment is of the required standard.

Your premises must be approved separately as a food business by your local authority before you can start trading.

Failure to comply with this requirement may result in a fine.

column3: Approval of places for civil marriages (Scotland)
column4:
If you wish to hold civil marriage ceremonies on your land or premises, that place must be approved by the local authority for the area where it is situated.

A boat or other vessel used to hold civil ceremonies in Scottish waters must also be approved by the relevant local authority.

You should contact the relevant local authority for an application form and return the completed form with a plan of your premises, the application fee and any additional information required by the authority. Application and renewal fees are set locally.

You may apply for permanent (period) approval which will last for up to three years, or temporary approval which is valid for a specific date.

You must comply with any conditions attached to an approval,. eg that the sale or consumption of food and drink should be kept separate from where the civil marriage ceremony takes place.

If you fail to comply with any conditions of approval or your place becomes unsuitable to host civil marriage ceremonies, your approval may be suspended or revoked.

To store explosives in Northern Ireland, you require a licence or a certificate of registration.

The requirement for a certificate of registration applies where you wish to store at one site no more than one of the following, at any one time:

  • 30 kilograms of explosives of any hazard type
  • 100 kilograms of Hazard Type 3 explosives or of a combination of Hazard Type 3 and Hazard Type 4 explosives
  • 250 kilograms of Hazard Type 4 explosives
  • 250 kilograms of small arms ammunition and percussion caps and 30 kilograms of shooters' powder

If you wish to store more than the above amounts of explosive, or a combination of types of explosive, then you will require a licence. However, certain amounts of certain types of explosives are exempt from the requirement for a licence or registration.

If you store explosives, you must:

  • take steps to prevent fires and explosions and protect people from the effects of fire or explosion
  • separate buildings with explosives from inhabited buildings

If you dispose of explosives, you must ensure they are disposed of safely.

If you decontaminate explosive-contaminated items, you must ensure that they are decontaminated safely.

You must not permit anyone under the age of 16 years to work in your storage business. You must only allow someone aged 16 or 17 years old to work in your business if they are being supervised.

You must ensure that the relevant separation distance, as specified in schedule 1 of the Manufacture and Storage of Explosives Regulations 2006, is maintained between the store and another specified building or place which is not within that site. You must maintain a separation distance of half of the specified amount between a store and any building on that site which is used either for accommodation or for work, other than work buildings which are normally unoccupied.

There are exceptions to the requirement for separation distance where the total quantities of explosives stored are below a certain amount and are stored in a safe and suitable place with all due precautions for public safety.

Applications must be made to the Secretary of State on an approved form. You must comply with any conditions of the licence, which will include specifications of the site and, within it, the places where the explosives may be stored and the maximum quantity of explosives which may be stored or otherwise present at any one time.

Where the licence relates to the storage of pyrotechnic articles at any site where those articles are to be offered for sale, conditions may also relate to the:

  • storage and display of pyrotechnic articles in areas where they can be purchased
  • prevention of risk of fire arising in respect of the pyrotechnic articles
  • safe use of fire escapes in that area

In certain situations, the licence will only be granted after a public hearing. In this case, you will be issued with a draft licence containing the proposed conditions. Within 28 days of receiving the draft licence, you must:

  • publish in a local newspaper a notice which gives details of the application, invites representations on matters affecting the health and safety of persons, and gives the address where the storage is proposed, at which a copy of the application and draft licence may be inspected
  • take other reasonable steps to give that information to every person who resides or works within the public consultation zone

You will only be granted a licence if the place in which explosives are proposed to be stored is suitable for that purpose, and if you are a fit person to store explosives.

To transport animals on journeys of over 65 kilometres in connection with economic activity, you require transporter authorisation from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD). A 'journey' is the time from when the first animal is loaded into the transport until when the last animal is unloaded at the final destination.

You will not need an authorisation if you are transporting animals not in connection to an economic activity - eg, not for business purposes.

If all of the journeys that you undertake last no more than 8 hours, you should apply to DARD for a short journey authorisation. For information on how to apply you should email DARD at transportwelfare@dardni.gov.uk.

If any journey is likely to take longer than eight hours, or if you transport animals by ship or air for any part of the journey, you must apply to DARD for a long journey authorisation.

To apply for either type of authorisation, your business must be established in Northern Ireland. You must also be able to prove that you have appropriate equipment and procedures for the safe transport of animals, and that your staff are correctly trained. You must also ensure that anyone involved in the transport of animals has no record of animal welfare offences in the last three years.

Authorisations last for five years and DARD may attach additional conditions to the authorisation. If your circumstances change, you must notify DARD within 15 working days.

If you transport horses, livestock or poultry by road only, your drivers or attendants must also hold a Certificate of Competence. For long journey authorisations, your drivers or attendants must be listed on your application form.

Transporters of species other than horses, livestock and poultry do not have to hold Certificates of competence.

For long journeys, in addition to your authorisation you must also have:

  • a vehicle approval certificate
  • procedures in place to trace and record vehicle movements
  • contingency plans to deal with emergencies

To transport farm livestock and horses on journeys in excess of eight hours, your vehicle must be inspected and approved by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

You do not need vehicle approval if you are transporting any other species within the UK and your journey is less than 12 hours. However, if you are transporting these animals to another European Union member state, you will need vehicle approval if any member state you pass through requires it.

Vehicle requirements vary depending on the species of the animal you are transporting, although all inspections will check that the vehicle is:

  • designed, constructed and operated to a suitable standard to avoid injury or undue suffering
  • strong enough to withstand movement stresses
  • secure enough to prevent escape and to ensure the safety of animals
  • accessible for the inspection and treatment of animals
  • large enough to provide ventilation, protection from weather and appropriately sized for the length of journey

You should contact DARD for the specific vehicle inspection criteria for the species you intend to transport.

Your vehicle must also be contactable at all times. A minimum requirement is that your driver can be contacted at all time by mobile phone.

If you transport livestock and unregistered horses, your vehicle must have a navigation and tracking system. This should record details of the journey and any information relating to the opening and closing of the loading flap.

You must also have a long journey authorisation from DARD before you can transport any animals.

column3: Laser or intense pulsed light treatment licence (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate an establishment that uses lasers or intense pulsed light treatment, you must be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

Applications must include specific information and be accompanied by a fee.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a registration.

If you plan to undertake any work on or next to a watercourse you may need consent from the Environment Agency, your local Internal Drainage Board or local authority.

To identify whether you need consent you must submit your plans to your internal drainage board or local authority if the river is an 'ordinary river', or the Environment Agency if it is a 'main river'. You can find out whether the river is an ordinary or a main river by contacting your local Environment Agency office.

Work for which you may need consent include:

  • any work affecting the bed or banks of a main river
  • constructing or altering structures such as a mill, dam, weir or other like structure which affects the flow of a watercourse
  • constructing or altering any culvert that would be likely to affect the flow of a watercourse
  • carrying out drainage works

Works on any watercourse may also need planning permission from your local authority as well as consent.

It can take up to two months for your application to be either approved or refused consent. A fee will be payable.

If you carry out an activity which obstructs the flow of a watercourse or causes flooding and do not comply with an order to change or remove the works, this may be carried out for you and the costs recovered from you. You may also be prosecuted and fined up to £5,000, plus a further fine for every day that the contravention is continued.

If you move cattle onto - or from - your holding, you must give notification of the movement to British Cattle Movement Service acting on behalf of Welsh Ministers either in writing, by phone or using the online Cattle Tracing System.

Notification must be made within three days of the movement.

To practise as a veterinary nurse and undertake any medical treatment or minor surgery on an animal, you may register with the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (RCVS) and be entered into the list of veterinary nurses or list of visiting European veterinary nurses.

If you were a listed veterinary nurse before 1 January 2003, you will automatically be registered. Otherwise you can apply to the RCVS for registration.

You must pay a registration fee.

Registered veterinary nurses are required to complete at least 45 hours of continual professional development each year. You must also comply with the requirements of the Guide to Professional Conduct for Veterinary Nurses.

Once you are entered on to one of these lists, you may carry out medical treatment or minor surgery - excluding entry into a body cavity - only if all of the following conditions are met:

  • the animal must be under the care of a registered veterinary surgeon or veterinary practitioner
  • the surgeon or practitioner must be your employer - or acting as your employer
  • the surgeon or practitioner directing the treatment must be satisfied that you are qualified to carry out the treatment or surgery

If you operate a skip hire business or you are an individual planning to use a skip not sourced from a private hire company, you need a permit from your local authority to place a skip on any public road, footway or footpath.

Your application should be made to your local authority and a fee may be payable.

A skip placed on any public road, footway or footpath must be clearly marked with the owner's name and address or telephone number.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a permit issued by the local authority. Failure to do so could result in the issue of a fixed penalty notice.

Your skip may be removed or repositioned if it is deemed to cause a danger or obstruction.

column3: Consent to carry out excavations in or break up the surface of a road (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you wish to carry out excavations in or break up the surface of a road, you must have consent from the Roads Service.

Applications can be made online via the Northern Ireland Direct website.

You must provide the following with the application form:

  • a drawing showing the nature of the work (where appropriate)
  • details of the appropriate planning approval including drawing if relevant

You must:

  • indemnify the Road Service against any claims in respect of injury, loss or damage arising from the works
  • provide insurance cover
  • make a returnable monetary deposit as assessed by the Roads Service

You will be responsible for traffic safety and control during the works.

You must comply with the statutory guidance given in HSG47 - Avoiding Danger from Underground Services.

If you carry out works without consent you may be fined up to £1,000.

To place tables, chairs or other temporary furniture on the pavement in England and Wales, you require permission from your local authority.

You will need to supply documents to support your application, including a site plan and a public liability insurance certificate.

You may also be required to pay an application fee.

Conditions may be attached to your permit - eg in relation to the size or location of the objects you are allowed to place on the pavement.

If you fail to comply with any conditions attached to a permit, the local authority may serve a notice requiring you to comply.

If you are a landlord letting out your own property and are not already a registered social landlord, you must be registered with your local authority.

Your application for registration must contain:

  • your name and address and any other addresses in the last 5 years
  • the address of each house you own and details for any that are subject to a lease or occupancy arrangement that allow an unconnected person to occupy the house
  • details of any agent who acts for you in relation to lease or occupancy arrangements
  • the details of any co-owners of the property
  • a correspondence address
  • any other information required

Registration may be subject to a fee.

You must be a fit and proper person to be registered. The local authority will take into account such things as convictions for fraud, firearms, sexual, violence or drug offences, any anti-social behaviour orders against you or any tenant, unlawful discrimination or breaches of letting codes, housing law or landlord and tenant law, when deciding if you are a fit and proper person.

If your circumstances change and information you have provided is no longer accurate you must notify the local authority of any changes as soon as possible after the change.

If you provide false or misleading information, fail to provide requested information or fail to notify the local authority of any changes to the information provided, you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

You must give notice to the local authority if you appoint an agent to act on your behalf in relation to renting a property. You may have to pay a fee when providing notification. If you fail to provide this information you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

If you rent a property without being registered or advertise a property for rent without being registered you may commit an offence and be fined up to £50,000. You may also be banned from being registered for up to five years. The local authority may also serve you with a notice stating that rent will not be payable on your property for a certain period.

If you advertise your property for rent in writing you must give your registration number in the advertisement.

If your tenant or a visitor of your tenant acts in an antisocial manner, you may be served with an antisocial behaviour notice. If you fail to comply with the requirements of the notice you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000. You may also have an order made against you preventing you from recovering rent for the property of tenant or visited by the visitor. A management order may also be made, meaning that control over your property will be taken over by the local authority, for up to one year and any rents recovered during the period will be payable to them.

column3: Artificial reproduction of animals licence (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate a centre which is involved in the artificial reproduction of animals, you must have a licence from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

You should contact DARD for information on how to apply for a licence. Your licence application may be subject to a fee.

In order to issue a licence, DARD must be satisfied that you are a suitable person to hold a licence and that:

  • issuing a licence will not encourage the spread of disease
  • you have adequate facilities for the collection, storage, distribution or sale of semen

You must not import the semen or ova of any animal into Northern Ireland unless permitted under your licence and unless you are acting in accordance with the conditions of the licence. However, this does not apply to:

  • bovine semen which is the subject of Council Directive 88/407/EE
  • bovine embryos which are the subject of Council Directive 89/556/EEC
  • porcine semen which is the subject of Council Directive 90/429/EEC
  • equine ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/294/EC
  • equine semen which is the subject of Commission Decision 95/307/EC
  • ovine and caprine semen, ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/388/EC
  • porcine ova and embryos which are the subject of Commission Decision 95/483/EC

You must allow any person with written authorisation from DARD to enter any:

  • premises, vehicle, stall or place in order to check whether any activity requiring a licence has been carried out without a licence
  • premises or place used in connection with a licence in order to establish whether there has been a breach of the terms of the licence

However, if the premises in question are private dwellings, you are only obliged to allow the authorised person to enter where they are acting under the authority of a warrant, or if you have been given at least 24 hours' notice of the intended entry.

You must allow an authorised person to inspect any premises, place, animals, plant or equipment, and to carry out tests or investigations.

If you are required to do so by an authorised person, you must give any required information, produce any records you are required to keep and allow copies to be taken of such records.

If an authorised person believes that an offence has been committed, they may seize and detain any semen or ova and their containers, and any animal, plant, equipment or documents.

If you fail to comply with these rules, you may be liable to a fine of up to £5,000, up to three months imprisonment, or both.

In addition, any semen, ova or animal detained may be forfeited.

column3: House in multiple occupation (HMO) licence (England & Wales)
column4:
If you rent out your property as a house in multiple occupancy (HMO) and it meets the requirements of Mandatory HMO Licensing under Part 2 of the Housing Act 2004, you must obtain a licence from your local authority.

To be granted a licence, the property must be suitable for multiple occupation and you must be the most appropriate person to hold the licence. The proposed manager of the HMO must either be in control of the house or an agent of the person in control and must have sufficient experience and be 'fit and proper'.

The management arrangements proposed for managing the property must also be satisfactory.

You will not be considered as a 'fit and proper person' if you have:

  • any criminal convictions for dishonesty, including fraud, violence, drugs or a sexual offence
  • breached any housing or landlord laws or codes of practice
  • been found to discriminate against race, colour, sex, disability or origin whilst carrying on a business

Licences will be subject to mandatory conditions and may have further conditions attached.

Mandatory conditions will cover the following:

  • producing a gas safety certificate to the local housing authority (LHA) every year if gas is supplied to the house
  • ensuring electrical appliances and any furniture supplied are safe and providing a declaration confirming this to the LHA if required
  • ensuring smoke alarms are installed and maintained and providing a declaration confirming this to the LHA if required
  • providing a tenant with written terms of occupation

Additional conditions could require you to:

  • restrict or ban the use of parts of the property
  • provide facilities and equipment to ensure the property meets minimum standards and to maintain such facilities and equipment
  • take steps to prevent anti-social behaviour by tenants
  • carry out any work required to meet minimum standards within any required period
  • take any required training courses

Applications may be subject to a fee.

A licence will be valid for a maximum of five years from the date it was granted.

If you own or run more than one HMO, you must have a separate licence for each.

If you operate a children's day care service for children under 12 years of age you must be registered with your local Health and Social Services Board (HSSB).

You will provide day care if you care for children for a period or total period of two hours or more per day.

To register, you should contact your local HSSB for an application form. You must provide the following information:

  • personal details including correspondence address
  • the type of daycare you provide - eg day nursery, playgroup or crèche
  • any relevant qualifications
  • doctors' information
  • details of relevant experience
  • personal references 
  • details of the members of your household and any regular visitors
  • consent to checks of your application
  • sufficient details for an identity check to be carried out

You will be required to attend an interview. You and anyone that lives in your premises will have to take a criminal records check and social services records checks.

A social worker will inspect your premises and assess your competence. You must meet the minimum standards for childminding and day care set by the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety (DHSSPS). Any staff will also be assessed for competence.

Your application may be refused if you or anyone in your household is considered to be unfit to look after, or be in proximity of, children under the age of twelve.

In addition to the application form, you may also have to provide:

  • any relevant building plans and planning permissions
  • staff vetting forms and qualifications
  • insurances
  • registration with Environmental Health - for health and safety and food safety purposes

You must comply with any requirements imposed by the HSSB, which may specify:

  • the maximum number of children you can look after on your premises
  • the security of your premises
  • that you must notify them if the facilities in your premises change
  • the minimum and maximum number of assistants you may have
  • records you must keep

When you receive your certificate of registration, you must display it in your premises. Your premises will be inspected at least once a year.

If you provide day care for children at different premises you must be separately registered for each.

You must have an explosives licence to:

  • bring explosives in to a harbour area (including the harbour)
  • carry or handle any explosive within a harbour area
  • load or unload any explosive in a harbour area

A licence fee may be payable.

When you bring explosives into a harbour, you must ensure the following:

  • 24 hours written notice is given to the harbour master, and, if the substance is to be brought to a berth, to the berth operator
  • your vessel conspicuously displays a flag during the day and a red light at night or in poor visibility
  • barges display hazard warning panels on each side
  • vessels have radios capable of receiving and transmitting in the very high frequency band
  • a listening watch is kept on vessels at all times except when the vessel is at a berth or for short periods when the radio is tuned to another frequency for operational purposes
  • any freight container containing explosives is adequately ventilated, appropriately labelled with hazard warning signs, and accompanied by a certificate confirming that the substance has been packed safely

Your notice must be in writing or another form agreed with the harbour master and must contain adequate information to evaluate risks to the health and safety of any person. In addition, if you operate a vessel, you may be required to state whether your vessel has the certificate of fitness.

For explosives (with few exceptions) to be permitted in a harbour or harbour area the Secretary of State must have licensed the harbour to bring in, load, unload, carry, handle or store those explosives.

You must secure the explosives against loss, theft or wrongful use. If you transfer the explosives to someone else, you must get a written receipt from them. You must take all appropriate precautions for preventing an explosion, fire or risk to health and safety.

If you load a vessel with explosives, you must take it out of the harbour as soon as is reasonably practical.

You must comply with any directions by the harbour master if they feel that there is a risk to health or safety. These directions may regulate entry, removal or handling of explosives, or anything that contains or carries explosives.

You must follow the harbour master's instructions as to when and where you may anchor, moor or move your vessel and you must ensure that any conditions imposed by the harbour master are complied with.

You must notify the harbour master, and follow his subsequent instructions, where:

  • any explosives are dropped overboard
  • there is any deterioration or change to explosives that might lead them to constitute a greater risk to health and safety
  • there is any incident involving the threat or occurrence on the vessel of a serious health and safety risk

You must comply with any conditions attached to the licence, and any byelaws prohibiting the entry or regulating the entry, carriage, handling and storage of explosives of the harbour authority.

column3: Approval of courses leading to external qualifications (England & Wales)
column4:
If you provide a course of education or training for those under 19 years of age that leads to an external qualification, the course must be approved by the Secretary of State or the National Assembly for Wales.

The approval is required for courses funded by an authorised body or by a maintained school.

Authorised bodies in England are:

  • the Young People's Learning Agency
  • Chief Executive of Skills Funding
  • a local education authority
  • any other body specified by the Secretary of State

Authorised bodies in Wales are:

  • the National Assembly for Wales (the Assembly)
  • a local education authority
  • any other body specified by the Assembly

An external qualification is a qualification awarded by an outside person.

column3: Controlled waste carrier and broker registration (Northern Ireland)
column4:
To transport controlled waste in Northern Ireland, you must register with the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA).

To register, contact NIEA for the correct application form. Return the completed form, along with:

  • any further information that the NIEA may request
  • the appropriate fee - £129 for a first application or £65 for the renewal of a previous registration

If your application is accepted, you will be given a registration number and issued with a certificate of registration.

You must keep this certificate in a safe place, and you must produce it within seven days of a request from NIEA to do so.

You must notify NIEA of any changes to your business that may affect the information you provided when you registered.

Your registration will last up to three years from the date of confirmation by the NIEA. The NIEA will then inform you six months before the expiry of your registration that you may renew your registration.

Your application may be revoked if you or another relevant person is convicted of certain offences, or if the NIEA believe it is unreasonable for you to continue to transport waste.

If your licence expires or is revoked, you must return your certificate to the NIEA as soon as possible.

There are exemptions from registration. You do not have to be registered with the NIEA before transporting controlled waste if you or your business can be classed in any of the following areas:

  • government department
  • district council
  • producer of controlled waste - unless it is building or demolition waste
  • Northern Ireland Railways Company Limited - if carrying waste by rail
  • ferry operator - only if the waste is being carried by a vehicle that the ferry is transporting
  • charities
  • voluntary bodies
  • those waiting for a response to their registration application
  • anyone who has a licence, approval or registration for moving animal by-products
  • businesses that remove animal proteins

If you act as a childminder you must be registered with your local Health and Social Care Trust (HSCT).

You are a childminder if you look after one or more children under 12 years of age for reward and the period or total period in any day that you spend looking after children is more than two hours.

To register, contact your local HSCT for an application form. You must provide the following information:

  • personal details
  • any relevant qualifications
  • doctors' information
  • details of relevant experience
  • personal references
  • details of members of your household and any regular visitors
  • consent to checks of your application
  • sufficient details for an identity check to be carried out

You and anyone that lives in the premises will have to take an Enhanced Disclosure check through AccessNI and social services records checks.

A social worker will inspect your premises and assess your competence. You must meet the minimum standards for childminding and day care set by the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety (DHSSPS). Any staff will also be assessed for competence.

Your application may be refused if you or anyone in your household is considered to be unfit to look after, or be in proximity of, children under the age of twelve.

You must comply with any requirements imposed by the HSCT which may specify:

  • the maximum number of children you can look after on your premises
  • the security of your premises
  • that you must notify them of any change in your circumstances
  • that you must notify them if the facilities in your premises change
  • the minimum and maximum number of assistants you may have
  • records you should keep - eg children's names and addresses, assistants details, and anyone that may live at your premises

Once registered, your premises will be inspected yearly.

If you provide tourist accommodation, you must be certified by the Northern Ireland Tourist Board (NITB).

You must not advertise or describe your property as certified tourist accommodation if you do not have a certificate in place.

Your premises will be inspected as part of the application process.

If your property does not meet the criteria for the category of accommodation you are applying for your application will be refused. You will be served with a notice detailing the reasons why the accommodation did not meet criteria.

The certificate must be displayed in your premises at or near the entrance, or in any other place the NITB specify.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a certificate including the condition that you notify the NITB as soon as a new person takes over as proprietor of the accommodation and provide them with the name of the new proprietor.

Your accommodation will be inspected at least once every four years. If on inspection it is found that your accommodation does not meet criteria for that category or you have failed to comply with any condition attached to your certificate you will be served with a notice revoking your certificate.

Inspection fees will be payable.

You must keep a visitor register containing specific details of guests.

The NITB may require you complete a return detailing whether you still provide tourist accommodation and any other information they deem necessary. You will be required to return the information no less than 30 days after the notice has been served and no earlier than 11 months after your last inspection or any other similar notice you have received. This process is known as a statutory review.

If you provide tourist accommodation without a certificate, advertise or describe your accommodation as being certified or allow another person to do so when it is not you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500, imprisoned for up to six months or both. If you fail to display your certificate you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £2,500.

If after the inspection, or after a statutory review, a NITB inspector finds that your accommodation no longer meets criteria for its particular category you will be served with a notice revoking your certificate. If you fail to comply with a notice to provide a return your certificate will be revoked.

You can apply to the NITB to review the decision. If the decision is upheld you can appeal to your local County Court.

Your premises may also be inspected at any other time. An inspector may serve you with a notice imposing conditions on your certificate if the inspector feels it would be appropriate to do so. If you refuse to allow your premises to be inspected on two occasions you will receive a notice revoking your certificate. You cannot appeal against a notice served on these grounds.

If your premises have been graded under a NITB scheme you must only describe premises as that grade. If your premises have not been graded you must not describe your premises with a grade. If you falsely describe your grade you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500.

You must display any sign provided by the NITB. You must not display any other signs showing the classification, grading or standard of your premises if it has not be supplied by the NITB. If you fail to comply with requirements in relation to displaying signs you may commit an offence and be fined up to £200.

If you fail to keep a visitor register you may commit a criminal offence and be fined up to £200.

If you operate an adult placement scheme business in England that offers an adult placement service, you must be registered with the Care Quality Commission (CQC).

The service provider - which can be an organisation, partnership or individual - must register. If you are registered as an organisation or partnership then the person responsible for managing the services must also register. If you are registering as an individual, you don't need to have a separately registered manager unless you don't intend to be in charge full-time.

There are separate registration forms for each category of provider. Applications forms are available from the CQC website and once complete should be e-mailed to the CQC.

No application fee is payable, however once registered, you must pay an annual fee towards ongoing compliance monitoring and any changes you wish to make to your registration. Fees can be paid by cheque or BACS.

Along with your application, you must:

  • provide details of each location from where you will provide adult placement services
  • list the regulated activities you intend to carry out
  • meet essential standards of quality and safety
  • make a declaration of compliance

If you carry out a regulated activity without being registered, you will be committing an offence, and you could be fined and/or imprisoned.

column3: Electricity interconnector licence (England, Wales and Scotland)
column4:
If you participate in an electricity interconnector operation, you must be licensed.

You will be participating in an electricity interconnector operation if you are involved in co-ordinating and directing electricity flow into or through an interconnector, or if you provide an interconnector for use.

Applications must be made in writing by completing the application form available from the Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (Ofgem). The completed form may be returned to Ofgem by post, email or via their website, with the fee of £1,050.

You can find guidance and details of paying the fee by BACS, CHAPS or cheque on the application form.

You will be required to provide detailed information on the application form, including:

  • your contact details
  • details of your company and its directors
  • details of the ultimate holding company and directors, if applicable
  • shareholder details
  • previous applications and licences held
  • details of modifications that you wish to request to the standard conditions
  • any criminal convictions
  • how you propose to start your business
  • specification of the actual or proposed point of connection or Ordinance Survey Grid Reference co-ordinates if you are unable to specify the point of connection

You should complete all sections of the form and enter 'N/A' to any questions that you consider do not apply.

Ofgem may contact you to request additional documents to support your application, including details of your bank, solicitors and auditors.

If you are required to attend an interview, you must may be asked to  provide certified copies of passports and driving licences for each director and the following original company documentation:

  • incorporation documents
  • resolutions
  • minutes from meetings
  • annual returns and accounts
  • forms appointing and resigning directors
  • register of directors
  • register of members

Your application will not be processed until all relevant information and documents have been received by Ofgem and the fee has cleared.

Once Ofgem considers that your application is complete they will provide you with a template with suggested wording for your notice of application. You must arrange for this to be published on either your own website or the Ofgem website within ten working days. The notice must be published for at least 28 days.

Your application may be refused if, amongst other things:

  • you are insolvent
  • any persons named in the application are disqualified from being involved in company affairs or have relevant unspent convictions
  • you have previously had a licence revoked or refused

You cannot hold an interconnector licence and any of the following at the same time:

  • an electricity generation licence
  • an electricity transmission licence
  • an electricity distribution licence
  • an electricity supply licence

Ofgem aim to make a decision about your application within 45 working days after they send you notice that your application has been 'duly made'.

Licences may contain certain conditions and once licensed you must adhere to strict codes of practice.

Exemptions from the licensing requirements apply. For full details contact Ofgem.

If you produce packaging waste and are not a member of an approved compliance scheme, you must be registered with the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA).

This only applies if your business:

  • has an annual turnover of more than £2 million
  • handled more than 50 tonnes of packaging materials or packaging in the previous year

If you have a turnover of between £2 million and £5 million you may choose to register as a small producer. If you do so, your recycling obligation will be based on turnover and the main material type you handle.

Handling packaging includes the following activities:

  • producing raw materials for packaging manufacture
  • converting raw materials into packaging
  • putting goods in packaging or packaging around goods
  • selling packaging materials or packaged goods to the end user
  • importing packaged goods, packaging materials or raw materials for packaging from outside of the UK
  • supplying packaging for hire or loan

You are also required to register if you:

  • have any of these activities carried out on your behalf
  • own the packaging on which any of these activities are carried out
  • supply packaging or materials at any stage in the production chain or to the end user of the packaging or, in the case of imported packaging, where you are the end user of the packaging

You must register online using the National Packaging Waste Database (NPWD).

If you have never been registered before and to get an NPWD account set up, you should first contact the NIEA Helpline on Tel 02890 569338 or by e-mail at packaging@doeni.gov.uk. You should let NIEA know if you were previously a member of a compliance scheme.

Once you have an account set up you must fill in the online registration form, providing details of your business, packaging activities and the amount of packaging that you handle.

You should indicate if you are a small producer and provide evidence of your turnover.

You should upload any supporting documents - eg an operational plan - and pay a registration fee of £950 (£564 for small producers) when you register.

Once registered, you must:

  • recover and recycle set amounts of packaging waste each year
  • provide evidence that recovery or recycling (or both) has been carried out
  • provide an operational plan where you recover and/or recycle more than 500 tonnes per year
  • fulfil your consumer information obligations, where you are selling to the end user

You must register or renew your registration before 7 April each year.

If you decide not to register, you must join an approved compliance scheme. Schemes all have their own systems and membership forms. You must ensure that you have supplied your scheme with all the information and fees they require in order to register by 7 April. The public register of current approved compliance schemes is available on the NPWD website.

If you operate without registering or joining a scheme when required to do so, or if you or fail to comply with your recovery or recycling obligations, you are committing an offence and may be prosecuted.

To practise as a solicitor in Scotland, you must be admitted as a solicitor, have your name on the roll and hold a practising certificate.

Practising certificates are obtained from the Council of the Law Society of Scotland.

You must pay a fee to obtain a practising certificate.

Conditions may be attached to a practicing certificate under certain circumstances.

If you are the operator of a business in England or Wales that requires an environmental permit, you may have to report your annual pollution releases and Resource Efficiency Physical Index (REPI) data to the Environmental Agency.

This includes reporting on your annual emissions of certain substances to air, controlled waters and land, and off-site transfers in wastewater and waste. It also includes reporting data on your energy, water and waste consumption.

You must provide this information if you receive an Environmental Permitting regulation (EPR) 60 notice from the Environment Agency.

You can either fill in and return a paper reporting form or use the Environment Agency's web-based reporting system.

There may also be specific requirements depending on the sector you operate in. Sector-specific guidance is available on the Environment Agency website.

Completed forms must be submitted by 28 February of each reporting year.

There is no charge for Pollution Inventory reporting.

Information submitted will be held on the Pollution Inventory, which is a public record of pollution levels in England and Wales.

If you require any help in completing a reporting form you can call the Environment Agency on Tel 03708 506 506.

If you fail to comply with an information notice requesting pollution data, you are committing an offence. Enforcement action may be taken, which could result in a fine, imprisonment for up to two years, or both.

Any operator, establishment or plant that generates, processes, stores, uses disposes or transports animal by-products must be approved or registered by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD). There have been some changes to the requirements for approval and registrations.

Low risk operations such as technical plants, which were previously approved, now only need to be registered, therefore reducing administrative burdens on operators. However, transporters of animal by-products now need to be registered for the first time. This requirement has been introduced in order to strengthen traceability. Premises handling animal by-products include:

  • rendering plants, these plants can take category 1, 2 or 3 animal by-products
  • handling and storage plants (previously known as intermediate plants)
  • incinerators
  • composting and anaerobic digestion (biogas) plants
  • petfood plants
  • technical plants

Category 1 material is the highest risk and consists principally of:

  • all body parts of animals believed to be infected with a Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE), killed as part of TSE eradication methods, animals other than farm animals, eg pet animals, zoo animals and circus animals, experimental animals and wild animals suspected of being infected with diseases that can transfer to animals or humans
  • specified risk material and the entire bodies of any dead animals that contained specified risk material
  • products from animals that were given prohibited substances
  • animal material collected when treating waste water from Category 1 processing plants and other premises where specified risk material is removed
  • catering waste from internationally operating transport
  • mixtures of Category 1 material with either Category 2 or 3 material or both

Category 2 materials is also high risk and includes are:

  • digestive tract content and manure
  • animal materials collected when treating waste from slaughterhouses or Category 2 processing plants
  • products from animals that contain traces of veterinary drugs and contaminants that exceed permitted European levels
  • products of animal origin other than Category 1 material imported from non European Union member states and that fail veterinary requirements for importation into the European Community
  • animals that died other than through slaughter for human consumption (or parts from such animals), including those killed to stop epizootic disease
  • Category 2 material mixed with Category 3 material
  • by-products other than Category 1 or 3 material

Category 3 material is low risk and includes:

  • parts of slaughtered animals that are fit for human consumption but for commercial reasons are not intended for this purpose and parts that are unfit for human consumption but are not affected by signs of disesase
  • any of the following that are from animals slaughtered in a slaughterhouse, had ante-mortem inspection and were fit for human consumption or are from animals that don't show clinical signs of disease - hides, skins, hooves, horns, pig bristles, feathers and blood
  • by-products from the production of products intended for human consumption, eg degreased bones
  • former foodstuffs of animal origin or which contain products of animal origin due to defects, problems with manufacturing or packaging defects or are no longer intended for human consumption
  • raw milk from animals that don't show clinical signs of disease
  • fish and other sea animals except sea mammals caught for fishmeal production purposes
  • fish by-products from fish products intended for human consumption
  • shells, hatchery by-products an
column5:
d cracked egg by-products from animals that don't show clinical signs of disease
  • catering waste, other than Category 1 catering waste

    • In order to become approved or registered, you should make your application direct to DARD Veterinary Service using the correct application form for your type of business. You can access your application form online or by writing to the department at:

    Room 922,
    Dundonald House,
    Upper Newtownards Road,
    Belfast BT4 3SB

    The application must be submitted in paper form.

    Once DARD has received your application, they will contact you within 15 days to arrange a site inspection. Your premises must be inspected before your application can be approved. If the required conditions are met, you will receive a notice of approval within ten working days.

    You must not store, dispose of, use, handle or process ABP until your application has been granted.

    You must ensure that the premises are properly maintained in compliance with any conditions of your approval, and the requirements of EU Regulations (EC) 1069/2009 and the accompanying implementing Regulation (EC) 142/2011. The Animal By-Products (Enforcement) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2011 is the national legislation in Northern Ireland which administers and enforces the EU Regulations.

column4:
You must have the correct qualifications if you supervise any street works that involve:

  • breaking up the street, any sewer or drain
  • tunnelling under the street, any sewer or drain
  • boring under the street

However, you do not require relevant qualifications or certification for supervising:

  • the replacing of poles, lamps, columns and signs
  • pole testing
  • works involving minimal breaking up of the street

You will be considered to have the relevant qualifications if you have a certificate of competence from an approved body. This certificate shows that you have achieved the relevant units of competence for the work you are supervising.

The approved bodies for issuing certificates of competence are:

  • City and Guilds of London Institute
  • Scottish Qualifications Authority
  • Certification and Assessment Board for the Water Industry (CABWI)

To obtain a certificate of competence, you must hold certification for the following areas:

  • location and avoidance of underground apparatus
  • monitoring signing, lighting and guarding, and excavation in the highway
  • monitoring reinstatement and compaction of various types of road construction materials

As well as the certificate of competence, you must also be able to show your practical competence in the above areas.

Alternatively, you can have a qualification from another member state of the European Community which gives an equivalent guarantee of skill and competence.

You must also register your Certificate of Competence with the Street Works Qualification Register (SWQR). The SQWR will then provide a plastic photo identification card to show you have the requisite qualifications.

A registration is valid for five years. In Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland you can reregister by contacting the registration body within three months of the expiry of the previous registration. To reregister in England, you must undertake a re-assessment of your held qualifications.

column3: Permission to award a degree (All UK)
column4:
If you operate an educational establishment which provides higher or further education and award degrees, diplomas, certificates or other academic awards to students you must have permission to do so from the Privy Council.

The types of awards referred to as awards are those that are given after completion of an appropriate course of study and assessment or after an appropriate supervised research programme and assessment.

In order to be granted power you must show the Privy Council details of the opportunities available to potential students to study for the awards.

If you operate a day care setting in Northern Ireland, you must comply with the Day Care Setting Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007 and be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

If you wish to operate or manage more than one service, you must make a separate application for each organisation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a registration.

If you fail to comply with requirements, you may commit an offence.

If you intend to undertake certain activities in relation to wild birds or animals that would otherwise be prohibited, you need a wildlife licence from the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA).

Activities that are prohibited without a licence include:

  • intentionally killing, injuring or taking wild birds or animals
  • taking, damaging or destroying the nest or place of shelter of wild birds or animals while in use or disturbing birds or animals while present there
  • taking or destroying the eggs of any wild bird
  • having in your possession any wild bird or certain types of wild animal

Licences may be granted:

  • for scientific or educational purposes
  • for the purposes of photography
  • to prevent the spread of disease or to preserve public health or public safety
  • for the purposes of ringing or marking or examining a ring or mark on wild birds or eggs or wild animals
  • for the purposes of conserving wild birds or animals
  • to protect any zoological collection or collection of wild birds
  • for the purposes of falconry or aviculture
  • for the purposes of public exhibitions or competitions
  • for the purposes of taxidermy
  • to prevent damage to livestock, or fisheries, foodstuffs for animals, vegetables, fruit, crops, growing timber, or pasture

Traps, nets, snares etc that are normally prohibited for killing or taking wild birds or animals may be used under licence.

Some activities can be carried out in respect of certain species - eg killing crows by a landowner to prevent the spread of disease - under a general licence issued by NIEA. These are listed on the Department of Environment (DOE) website. You don't need to apply for these licences but you must comply with the conditions attached to them.

If the activities you want to carry out are not covered by a general licence you will need to make an individual application. Application forms are available on the DOE website.

You may be required to provide documents in support of your application, such as written consent from the landowner and details of your experience in carrying out this type of activity, eg past photographic work. You must also provide details of any previous convictions for wildlife offences.

Licence fees are only payable for certain types of licence, eg to hold or breed birds of prey in captivity.

Licences will state how long they are valid for and any conditions that you must comply with.

If you fail to obtain a licence or comply with the terms of a licence, you are committing an offence and may be imprisoned for up to six months or receive a fine of up to £5,000. Any vehicle, bird, animal, nest or egg in your possession and any vehicle, weapon or other thing used to commit the offence may also be confiscated.

If you wish to supply gas in Northern Ireland, you must be licensed by the Utility Regulator.

Full details of the documents and particulars to be provided, along with a sample application form, can be found in the Gas (Applications for Licences and Extensions) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 1996 on the Legislation.gov.uk website.

You may also request that a licence is exclusive, ie that no one else can carry out operations of the type you are authorised to carry out or within the area you are authorised to operate in for a period specified by the Utility Regulator (but not exceeding 20 years). However, if you apply for an exclusive licence you will have to provide reasons for this in your application.

You must pay an application fee of £500.

Within 14 days of making your application, you must place a notice - including a copy of the application - in the Belfast Gazette and in a local newspaper for each area where you intend to operate. You should send a copy of each notice to the Utility Regulator as soon as possible after it is published.

The Utility Regulator will review applications within one month of receipt. The criteria against which your application will be reviewed are available on the Utility Regulator's website.

If the Utility Regulator is satisfied that your application should be granted, a notification of intent will be placed on their website and a consultation will run for at least 28 days.

You will be notified of the Utility Regulator's decision at the end of the consultation period. 

If your licence is granted, it will subject to a range of standard and bespoke conditions.

Your authorisation will be valid for the period specified in the licence.

If you operate without a licence or outside the terms of your licence or make false statements in your licence application, you are committing an offence and may be faced with an unlimited fine.

If you intend to move hazardous waste in Northern Ireland, you must pre-notify the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA) at least 72 hours in advance.

You must contact NIEA directly to obtain a consignment note containing a unique number - or a consignment number if using your own forms.

The producer or holder must complete Parts A and B of the consignment notice. This must include:

  • the unique consignment number
  • a specific waste code for the type of hazardous waste
  • the producer's details
  • an accurate description of the waste
  • details of where the waste is going
  • a declaration that the waste management hierarchy has been applied - which means that all practical steps have been taken to reuse or recycle the waste before deciding to dispose of it

A copy of Parts A and B must be sent to NIEA. It must be received at least 72 working hours before moving waste, unless the waste cannot stay where it is for 72 hours, or if it has previously been rejected by a receiver - you must consult NIEA in these cases.

The carrier must complete Part C and the consignor must complete Part D. The consignor and producer should then be given a copy each, and the carrier should be given the three remaining copies.
