The consignor must ensure that any hazardous waste is properly packaged and labelled throughout the course of its collection, transport and temporary storage.

The carrier must ensure that all copies of the consignment notice travel with the waste and are given to the receiver upon delivery. The waste must ordinarily be delivered within a week.

The receiver must complete Part E on these copies and keep one, give a copy to the carrier for their records, and return a copy to NIEA. They also must provide returns or copies of completed consignment notices to the producers or holders of the waste.

If a receiver rejects the hazardous waste, they must complete Part E, retain a copy, return a copy to the carrier and return a copy to NIEA. If there are no consignment notices, they must provide NIEA with a written explanation of why.

The carrier must contact the NIEA and find alternative arrangements through the consignor.

If there is more than one carrier transporting the waste, the consignor must ensure that there are enough copies of the consignment notice for all parties including the additional carriers. The process is as above except each carrier must keep a copy of the notice for themselves and hand over the remaining copies to the next carrier.

You may not have to pre-notify NIEA if the movement is a subsequent repetitive movement - eg waste of the same description, from the same premises and consignor and being moved to the same premises and consignee. However, you will need to notify NIEA of the first movement in the succession. You will also need to follow the same procedures as above, without the notification to NIEA.

Anyone involved in the movement of waste must keep a register containing records of consignment notices, consignee returns and carrier schedules for at least three years. NIEA may request this information at any time.

Producers, holders, consignors, dealers and brokers of hazardous waste must also keep a record of the quantity, nature, origin, destination, frequency of collection, mode of transport and treatment method of the waste.

Additionally, if hazardous waste is deposited on any land, the location and identity of the waste must be recorded. This must be accompanied by a plan of the site locating the waste.

There are different movement requirements for removal of waste from a ship or through a pipeline, but you must still pre-notify NIEA.

For removing waste from a ship, the process is as outlined above, but the master of the ship must deal with the movement instead of a consignor.

For wast
column5: e removal through a pipeline, you do not need to complete Part C of the notice as there will be no carrier present.

column4:
If you operate a residential family centre in Northern Ireland, you must comply with The Residential Family Centres Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007 and be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

If you wish to operate or manage more than one agency, you must make a separate application for each agency.

Failure to comply with the requirements might constitute an offence.

If you operate a nursing agency in Northern Ireland, you must comply with the Nursing Agencies Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2005, The Minimum Standards for Nursing Agencies and be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

Applications will be subject to a fee.

If you wish to operate or manage more than one agency, you must make a separate application for each agency.

Failure to comply with the requirements might constitute an offence.

If you are a social landlord in Wales, you must be registered with the Welsh Ministers.

You will be eligible for registration if you are:

  • a registered charity which is a housing association
  • a society that is registered under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1965 and satisfies certain conditions
  • a company that satisfies the same conditions

The conditions to be met are that your organisation is non-profit making and was established for the purposes of or your objectives or powers including the provision, construction, improvement or management of:

  • houses kept available for letting
  • hostels
  • houses kept for occupation by members of your organisation, where the rules of the organisation entitle the member to occupy the premises

Other additional permissible objectives or conditions may apply.

Applications must be in the format specified by the relevant Authority and may be subject to a fee.

If you intend to practise as a solicitor in Northern Ireland, you must:

  • have been admitted as a solicitor - ie completed your training
  • have your name on the roll (a list of all solicitors of the Court of Judicature in Northern Ireland)
  • hold a practising certificate

Practising certificates are issued by the Law Society of Northern Ireland (LSNI) and you should contact them for an application form.

You must pay a fee in connection with your practising certificate.

Conditions may be attached to a practising certificate under certain circumstances - eg where you have been the subject of disciplinary sanctions.

You must renew your registration every year that you intend to practise as a solicitor.

As a solicitor you must comply with rules regarding:

  • professional practice, conduct and discipline
  • continuing professional development activities
  • accounts and trust accounts
  • interest on clients' money
  • inspection of practice bank accounts
  • requests for accountants reports
  • professional indemnity

If you are a European lawyer you can apply to LSNI for initial registration as a registered European lawyer (REL) if you intend to practise as a lawyer in the UK.

If you practise as a solicitor without obtaining a practising certificate or an REL without being registered, you may be fined and held in contempt of court.

You must be approved by the Department of Education (DfE) in order to inspect independent schools in England.

If you are approved, Ofsted will monitor samples of your inspections and reports and report to DfE on the quality of these.
You must be approved by the National Assembly for Wales in order to inspect independent schools in Wales.

In order to provide paid childcare in the child's home in Northern Ireland, you must be approved by your local Health and Social Care (HSC) Trust.

Approval will be given by the HSC Trust if you:

  • are 18 years old or over
  • have a relevant childcare qualification or have attended an appropriate induction course
  • have a relevant first-aid certificate
  • are not considered unsuitable to work with or have unsupervised access to children

You should send a completed application form to the Early Years Team (part of your local HSC Trust). As well as providing details of your childcare and first-aid qualifications, you must consent to having an Enhanced Disclosure check carried out through AccessNI.

After initial checks have been carried out, you will be invited to an interview with a social worker to verify your identity.

Once the HSC Trust is satisfied that you are eligible, you will receive an approval letter which allows you to start work as a home childcarer. It may also enable the family you work for to claim tax credits to help with the cost of childcare.

Approval is valid for one year, and you must apply for renewal of approval each year.

You should make sure you are properly insured with:

  • public liability insurance to protect you against legal costs for any accident or injury that a child might suffer in your care
  • 'business use' cover on your motor insurance (if using your car for business purposes)

If you don't apply for approval or don't have your approval renewed, the family you work for may no longer be able to claim tax credits. This might lead to you losing your position.

column3: Accredited electrical and electronic equipment producer compliance scheme (England & Wales)
column4:
If you import, rebrand or manufacture electrical and electronic equipment (EEE) in England or Wales, you are classed as a producer of EEE and must be a member of an approved accredited producer compliance scheme (PCS).

You can find information on what products are classified as EEE on the Environment Agency website.

If you import, or arrange for others to import, EEE into the UK or another European Union member state to sell them on to other people on a professional basis you will be classed as an importer.

If you buy finished EEE products from a manufacturer and then add your own brand name before putting them on the market you will be classed a rebrander.

If you sell EEE products which you have made or manufactured under your own brand name you will be classed as a manufacturer.

PCSs arrange for waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) to be collected and treated, recycled or reused on behalf of their members. You can find a list of PSCs including contact details on the Environment Agency website.

Alternatively, you could establish your own PCS for your business or a group of businesses. Information on how to do this is available on the Environment Agency website.

To register with a PCS you will need to:

  • pay a registration fee
  • inform the PCS of how much EEE you place on the UK market each quarter
  • inform the PCS whether the equipment was supplied for household or non-household use

When you are registered you will receive a producer registration number which you'll need to give to anyone who distributes or sells your EEE.

If you are a producer of EEE and you fail to join a PCS you will be committing an offence and you could receive an unlimited fine.

If you are the Construction (Design and Management) Regulations (CDM) co-ordinator for a construction project, you must notify the Health and Safety Executive Northern Ireland (HSENI).

You must provide specific information including:

  • the address of the construction site
  • the name of the district council where the site is located
  • a description of the project and work
  • contact details of the client, CDM co-ordinator and principal contractor
  • contact details for any contractor and designer already contracted
  • the date for construction to start and the planned duration of the construction
  • the time allowed for preparation of construction work
  • the estimated number of people working on site
  • a declaration signed by or on behalf of the client, confirming they are aware of their duties

If you act as a childminder in Wales, you must be registered with Care and Social Services Inspectorate Wales (CSSIW).

You are considered a childminder if you look after at least one child under the age of eight on domestic premises in return for payment or other reward.

Applications for registration must contain specific information on you, your premises, any person who may be on your premises, and your arrangements for childminding.

Registration may be refused if you don't comply with certain criteria, and will be refused if you are disqualified from registration - eg if you are barred from regulated activity relating to children. If registration is granted, you must comply with any conditions attached to the registration.

At any time, CSSIW can notify you of any action you must take to ensure compliance with the requirement to register, registration conditions, legislation, regulations or the National Minimum Standards for Regulated Child Care.

Failure to comply with the above may result in enforcement action.

column3: Pollution prevention and control permit Part A and B (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you carry out activities that can affect the environment, under Schedule 1 of the Pollution Prevention and Control Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2003, and in particular affect emissions into the air, water and/or land you must hold a Part A permit for your installation or mobile plant.

If the activities involve emissions into the air only, you may need a Part B permit. (Air emissions are also covered by Part C permits which are issued by your local district council).

Part A and B permits are issued by the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA).

Applications must be in writing, contain specific information and and documents regarding your business and the emissions you produce, and will be subject to a fee. You must pay the fee at the time you apply, and the amount will vary depending on whether your application is a new one or a renewal, and whether you need to pay any other charges.

Your application should describe:

  • process activity
  • nature of the releases to the environment
  • how releases will be controlled to comply with Best Available Techniques (BAT) requirements
  • how the environmental impact of these releases are acceptable

You should return the completed application form to the NIEA.

Some applications may be subject to a consultation process involving other Departments, Agencies and bodies. You may have to advertise your application in a local newspaper and, for Part A activities, also in the Belfast Gazette.

Your permit will have conditions specific to your operations and requires you to utilise BAT to prevent and minimise releases to the environment. It may also contain specific emission limit requirements for your activities. For specified waste management activities the activity must be managed by a fit and proper person. Planning permission must be obtained before a permit is issued.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a permit. The types of conditions may vary dependent upon the type of permit.

If you operate a Part A installation or mobile plant and wish to surrender your permit you must make an application to the enforcing authority accompanied by a site closure plan along with a fee. Only when the enforcing authority is satisfied that the closure plan has been implemented will the permit be revoked.

If you operate a Part B installation and wish to surrender your permit you must notify the enforcing authority.

You must obtain a licence if you want to dive or anchor near, survey, remove artefacts from, excavate or disturb a wreck that has been designated for protection under section 1 of the Protection of Wrecks Act 1973.

Each designated wreck has a restricted area around it and you require a licence to carry out any of the following activities within the restricted area:

  • tamper with, damage or remove any part of the vessel, or any object contained in such a vessel
  • carry out diving or salvage operations on such a wreck or remove objects from the sea bed
  • deposit, so that it falls and lies on the sea bed, anything which could wholly or partly obliterate the site or obstruct access to it, or damage any part of the wreck

Four types of licence can be applied for:

  • a visitor licence
  • a survey licence
  • a recovery licence
  • an excavation licence

You should apply for the relevant licence from:

  • English Heritage in England
  • Cadw in Wales
  • Department of the Environment in Northern Ireland (DOENI)
  • Historic Scotland in Scotland

You will be required to provide, as a minimum, details of:

  • your qualifications and experience
  • two referees
  • the diving Code of Practice that you will be following
  • other divers

You will only be granted a licence if you are considered to be competent and properly equipped to carry out operations appropriate to the importance of the wreck and its artefacts or if you have a legitimate reason for operating in the designated area.

You do not normally require a licence for bathing, angling and navigation within the restricted area, providing there is no likelihood of damaging the wreck or obstructing work on it. Anchoring on the site is only permitted for licensed activities or in cases of maritime distress.

Diving on wrecks that have been designated as dangerous under section 2 of the Protection of Wrecks Act 1973 is strictly prohibited.

You must not move cattle, deer, goats, pigs or sheep from any premises unless the movement is made under the authority of a General Movement Licence for each species from the Welsh Government. All movements must also comply with the conditions of the licence.

In addition, all movement of deer, pigs, sheep and goats must be accompanied by a completed Animal Movement Licence (AML) obtained from your local authority.

Movement of sheep and goats must be recorded on an AML1, movement of pigs on an AML2 and movement of deer on an AML24.

The keeper of the animals must complete the AML and retain the yellow copy, and the rest should be passed to the haulier. The haulier must keep the blue copy and give the white and pink copies to the recipient of the animals who must report the movement and supply the white copy to their local authority within three days.

Cattle must be accompanied by their passports and all cattle movements must be notified to the British Cattle Movement Service within three days of the movement taking place.

Any animal movement will also trigger a six day standstill (or 20 days for pigs) on the premises of destination where other movements are prohibited unless an exception applies.

If you operate a business offering adult placement services in Northern Ireland, you must be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority (RQIA).

Applications must give specified information and may be subject to a fee.

If you wish to operate or manage more than one service, you must make a separate application for each organisation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a registration.

column3: Licence to generate, transmit, distribute or supply electricity (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you generate, transmit, distribute or supply electricity, you must be licensed by the Northern Ireland Authority for Utility Regulation (NIAUR), unless an exemption is applicable.

Applications must be in the form, and contain the details, specified in the relevant schedule of Electricity (Applications for Licences and Extensions of Licences) (No. 2) Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2007. Applications will be subject to a fee and you must publish a notice of the application within 14 days of making it.

Notices must be placed in the Belfast Gazette and in a local newspaper, or newspapers circulating in the area which includes the premises specified or described in the application. Where a map is required for your application, you must include in the notice a statement of the details where a copy of the map is available for inspection by the public. Copies of any newspaper in which the notice appears must be sent to NIAUR.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

You must develop and maintain a co-ordinated, efficient and economical supply system.

If you hold a licence to transmit electricity you must maintain a similar transmission system that has a long-term ability of meeting transmission demands and help/facilitate supply and generation competition.

If you are a public supplier, you must supply electricity and any lines or plants as soon as possible on request. You must give a notice detailing such things as pricing to a person who has not previously had electricity to the premises in question.

You must maintain any meter let or lent to a customer in proper order so that it correctly registers the quantity of electricity supplied and, in the case of pre-payment meters, operates properly upon receipt of payment.

If you are supplying electricity through a meter which is used for ascertaining the quantity of electricity supplied, you must ensure that the meter is constructed and installed in an approved manner.

You may not charge for any alteration or replacement of an electricity meter in order to meet the needs of a disabled person.

If you cut off the supply of electricity to any premises due to a default in payment, you must resume the supply within two working days of the customer paying the outstanding sums, including reasonable expenses of disconnection and re-connection.

Exemptions to supply by public suppliers may apply.

You must comply with rules relating to how you fix tariffs.

You must have consent to construct a generating station and to put up overhead lines.

You must comply with any directions by the Department in order to preserve the security of buildings or installations connected with the generation, transmission or supply of electricity, or mitigating the effects of an emergency.

If you generate, transmit, supply or distribute electricity without a licence you may commit an offence and be fined.

If you fail to provide any documents when requested you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000. If you destroy or alter any document requested you may be fined. If you fail to provide any information when requested you may be fined.

column3: Safety certificate for sports stands (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate a sports ground in Northern Ireland, which is not designated as requiring a safety certificate, you require a safety certificate for the use of any stand that holds 500 or more spectators.

One certificate may cover more than one stand.

Applications should be made to the district council in whose area your stand is situated. You should return the completed application form with a fee of £50.

You must provide requested information and plans to the district council within the time they specify.

You may apply for:

  • a general safety certificate to permit the use of the stand for viewing a specified activity or number of activities over an indefinite period
  • a special safety certificate to permit the use of the stand for viewing a specified activity or number of activities on specified occasions

To be eligible for a general safety certificate you must be the person responsible for the management of the ground. To be eligible for a special safety certificate you must be responsible for the activity to be viewed from the stand on that occasion.

column3: Safety certificate for sports stands (England, Scotland and Wales)
column4:
If you operate a sports ground in England, Scotland or Wales which is not designated as requiring a safety certificate, you must hold a safety certificate for any covered stand that holds 500 or more spectators.

One certificate may cover more than one stand.

To obtain an application form, you should contact the local authority in which your stand is situated.

In addition to the application form, you may be required to provide a location/site plan, a risk assessment, contingency plans, spectator safety policy and an electrical certificate. You may be asked to provide further information which must be submitted within the time specified.

You may apply for either:

  • a general safety certificate to permit the use of the stand for viewing a specified activity or number of activities over an indefinite period
  • a special safety certificate to permit the use of the stand for viewing a specified activity or number of activities on specified occasions

To be eligible for a general safety certificate you must be the person responsible for the management of the ground. To be eligible for a special safety certificate you must be responsible for the activity to be viewed from the stand on that occasion.

You must comply with the terms and conditions attached to the certificate, such as keeping safety maintenance or attendance records, and with any other specified requirements.

You may apply to have your safety certificate amended, replaced or transferred to another suitable person.

If you hold a general safety certificate you must notify the local authority before extending or altering the stand or installations, for example by changing the entrances or exits to or from the stand.

You must allow authorised officers to inspect your stands and take copies of your records at any reasonable time.

Failure to comply with the safety certificate requirements may result in a fine and/or imprisonment for up to two years.
To operate as an energy assessor you must be a member of an accreditation scheme which covers the types of work you undertake and is approved by the Secretary of State.

column3: Estate agency redress scheme registration (All UK)
column4:
If you operate as an estate agent and deal with residential property, you must join a redress scheme. The redress scheme will deal with complaints.

If you fail to join a redress scheme, you may be issued with a penalty charge notice.

The current approved redress schemes that can be joined are the Property Ombudsman (TPOS) and the Surveyors Ombudsman Service (SOS).

If you operate a public weighbridge for which a charge is made, you require a certificate of competence issued by the Chief Inspector for Weights and Measures at the Northern Ireland Trading Standards Service.

Application forms are available from the Northern Ireland Trading Standards Service by calling Consumerline on Tel 0300 123 6262.

Your application must include the name of the person to be certified, the type of weighbridge to be used and its address. Arrangements will be then made for you to sit a test.

If you hold a public weighbridge certificate of competence then you must:

  • carry out weighing on demand (unless you have reasonable cause not to)
  • carry out the weighing fairly
  • provide a written statement of the weight to the person requiring the weighing
  • make a record of the weighing including the date, time and, for vehicles, details to identify the vehicle and the type of load on the vehicle
  • keep records of weighings for two years
  • make sure that you obtain the name and address of the person requesting the weighing
  • not carry out double weighing for trade purposes (this is also known as axle weighing)

If you fail to comply with the requirements you could be fined up to £5,000, imprisoned for six months or both.

To act as solicitor in England and Wales, you must hold a practising certificate issued by the Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA).

You must pay a fee in connection with your practising certificate.

Conditions may be attached to a practising certificate under certain circumstances.

column3: School special educational needs (SEN) approval (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you are a non-maintained school that caters for special educational needs, you must be approved by the Department of Education.

A child will be deemed to have special educational needs if he or she has a learning difficulty that requires special education to be provided for him or her.

The Department of Education must consent for any child to be educated at your premises.

Your school must specialise in providing education for children with special educational needs.

If you wish to practise as a barrister in England or Wales, you must:

  • have a qualifying law degree of at least lower second class honours or an undergraduate degree of at least lower second class honours in any other subject followed by a law conversion course
  • have completed the Bar Professional Training Course 
  • have completed 12 qualifying sessions 
  • have been called to the Bar by one of the Inns of Court 
  • have completed a one-year pupillage with an authorised training organisation, such as barristers' chambers

The Bar Code of Conduct requires all pupillage vacancies to be advertised online. You can find more details on the Bar Council website.

Once you have completed your pupillage you must either obtain:

  • tenancy in a set of barristers' chambers
  • employment with a company or other organisation that employs barristers

To practise you must:

  • hold a current practising certificate issued by the Bar Council - you will need to apply to the Bar Council for this and pay a fee (renewal is required each year)
  • provide in writing to the Bar Council details of your current address, telephone number of your office or chambers and, if an employed barrister, name, address, telephone number and nature of the business of your employer
  • undertake all required continuing professional development (CPD)
  • comply with all requirements of the Bar Code of Conduct

During the first three years in which you hold a practising certificate you must complete a minimum of 45 hours' CPD, including at least nine hours of advocacy and three hours of ethics. In each subsequent year you must complete at least 12 hours of CPD.

If you control non-domestic premises, you must ensure that you notify the local authority of any cooling tower or evaporative condenser (notifiable devices) on the premises.

Notification must be in writing (including by electronic means) on a form approved by the Health & Safety Executive.

You must notify the local authority of any changes to your cooling tower within one month of the change.

If the device ceases to be a notifiable device, you must notify the local authority in writing (or by electronic means) as soon as possible.

If you wish to carry out reserved legal activities as a legal executive you must be authorised.

A reserved legal activity is one of the following:

  • exercising a right of audience
  • conducting litigation
  • reserved instrument, probate or notarial activities
  • administering oaths

Authorisation is obtained from the Institute of Legal Executives (ILEX).

If you wish to place apparatus on a street or road in England and Wales, you must be licensed by the local street authority.

In Scotland, you must obtain permission in writing - this can include by electronic means.

Licences are also required if you wish to inspect, adjust, maintain, repair, renew, move, alter or remove such apparatus, or break up a street, or sewer, drain or tunnel under a street, for the purpose of doing so.

However, if you need to carry out such actions for emergency works - ie works necessary to avoid or prevent danger - you must instead give notice as soon as reasonably practicable, and at the latest within two hours of the works commencing.

If you wish to carry out street works involving breaking up a street, or a sewer, drain or tunnel under a street, you must give at least seven working days' notice and ensure that you complete the works as soon as reasonably practicable.

A fee may be payable for a licence, and you must comply with any conditions that are attached to the licence.

You must comply with any directions by the authority in regard to timing of works and placing of apparatus, and comply with any codes of practice to ensure that you:

  • minimise inconvenience to people using the street
  • protect the structure of the street

You must comply with prescribed safety measures, including ensuring that:

  • any part of the street which is broken up or obstructed is adequately guarded and lit
  • traffic signs are placed and operated as necessary for the guidance or direction of people using the street

Works must be supervised by a suitably qualified supervisor and there must always be a qualified trained operative on site.

You must record the location of all apparatus placed or moved in the street, stating the nature of the apparatus and whether it is currently in use. The apparatus must be satisfactorily maintained for the safety and convenience of people using the street and the structure of the street.

If you are carrying out works in a street which is in the vicinity of a railway, tramway, dock, harbour, pier or canal, you must comply with requirements by the transport authority as to the displaying of lights to avoid any risk of their being mistaken for, or a hindrance to, a signal light.

If you wish to carry out works affecting a public sewer you must consult the sewer authority - or in Scotland, Scottish Water - before giving notice.

Where your apparatus is to be affected by other major works you must consult with the local authority and take any necessary measures regarding the apparatus in order to secure efficient implementation of the works in question.

If your works are likely to affect another person's apparatus you must comply with any reasonable requirement to allow them to protect or access their apparatus.

You must reinstate the street as soon as practicable after the completion of your street works, and you must give notice to the local authority within ten working days of the reinstatement. In Scotland, this notice must be given by the working day following the completion.

If the reinstatement is interim, you must complete permanent reinstatement as soon as possible, and within six months from the completion of the interim reinstatement.

Permanent reinstatement must include reinstatement of features designed to assist people with a disability, and must comply with any requirements on materials to be used, standards of workmanship and performance standards.

If you fail to comply, you may be fined up to £5,000.

To collect money or sell articles in the street or any public place for charitable or other purposes in England or Wales, you generally require a street collection licence.

If a licence is required in your area, it will be administered by your local council. Details are usually available on their website. The exception to this is in Greater London (other than the City of London), where the Metropolitan Police Service is responsible for licensing street collections.

This requirement does not apply where the selling or collection takes place in the ordinary course of trade for the purposes of earning a livelihood and there is no representation that any proceeds will be donated to a charitable, philanthropic or benevolent purpose.

If you fail to comply you may be fined £200.

To provide ATP certification for refrigerated trucks carrying perishable goods from or to the UK you need to be licensed by the Vehicle and Operator Service Agency (VOSA).

Applications must be sent electronically to VOSA.

If you wish to use a raised structure in Scotland, eg platform or stage, to provide seating or standing accommodation, you require approval from your local authority.

Conditions may be attached including the maximum number of people permitted on the structure.

Application fees are payable.

If you intend to rent out a property you may have to apply to your district council for a certificate of fitness.

You don't need to apply for a certificate of fitness if:

  • the tenancy began before 1 April 2007
  • a renovation or houses in multiple occupation (HMO) grant has been paid by the Northern Ireland Housing Executive (NIHE) - this only applies for a period of ten years from the date of the grant
  • the property is registered with NIHE as an HMO
  • the property was formerly let under a protected or statutory tenancy where a regulated rent certificate has been issued - this only applies for a period of ten years from the date of issue of the certificate 

If none of these exemptions apply you should contact your district council for an application form or visit their website to apply online.

You must provide certain information about your property, including when it was built, number of rooms and the facilities provided.

You will also need to pay an application fee -these are set by district councils and may vary from area to area.

Your property will be inspected by the council to ensure it is fit to live in. They will check for issues like structural soundness, the state of repair, dampness and access to clean water.

If the property is fit for human habitation you will be issued with a certificate of fitness.

Unless the tenancy is a protected or statutory tenancy, you will then be free to charge your tenants a market rent.

If you fail to apply for the inspection of a qualifying property within 28 days of a new tenancy being granted, you may be fined up to £2,500.

If you offer driving instruction for payment (either as money or goods), you must be registered in the register of approved instructors, maintained by the Driving Standards Agency (DSA) and hold a licence authorising you to give instruction.

In order to be registered you must meet the following criteria:

  • be the holder of either a current UK driving licence or a Community Licence
  • have held either the driving licence or a relevant equivalent for a total of at least four years within the last six years
  • have passed the instructor's examination - the theory, driving ability and instructional tests

When you successfully pass the instructor's examination, you should apply to the DSA for inclusion on the register. Your application must include:

  • your examination pass certificates
  • your driving licence
  • evidence or a statement that you have not been disqualified from driving for at least four years
  • a declaration that you are a 'fit and proper' person to be entered on the register

All applications must be in the format specified by the DSA and will be subject to a fee.

You must display a certificate - or current licence - in your vehicle that confirms you are authorised to provide driving instruction.

You will occasionally be required to undergo continued ability and fitness tests, which consist of an examiner being present whilst you are instructing a pupil. If you are unsuccessful, you must retake the test within fourteen weeks.

Registration lasts for four years.

For registration extensions, you must apply to the DSA in the required format and pay the relevant application fee. You must also be able to show that:

  • you have not refused to undergo any ongoing testing obligations throughout your registration period
  • your ability and fitness to give instruction are still of a satisfactory standard
  • you still hold a driving licence
  • you have not been disqualified from driving
  • you are still a fit and proper person

If your name is removed from the register, you will have to retake the approved driving instructors examination again.

To provide registered day care services in Scotland you must be registered with Social Care and Social Work Improvement for Scotland (SCSWIS).

You can apply online, or by contacting your local SCSWIS office for an application pack. You will have to pay a registration fee when you apply, and your application must include:

  • details on yourself (if operating as an individual) or your organisation
  • details of the manager (if you will not be the manager of the service)
  • references
  • financial details - eg a statement from the bank on your financial standing and reliability
  • declarations regarding any convictions, bankruptcy or previous involvement in registered services

You must provide information on your proposed service, in particular:

  • its name and address
  • a statement of aims and objectives
  • staffing, recruitment and training
  • suitability and fitness of accommodation

You must also attach the following documents:

  • recruitment policy
  • programmes for staff induction, development and training
  • plans of the premises
  • copies of planning permission, the building warrant and building completion certificates - if relevant
  • surveyors reports
  • ventilation, heating and lighting details
  • Confirmation of registration by Registrar of Independent Schools
  • financial information
  • aims and objectives statements

SCSWIS will inspect your premises, staff and management before they approve the application. You must be able to prove that you meet the relevant National Care Standards to be registered. You can find these online.

To meet the required standards you must:

  • provide appropriate information for users of the service - this includes the aims of the service, the support it provides, fees information and the complaints procedure
  • allow visitors to observe the service before they use it
  • provide a safe environment - this should be smoke free, hygienic and stimulating
  • provide services and facilities that conform to relevant legislation and are clean and well maintained
  • ensure standards of care that protect a child's health and wellbeing - this includes providing the opportunity for children to rest or sleep, maintain a well-balanced diet, and have access to fresh air and physical play
  • employ highly skilled and competent staff who understand child and young person development, can interact effectively with children, and can assess their development to improve future learning
  • offer a balanced range of activities to all ages of young persons
  • provide  individual support for each child's needs
  • ensure mutual respect between staff, children, parents and carers
  • have in place adequate management and staffing arrangements - demonstrate that staff receive quality training, have knowledge of policies and procedures, and benefit from supportive and reliable management, and that the recruitment process is comprehensive
  • draw up written agreements with users to define the service and set out terms of the contract - this should include information on the date the service begins, who provides the service, charges, and length of service

SCSWIS will monitor your adherence to the care standards after registration through ongoing evaluation.

You must comply with any conditions attached to the registration. You must keep your certificate of registration - or a copy of it - in a prominent place in any premises you have.

column3: Registration to practise as a vet (All UK)
column4:
To practise as a vet, you must register as a member of the Royal College of Veterinary Surgeons (RCVS) under one of the five lists. These are the:

  • general list
  • Commonwealth list - for those holding a Commonwealth qualification
  • foreign list - for those holding a foreign qualification
  • temporary list
  • visiting European list

You must provide evidence of your qualifications and any other information required by the RCVS.

You must pay a registration fee.

If you are convicted in the UK or relevant European country of a criminal offence, found to have acted in a disgraceful or unprofessional manner, or if you are found to have provided misleading or false information on your application, the RCVS will investigate and you could be removed from the register.

Your name will not be reinstated to the register unless a disciplinary committee agree to it. Applications for your name to be reinstated cannot be made for at least ten months after you have been removed or suspended from the register.

If you practise as a vet, or claim to be one without being registered with the RCVS, you could be guilty of a criminal offence and liable to a fine.

If you wish to sell alcohol, for consumption on or off your premises in Scotland, your premises must be licensed by the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing board) for the area in which your premises are based.

Your premises will also require a personal licence holder to sell and authorise the sale of alcohol.

Applications for a premises licence must include details about yourself (including any criminal convictions) and your premises, and should be accompanied by:

  • a detailed operating plan
  • a scale plan of the layout of your premises
  • a planning certificate, building standards certificate and, if food is to be sold, food hygiene certificate
  • an application fee based on the non-domestic rateable value of your premises

The operating plan for your premises must contain details on:

  • the activities to be carried on
  • whether alcohol will be sold for consumption on or off the premises (or both)
  • the times when alcohol will be sold for consumption on and/or off the premises
  • the times when any other activities - eg sale of food - will be carried on
  • whether children will be allowed on the premises and, if so, the age at which they can enter, the times they can do so and the parts of the premises they are allowed access to
  • the capacity of the premises
  • information about the premises manager (you may nominate yourself)

If your premises are about to be constructed, altered or extended, you may apply to the licensing board for a provisional premises licence. This enables you to have an assessment made as to the feasibility of the proposed development before you obtain a full licence and potentially incur substantial expenditure and costs. However, you will not be able to sell alcohol until you have been granted a full licence and if you don't apply for a full licence within a certain period the provisional licence will be revoked.

Contact your licensing board for an application form or visit their website to apply online. You must be aged 18 or over to apply for a premises licence or a provisional licence.

If your application is granted you will be issued a premises licence and a summary of the licence.

Conditions will be attached to the licence - eg stating that you must comply with the operating plan, have an age-checking policy in place and ensure that the premises manager holds a personal licence.

Licences are valid indefinitely, but you will need to pay an annual fee.

You must keep the licence (or a certified copy) in a safe place on your premises and display the summary licence in a prominent position on the premises. You must produce the licence on request for inspection by the police or other enforcement officers. You can be fined up to £1,000 if you fail to do so.

You must also notify the licensing board of any change to your name or address, or that of your premises manager.

If you sell alcohol, or allow alcohol to be sold on your premises, without a licence you may be fined up to £20,000, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

If you wish to serve alcohol outside of your licensed hours - eg for a wedding - you must apply to extend your hours.

If you wish to cater for an event taking place off your premises - eg providing alcohol for a wedding - you must apply for an occasional licence.
If you breed dogs in Northern Ireland, you must register your breeding establishment with the district council where the establishment is situated.

To act as an insolvency practitioner in Northern Ireland, you must be a member of and authorised by a recognised professional body or hold an authorisation granted by the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI).

Applications to the DETI must be on Form IA1 and be accompanied by a fee.

The application will only be granted if you hold the relevant educational and practical training and experience and you are classed as a fit and proper person.

You will receive a written notice if your application is successful. This will state the date on which the authorisation starts.

If your application is unsuccessful you will be given a written notice detailing the reasons for the refusal.

You have 14 days in which to make written representations to the competent authority in relation to any refusal.

Authorisations may be withdrawn if you:

  • are found to be no longer fit and proper
  • fail to comply with any requirements under the Insolvency (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 or the Insolvency Practitioners Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2006
  • have provided any false or misleading information

You will be the insolvency practitioner for a company if you act as its liquidator, provisional liquidator, administrator, administrative receiver or as a supervisor under a company voluntary arrangement.

You will be the insolvency practitioner for an individual if you act as a trustee in bankruptcy, interim receiver, trustee under a deed of arrangement for a creditor, a supervisor of an individual voluntary arrangement or as the administrator of a deceased individual's estate.

If you sell alcohol from licensed premises, you or a member of your staff must hold a personal licence.

To qualify for a licence you must:

  • be 18 years or older
  • hold a licensing qualification
  • not already hold a personal licence
  • not have had a personal licence revoked in the past five years

Applications are made to your local licensing board.

Applications may be refused if:

  • you have a criminal conviction for a 'relevant offence'
  • you held a personal licence which expired or you surrendered a personal licence within three years of your application

You must tell the Licensing Board if you are convicted of a 'relevant offence' between the making of an application and it being determined.

A 'relevant offence' includes violent or sexual offences, firearms offences, drugs offences, aiding and abetting, inciting, counseling or procuring any relevant offence or any other offence which resulted in imprisonment.

Once granted, your personal licence will be valid for ten years.

To hold an ad-hoc event in England or Wales you need a temporary event notice (TEN).

A temporary event is any event where you intend to carry out a licensable activity on unlicensed premises or wish to operate outside the terms of your existing premises licence or club premises certficate (eg by putting on a wedding).

Licensable activities are:

  • the sale of alcohol
  • the supply of alcohol to members of a private club 
  • regulated entertainment including music, singing, dancing, film exhibitions, theatrical performances or indoor sporting events
  • the provision of hot food or drink to be consumed on or off the premises between 23.00 and 05.00

Your event must:

  • involve less than 500 people at any one time
  • last no more than 96 hours

You must give a TEN to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) for the area in which your event is due to be held at least ten working days before the proposed start of the event.

You must also give a copy of the notice to the police no later than ten working days before the event.

You must be aged 18 or over to apply.

Your TEN must be accompanied by an application fee of £21.

If there is no objection to your TEN, the licensing authority will issue you with a copy of the TEN containing an acknowledgement of receipt.

You must keep the TEN (or a certified copy) in a safe place on the premises and display a copy of the notice in a prominent position on the premises.

You can give a maximum of five TENs per year unless you are a personal licence holder, in which case you can give a maximum of 50 TENs per year.

If you are holding consecutive events on the same premises, there must be a minimum 24-hour break between events.

You may apply for a notice on 12 occasions each year in respect of any particular premises subject to a maximum aggregate duration of the periods covered by TENs at any individual premises of 15 days in any year.

If you carry out a licensable activity, or allow your premises to be used for such an activity without a TEN, you may be fined up to £20,000, imprisoned for up to six months or both.

If you knowingly make any false statements in your application form you may be fined up to £5,000.

All products used for the protection of plants in agriculture, horticulture, forestry, industrial or amenity situations, and home gardens must be authorised by the Chemicals Regulation Directorate (CRD), of the Health and Safety Executive, before they can be sold, distributed, stored or used in the UK.  This includes imported products.

Plant protection products (PPPs) may be used to control fungi, bacteria, viruses, insects, weeds, molluscs and any other 'pest' that would be harmful to crops or garden plants. Weed killers used on hard surfaces to control weeds are also included. 

Active substances used in PPPs may include micro-organisms (such as bacteria or nematodes) or plant extracts which are classed as biopesticides, as well as chemically manufactured compounds.

For further information about the legislation affecting PPPs, or applying for authorisation of a PPP, or to check what products are authorised for use, go to CRD's website (www.pesticides.gov.uk) or telephone 01904 455775.

If you wish to supply water to non-household premises, you must be licensed by Ofwat (the Water Services Regulation Authority).

There are two types of licence you may apply for:

  • retail licence - this authorises you to purchase a wholesale supply of water from an appointed water company (known as a water undertaker) in order to supply water to your customers' premises
  • combined licence - this authorises you use a water undertaker's supply system (as per a retail licence) and to introduce water into that supply system for the purposes of supplying your customers

Each premises you supply must:

  • not be household premises
  • be likely to use at least 50 megalitres of water per year
  • not be supplied with water by another company with a water supply licence

Before making an application it is recommended that you contact Ofwat for informal advice.

You must include the following with your application:

  • details about your business
  • evidence of your financial and managerial capability, including audited accounts, a business plan and details of the systems and procedures you have in place to comply with statutory duties, licensing conditions and operational standards
  • an application fee of £2,000 (for a retail licence) or £2,500 (for a combined licence)

Within ten working days of receiving written confirmation that your application is valid from Ofwat, you must publish a notice of your application on your website or in such other way that you consider will bring it to the attention of interested parties. You must let Ofwat know that you have published the notice.

The application process will take up to 60 working days, during which time Ofwat will work with you to clarify what you need to do to satisfy the criteria for obtaining a licence.

During this period you will also need to demonstrate to the Drinking Water Inspectorate (DWI) that your water is wholesome at the point of supply. This is achieved by way of paper-based assessment showing that you have an understanding of water supply and water quality issues.

If you are applying for a combined licence you must also demonstrate to DWI that you are aware of your responsibilities with regard to the introduction of potable water into the water supply system, and that you have the resources to meet these.

You will only be granted a licence if your business is a limited company and is not a water or sewerage undertaker.

If your application is successful you will receive a copy of your licence.

This will give the date from which the licence comes into effect and will also state that the licence will remain in force unless revoked or terminated by the Secretary of State with not less than 25 years' notice. The licence will also be subject to a number of standard conditions which you must comply with or risk having your licence revoked.

You will then be able to supply water to customers subject to:

  • entering into an access agreement with the relevant water undertaker for retail supply
  • completing a detailed technical assessment for DWI before introducing potable water into a water undertaker's supply system (combined licence holders only if they intend to put their own water into the undertaker's supply system)

If you breach any conditions of your licence, Ofwat may revoke the licence and/or take appropriate enforcement action.

column3: Pollution prevention and control permit - petrol vapour recovery (Scotland)
column4:
If you operate an installation for the unloading of petrol into stationary storage tanks or motor vehicle refuelling activities at a service station in Scotland, you may require a pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

You must include the following information in your application:

  • your name, telephone number, address, or those of your authorised contact, and any other necessary contact details
  • the address of the site and a national grid reference, map or plan to show the site location and boundaries
  • the local authority where the business is to be based
  • details of any existing permits for the installation
  • the legal status of the operation

If you are applying for a PPC for a new installation or to change an existing PPC, you must also include the following documents:

  • site maps of the installation - showing the location of the site and the activities to be completed
  • details of how the petrol is to be unloaded - eg when the vapour balancing equipment was installed, how much petrol is unloaded in a year, and how deliveries are controlled
  • copies of technical documents - site specific assessments, process diagrams for vapour balancing
  • supervision, training and qualification documents for staff
  • examination schedules for equipment
  • contingency measures

An application and annual subsistence fee will be charged.

Your permit may have specific conditions to adhere to, depending on your operations. You must also follow any best available techniques to prevent and minimise pollution.

If you wish to surrender a PPC, you will have to apply to SEPA using the relevant form and pay a processing fee.

If you are an operator of a business in Scotland regulated by a pollution prevention and control permit (PPC), you may have to report your annual emission releases to the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) for inclusion in the Scottish Pollutant Release Inventory (SPRI).

Part A permit holders - businesses that have the potential to cause emissions to land or water, or larger volume emissions to the air - must report to SEPA at yearly intervals and immediately inform them of any accident or incident that may affect the environment. When reporting you must include the following information:

  • your NIC number
  • the name, address and permit number of your site
  • company details - including contact details
  • levels of pollutants to air, water, waste water, land and off-site transfers

You must report using the SPRI reporting form in either electronic or paper format.

Permit holders may be requested at any point by SEPA to provide information on their emissions or discharges.

column3: Pollution prevention and control permit - Part A (Scotland)
column4:
If your business operates certain types of installations in Scotland which have the potential to cause emissions to land or water, or larger volume emissions to air, you will require a Part A pollution prevention and control permit (PPC).

PPC Part A permits regulate a broad range of environmental impacts, including:

  • emissions to air, land and water
  • energy efficiency
  • waste reduction
  • raw material consumption
  • noise vibration and heat
  • accident prevention
  • the condition of your site

When applying, you must include:

  • your name, telephone number, address and any other necessary contact details
  • the address of the site and a national grid reference, map or plan to show the site location and boundaries
  • a site report explaining the condition of the site and identifying any pollutants on the land
  • description of the activities to be carried out at the site
  • materials and substances that will be used
  • all emissions from the installation - the nature, quantity and sources - and details of what measures will be taken to limit these emissions
  • a copy of a safety report
  • a non-technical summary of all the information provided

You can apply online or on a paper form. An application fee may be charged.

You must advertise your application in the Edinburgh Gazette and at least one local newspaper. The advert must explain who the applicant is, the site of the installation, the activities to be carried out, and any possible effects of emissions. It must state where the application can be viewed, and advise that any representations can be made to SEPA.

Your permit will have specific conditions attached, depending on your operations. You must also follow any best available techniques to prevent and minimise pollution.

If you want to surrender your Part A permit, you must apply to SEPA and pay the relevant fee.

Smaller installations that only have the potential to produce emissions to air may be required to obtain a Part B PPC permit.

column3: Pollution prevention and control permit - Part B (Scotland)
column4:
If your business operates certain types of installation which have the potential to cause emissions to air in Scotland you will require a Part B pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit.

Part B PPC permits regulate smaller installations that only have the potential to cause emissions to air.

The Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) provides guidance on what activities require a Part B permit.

You can apply online or use a paper form. You must include the following information when you apply:

  • your name, telephone number, address and any other necessary contact details
  • the address of the site and a national grid reference, map or plan to show the site location and boundaries
  • the local authority where the business is to be based - if a mobile plant
  • description of the activities to be carried out at the site
  • all emissions from the installation - the nature, quantity and sources
  • a copy of a safety report

An application fee may be charged.

Your application may also be considered by any of the following consulting bodies:

  • the Health & Safety Executive - for sites that require a nuclear licence
  • the relevant Health Board where the installation will operate
  • your local authority
  • Scottish Natural Heritage - if the installation may affect a Site of Special Scientific Interest

Your permit will have specific conditions to adhere to, depending on your operations. You must also follow any best available techniques to prevent and minimise pollution.

If your operation is larger, or causes emissions to water or land and is an activity prescribed for control under part A of the PPC Regs, you will be required to obtain a Part A PPC permit.

If you offer amusements with prizes on your premises in Northern Ireland, you may need to hold a pleasure permit. Pleasure permits are only issued for premises used wholly or mainly for the provision of amusements.

Applications must be made to the district council where your premises are situated and will be subject to a fee.

Conditions may be attached to a permit.

If you operate as a slaughterman in Great Britain, you require a licence from the Food Standards Agency.

You are considered to be operating as a slaughterman if you:

  • restrain any animal for the purpose of stunning, slaughtering or killing that animal
  • stun, slaughter or kill any animal
  • pith any stunned animal
  • assess the effective stunning or killing of any animal
  • shackle or hoist any stunned animal
  • bleed any animal which is not dead

However, you don't need a licence for the following activities:

  • killing an animal in an emergency, eg if it's in distress and where it needs to be killed immediately for welfare reasons
  • slaughtering your own animals for your private consumption on premises other than a slaughterhouse or knacker's yard
  • slaughtering or killing animals for a non-commercial purpose
  • killing animals by certain approved methods as a means of disease control
  • shooting animals in the field eg with a shotgun or rifle
  • dislocating the necks of, or decapitating, poultry on the agricultural premises where they were raised
  • killing farmed foxes or mink by certain approved methods
  • killing surplus chicks or embryos in hatchery waste by certain approved methods
  • shackling birds before stunning or killing
  • operating automatic equipment that stuns, slaughters or kills animals, without requiring you to carry out any of the activities above for which a licence is required
  • slaughtering or killing animals under veterinary supervision

To apply for a licence, you must be at least 18 years old and you require a certificate of competence from an authorised veterinary surgeon.

If you work at a licensed slaughterhouse, the assessment for the certificate of competence will usually be carried out by the authorised veterinary surgeon at that slaughterhouse. If you work in any other premises you should apply to the local Animal Health Divisional Office and they will arrange an assessment. A fee may be payable. You can then apply for either a full licence.

If you are in training to become a slaughterman you must apply for a provisional licence. This will be valid for a period of up to three months and will authorise you to carry out the relevant activities only in the presence, and under the direction of, a veterinary surgeon or the holder of a full licence covering the same species, operations and equipment.

You must disclose in your application form if you have been refused a licence to slaughter animals, had such a licence revoked or been convicted under any legislation concerning the welfare of animals.

If applying for a full licence, you must also enclose:

  • your certificate of competence
  • two passport sized photographs (with your name written on the back of each)

No fee is payable for a provisional licence but there a registration charge of £26 for a full licence.

Application forms can be downloaded from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) website. The same form is used to apply for a certificate of competence, provisional licence or full licence.

If granted, your licence will state the operations you are licensed to carry out, the relevant species of animal you may carry out those operations on and the equipment or instruments to be used.
 
You must:

  • ensure the welfare of the animals kept on your premises
  • ensure all employees have knowledge of the welfare legislation
  • follow all requirements applicable to slaughterhouses and knackers' yards

Additional requirements apply to the slaughter and killing of animals other than at a slaughterhouse or knacker's yard.
column5:
The slaughter of animals without stunning to meet Jewish and Muslim religious requirements must only be carried out in approved slaughterhouses.

If you wish to slaughter animals for food using the Jewish religious method (shechita), instead of a certificate of competence you may obtain a licence from the Rabbinical Commission for the Licensing of Shochetim in England and Wales or the Chief Rabbi in Scotland. You must then submit this with your application for a slaughterman licence.

If you operate without a licence or fail to comply with these requirements, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to three months or both.

column4:
If you own or operate a boat which you let out for hire or to carry a maximum of 12 passengers for reward, you need a boat hire licence.

Licence applications must be made to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) for the area in which your business operates and should be:

  • made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority)
  • signed by yourself
  • accompanied by a fee

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the area from which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • any other information required by the licensing authority

You may be required to produce a certificate, from a suitably qualified person, which states that each vessel covered by the licence is suitably designed, constructed, maintained and equipped and is safe for the purpose for which, and the place or waters in which, it is to be used.

Conditions may be attached to your licence, eg fixing the maximum number of people you can carry or which inland or tidal waters each vessel can be used in.

You must have public liability insurance, approved by the licensing authority, for each vessel.

If some of your passengers embark from a place outside the area of the licensing authority, you may also need to apply for a licence from that other area's licensing authority.

A licence is usually valid for three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

If you fail to have insurance for your vessel whilst holding a licence, fail to hold a boat hire licence or provide a false statement on your licence application, you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to comply with a licence condition you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

You must notify the licensing authority of any changes in circumstances that affect you or boat hiring activities and you must have their consent to make changes to your vessel. If you fail to notify the licensing authority or fail to obtain consent you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

If you have to surrender your licence and fail to do so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £500.

If you buy and sell scrap metal on a door-to-door basis (ie without using premises on which the metal is stored), you need an itinerant metal dealer's licence. This licence will allow you to carry on business anywhere in Scotland.

Licence applications must be made to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) for the area in which your business operates and should be:

  • made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority)
  • signed by yourself
  • accompanied by a fee

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the area from which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • any other information required by the licensing authority

Conditions may be attached to your licence.

A licence is usually valid for three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

Once you have a licence, you must keep records, either by using books with serially numbered pages or a computer or similar device which details any changes you make to your records.

For metal you buy, you must keep records of the:

  • description and weight
  • name and address of the seller
  • price paid for the metal

For metal you sell, you must keep receipts detailing the:

  • description and weight
  • name and address of the buyer
  • price you sold the metal for

Records and receipts must be kept for six months.

If you deal in second-hand goods as well as scrap metal, you also need a second-hand dealer's licence.

If your application is rejected the licensing authority won't consider any further application made within a year unless there are significant changes in your circumstances.

If you work as an itinerant metal dealer without a licence or make a false or misleading statement in your application you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500. If you fail to comply with any conditions you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

You must notify the licensing authority of any changes to your circumstance. If you fail to do so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000. If you fail to surrender your licence when requested you may commit an offence and be fined up to £250.

In addition a court may issue you with an order that prevents you from selling metal until seven days after acquiring it. This notice could be in force for up to two years.

If you fail to keep records you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000. If you falsify records or receipts you may commit an offence and be fined up to £2,500.

You must not sell metal to or buy metal from anyone under the age of 16. If you do so you may commit an offence and be fined up to £1,000.

If you are a scrap metal dealer operating from premises, you need a licence, unless you have an exemption warrant/temporary exemption warrant (see below). The licence will specify the place where you can carry out your business.

Applications must be made to the local authority (the licensing authority) for the area where your business operates and should be made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority), signed by yourself and accompanied by a fee.

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the address and the area from which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address 
  • any other information required by the licensing authority

Your application must also contain either a declaration that you are displaying a public notice in relation to your application or that you do not have rights in the premises that enable you to put up a notice and detailing the reasonable steps that you have made to get those rights.

From the date of making your application, you must (where possible) display a notice in or near your premises for 21 days stating:

  • that you have made an application for a licence
  • the particulars specified in your application
  • that any objections/representations relating to your application must be made to the licensing authority, the form in which they must be made and the deadline for doing so

At the end of this period you must submit a certificate to the licensing authority stating that you have complied with the requirement to advertise notice of your application.

Conditions may be attached to your licence, eg restricting your activities to a particular area.

A licence is usually valid for three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

Once you have a licence, you must keep records, either by using books with serially numbered pages or a computer or similar device which details any changes you make to your records.

For metal you receive at each place of business, you must record, immediately after receipt, the:

  • description and weight
  • date and time of receipt
  • name and address of the person it came from (where applicable)
  • price paid (if any) or your estimate of its value
  • registration mark of the delivery vehicle

For metal you process, despatch or otherwise dispose of from each place of business, you must record immediately after the disposal the:

  • description and weight of the metal at the time of disposal
  • date of disposal
  • the specific process you used to process the metal (where applicable)
  • name and address of the recipient and either the money or whatever you received in exchange (if you sold or exchanged the metal) or your estimate of its value

You must not dispose of scrap metal until at least 48 hours (excluding weekends) have elapsed since you acquired it, unless either your licence or an order made by the licensing authority allows you to do so.

If you have a certificate from the auditor of your business stating that, in a financial year within the last 18 months, the total amount you received in respect of metal sold or supplied exceeded £100,000, you can apply to the licensing authority for a
column5:
warrant exempting you from being licensed. A warrant is valid for three years and a temporary warrant for up to 18 months.

If you deal in second-hand goods as well as scrap metal, you also need a second-hand dealer's licence.

column3: Approval of course leading to regulated qualification (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you are an organisation wishing to offer regulated qualifications in Northern Ireland you must first be recognised as being suitable to operate as an awarding organisation.

Regulated qualifications are published on the Register of Regulated Qualifications, which assures users (learners, schools, colleges, etc) that your organisation has successfully completed independent checks with regards to integrity, governance, resources and competence.

The process of recognition is undertaken jointly by the qualifications regulators in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In Northern Ireland this is the Council for the Curriculum, Examinations and Assessment (CCEA).

In Northern Ireland, CCEA is the regulator for non-vocational qualifications and Ofqual regulates vocational qualifications.

Application forms are available on both the CCEA and Ofqual websites. You can use the same form for vocational or non-vocational qualifications - just indicate which body you want recognition from.

You will need to meet certain criteria, such as integrity and governance, in order to be recognised. You will be required to supply supporting documents with your application that show how you meet these criteria.

Completed application forms should be submitted to Ofqual, which will forward them on as appropriate.

No application fee is payable.

In order to stay recognised you will need to declare your compliance with the recognition criteria on an annual basis.

Once you are recognised as an awarding organisation, you must also have your qualifications accredited.

An external qualification will qualify for accreditation if it is provided for learners who are:

  • attending grant-aided schools
  • under 19 years of age and in full time further education
  • over the age of 19

column3: Waste packaging reprocessor accreditation (England, Wales & Scotland)
column4:
If you recover, recycle or export packaging waste for recovery overseas, you can apply to your environmental regulator for accreditation.

Your environmental regulator is the:

  • Environment Agency in England and Wales
  • Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) in Scotland

Recovering waste involves burning it as a fuel or using it to create energy in some other way. Recycling waste means creating new products from materials which have been thrown away.

Accreditation is a voluntary process but will allow your business to receive payments from registered producers for issuing electronic packaging waste recovery notes (ePRNs) and electronic packaging waste export recovery notes (ePERNs).

You can apply for accreditation online using the National Packaging Waste Database (NPWD).

Accreditations last for a maximum of one year and run from January to December. You must apply by 30 September if you want your accreditation to start from 1 January of the following year.

Before granting accreditation, an environmental officer may contact you to arrange a site visit.

Your regulator will notify you whether your application was successful within 12 weeks of submission.

Once you are accredited you can use the NPWD to:

  • record the waste packaging you have received for reprocessing or export
  • fill in your three-monthly returns for waste packaging you have reprocessed or exported
  • issue ePRNs and/or ePERNs
