If you are reprocessing or exporting iron, steel or aluminium packaging, you must check whether your supplier is accredited and, if so, whether they have issued ePRNs on the loads they are sending to you - ie to prevent issuing a second ePRN for the same metal waste packaging.

When renewing your accreditation, you should revise your business plan to reflect your strategy for the new accreditation period.

If you fail to comply with any accreditation conditions - eg supplying records and reports - your accreditation may be suspended or cancelled.

If you want to carry out work that could be detrimental to the navigation of waters, you must have consent from the Board of Trade.

Work detrimental to navigation could be:

  • construction, alteration or improvement works on, under or over part of the seashore that lays below the level of mean high water springs
  • depositing any objects or materials on such a seashore
  • removing any object or material on seashore that lays below the level of mean low water springs

You may be required to provide plans or other information.

If you dispose of, recover, collect or transport special waste in Scotland,  you must not mix different categories of special waste or mix special waste with non-special waste unless you have:

  • a waste management licence
  • authorisation under Part 1 of the Environmental Protection Act 1990
  • a pollution prevention and control permit.

column3: Authorisation to issue horse passports (All UK)
column4:
If you issue horse passports you must be authorised by:

  • the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra), if you operate in England
  • the Department for Agriculture and Rural Development, if you operate in Northern Ireland
  • the Scottish Government, if you operate in Scotland
  • the National Assembly for Wales, if you operate in Wales

column3: Licence to keep or release certain non-native fish (England and Wales)
column4:
If you wish to keep or release certain species of non-native fish, you must obtain a licence from the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) in England or from the Welsh Government in Wales.

Introducing non-native fish can have direct effects on native species, for example by predation, or can upset the natural balance that operates between species. Non-native species can also introduce and spread diseases and parasites to which native species may have no resistance.

Types of fish requiring a licence include:

  • catfish
  • sturgeon
  • grass carp
  • bitterling
  • pumpkinseed

A full list of non-native fish species can be found on the Defra website.

You must complete application form ILFA1, providing details about your business, fish species and proposed activity. There is no charge for a licence.

You should send completed application forms to the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas) - on behalf of Defra - or the Welsh Government.

Licence applications can take between two weeks and three months to process depending on the complexity of the scenario.

Cefas will only issue licences where:

  • a non-native species is considered appropriate
  • there is no flood risk
  • site security is considered to be adequate

If you run a fishery, your licence will allow the introduction and keeping of named species. However, you must ensure the animals are not moved, eg by anglers, and you must obtain a Section 30 consent from the Environment Agency to stock each introduction.

If you are a public aquarium, retailer or dealer your licence will usually authorise multiple introductions and the keeping of certain species at the named site.

If you plan to farm a non-native species you should contact Cefas as applications to farm an alien species are processed in conjunction with applications to be authorised as a fish farm.

Other conditions may be attached to your licence.

A licence will normally authorise the keeping of fish for an indefinite period.

If you keep or introduce prohibited species of fish, fail to obtain a licence when required to do so or fail to comply with licensing conditions, you are committing an offence and may be fined up to £2,500. Where appropriate, your licence may also be revoked.

You may require a licence from your local authority to busk in England and Wales.

There is no national regime for busking although some local authorities may have bye laws/permits.

If you trade in the street you may require a street trading licence.

Applications should be made to your local district council, or the district council for the area you wish to trade in writing (including by electronic means).

You must provide specific information, including details of the street you wish to trade on and the days and times you wish to trade.

You may also be required to provide two photographs of yourself.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

Electronic means is the facility to submit written applications, including providing signatures, by electronic means by not be provided by all district councils.

column3: Pig holding registration and movement notification (Scotland)
column4:
If you keep pigs, you must register the place where they are kept (the holding) with your local Rural Payments and Inspections Directorate (RPID) Office within 30 days from the date you first keep them.

You must supply RPID with the following details:

  • your name and address
  • the address of the holding
  • the number of herds on the holding

RPID will then provide you with a county parish holding (CPH) number. This is a unique code allocated to the land where the pigs are kept and must be used when reporting and recording animal movements.

You should not move pigs on or off your holding until you have been issued with a CPH number.

You must also notify your local Animal Health Veterinary Laboratory Agency (AHVLA) Divisional Office where you are going to keep pigs and they will give you a herdmark for your holding.

All pigs must be identified by an eartag or tattoo (either on the ear or a slapmark on the shoulder) containing your herdmark before they can leave the holding. Pigs less than 12 months old moving between farms can be identified by a temporary paint mark instead.

If you are moving pigs to a show or exhibition, to a semen collection centre, for breeding purposes, intra-Community trade or export or under a walking licence, they must also be identified with a unique individual identification number - eg by adding that number to the eartag.

Before you move a pig on or off your holding you must notify the movement to the Scottish livestock traceability team (ScotEID) by registering electronically on the ScotEID website or by calling or writing to the information centre.

Your notification must specify the:

  • address (including postcode and CPH number) of the holdings from and to which the pigs are being moved
  • date of the movement
  • number of pigs moved
  • identification mark of each pig moved
  • lot number of pigs being moved, if they're being moved from a market

This information should also be recorded in your own holding register within 48 hours of a movement on or off your holding. You should keep a separate register for each holding you use. Holding registers can take any form that you like but you must keep records for a minimum of three years and make them available for inspection on request. Once a year you must also record all the pigs in your holding.

Pig movements must be accompanied by a movement document. This can be printed off if you have registered on the ScotEID website or sent to you if you notified the movement by telephone. However, if you have chosen to notify ScotEID in writing, you must supply your own movement document.

When pigs arrive on your holding, this triggers a 'standstill' during which other livestock must not be moved off the holding for a set period of time. More details on this are available in guidance issued by the Scottish Government.

RPID carry out pig inspections each year to ensure that identification and traceability rules are being complied with. If you fail to comply with any of these rules, RPID inspectors may take enforcement action. This ranges from the issuing of guidance on how to take steps, to prosecuting you for committing a criminal offence. Movement restrictions may also be placed on your holding until problems are rectified.

If you wish to burn heather, rough grass, bracken, gorse or vaccinium outside the burning season or in a way that the regulations prohibit you can apply to the Welsh Ministers for a licence.

You must submit the proper form at least 28 or 56 days ahead of the planned burn, depending on whether you wish to make a burn in or out of season.

Skip hire companies may require a skip operator's licence from their local authority before they can place a skip on a public road.

Some local authorities will require registration and you must have adequate public liability insurance.

Some local authorities will issue licences to the skip hire companies, while others will issue them to individuals as a skip permit. Please consult your local authority for details.

column3: Environmental permits issued by the local authority (England & Wales)
column4:
You must hold an environmental permit from your local authority if you either:

  • carry out Part A(2) or Part B activities
  • run a Part A(2) or Part B installation or mobile plant

Activities which require a Part A(2) permit include:

  • refining gas
  • metal works - eg producing pig iron or steel, casting ferrous metal, operating forge hammers or applying fused metal coatings
  • melting non-ferrous metals
  • surface treating metals and plastic materials
  • grinding cement clinker or metallurgical slag
  • glass manufacturing
  • cellulose fibre reinforced calcium silicate board manufacturing
  • ceramic product manufacturing - including roof tiles and bricks
  • non-hazardous or animal waste incineration
  • manufacturing wood based boards - eg plywood
  • new tyre manufacturing
  • disposing of or recycling animal carcases or waste

Activities which require a Part B permit are those which cause emissions to air.

However, not all activities which fall within those categories will require a Part A(2) or B permit. Waste operations that cause more significant pollution will instead require a Part A(1) permit from the Environment Agency. If you carry out an exempt waste operation, an exempt water discharge activity or an exempt groundwater activity, you may need to register the activity as an exempt operation with either the Environment Agency or your local authority.

You may be charged a fee when you apply for a Part A(2) or B environmental permit.

If your local authority believes that you have breached a permit condition, or are likely to breach a condition, you may be served with an enforcement notice. This will detail the suspected breaches, the steps that you must take to remedy them and the time period you have to take such steps.

If they believe that your regulated facility is causing, or is likely to cause serious pollution, they may serve you with a suspension notice, suspending your permit.

If you fail to provide information when requested, provide false or misleading information, make a false entry in any records you keep or forge or use a forged document or permit, you may be committing a criminal offence and may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both. If you fail to provide information requested in relation to your application, the application may be withdrawn.

If the court believes you have the power to remedy your contravention, you may be ordered to take specified steps for remedying the matter, in addition to or instead of a fine or imprisonment.

If the local authority takes action to prevent pollution or remedy any pollution that has occurred as a result of your actions, they may seek to recover the costs of doing so from you.

If you fail to comply with the requirement to hold an environmental permit, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to five years or both.

If you operate a members' club or miners' welfare institute, you need a club gaming permit in order to provide:

  • up to three gaming machines for use (each of which must fall within category B, C or D)
  • facilities for equal chance gaming (eg poker)
  • facilities for certain prescribed games of chance (eg pontoon)

You need to apply for a permit from the Licensing Board of your local authority. Your application should be accompanied by the appropriate fee.

If you operate a members' club, miners' welfare institute or a commercial club, you need a club machine permit in order to provide up to three gaming machines for use (each of which must fall within category B, C or D).

You need to apply for a permit from the Licensing Board of your local authority. Your application should be accompanied by the appropriate fee.

If you want to have three or more category C or D gaming machines on your premises, you must hold a gaming machine permit. Applications should be made, along with the appropriate fee, to the Licensing Board of your local authority.

If you do not already hold a licence to sell alcohol for consumption on your premises, your application will be refused.

column3: Pollution Prevention and Control Permit Part C (Northern Ireland)
column4:
If you operate a plant or installation that emits pollutants to air in Northern Ireland you will require a Pollution Prevention and Control (PPC) certificate.

Part C permits cover regulated installations or mobile plants which result in air emissions that are not significantly polluting. PPC Part C permits are issued by District Councils.

To apply for a Part C permit, you should contact the Local Authority Pollution Prevention and Control (LAPPC) department of your District Council. They will then provide you with the correct application procedure and any relevant application forms.

Your application should usually describe:

  • process activity
  • nature of the releases to the environment
  • how releases will be controlled to comply with Best Available Techniques (BAT) requirements
  • how the environmental impact of these releases are acceptable

Your permit may have specific conditions attached to it, requiring you to use BAT to prevent and minimise releases to the environment. There may be emission limit requirements for your activities.

Some applications may be subject to a consultation process where other Departments, Agencies and bodies can comment.

If your operation is more polluting you may require a Part A or Part B permit. Part A and B permits are issued by the Northern Ireland Environment Agency.

If you wish to surrender your permit you must notify the enforcing authority.

You must register your premises in the early years register if you provide either:

  • early years provision on non-domestic premises
  • early years provision on domestic premises where there are more than three persons providing or assisting with the provision

Early years provision is provision for a child who is no more than five years old.

You must register your premises in Part A of the general childcare register if you provide either:

  • later years provision on non-domestic premises 
  • later years provision on domestic premises where there are more than three persons providing or assisting with the provision

Later years provision is provision for a child who are younger than eight years old and begins on the 1 September following a child's fifth birthday.

You provide early or later years provision if:

  • the provision is in return for payment or reward
  • you look after one or more children on domestic premises that are not the home of any of the children, or care for children from more than two families in the home of one of the children
  • you provide the care for at least one of the children for more than two hours per day

If you are registering an organisation, you must nominate a person to represent the organisation in its dealings with Ofsted.

However, certain circumstances may be exempt from the requirement to register.

Applications must be made to the Chief Inspector and accompanied by the fee.

You will also have to complete the declaration and consent form (EY2), a health declaration booklet, and a notification to Ofsted (EY3).

Once you have applied for registration you will be inspected, and once you are registered you will continue to be inspected at regular intervals.

You must comply with any conditions of the registration, and with the relevant national minimum standards which apply to your business. You must also inform Ofsted if any relevant circumstances change.

If you provide childcare on domestic premises with no more than two other childminders or assistants you are deemed a 'childminder' and personal registration is required instead of premises registration.

If you act as an executry practitioner in Scotland, you must be registered with the Council of the Law Society of Scotland.

You must be a fit and proper person and comply with conduct and practice rules.

Registration will be subject to a fee.

Registration may be subject to conditions.

column3: Environmental permits and exemptions issued by the Environment Agency (England and Wales)
column4:
If you operate a Part A(1) regulated facility in England or Wales, you will need to obtain a Part A(1) environmental permit.

A regulated facility is:

  • an installation or mobile plant which carries out Part A(1) listed activities described in Schedule 1 of the regulations
  • a waste mobile plant
  • waste operations, including those carried out at a Part B installation or by Part B mobile plant (unless the waste operation is a Part B activity)
  • a mining waste operation
  • a radioactive substances activity
  • a water discharge activity
  • a groundwater activity

Your permit will be issued by the Environment Agency, and will be either a standard permit or a bespoke permit, depending on the activity in question.

Not all activities which fall within those categories will require a Part A(1) permit. Some less polluting waste operations may instead require a Part A(2) or Part B permit from the local authority. If you carry out an exempt waste operation, an exempt water discharge activity or an exempt groundwater activity, you may need to register the activity as an exempt operation with either the Environment Agency or your local authority. Please refer to the Environment Agency for details.

Applications must be on the form provided by the Environment Agency. You must provide any information requested in the form or any information requested in addition.

An application fee may be charged.

You must comply with the conditions of your environmental permit or exemption. If you fail to comply with the requirement to hold an environmental permit, on summary conviction you may be fined or be imprisoned or both.

If you operate a boarding establishment for cats and dogs in Northern Ireland you must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

Licences are issued by local Divisional Veterinary Offices (DVOs). The licence must be renewed every year.

Fees will be payable and conditions may attach to a licence.

If you operate a shellfish farm in Northern Ireland, the farm must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD).

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence.

In addition you now have to apply for approval as an aquaculture production business.

column3: Licence to sell intoxicating liquor (Northern Ireland)
column4:
You can only sell intoxicating liquor in certain premises and if you are licensed.

Licences are obtained from your local county court and applications must follow set procedures.

column3: Operate a marine fish farm (Northern Ireland)
column4: If you operate a marine fish farm in Northern Ireland, the farm must be licensed by the Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs (DARD).

column3: Authorisation to act as an insolvency practitioner (England, Scotland & Wales)
column4:
If you act as an insolvency practitioner in England, Scotland or Wales, you must be authorised.

Authorisation may be obtained from the authorised body. These are listed on the Insolvency Service website.

Authorisation applications must contained specified information and be accompanied by a fee.

You may apply for registration as a home childcarer in Part B of the general childcare register if you wish to provide, for reward, childcare - eg as a nanny or au pair - which is:

  • for a child or children aged 17 or younger
  • for two or more hours per day (or for less than two hours where this includes care immediately before or after school)
  • for no more than two families at any one time
  • at the home of one of the children 

This registration is on a voluntary basis, and is not required where care is provided as part of reciprocal care arrangements between friends where there is no exchange of money.

Your application should be made to the Chief Inspector and must be accompanied by the prescribed fee, as well as any required information on:

  • yourself
  • the premises on which the early years provision is to be provided
  • the arrangements for the early years provision in those premises
  • any other person who may be caring for the children on those premises, or may otherwise be on those premises
  • any other information which the Chief Inspector reasonably requires

Before you can be registered, you must:

  • make a declaration that you meet all the requirements of the Childcare Register
  • give consent for checks to be carried out to see that you are suitable to work, or be in regular contact, with children
  • have a current first aid certificate

There will be an application fee, and you must comply with any conditions of your registration.

column3: Operator of approved slaughter house RPA notification (England)
column4:
If you become an operator of an approved slaughterhouse you must notify the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) in writing within 28 days of starting the business.

You must provide the following details:

  • your full name and address
  • if applicable the full name and address of partners and joint owners
  • if the operator is a body corporate, the full name, registered office address and registration number of the body
  • the address, telephone number and approval number of the slaughterhouse

If changes occur to the above details you must give notice of these changes within 28 days.

If you cease to be the operator you must notify the RPA within ten days of:

  • the date of cessation
  • your successor as operator

If the approved slaughterhouse ceases to be a slaughterhouse you must notify the RPA within ten days.

If you provide early years childminding on domestic premises for a child who is no more than five years old, you must be registered in the early years register as an early years childminder.

If you provide later years childminding for a child who has not attained the age of eight, you must be registered in Part A of the general childcare register as a childminder.

You provide childminding if, in return for payment or reward, you provide care for more than two hours per day and either:

  • look after one or more children on domestic premises that are not the home of any of the children
  • care for children from more than two families in the home of one of the children

However, certain circumstances may be exempt from the requirement to register.

Applications must be made to the Chief Inspector, and accompanied by the fee.

In addition, every person living or working on the premises where you provide childminding must be suitable to be in regular contact with children and must complete a declaration and consent form (EY2).

If you work with more than two other childminders or assistants, you are then considered to be 'providing childcare' and you will instead have to register your premises.

Once you have applied for registration you will be inspected, and once you are registered you will continue to be inspected at regular intervals.

You must comply with any conditions of the registration and you must inform Ofsted of any relevant change in circumstances.

If you move clean, greenfield soil within Northern Ireland in accordance with greenfield soil guidance, it may not be regarded as waste and waste management controls may not apply.

You must submit a completed Greenfield Soil Declaration Form to the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA) and be satisfied that you have complied with their guidance before you move the soil.

No formal consent will be issued, but you must retain your paper work for two years as it may be audited to ensure compliance.

Greenfield Soil Declaration applications must be made online.

You should also review waste management licensing requirements.

column3: Approval of a centre to offer SQA qualifications (Scotland)
column4:
If you run an education or training establishment and you wish to offer courses which lead to qualifications by the Scottish Qualifications Authority (SQA), you must be approved by the SQA.

You must apply for centre approval and approval to offer your first specific qualification at the same time.

Prior to application you should contact the SQA Business Development and Customer Support Team on Tel 0303 333 0330. They will answer your initial queries and arrange for a Business Development Manager to contact you to advise on the viability of your proposal to become an approved centre and to provide you with a combined centre and qualification form.

In order to complete the application form you should consider whether:

  • an appropriate member of staff has been appointed as SQA co-ordinator
  • you can provide details of your organisation's structure, with lines of responsibility and support for both staff and candidates, and show how this relates to the delivery of SQA qualifications
  • your administrative support is adequate
  • you have a procedure or plan to ensure adequate numbers of trainers, assessors and internal verifiers for the anticipated number of candidates

You should return your completed application form with your:

  • completed Financial Status Enquiry Consent form
  • appeals procedure for candidates
  • equal opportunities policy
  • health and safety policy
  • internal verification procedures

You should also include, if appropriate:

  • your site selection checklist
  • awarding body letter of approval

It is likely that a Quality Enhancement Manager will then visit your centre, complete a report on the systems you have in place and let you know if you meet the requirements to allow your centre to offer SQA qualifications. Written confirmation will be provided to your SQA co-ordinator within one week of the visit.

You must also obtain approval to offer your initial qualification before you will receive a centre number.

column3: Licence for projections over a highway (England & Wales)
column4:
If you wish to construct a bridge or building over a public highway, or alter such a construction, you must have a licence from the highway authority. Your highway authority will depend on the type and location of the road.

Terms and conditions will be attached to the licence, and a fee may be payable.

You may be required by the authority to remove or alter any bridge at your own expense.

You must also obtain the consent of the highway authority if you wish to position any overhead beam, rail, pipe, cable, wire or similar apparatus over, along or across a highway.

However, you are exempt from this requirement if you are:

  • carrying out work authorised by a licence under Chapter I of Part I of the Transport Act 2000
  • a provider of a universal postal service
  • the operator of an electronic communications code network
  • the operator of a driver information network

Failure to comply with these requirements may result in a fine.

column3: Cockle fishing licence - Dee Estuary (England & Wales)
column4:
If you dredge, fish for or take cockles from within the Dee Estuary you require a licence from the Environment Agency.

Licences will be valid for a maximum of one year and a fee (referred to as a 'toll') of up to £992 is payable on application.

A total of 50 licences are available annually. When the Environment Agency believes stock levels are such that more licences can be issued, further temporary licences will be issued at the Agency's discretion.

The initial 50 licences are issued based on experience of active and material participation in the commercial Dee Estuary cockle fishery, in accordance with the Environment Agency's published licence allocation policy. Any additional licences will be issued to those on a waiting list. Licences will be allocated on a points system, based on historic track record of fishing activity.

Conditions may be attached to your licence, eg in relation to the cockle beds you can take cockles from, when you may do so or the size or description of dredges, fishing instruments or vessels you may use.

You must comply with the following restrictions regardless of the conditions attached to your licence:

  • not to remove culch or other material used for the reception of spat (ie very young cockles) without written permission
  • not to fish for cockles from a closed bed unless you have been given written consent from the Environment Agency
  • not to introduce cockles into the estuary

You must produce a copy of your licence on request by an Environment Agency officer. If you are unable to do so, you must not fish for or remove cockles until you have located a copy of the licence.

A second person may be authorised to fish for cockles if you apply for them to be added to your licence. An authorised person can't fish for cockles at the same time as the licence holder.

You should call the Environment Agency on Tel 03708 506 506 to find out more about obtaining a licence.

If you dredge, fish for or take cockles without a licence or other authorisation, or in breach of any condition of a licence, you may be fined up to £5,000.

You do not require a licence to fish for cockles if you collect by hand no more than 5 kilograms per day for your own consumption.

If you wish to deposit any building materials in the road or erect staging or scaffolding, you must have Road Occupation Consent from your local authority.

Conditions may be attached to any consent granted and a fee may be payable.

To place tables and chairs or advertising displays outside your premises you also require Road Occupation Consent.

If you wish to place tables and chairs on the pavement or road outside your premises you must have consent from your local authority.

A fee may be payable.

To place advertising displays outside your premises or deposit building materials in the road or erect staging or scaffolding you also require Road Occupation Consent.

If you intend to burn specified vegetation outside of the burning season or in a way that is restricted you must apply to Natural England for a licence.

You must submit the proper form at least 28 or 56 days ahead of the planned burn, depending on whether you wish to carry out a burn in or out of season.
To impound water (eg by using a dam or weir) in Scotland, you must get authorisation from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

column3: Importing or exporting drug precursors (All UK)
column4:
If you import, export or carry out intermediary activities, ie arranging the sale/supply or purchase of scheduled substances (substances) involving category 1 scheduled substances, you must hold a licence from the Home Office. The licence will be valid for up to three years.

The Home Office will take into account your integrity and competence when deciding your application.

You must ensure that imports, exports and intermediary activities are documented. This means you must have all relevant summary/customs declarations, cargo manifests, invoices, transport or shipping documents. They must be kept for three years from the date of the activity, eg the date of import.

The document must detail the name of the substance, or in the case of a mixed or natural product it's name and the substances it contains, followed by the words "DRUG PRECURSORS". It must also have the quantity, weight, and in the case of mixtures or natural products, the percentage of the substance. The name and address of the importer, exporter, consignee and any person involved in intermediary activities must also be detailed.

You must ensure that a label is attached to packaging detailing the substance. You can also attach your own labels to packaging.

You must give the Home Office information regarding your import, export or intermediary activities.

You'll need an export authorisation for exports that require a customs declaration and that aren't to be re-exported within ten days. You may need an import authorisation for certain substances, eg category 1 scheduled substances. To obtain either authorisation you must apply to the Home Office with the following details of any operators involved in the shipment (including you), the name, quantity and weight of the substance, transport arrangement details and your licence/registration number.

If the transport and itinerary details aren't provided you'll have to give this information to the customs office before the substance is exported.

You'll also need any required import authorisation issued by the country where the substance is to be exported.

You must show the export authorisation to the customs office when the customs declaration is made, or if this is not made, to the competent authority at the point of exit from the European Community.

An import authorisation must stay with the substance until it reaches the importer's premises or the final consignee. You must be able to provide a translation where required if you have to present it to a customs office in another country.

 

Applications will be decided within 15 days. If granted the authorisation will be valid for six months from the issue date.

You'll not be granted an authorisation if you fail to provide all the required information, if any information you provide is false or incorrect, there are grounds for believing that the substances will be used for the illegal manufacturing of narcotic drugs or psychotropic substances (illegal manufacture) or the export is not authorised by the country of destination. Similarly an authorisation can be revoked or suspended if the Home Office believe that the substances will be used for illegal manufacture.

You must tell the Home Office immediately if you receive orders or transactions that involve unusual amounts of substances and that appear to you could be involved in illegal manufacturing.

You must register your premises and update the Home Office with any changes to these details as soon as you can after the change. You may be exempt from the registration requirements if you deal in small quantities of scheduled substances and meet criteria.

Your licence could be suspended or revoked if the Home Office believe that you are not complying with conditions or you're dividing substances.

If you fail to obtain a licence or to comply with other requirements you could commit an offence and be fined, im
column5: prisoned for up to two years (dependent on the offence) or both.

column3: Competence to self-certify building work registration (England & Wales)
column4:
If you wish to be able to self-certify that your work meets requirements of the Building Regulations 2010 you must be a member of an authorised scheme listed.

Self-certification enables you to produce a certificate which states that your work complies with building regulations, without the need to submit a building notice or pay a building control charge. In particular, the certificate must state that:

  • the work has been carried out in accordance with regulations and with adequate and proper materials which are appropriate for the work, are adequately prepared and used so as to properly perform their functions
  • the building, service or fitting complies with the relevant requirements of Schedule 1 to the Building Regulations 2010, eg complying with requirements relating to fire safety, site preparation, ventilation, etc

If you self-certify your work you must, within 30 days of completion:

  • give the occupier a copy of the certificate
  • give the local authority either notice of completion and compliance, or the certificate

The types of work that can be self certified are installing:

  • gas heating appliance (if carried out by a person deemed competent under the Gas Safety (Installation and Use) Regulations 1998)
  • heating or hot water systems that connect to gas heating appliances or controls
  • oil fired combustion appliances or oil storage tanks and pipes connecting to such appliances
  • solid fuel burning equipment
  • heating or hot water systems to oil-fired systems
  • solid fuel heating or hot water systems
  • electric heating or hot water systems
  • ventilation or air conditioning in non dwellings
  • ventilation or air conditioning in dwellings
  • lighting or electric heating systems
  • fixed low or extra low voltage electrical equipment
  • replacement windows, roof windows, doors or roof lights in dwellings
  • sanitary ware, eg bath, sink, toilet etc if the work doesn't involve shared or underground drainage
  • wholesome or softened wholesome cold water supplies
  • non-wholesome water supplies to flushing sanitary ware if the work doesn't involve work on underground or shared drainage
  • source electrical heating or cooling systems powered by microgeneration or renewable sources
  • cavity wall insulation
  • replacement pitched or flat roof coverings (except solar panel installation)
  • any work to ensure that any of the above works are carried out correctly (except to work regarding masonry chimneys
  • replacement windows, roof windows, doors or roof lights in non-dwellings (except to load bearing or structural glass or glass that is part of a revolving door or glazed curtain walling

The relevant self certification company will vary dependant on the work carried out, eg those replacing pitched or flat roofs have to be registered by National Federation of Roofing Contractors Ltd.

The approved self certification companies are:

  • Ascertiva Group Ltd
  • Association of Plumbing and Heating (Certification) Ltd
  • Benchmark Certification Ltd
  • BM Trada Certification Ltd
  • British Standards Institution
  • Building Engineering Services Competence Accreditation Ltd
  • Capita Gas Registration and Ancillary Services Ltd
  • Cavity Wall Insulation Self Certification Scheme by Cavity Insulation Guarantee Agency Ltd
  • CERTASS Ltd
  • ECA Certification Ltd
  • Fenstration Self-Assessment Scheme run by Fensa Ltd
  • HETAS Ltd
  • NAPIT Registration Ltd
  • National Federation of Roofing Contractors Ltd
  • Network VEKA Ltd
  • Oil Firing Technical Association Ltd
  • Stroma Certification Ltd

If you are a master or skipper of a vessel that operates commercially in categorised waters and limited coastal areas, you will have to be qualified by either holding a Boatmaster's Licence (BML) or one of the accepted alternatives.

A BML is not necessary for crew.

There are three types of the BML falling into National and Restricted Area categories:

  • National Licence Tier 1 Level 1 (T1L1) for all category A, B and non-linked C waters
  • National Licence Tier 1 Level 2 (T1L2) for all UK inland waterways (categories A-D) and limited coastal area
  • Restricted Area Licence is Tier 2 (T2) for a specified area, which may be category A, B and non-linked C waters

Tier 1 is transferable between different areas subject to any local knowledge requirements. In addition to the licence, a Tier 1 candidate may need to obtain one or more endorsement according to the type of operation he wishes to undertake, eg cargo endorsement, dredging endorsement, etc. Endorsements may have separate requirements, which must be met and/or complied with.

Tier 2 is restricted to the waters and type of operation specified in the licence and does not contain any separate endorsement.

BML applications should be made to your local Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) Marine Office, and you must submit:

  • an application form
  • evidence of completing the three basic safety courses - personal survival, first aid and fire safety
  • a medical certificate - eg ML5, ENG1
  • a Task Record Book
  • work record or other evidence of time served - Tier 1 applicants only
  • Pilotage Exemption Certificate for local knowledge areas (if held) - Tier 1 applicants only
  • certificates for other related qualifications

There are conditions as to competence, qualifying periods of service and age and you must undergo a medical. Your application will be reviewed by an examiner, after which you must undertake an oral assessment on theoretical knowledge and a practical test of seamanship and boat handling. If you pass these tests, you will be granted a BML.

Licences are generally issued for a period of five years and a fee is payable.

Holders of a BML must also be aware of and comply with:

  • relevant local byelaws
  • navigational requirements
  • restrictions of local harbour authorities or navigational authorities

There are certain waters for which you may require an additional local knowledge endorsement to operate.

You may hold an alternative small vessel certificate instead of a BML if operating the following vessels:

  • Class IV
  • Class V
  • Class VI
  • Class VI(A)
  • Class IX(A)
  • Class IX(A)(T)

Small passenger vessel is defined as a vessel carrying 12 passengers or less. Small commercial vessel mean one less than 24 metres in length.

You can find the accepted alternative certificates for small vessels in Annex 1 of Merchant Shipping Notice (MSN) 1808 with additional certificates listed in Marine Guidance Notice (MIN) 368.

You may also hold the following certificates instead of a BML:

  • Standards of Training Certification and Watchkeeping (STCW) Inshore Tug Certificate of Competency (Master) for inshore tugs
  • STCW (Category D Waters) Certificate of Competency (Master II/3) for domestic vessels operating in Category C and D waters

The regulations apply to masters operating on Category A-D waters and limited coastal areas.

The BML Regulations do not apply:

  • if you are a master of a vessel, certified under the Small Commercial Vessel (SCV) Code, holding the appropriate SCV Code qualification
  • to certain vessels considered to below risk are exemp
column5:
t for the Regulations, they are specified in MIN 368

You can also apply for a European Community (EC) Boatmaster's Certificate which is required for operation on inland waterways within the EC. To be eligible for a Boatmaster's Certificate, you will need to hold a UK Tier 1 BML or a Boatmaster's Certificate issued by a European Economic Area member state other than the UK.

column4:
If you prepare or manufacture food and wish to treat it with irradiation you must hold a licence from the Food Standards Agency.

Applications must be in writing and contain specific information including details of each food that you propose to irradiate and details of the methods to be used.

A licence will contain your name and the address of the licensed food facility. It will also detail the licence number, a description of each food the licence applies to, the valid from and to date of the licence and may contain conditions.

column3: Possessing or selling drug precursors (All UK)
column4:
If you possess or sell category 1 scheduled substances, you must obtain a licence from the Home Office. Your licence will be valid for three years from issue, or for longer if you can show every three years that conditions are being met, and will state the operation(s) and substance(s) for which it is valid.

You may supply those substances only to people who hold a licence and have signed a customer declaration which shows their intended use of the substances. You must obtain a copy of this declaration which must be in a set format. You must stamp and date a copy of the declaration and certify that it is a true copy.

If you work as a pharmacist or veterinarian, you may apply to the Home Office for a special licence, which will be valid only for the use of the scheduled substances within the scope of your official duties. Special licences are for an unlimited duration, but may be revoked or suspended.

If you sell category 2 scheduled substances, you must register with the Secretary of State, providing the address of the premises where the substances are manufactured or traded, and if you are a pharmacist or veterinarian, you may apply for special registration.

If you sell either category 1 or 2 scheduled substances, you must appoint an officer to be responsible for ensuring that the trade is conducted properly. You must notify the Home Office of the officer's name and contact details.

Exceptions apply to certain category 2 substances.

Licences and registration may be subject to fees and conditions.

The Home Office will consider your competence and integrity when deciding your licence application.

You must ensure that all transactions leading to the sale of the substance are properly documented. Documents, eg cargo manifests, invoices, etc must include enough information to identify:

  • the name of the scheduled substance
  • the amount and weight of the scheduled substance and in the case of a mixture or natural product, the percentage of the scheduled substance it contains
  • the name and address of the supplier, consignee, distributor and any other operator involved

The documentation and records must be kept for at least three years and be made available for inspection by an authorised person.

The above requirements do not apply to transactions involving category 2 scheduled substances where the quantities involved in a period of one year do not exceed the specified threshold.

You must ensure that labels showing the names of the substances are attached to category 1 or 2 scheduled substances before they are supplied.

You must notify the Director General of the Serious Organised Crime Agency immediately of any circumstances where you suspect that scheduled substances might be used for the illegal manufacture of drugs.

You must provide the Home Office with a summary of your transactions involving scheduled substances every six months.

You must allow any authorised person to enter your premises and inspect any scheduled substances or documents relating to your dealings with scheduled substances.

Your licence may be revoked or suspended if the Home Office believe you no longer meet the competency and integrity criteria or you have failed to comply with licence conditions.

If you possess or sell scheduled substances without a licence, without being registered or if you fail to appoint a responsible officer you may commit an offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

If you fail to comply with documentation, labelling and notification requirements you may commit an offence and be fined, imprisoned for up to three months or both.

If you operate premises to take bookings for four or more taxis and/or private hire cars, you need a booking office licence.

Applications must be made to the local authority (known for these purposes as the licensing authority) for the area in which your business operates and should be:

  • made in writing (usually on application forms available from the local authority)
  • signed by yourself
  • accompanied by a fee

Fees are set at local authority level and may vary from area to area.

The application must specify:

  • the type of licence you're applying for
  • your name and address and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address
  • where the application is made on behalf of a company or partnership, the name and registered or principal address, the address and the area from which the licensed activity will be carried out, names and private addresses of directors or partners and, if someone else is exercising day-to-day management, that person's name and address

Your application must also contain either:

  • a declaration that you are displaying a public notice in relation to your application (see below)
  • a declaration that you do not have rights in the premises that enable you to put up a notice, and detailing the reasonable steps that you have made to acquire those rights

From the date of making your application, you must (where possible) display a notice in or near your premises for 21 days stating:

  • that you have made an application for a licence
  • the particulars specified in your application
  • that any objections/representations relating to your application must be made to the licensing authority, the form in which they must be made and the deadline for doing so

At the end of this period you must submit a certificate to the licensing authority stating that you have complied with the requirement to advertise notice of your application.

A licence is usually valid for three years, after which you will need to renew it following the same process.

Once you are licensed, you must keep the following records:

  • every booking made from your premises
  • the registration number of the vehicle hired and the name of the driver for every booking

You must also take all reasonable steps to ensure that vehicles and drivers used to fulfil bookings are correctly licensed.

In addition to these mandatory licensing conditions, licensing authorities may attach to any grant or renewal of licence such reasonable conditions as it considers appropriate

column3: Approval for products and substances used by drinking water suppliers (England and Wales)
column4:
If you manufacture or supply products or substances directly to water suppliers in England and Wales for use in the treatment or distribution of public water supplies, you may need approval before such products or substances can be used. Applications for approval are administered by the Drinking Water Inspectorate (DWI).

Products and substances for which approval may be required include:

  • all construction products used in direct contact with water intended for human consumption from the point of abstraction to the point of supply (including water treatment processes, water supply pipelines and drinking storage)
  • water treatment chemicals and filtering materials that are not covered by an appropriate British or European standard

Products or substances used when water has passed into consumers' pipes and premises are regulated separately by the Water Regulations Advisory Scheme.

Some products and substances that only provide short or transient contact with water may not need approval, but you will still have to meet some safeguards. Check with DWI for further information.

You are advised to check carefully whether your product or substance requires approval. If it does, when making an application for approval, ensure that you:

  • use the correct form for the type of product or substance for which you are seeking approval
  • complete all parts of the application form and make all of the required paperwork available
  • have an Instructions for Use document as part of your application
  • have asked your suppliers to provide confidential product or ingredient formulation information to the DWI

You should not submit applications for approval of products and substances that are undergoing development, otherwise a fresh application may be required once changes have been made.

Fees are payable to DWI to consider applications. You may also incur costs from consultants and laboratories if testing of your product is required to assess its impact on drinking water quality.

Conditions may be attached to any approval granted.

Products and substances that are used in private water supplies must also be similarly assessed as products and substances used in public water supplies. If you supply products and substances for use in direct contact with water in private water supplies you may also need approval.

column3: Approval and accreditation of vocational training courses (Scotland)
column4:
Centres of learning including colleges, employers and private training providers who provide vocational training in Scotland need approval from the Scottish Qualifications Agency (SQA).

This includes the provision of training leading to external qualifications including, but not limited to, Scottish Vocational Qualifications.

All new external qualifications offered in Scotland are required to be accredited by the SQA.

You will need either an export or trade control licence issued by the Export Control Organisation (ECO) if you are exporting specific 'controlled' goods. This means items that are listed on the UK Strategic Export Control Lists or on Sanctions Lists or that fall under 'end-use controls' require a licence. 

The controls include the licensing of dual-use and military goods, as well as components, software and 'intangible' technology.

Depending on the nature of your export (such as export destination and type of goods being exported) you might need to register or apply for one of the following licence types:

  • Open General Export Licence (OGEL) including the Community General Export Authorisation (CGEA)
  • Standard Individual Export Licence (SIEL)
  • Open Individual Export Licence (OIEL)
  • Global Project Licence (GPL)
  • Open General Transhipment Licence (OGTL)
  • Standard Individual Transhipment Licence (SITL)
  • Open General Trade Control Licence (OGTCL)
  • Standard Individual Trade Control Licence (SITCL)
  • Open Individual Trade Control Licence (OITCL)

In applying or registering to use a particular licence, you should:

  • know the 'rating' (Control List classification entry) of your products on the UK Strategic Export Control List
  • understand your responsibilities, such as keeping accurate records
  • keep updated via the ECO's Notices to Exporters email service and regular training programme
  • be prepared for ECO Compliance Audits if required

Open General Licences are designed to cover the export of controlled goods that still require a licence but are of a less restricted nature or being exported to less sensitive destinations. Before using an OGEL you need to:

  • register to use the licence
  • read and understand the licence and its specified conditions carefully - (do not just read the title!)
  • ensure that you can meet all the terms and conditions specified, eg record keeping and end-user requirements
  • be prepared for ECO Compliance Audits

If you are unable to use an OGEL and the goods are still controlled you will need to apply for a SIEL.

All applications should be made via the ECO's SPIRE export licensing system.

Breaching export controls is a criminal offence. Penalties can vary depending on the nature of the offence. They range from:

  • revocation of a licence (costing you both time and money and loss of business reputation)
  • seizure of goods 
  • issuing of compound penalty fine 
  • imprisonment for up to ten years

For more details see our guides on this site about the Export Control Organisation.

You can also contact the ECO helpline on Tel 020 7215 4594 for further information.

To keep or use radioactive material at premises you need a certificate of registration from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

Application forms can be accessed via the SEPA website.

column3: Cash and valuables in transit licence (All UK)
column4:
You must obtain a cash and valuables in transit licence from the Security Industry Authority (SIA) if you work or supply operatives under a contract for services guarding property against destruction or damage, being stolen or otherwise dishonestly taken or obtained, involving the secure transportation of property in vehicles specially manufactured or adapted to have secure transportation as their primary function.

There are two types of SIA licence:

  • a front line licence for operatives who guard and transport cash and valuables
  • a non-front line licence for managers, supervisors and other staff who don't carry out front line duties

In order to obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check and a criminal record check. For front line roles you must also hold the appropriate SIA-approved qualification.

You can complete you SIA licence application online or through the post. You must supply the supporting relevant documentation and pay a fee.

The licence application costs £245 and is non-refundable. Granted licences last for three years. If you pay your own licence fee, you can claim tax relief - worth £49 for basic rate tax payers. If you are an employer paying an employee's licence fee, there will be no tax or National Insurance liability. If you require more than one licence for your activities, you may be eligible for a 50 per cent discount for the second application fee.

The SIA can attach any conditions to the licence as they believe to be reasonable.

You must renew your licence before it expires to continue working. You can apply to renew your licence up to four months before the expiry of your current licence.

The SIA may authorise a person to enter your place of business or place of work (where your licensed action is undertaken) to assess your compliance with any ongoing obligations. You may also have to provide any relevant documents or information to show your compliance with any licence obligations.

You require a close protection licence if you work as a bodyguard, or guard one or more individuals from the threat of assault or other injuries that might be inflicted by others. You must also have a licence if your services are supplied for or in connection with a contract with a consumer..

Licences are issued by the Security Industry Authority (SIA).

There are two types of licence:

  • a front line licence for bodyguards
  • a non-front line licence for managers, supervisors and other staff who don't carry out front line duties

In order to obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check and a criminal record check. For front line roles you must also hold the appropriate SIA-approved qualification.

You can complete you SIA licence application online or through the post. You must supply the supporting relevant documentation and pay a fee.

The licence application costs £245 and is non-refundable. Granted licences last for three years. If you pay your own licence fee, you can claim tax relief - worth £49 for basic rate tax payers. If you are an employer paying an employee's licence fee, there will be no tax or National Insurance liability. If you require more than one licence for your activities, you may be eligible for a 50 per cent discount for the second application fee.

You must renew your licence before it expires to continue working. You can apply to renew your licence up to four months before the expiry of your current licence.

The SIA may authorise a person to enter your place of business or place of work (where your licensed action is undertaken) to assess your compliance with any ongoing obligations. You may also have to provide any relevant documents or information to show your compliance with any licence obligations.

You must obtain a key holding licence from the Security Industry Authority (SIA) if you work or supply operatives under a contract for services, when keeping custody of, or controlling access to, any key or similar device for operating (whether mechanically, electronically or otherwise) any lock.

This does not apply to:

  • activities of a person who holds a key or other device for obtaining access to premises for purposes incidental to the provision of the manned guarding activities in relation to those premises, or an individual present on those premises, or any services that do not consist or include the carrying out of any manned guarding activities
  • activities carried out incidentally to the provision of services in connection with the sale of premises or other property to which the key or similar device gives access

A key holding licence is required only if your services are supplied for the purposes of or in connection with any contract to a consumer.

The key holding licence is a letter which must be kept and (if required) produced for inspection by authorised personnel.

In order to obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check and a criminal record check.

You can complete you SIA licence application online or through the post. You must supply the supporting relevant documentation and pay a fee.

The licence application costs £245 and is non-refundable. Granted licences last for three years. If you pay your own licence fee, you can claim tax relief - worth £49 for basic rate tax payers. If you are an employer paying an employee's licence fee, there will be no tax or National Insurance liability. If you require more than one licence for your activities, you may be eligible for a 50 per cent discount for the second application fee.

The SIA can attach any conditions to the licence as they believe to be reasonable.

You must renew your licence before it expires to continue working. You can apply to renew your licence up to four months before the expiry of your current licence.

The SIA may authorise a person to enter your place of business or place of work (where your licensed action is undertaken) to assess your compliance with any ongoing obligations. You may also have to provide any relevant documents or information to show your compliance with any licence obligations.

You must obtain a licence from the Security Industry Authority (SIA) if you work or supply operatives under a contract for services, when manned guarding activities are carried out through the use of closed circuit television equipment to:

  • monitor the activities of a member of the public in a public or private place
  • identify a particular person

This includes the use of CCTV to record images that are viewed on non-CCTV equipment, but excludes the use of CCTV solely to identify a trespasser or protect property.

There are two types of SIA licence:

  • a front line licence for operatives carrying out surveillance
  • a non-front line licence for managers, supervisors and other staff who don't carry out front line duties

In order to obtain your licence you must be at least 18 years of age, and you must pass an identity check and a criminal record check. For front line roles you must also hold the appropriate SIA-approved qualification.

You can complete you SIA licence application online or through the post. You must supply the supporting relevant documentation and pay a fee.

The licence application costs £245 and is non-refundable. Granted licences last for three years. If you pay your own licence fee, you can claim tax relief - worth £49 for basic rate tax payers. If you are an employer paying an employee's licence fee, there will be no tax or National Insurance liability. If you require more than one licence for your activities, you may be eligible for a 50 per cent discount for the second application fee.

The SIA can attach any conditions to the licence as they believe to be reasonable.

You must renew your licence before it expires to continue working. You can apply to renew your licence up to four months before the expiry of your current licence.

The SIA may authorise a person to enter your place of business or place of work (where your licensed action is undertaken) to assess your compliance with any ongoing obligations. You may also have to provide any relevant documents or information to show your compliance with any licence obligations.

column3: Authorisation to accumulate and dispose of radioactive waste (Scotland)
column4:
To accumulate and dispose of radioactive wastes you need an authorisation from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA).

Application forms can be downloaded from the SEPA website.

If you are a forestry trader and wish to produce or import wood or bark material or issue plant passports you must be registered with the Forestry Commission.

Applications must be in writing and contain specific information.

Conditions will apply requiring you to:

  • keep an accurate plan of your premises
  • keep records of relevant material bought by you or brought onto the premises for storage or production and of any such material produced or dispatched from your premises
  • keep all documents relating to such records for one year from the date they were created or received
  • designate someone technically experienced to be available to liaise with the Forestry Commission
  • examine your premises and material in accordance guidelines
  • make declarations when required to confirm you are willing and able to comply with conditions
  • comply with any other conditions imposed

You must notify the Forestry Commission of any changes to the information provided in your application.

column3: Gold & Silver Mining Option for Lease (Scotland)
column4:
If you wish to explore or mine gold or silver commercially, you must apply for an Option for lease from The Crown Estate.

The Crown has rights to gold and silver wherever they occur in the UK. All dealings are administered by Wardell Armstrong, The Crown Estate mineral agent (CEMA).

Applicants must satisfy CEMA of their financial and technical standing and their ability to manage exploration through to completion and will be required to obtain all other necessary permissions for their activities.

If you market, pack or re-pack, seal or reseal or label or re-label seed, prepare seed mixtures, clean, treat or process seed for marketing you must be licensed by the Food and Environment Research Agency (Fera).

Licences will be issued electronically and will have conditions attached.

Applications can be made by post or online.

If you run an independent school in Wales that admits children who have been assessed by the local authority as having special educational needs, you must be approved by the Welsh Government.

Approval may be subject to conditions and that the school meets the requirements of the Independent School Standards (Wales) Regulations 2003.

column3: Notification of marketing of food for particular nutritional uses (England)
column4:
If you manufacture or import food that is sold for particular nutritional uses, sometimes known as 'parnuts' or 'PNU' food, you must notify the Department of Health (DH) when you first put a product on the UK market.

Notification is made by providing the DH with a copy of the product label and completing a form.

If you place the food on the market in another European Union member state, you must make similar notifications to the relevant body in that member state before the food goes on the market.

You must also provide any scientific data or information required by the DH in order to show the food fulfils nutritional requirements for those they are aimed at.

A parnuts food is a food which, due to its special make-up or manufacturing process, is easily identifiable from food intended for normal consumption, and is sold so that it indicates its suitability for its claimed nutritional use.

These are usually foods marketed to:

  • people with digestive or metabolic issues (eg coeliacs)
  • people whose physiological condition means that they would get special benefit from eating certain substances in the food
  • infants or young children in good health

The DH may suspend or restrict trade in a product that they find does not comply with requirements or endangers public health. A declaration from the DH in restricting trade may detail conditions on trading. If so, any food marketed must comply with the conditions.

If you market foods without notifying the DH trade in food whilst a suspension or restriction is in place or fail to comply with any trade conditions you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000.

If you are an operator of a business in Northern Ireland regulated by a Part A pollution prevention and control permit issued by the Northern Ireland Environment Agency (NIEA), you will be required to report your annual pollution releases to NIEA.

To do so you must fill out a pollution inventory form and include information on the following:

  • details of your business and business premises
  • all chemical releases you have made into the environment
  • all chemical transfers you have made into wastewater
  • waste transfers - off-site or overseas

You must return your reporting form to the NIEA by 31 January each year.

column3: Massage and special treatments, therapist registration (England & Wales)
column4:
If you are a therapist administering special treatments you may need to be registered.

Special treatments which require a licence are different in different parts of the country, but may include:

  • massage
  • manicure
  • chiropody
  • light treatments - eg sunbeds
  • electric treatments - eg electrolysis
  • other treatments involving heat, light or vapour - eg sauna or other bath treatments

In most parts of the country a separate licence will be required if you carry out any skin piercing treatments - eg tattooing or acupuncture. However, in Greater London (except for the City of London) these treatments are also covered by special treatments registration.

You should contact the local authority for the area where your premises are based to find out whether you need to be registered.

If you do need to be registered, you will usually have to fill out an application form and you may need to pay an application fee.

If you operate without being registered in an area where registration is required or fail to comply with conditions attached to your registration, you may be fined.

As well as being registered yourself, the premises on which you operate may also require a licence from the local authority.

If you offer a regulated claims management service, you must be authorised by the Claims Management Regulator (CMR) - part of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) - unless you're exempt.

Regulated claims management services include:

  • advertising for claimants
  • referral of claimants to legal practitioners
  • advice in relation to claims
  • investigation of claims
  • representing claimants

Claims for which these services may be provided include:

  • personal injury and criminal injuries compensation claims
  • claims for industrial injuries benefit (includes disablement benefit, reduced earnings allowance, retirement allowance and industrial death benefit)
  • employment-related claims such as claims for wages, unfair dismissal and discrimination
  • claims for housing disrepair
  • claims relating to financial products or services

Application forms are available from the CMR. You can either:

  • register in the application area of the CMR website and then print off the form for completion
  • call the CMR Monitoring and Compliance Unit on Tel 0333 200 1321 and request a form for completion

Completed forms should be returned to the Monitoring and Compliance Unit.

You must pay an application fee of £750 when you submit your application form.

To be authorised you must be found to be a 'competent and suitable' person. This entails:

  • not having been convicted (or currently being subject to proceedings) for relevant criminal offences (perjury, fraud theft, etc) or breaches of any law or rule of practice regulating the provision of financial, legal or other relevant services
  • not having any arrangements in place with another person that could give rise to a conflict of interest
  • having suitable arrangements in place to hold client's money (where appropriate)

A decision should be made within three months and, if approved, you will receive a written authorisation.

You must comply with any rules and codes of practice issued.

You must also pay an annual fee, which is determined according to your organisation's turnover.

If you are an authorised personal injury business that represents clients, you need to have professional indemnity insurance.

The authorisation may also be subject to other conditions, eg that you only supply specified services or that you meet a requirement within a stated time limit.

Your authorisation may be suspended or cancelled if you do not comply with a condition of authorisation.

If you operate a claims management service either without being properly authorised or if you pretend to be authorised, you may be fined, imprisoned for up to two years or both.

You are exempt from the need for authorisation to carry out regulated claims management services if you are:

  • a legal practitioner (barrister, solicitor, advocate, legal executive or foreign lawyer) already regulated by a professional body
  • carrying out a service that is a regulated activity by the Financial Services Authority, or have been exempted or benefit from an exclusion under the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000
  • working for a not-for-profit body (eg a charity or advice centre), provided that it meets certain requirements
  • an official of an independent trade union and are carrying out that service for a union member, former union member or the family of such a member
  • a students' union official and are carrying out that service for a member of the students' union or affiliated body
  • a small scale 'exempt introducer' - ie you refer no more than 25 cases every three months and this is incidental to your main business  an
column5: d you don't carry out any other regulated activity

column4:
If you wish to become an Approved Inspector (private sector building control officer), you must apply to the Construction Industry Council (CIC). The application fee for approval or re-approval is £3,500.

Individuals must provide details of their qualifications and experience, and companies must provide information on the number, qualifications and experience of the people employed who would carry out the work.

The CIC may request additional information if anything is missing.

Your application will be considered by CIC-registered professional assessors who will decide if your experience and knowledge is sufficient. You must also attend an interview - made up of three assessors and the CICAIR registrar - to demonstrate your competence and discuss the information you have provided.

Approvals will be valid for five years and you must pay a registration and re-approval fee.

The re-approval process is the same as the application process above.

You must comply with all Approved Inspector ongoing obligations including the Code of Conduct for Approved Inspectors.

You must specify the information for various notices and certificates in the specified form or the local authority may reject these notices.

You must not have any professional or financial interest in the work you supervise.

You must ensure, as far as possible, that after taking all reasonable steps to be satisfied within the limits of professional skill and care the regulations are complied with.

You may also be required to consult the local fire and rescue authority and/or sewerage undertaker at certain stages of work.

column3: Disposal of dredged material at sea (All UK)
column4:
If you wish to deposit substances or articles within UK waters or UK-controlled waters, or into any waters from a UK vessel, either in the sea or under the seabed, you may need a licence from the Marine Management Organisation (MMO).

The MMO is responsible for marine licensing in most English inshore and offshore waters. However, it is only responsible for Wales and Northern Ireland offshore waters.

When deciding whether to grant the licence, the authority will take into account the availability of alternative methods of dealing with the intended waste.

The MMO may include any provisions in the licence they believe necessary to protect the marine environment, the living resources which it supports and/or human health.

Fees may be payable and you must comply with any provisions of the licence.

You must supply such information and permit such examinations and tests as the licensing authority feel are necessary to enable them to decide whether a licence should be issued. It is an offence to present false information or fail to disclose information when requested.

Certain material depositing activities may be exempt - such as the deposit of scientific instruments, fishing gear, or material on the site of drilling for oil and gas.

For information on licences for inshore waters in Wales you should contact the Marine Consents Unit and for Northern Ireland you should contact the Department of the Environment.

For information on licences for inshore waters in Wales you should contact the Marine Consents Unit and for Northern Ireland you should contact the Department of the Environment.

Regulation and licensing for Scotland is now devolved, and to find information on licensing for this activity, you should contact Marine Scotland.

You require a licence to classify bovine carcases at an approved slaughterhouse from the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) Meat Technical Schemes.

To be granted a licence you must complete a test organised by the RPA Livestock & Meat Inspectorate and be a 'fit and proper person' to carry out classification. 

Classification of bovine carcases means assessing the carcase according to conformation and fat cover, which enables a meat price to be placed on the carcase.

You must classify, identify and weigh a bovine carcase within one hour of the animal being struck. In instances where automated grading techniques fail to classify the classification, identification and weighing must take place on the day of slaughter.

column3: Automated grading of bovine carcases licence (England)
column4:
To use automated grading equipment in the classification of bovine carcases at a slaughterhouse you require a licence from the Rural Payments Agency (RPA) Meat Technical Schemes.

The operator of the slaughterhouse must apply for the licence.

Once granted you must

  • identify the category of carcase
  • keep daily control reports on the functioning of the equipment, in particular any problems encountered and actions taken to remedy

If you treat, keep, or dispose of waste in Scotland, you must be licensed by the Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) unless an exemption applies.

Waste includes:

  • products whose date for appropriate use has expired
  • contaminated or soiled materials
  • unusable parts
  • substances that no longer perform satisfactorily
  • residues of industrial processes
  • machining/finishing residues
  • other production or consumption residues
  • materials, substances or products whose use has been banned
  • discarded products

There are two types of waste management licence:

  • site licence - for businesses that treat, keep, or dispose of waste in or on land
  • mobile plant licence - for businesses that treat or dispose of waste with a plant that is designed to or can be moved from place to place

Application forms for both licences are available on the SEPA website.
