You need to provide your details - including information about your financial standing, previous convictions for environmental offences (if any) and technical competence to manage the site or plant - as well as details of the site or plant operation and the type of activity you want to carry out.

You should submit the following documents with your application:

  • company registration or partnership documents
  • details of qualifying experience - eg a certificate issued by the Waste Management Industry Training and Advisory Board (WAMITAB)
  • any other relevant documents
  • an application fee based on the type of activity and the amount and type of waste to be kept, treated or disposed of

For site licences, you should also provide:

  • copies of a site location plan
  • evidence of land occupancy
  • planning permission
  • a working plan that explains how the site is to be developed and operated
  • other relevant documents - eg an environmental statement or hydrogeological report

You should send your licence application and supporting documents to the SEPA office responsible for the area where your facility is located or, for plant operators, where you have your principal place of business.

Licences will be subject to any conditions that SEPA consider necessary to prevent environmental pollution, harm to human health or serious detriment to the amenities of that area. If you fail to comply with any of the conditions of your licence, you will be guilty of an offence and could be fined up to £5,000.

If you fail to obtain a licence when required to do so, you are committing an offence and may be fined, imprisoned for up to five years or both.

Your licence may be suspended or revoked if you are convicted of a relevant environmental offence or if the continuation of the activities authorised by the licence would cause pollution, harm human health or be seriously detrimental to the amenities of that area.

Certain activities involving the recovery or disposal of waste are exempt from the requirement to be licensed, as long as they don't cause pollution or endanger human health.

However, you are still required to register that activity with SEPA. If you fail to do so, you may be fined up to £5,000.

Notification forms and a list of exempt activities are available on the SEPA website.

Some waste management activities, such as landfilling, incineration and disposal of hazardous waste, require a pollution prevention and control (PPC) permit from SEPA instead.

To run a residential care home you must be registered with the Health and Social Care Regulation and Quality Improvement Authority.

You are deemed to be running a residential care home if you run an establishment that provides residential accommodation with board and personal care for people in need of personal care due to:

  • old age and infirmity
  • disablement
  • dependence on alcohol or drugs
  • mental disorder

If you operate a business in the financial sector, a casino or you are a high-value dealer, you may be required to register with your supervising body in relation to money laundering requirements.

If you are required to register, you must do so with the appropriate supervisory body.

The supervisory body will vary dependent upon your business.

The requirement to register applies to any of the following types of businesses:

  • credit institutions
  • financial institutions
  • auditors, external accountants, tax advisers and insolvency practitioners
  • independent legal professionals
  • estate agents
  • trust and company service providers
  • high value dealers
  • casinos

If you operate a voluntary adoption agency you must be registered with Her Majesty's Chief Inspector of Education, Children's Services and Skills.

A registration fee will be payable.

In order to register to operate a voluntary adoption agency, you must prove that you:

  • are a fit and proper person
  • have the necessary skills and experience
  • have all the satisfactory information available
  • have given notice to the registration authority of contact details for a responsible individual who supervises the management of the agency

If you wish to manage more than one agency you must be registered for each.

column3: Massage and special treatments premises licence (England & Wales)
column4:
If you run an establishment for massage or other special treatments you may require a licence for your premises.

Special treatments which require a licence differ across England and Wales, but may include:

  • massage
  • manicure
  • chiropody
  • light treatments - eg sunbeds
  • electric treatments - eg electrolysis
  • other treatments involving heat, light or vapour - eg sauna or other bath treatments

In most parts of the country, a separate licence will be required for any skin piercing treatments - eg tattooing or acupuncture. However, in Greater London (except for the City of London) special treatments registration also covers these treatments.

You should contact the local authority for the area where your premises are based to find out whether you need a licence.

If you do, you will usually need to fill out an application form and you may need to pay an application fee.

Your premises may be inspected before a licence will be granted.

You must comply with any conditions attached to a licence by your local authority.

If you operate without being licensed in an area where a licence is required or fail to comply with conditions attached to a licence, you may be fined.

As well as having a premises licence, you must ensure that therapists who carry out special treatments are registered with the local authority if local byelaws require this.

column3: Wedding and civil ceremony premises approval (England & Wales)
column4:
If you use your premises for wedding or civil partnership ceremonies in England or Wales they must be approved by your local authority.

Applications should include details about yourself and your premises and be accompanied by a plan of the premises identifying the room(s) to be approved and any other documents that the local authority requests, such as a copy of your current public liability insurance certificate and fire certificate. You may also need to pay an application fee - these are set by the local authority and may vary from area to area.

Your local authority will inspect the premises before approving them.

Standard conditions will be attached to your approval. To comply with them, you must:

  • appoint a suitably qualified 'responsible person' to ensure compliance with the conditions
  • notify the authority of your name and address and the name, address and qualification of the responsible person as soon as your premises are approved
  • make sure the responsible person, or a qualified deputy, are available for one hour before and throughout each marriage or civil partnership
  • make available your premises at all reasonable times for inspection
  • display, for one hour before and throughout each ceremony, a notice that the premises have been approved, with directions to the room where that ceremony is taking place
  • ensure that marriages and civil partnerships take place in a room which you identified for that purpose in your application and which is separate from any other activity on your premises
  • not allow food or drink to be sold or consumed in that room for one hour before or during a marriage or civil partnership
  • ensure the ceremony is not religious in nature
  • permit free public access to any marriage or civil partnership
  • immediately notify the authority if you change address, appoint a new responsible person or change the name or layout of the premises

Your local authority may also attach specific conditions to the approval of individual premises.

Approvals will be valid for three years and applications for renewal cannot be made more than twelve months before expiry.

If you fail to comply with any conditions of approval or your premises become unsuitable to host weddings or civil ceremonies, your approval may be revoked.

If you operate a market for the sale of animals in a public place, you must obtain a notice of approval from the Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD). This may be issued subject to conditions.

The requirement for approval does not apply to draft sales where only one such sale of bovine animals, swine or goats is held in any period of six months on the same premises.

If you run an approved market, or a lair used in connection with such a market, you must comply with rules on:

  • standards of planning and construction, as laid out in Schedule 1 to the Sales, Markets and Lairs Order (Northern Ireland) 1975
  • standards of cleansing and disinfection, as laid out in Schedule 2 to the Sales, Markets and Lairs Order (Northern Ireland) 1975

You must provide adequate covered accommodation with adjustable ventilation, which has been approved by DARD as meeting design and construction standards and as being adequate for the number of animals in question.

You must provide facilities for the washing and disinfection of vehicles and containers used in transporting animals that meet with relevant standards and are approved by DARD.

You must also provide suitable and approved facilities for people attending the market to cleanse their footwear before leaving the premises, and you must ensure that there is adequate drainage for the disposal of water.

You must ensure that:

  • animals are confined to the market at all times during the sale
  • you provide adequate drinking water and suitable food to animals
  • you provide suitable bedding for animals which are being kept overnight
  • swine are not admitted to a market on the same day that a sale of cattle is being held
  • you only allow animals to be penned in a way that avoids injury, overcrowding or other cause of unnecessary suffering
  • where penning animals, each bull over 12 months old and each boar over six months old is kept separate from any other animal
  • where penning animals, rams and male goats that are capable of being used for breeding purposes are kept separate from other animals
  • you only admit a bovine animal to the market where it is accompanied by an appropriate and valid notification document and, where necessary, you have examined the animal and notification document to ensure validity
  • you only admit any swine to the market where you have examined the animal, along with any document required as a condition of a licence issued by DARD to ensure that the document has been correctly completed
  • you only admit any sheep or goat to the market if they are accompanied by a valid movement document

If a veterinary inspector is of the opinion that an animal at your market or lair is being, or is likely to be, caused unnecessary suffering they may treat or remove the animal. The cost of this treatment or removal may be recovered from you.

You may be able to hold a public sale of sheep otherwise than in an approved market if you have a specific notice of approval from DARD.

column3: Vehicle Registration Plate Supplier Registration (All UK)
column4:
If you supply vehicle registration plates (including manufacturers, distributors, motor factors, motor dealers, car repairers and retail outlets), you need to register with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA).

You must complete an application form with specific information and pay a fee.
